HEADLINE: FILM; 
Forget Voting Them Off the Island. They're Just Shot.

BYLINE:  By JAMIE MALANOWSKI; Jamie Malanowski's most recent article for Arts & Leisure was about the comedian and actor Chris Rock.

 BODY:
TALK about timing. A smorgasbord of reality programs is being presented on the big 100-channel buffet, and the post-Super Bowl premiere of "Survivor II" racked up the season's highest rating for an entertainment show.
 Into this embracing environment comes "Series 7," a movie opening Friday that consists wholly of six back-to-back episodes from the seventh series of an imaginary hit tabloid television show called "The Contenders." Fortunately, the film has more going for it than timing. 
 Conceived and shot in the heyday of relatively low-concept reality shows like "The Real World" on MTV and "Cops" on Fox, in which the subjects' circumstances are only minimally contrived, "Series 7" anticipates the current wave of higher-concept shows like "Survivor" and "The Mole" and "Temptation Island," in which people are plopped into elaborate petri dishes and asked to seem natural while skydiving, eating bugs and fomenting betrayal. 
Indeed, "Series 7" not only anticipates these shows; it skips ahead to portray the most cynical contrivance of all. In "The Contenders," a handful of ordinary people in an ordinary town -- in this case, Danbury, Conn., masquerading under a stage name, Newbury -- are given handguns and pitted against one another until there is only one survivor. (And they mean survivor; the losers don't show up later grousing to David Letterman.)
It's a satire, smart and funny, but as Daniel Minahan, the film's 37-year-old writer and director calmly acknowledges, it's not a nice movie. "The movie keeps you off balance," he said recently in New York. "The audience wants to laugh, but it's not sure, so there's a kind of uncomfortable laughter first, and then there's this real laughter. The movie shames you and pokes you even while it amuses you."
One delight of "Series 7" is the way it perfectly mimics the visual grammar of tabloid TV -- the quick cuts, the mix of emotional commentary and you-are-there action, the pedal-to-the-metal pursuit of anything that whiffs of dramatic possibility. It's no surprise that after producing documentaries at the Kitchen, an arts center in Manhattan, and news programming at the BBC in London (where he met a fellow filmmaker, Mary Harron, with whom he co-wrote the screenplay of the 1996 indie success, "I Shot Andy Warhol"), Mr. Minahan spent two years working on tabloid shows at the Fox network. The guiding principle there, he recalled, was "economy, economy, economy.
"You never stop telling the story," he said. "The funniest thing I remember from the experience is the executive producers coming in and looking at a piece I was working on and saying, 'That's great -- now take out all the pauses.' 
"I always felt like I was a spy when I worked there," Mr. Minahan said. "I had the idea for 'Series 7,' and I was always getting ideas, tucking away little bits to use in the film."
The economy Mr. Minahan learned in Fox's cutting rooms rules the movie. There are no artful or leisurely setups explaining the premise -- immediately they're recapping the last kill of Dawn, the angry, 8-months-pregnant defending champion and killer of 10, played by Brooke Smith ("The Silence of the Lambs," "Vanya on 42nd Street"). The horrified new contestants are handed their guns. No explanation is provided, nor do they seem to need one.
"We talked about this a lot," Mr. Minahan said of the film's narrative strategy. "The more we explained the rules, the more questions that were asked and answered, the less the conceit held up. So we made it that the show was this thing that was in the consciousness of people, a game, and that everybody knew what it meant when you said 'I'm a Contender.' "
This recognition -- that veteran channel-surfers would be sufficiently steeped in the vocabulary of TV to grasp the story -- was the key to pulling "Series 7" off. It was, however, a realization that took some time coming. 
"Originally Daniel set it up as a show within a show, as a TV program within a movie," said Jason Kliot of Blow Up Pictures, a producer of the film, "but it kind of bogged down over the question of how you show the difference between what's the TV show and what's the movie. Finally we suggested to him that he just never leave the show. Make it like 'War of the Worlds,' and never leave the construct. And after we suggested that, you could see this almost electric transformation in Daniel, and he went off and rewrote the entire script." 
The performances Mr. Minahan got from his actors also serve the conceit extremely well. "Dawn is a character who is at once very fierce and very vulnerable, and Brooke had those qualities," he said. "Of all the things in 'Silence of the Lambs,' I remember her performance best, because it was so shocking, so stripped bare. She was the girl in the pit. She totally knew how to go to that place."
Ms. Smith said: "It was interesting working with Dan because we knew he wanted this nonacting thing in our performances. But at the same time, he would show us episodes of 'Cops,' and he would point out how the people on the show, the people on the screen, were in fact acting. Because a camera was on them, they changed. They started to act for the camera. There was one episode, the police were arresting a drunk guy. His friend came over to help, and a police officer pushed him out of the frame. Not out of the way of the arrest, out of the frame of the camera."
Mr. Minihan recalled, "I had to remind the actors that the cameraman was a character in the film. Film actors are taught not to look at the camera, but these characters needed to show an awareness that the camera was in the room and that everything was being witnessed by someone. That really changed the performances. And I would use that. Two characters would be playing a moment where they were discussing a secret, and I would tell the cinematographer to go in closer. The proximity of the camera, the invasion of privacy, completely changed the tone of the performance."
Mr. Minahan said he was particularly pleased with the performance of the actress who played the mother of a teenage contender, a woman who knows a thing or two about cameras and invasions of privacy, Donna Hanover, the estranged wife of Mayor Rudolph Giuliani of New York.
"She was really good at it," Mr. Minahan said. "She and another character would be having a private moment, and I would remind her that the camera was there, and she would glare right at it."
In directing "Series 7," Mr. Minahan had to undergo the usual rigors of directing a low-budget feature ("We got permission to shoot at a Qwik Mart in Danbury," Ms. Smith recalled, "but the Qwik Mart wouldn't close. We had customers coming in, stepping over a body, and saying 'Gimme $10 on Pump No. 2"). But he also had to serve another, very subtle, function for the film. As Joana Vicente, a partner in Blow Up Films, put it: "Daniel had to be the network, And of course, the network is the villain."
N ONE of the characters are villains," Mr. Minahan said. "The real villain is the producer who pushes people into these terrible situations. My model for 'The Contenders' were shows like 'Cops' or 'The Real World,' which are mean shows. The invasion of privacy in 'Cops' is a violent act. There's a tendency in 'The Real World' towards humiliation, towards ostracizing the person you don't like. 'Survivor' and 'Big Brother' are completely mean-spirited, all about singling out the person the group hates. And now there's 'The Mole,' where there's a spy in the group. To me that's completely antisocial, and it's because the producers want it that way.
"It's interesting that these shows have chosen to be about mistrust and hatred," he added. "They could easily all be the other way around. They could all be about people trying to work together."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Glenn Fitzgerald, as a contestant, and Angelina Phillips in "Series 7." It was filmed before the tide of contrived reality TV. (USA FILMS)

HEADLINE: SPRING THEATER/LIFE AND ART; 
The Timeless Dance Of Art and Money Takes Center Stage

BYLINE:  By CELIA WREN; Celia Wren is the managing editor of American Theater magazine.

 BODY:
THERE must be a cost!" Benvenuto Cellini cries to his benefactor, the Duke of Florence, in John Patrick Shanley's new play, "Cellini," about the 16th-century Florentine sculptor. A study of the creative temperament, "Cellini" resounds with thematically freighted artist-patron squabbles. In the interest of holding down expenses on a bronze statue of Perseus, the Duke -- a member of Florence's Medici family, noted for supporting the arts -- suggests eliminating one component: the body of the slain Medusa, on which Perseus stands. 
 But that idea is anathema to Cellini, for whom the pairing of hero and monster represents all the yins and yangs of the creative process: control and freedom, impulse and tenacity, ecstasy and pain. Gain and sacrifice, too, of course -- metaphorical, but also monetary: before Cellini's bronze masterpiece emerges from the furnace (represented in the production by a scaffold, a bright light and a sheet), the Duke must fork over a significant amount of cash. 
 Even at its most sublime, art rubs shoulders with filthy lucre, as "Cellini" and a host of other dramas remind us this season. Indeed, if you favor plays that might spark a brawl at an auction house, this may be your year. 
In New York, Mr. Shanley's play, inspired by Cellini's autobiography and directed by the playwright, runs at Second Stage through next Sunday.
Jumping forward a couple of centuries, Jon Robin Baitz's newest work, "Ten Unknowns," about a world-weary painter who catches the eye of a greedy art dealer in the early 1990's, opens March 8 under the direction of Daniel Sullivan at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center. 
Yasmina Reza's international hit "Art," about three male friends who quarrel after one of them purchases an all-white painting, will be mounted at no fewer than 30 nonprofit theaters across America this season, according to American Theater magazine.
In California, a play about John Ruskin, seen at South Coast Repertory in December, will be mounted at the Globe Theaters in San Diego beginning in March. The play, "The Countess," by Gregory Murphy, about the Victorian art critic who championed the Pre-Raphaelites and, later in his life, railed against laissez-faire economics, was an Off Broadway sleeper that closed last year after more than 600 performances. It is currently being turned into a film.
If you count plays that by dint of their very subject matter might be said to challenge assumptions about art and value, the total rises. Opening at the Actors Theater of Louisville on March 23 as part of the annual Humana Festival of new plays is Charles Mee's "Bobrauschenbergamerica," a fantasia inspired by Robert Rauschenberg, who incorporated items like a stuffed hen and a scavenged ventilation duct into his found-object "combines."
And the music-theater piece "Jennie Richee," written by the playwright Mac Wellman with a score by Julia Wolfe, had its world premiere earlier this month at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago. (The production will visit the Kitchen in New York in April.) The work portrays the outsider artist Henry Darger, whose watercolors and collages, discovered amid hundreds of empty Pepto-Bismol bottles after his death, now sell for up to $100,000 each.
A few of these plays take frank stock of the tension-fraught relationship between art and money: "You haven't bought this painting for 200,000 francs?" expostulates the shocked philistine Marc in "Art." Others -- like "The Countess," with its barbed portrait of Ruskin the tastemaker -- reflect on the preconceptions that may make viewers less likely to admire (read: buy) a certain work.
More profoundly, the plays explore aesthetic, philosophical and social questions. What makes art authentic? Do patrons and price tags inevitably compromise a creator's vision? Does a painting have inherent value -- even if it is all white and looks just plain blank? Or is value a market-conjured mirage? Is the connoisseur who hands over a wad of cash for a canvas -- or a Broadway ticket, for that matter -- just a gullible snob, "dazzled by what he believes to be culture," as Marc scoffs in "Art," the Tony-winning comedy of ideas?
The theater's scrutiny of such matters may relate to the notable buoyancy of the art market in recent years, says Malcolm Goldstein, who has written books on American drama and just published "Landscape With Figures: A History of Art Dealing in the United States" (Oxford University Press). He points out that detective novels about art theft and fraud have also proliferated of late, a trend he attributes to impressive auction prices splashed across the headlines. "When people see those figures in the newspapers, they become fascinated," he said.
"Appalled" might be a more accurate word, to judge by popular culture's frequent depiction of art dealers and connoisseurs as pretentious mercenaries who race after fashionable trends. A telling piece of conceptual art spelled out this attitude in pink lights in Timberlake Wertenbaker's "Three Birds Alighting on a Field," which played at the Manhattan Theater Club in New York in 1994. "ART IS MONEY-SEXY-SOCIAL-CLIMBING-FANTASTIC," it said. 
Speaking by telephone from London recently, Ms. Wertenbaker said that the play, which contrasts a cynical gallery owner with an idealistic painter, was inspired by the skyrocketing art prices of the late 80's. To her at that time, she recalled, "The art market represented something about society -- that things have no value except when attached to a price." Nevertheless, art remains "humanizing and enriching," even in the temple of Mammon, she said, adding, "Art can -- you hope it can! -- survive the marketplace."
This season Mr. Baitz strikes a few of the same notes in "Ten Unknowns," whose plot pivots on the way artistic movements eclipse one another in popularity. In the play, Malcolm Raphelson (played by Donald Sutherland), a bitter 72-year-old figurative painter, must confront terrifying questions about his own motives and talents when he finds himself in vogue, several decades after being thrust into obscurity by the Abstract Expressionists.
"Ten Unknowns," Mr. Baitz said just before a rehearsal, echoes some of his own ambivalent feelings about modern-day America and the theater's rivalry with film, television and popular culture. While cautioning that the play is about more than art -- it is also about relationships and endurance and aging -- Mr. Baitz allowed that Raphelson's resentment of Abstract Expressionism reflected his own "sense of being part of a form that's been blotted out by the electronic."
Most playwrights, Mr. Baitz said, tend to feel they are "doing something very small and out of step -- which I don't mind; out of step doesn't mean unnecessary to me."
Being in step, by contrast, means marching in sync with commercialism. "There's a world pressing in on the world of the play, and it's the world of merchandising," Mr. Baitz said. "I do have a sense that the culture has succumbed to salesmanship entirely."
Artistic integrity, he suggested, is particularly vulnerable in a greenback-fixated environment pulsing with questions like: "What is the photo op? What are the market conditions? What are the numbers? What is the zeitgeist doing now? What little twist will pique the curiosity of a ravenous consumer body?"
"I think you're sunk, obviously, if you're hypnotized by that," Mr. Baitz said. "For me, art comes out of grief and exaltation and rage. It doesn't come out of being smart or hip."
But if Raphelson is "a self-portrait to some extent," Mr. Baitz said, so too is the play's art dealer, Fabricant, whose "not particularly competent attempt at self-promotion reminds me of a failing version of myself."
Other playwrights have similarly used the art market theme as a way to address self-doubt. "Artists often have this question about their own fraudulence," said Brad Rosenstein, whose "Vermeer Room," a play about an art dealer in 1945 Amsterdam based on a historic forgery case, won the National Repertory Theater Foundation's National Play Award last year and was presented at the foundation's festival in Los Angeles in November. The scenario, he said, allowed him to dramatize such misgivings, while questioning "what is real, what is fake, what we value in art and in human beings, and how we make those judgments about things we prize."
ANGST also lurks behind the brush strokes in "Sight Unseen," the 1991 play by Donald Margulies, whose "Dinner With Friends" won a Pulitzer Prize last year. Mr. Margulies said that by centering "Sight Unseen" on an acclaimed but troubled painter named Jonathan Waxman, he was able to underscore the play's broader concerns with "lost values and compromise."
Gallery and atelier trappings, easels and pretentious critics deck out "Sight Unseen," but Mr. Margulies said he was more interested in Waxman as "a lapsed Jew who had assimilated into mainstream culture at the same time that he was being embraced on a large scale in his profession -- the compromise that entails, the feelings of emptiness and fraudulence."
Why is the museum and gallery world a magnet for playwrights musing about the genuine? Reality, after all, teems with confidence games and dubious vendibles, from dot-com stocks to black-market caviar. The playwright Michael Frayn, the author of "Copenhagen," whose recent novel "Headlong" depicts a hoax involving Bruegel paintings, pointed to the "interesting questions raised by the uniqueness of works of art."
We treasure paintings and sculpture, he said, because "we need to have repositories of value." That symbolism becomes all the starker, he said, to the extent that in the art world "originals are extremely valuable and even extremely good copies have almost no value at all."
Concern with value, in all its subtleties, lies at the root of the public's fascination with the art world, said the gallery owner Mary Boone. In the case of a painting, she said: "The thing that defines the difference in price is quality. How do you define that quality? It's not size or weight or the amount of money. It's about the reputation of the artist, and that's mysterious to people."
While it is intensely competitive, she added: "The art world in general is not as trend-fixated or money-fixated as the media makes it appear. This misconception rests on the media's habit of using price as shorthand for quality. To try to describe why the art of Jasper Johns or Jackson Pollock is considered great is very elusive. The simplest way of distilling all this information is dollars and cents."
Mr. Wellman, the author of "Jennie Richee," said he saw a connection between the current batch of art-themed plays and theater's relation with the press.
"Theater is in a state of despair," said Mr. Wellman, who takes a dim view of the field's reliance (as he sees it) on facile middlebrow fare. "It doubts its purpose," he said, "because for decades it's been trying to function journalistically. There are 'hot topics' determined by journalism in a stricter way than has ever happened before." Stranded at this impasse, he suggested, people in the theater have begun looking for inspiration to "other arts and how they function." Mr. Wellman mentioned last season's crop of plays with themes involving mathematics and science as an example of this phenomenon.
John Patrick Shanley has a less gloomy take on the theater's scrutiny of the art world and art-world finance. "Part of playwriting," he observes, "is about tricking yourself into thinking that you're not writing about yourself." Not only did he identify with Cellini's struggle to "express something inward in an outward art," he also saw parallels between Renaissance-era artist-patron rapport and partnerships in modern American theater and film.
"There are things in this play about my relationship with Joe Papp, Lynne Meadow, Steven Spielberg," he confessed, listing impresarios (from the Public Theater, Manhattan Theater Club and Hollywood, respectively) with whom he has collaborated. 
When it comes to the purse-string holder, Mr. Shanley added, the artist's question is usually, "Why can't he just give me the money and leave me alone?" But the subsequent give and take, he said, resembles the dialectic Cellini saw in Perseus and Medusa. "The struggle between those two opposing forces is the struggle between the patron and the artist, which can ultimately be a very fruitful friction," Mr. Shanley said. 
And when the friction between muse and money is not fruitful -- well, there is not much the artist can do about it.
"Hasn't it always been thus?" rejoined the playwright John Guare when asked if plays like "Cellini" and "Ten Unknowns" reflect widespread anxiety about art's niche in a commercial world. Mr. Guare -- who said he made an art dealer a central character in his 1990 play "Six Degrees of Separation" because "it's a real cutthroat world" -- theorized that "the minute art became a commodity for the grandeur of the patron, whether pope or Medici, it's always been, 'Who's going to get that commission? My palace is better than your palace!' "
And before the Medicis? "My cave is better than your cave!" Mr. Guare said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Donald Sutherland, right, Julianna Margulies and Denis O'Hare in "Ten Unknowns." (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 2; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk; Pg. 16

LENGTH: 2357 words

HEADLINE: SPRING THEATER/A ROUNDTABLE; 
Talking Shop (Which Takes In the World)

 BODY:
 ON a Saturday morning last month, four playwrights whose work is being seen in Off Broadway theaters this year gathered at the Joseph Papp Public Theater to talk about their plays and, as it turned out, other subjects: Kia Corthron, 39, the author of "Force Continuum," which closes today at the Atlantic Theater Company, and "Breath, Boom," at Playwrights Horizons in May; Rebecca Gilman, 36, whose "Boy Gets Girl" runs through April 8 at the Manhattan Theater Club; Suzan-Lori Parks, 37, whose "Topdog/Underdog" will be at the Public Theater in July (Ms. Parks and Ms. Corthron also each have plays in the current "Urban Zulu Mambo" at the Signature Theater Company); and Kenneth Lonergan, 38, whose play "Lobby Hero" opens March 13 at Playwrights Horizons (and whose screenplay for the movie "You Can Count on Me," which he also directed, has been nominated for an Academy Award). The moderator was Pamela Renner, manager of editorial services at Variety in New York. Following are excerpts from the discussion. 

PAMELA RENNER: Has everyone been watching "N.Y.P.D. Blue" or is there something going on here? In three of your plays there are characters who are New York City police or security guards. Kia, your play, "Force Continuum," is about a Harlem family, three generations of cops----

KIA CORTHRON: Black cops.

RENNER: A black family who have made their lives in the force. In "Lobby Hero," your play, Ken, there are four characters: two of them are cops and two are security guards.

KENNETH LONERGAN: I just like blue.

RENNER: In Rebecca's play "Boy Gets Girl" there is a police officer who is the repository of experience. And interestingly, in Suzan-Lori's play there are two adult brothers who have no parents, and no police officers: a total absence of authority.

LONERGAN: Always swimming against the tide----

SUZAN-LORI PARKS: That's true. I heard you all were writing about the police so I went 180.

LONERGAN: I just wanted to write a cheap police melodrama. There is so much cop stuff on television that I get very nervous about saying words like alibi on a stage and having them sound cheesy. But real cops are kind of interesting, and real police issues are pretty interesting. I thought it might be kind of theatrical: uniforms with guns and sticks and stuff. I don't know. I don't watch those shows. Nothing against them, but I like "Larry Sanders."

REBECCA GILMAN: I don't know either. I've never seen "N.Y.P.D. Blue." But pragmatically the situations are going to be heightened, there's going to be more drama attached to them. And I have to tell you, for the sake of disclosure, that my newest play is about two cops. For me, when the police are involved it's usually because it's an extreme situation, and in extremity you have extreme conflict, and in conflict you have drama.

CORTHRON: I wrote my play because I'm a black woman living in Harlem, and there are issues all the time of black people and the police. It was somewhere between Louima and Diallo when I started writing it, and I said then I thought I'd address police brutality. It wasn't until we were close to production that I stopped saying that, because I felt it was not really what the play is about. It's part of it, but the play is about the relationship between the black community and the police.
Off the bat, I knew the main character was going to be a black cop, because it would be too easy for it to be a white cop, and I wanted to explore the complexity of the situation and its pressures. There's a line I have where the grandfather character says something like, "A black man in a police uniform -- it's like you're a black man in a Confederate uniform."
When I wrote this play the most important thing to me was not to say that there's a problem in this city with police brutality, because we know that. I talked with some cops and they actually feel there are ways out of this. Whatever I write, I hope there is hope at the end of the play, not just tragedy and devastation.

PARKS: I just write tragedy and devastation.

CORTHRON: I just want to stay off of Suzan-Lori's turf.

PARKS: Tragedy and devastation. It's like bleeding, like when they used to bleed folks. The play creates a wound that is actually the first stage in the healing process. So there are no cops in my play, there are just two people who can't get along.

RENNER: Rebecca, can we talk a little bit about your play and how you're using this policewoman, this figure of authority, who comes in both to give the main character comfort and to give her fear?

GILMAN: When I started the play I was reading a newspaper article specifically about women who were stalked by their policemen husbands and/or boyfriends or ex-husbands.

CORTHRON: That's the worst problem -- people you know.

GILMAN: Who are you going to ask for help in that situation? With the article was one of those public service pieces: "Things to do if you're being stalked." Since then, I've done research and gone to police departments, and there was always some printed-up pamphlet for this. And the suggestions were all so defensive and reactive and frightening. Yet it was presented so straightforwardly that I found that much more frightening than if there was something melodramatic about it.
With the police officer, I tried to incorporate that sense of business as usual as being a frightening thing. Sometimes the calmness doesn't always make you feel better. And so the officer who comes to talk to the main character, Theresa, is doing her best to alarm her to save her life, if that makes sense.

RENNER: Ken, your cops are not in such a tragic kind of situation -- they are dealing with a lot of messy human problems.

LONERGAN: I was interested in people's personal behavior versus what they expect of themselves professionally, and also what other people expect of them professionally. I had this idea of a young woman police officer who's trying very hard to be a police officer but she happens to fall in love with her partner. She doesn't want to be seen as a woman, she wants to be seen as a cop, but she's a human being and she falls in love. So which is she supposed to be?

RENNER: The people in these plays are not members of messy Eugene O'Neill families, drinking themselves to death, but are working in offices, in police training, in journalism or even in a shooting arcade dressed as Abraham Lincoln. Is there something that is interesting to you as writers in portraying people trying to hold down a job?

GILMAN: It's a big issue with me because I think -- especially in our country, the way the economics is evolving -- that people spend a huge amount of their life at work. I do tend to write about people who have work lives that are meaningful to them; in "Boy Gets Girl," Theresa is very invested in her work as a journalist.
But in reality I don't think that's the case. I think most people spend their time doing jobs that they hate and doing things that they hate and that they feel alienated by. When I look at the world now, I see people whose family life is impacted by work to the degree that a lot of them define their families as the people they work with. They spend so much time at work that they are disconnected from their immediate community.

CORTHRON: A lot of my plays involve teenagers, so there is no regular work life. But besides "Force Continuum," "Digging Eleven" -- it was done at Hartford Stage -- was about workers' rights in a factory and a strike in which two men -- friends and, though they keep it secret, lovers -- go separate ways politically.

PARKS: In "Topdog/Underdog" Lincoln works in a shooting gallery playing Lincoln. And his brother wants to develop some skill in three-card monte. The questions they're asking are: "What am I doing here? How do I fit? And how do I make life work for me?"
I think these are the questions in every play. "Who am I?" and "What am I doing here?" Basically, "Who are we?"

RENNER: So maybe the bigger question is, "How do I become enfranchised in America as myself, whoever and whatever I am?"

PARKS: America is this sea and we have to somehow swim and negotiate. You can get a job that you love and feel like you're making things happen. Or you can have another kind of experience. The people in my plays always seem to have that other kind of experience.

RENNER: You can lose it, too, whatever you have.

PARKS: My characters are struggling to lose it. They're trying to let it go. And it won't let them go, it has its hand around their neck. That's what I mean about America. It can cradle you, and it can grab you by the throat.

CORTHRON: Gloom and doom.

PARKS: Gloom, despair and tragedy. Nothing but the truth.

RENNER: Is it harder now to create a character across racial lines? Is there a self-consciousness about if you're a black playwright writing white characters, or a white playwright writing black characters, or a man writing a young woman?

LONERGAN: I worry about that sometimes. Mostly you try to put yourself in the position the character's in and use your imagination. The audience puts themselves in the place of the characters. That's what theater is in a way, and what novels are. You're getting inside somebody else's head who has gotten inside these imaginary people's heads. And that's the fun of it. But some things you just don't know anything about.

PARKS: Because "Topdog/Underdog" has two guys in it and only two guys, people keep asking, "Well, where are you in the play?" That's the joy of it for me.

RENNER: Do you think audiences are hungry for plays that grapple with social issues that they've read about in the newspapers or heard on the news?

LONERGAN: I don't know. I sometimes feel like audiences just want to see a good show, and I don't mean it in a crass way.

PARKS: I hope they're hungry for more than what they read in the newspaper -- deeper things than a newspaper has the space or the time or the finances to talk about.

CORTHRON: There's a potential audience that doesn't go to the theater because they think it doesn't speak to what they want to hear. There should be discount ticket prices. At the Royal Court in London there were $:5 Mondays. And Mondays it would be packed.

LONERGAN.: Every theater should do that. But they can't with commercial productions because the margin of profit is so narrow.

PARKS: If you're spending $45 or $50 for a ticket, seeing a show is a big deal.

LONERGAN: Even if you go to a movie for $10 and it's lousy you feel burned.

GILMAN: And if you pay $ 70: "That's it, forget it. I'm not going to go see any more plays."

PARKS: For the rest of your life.

GILMAN: What you end up with is a more and more elite audience. And right now, of course, an older and older audience. You don't get the kind of diversity or the young crowd that you want, and theater starts to feel like some sort of rarefied art form.

RENNER: Ken, you mentioned movies. Are they friend or foe to a playwright?

LONERGAN: Financially, if you're working for Hollywood, one job can support you for two years. So you can do a lot of theater writing in that time if you want to. And if you want to try to work in the independent world and have some artistic control, it's a wonderful outlet. The obvious difference is that once you get out of the theater, the writer is no longer the last word on what happens; the director or the producer is.
A lot of people go to Hollywood for the money -- to write for television shows and movies -- and their work is mostly thrown away or rewritten. So that's time spent that they can't spend doing things they might care about more. And that's a shame.

CORTHRON: But you directed "You Can Count on Me," so you did have----

LONERGAN: Yes, the same basic control over the situation. I met a couple of people at Sundance last year who seemed like directors with whom you might be able to work as you do in the theater. Miguel Arteta, who directed "Chuck and Buck"; he's doing another movie now that Mike White wrote. I had a long talk with him. I don't know if you saw that movie, but it's very clearly directed the way you'd direct a play.
You could develop relationships with movie directors that were more like those you have in the theater with directors, where it's not just raw material they take to do with as they will, but a script that has its own integrity, that they're supposed to be serving in some way, supposedly. It doesn't always work that way in the theater either. But that's the stated goal.

RENNER: What about working commercially in the movies, like writing "Analyze This," which I understand you have never wanted to see?

LONERGAN: No, I never saw that movie. It's just a really good day job, you know? It's like just better than speech writing -- for me anyway. And it's fun to work on movie scripts. But I always try to keep them pretty separate because everybody knows what happens. There were 14 writers on "Analyze This." I'm sure it turned out very well, but it's not a situation you would tolerate as a playwright. So you have to be willing to make that trade-off. The more they pay you, the less control you're going to have over the material.

RENNER: So you divorce yourself from the final product?

LONERGAN: Yeah. Which is somewhat painful but not as painful as if you went into it not knowing that could happen or expecting something different. I'd be unlikely to sell a play to the movies because they'd just rip it to pieces. I mean, that's sort of their job.

RENNER: As a playwright yourself what would you say to younger playwrights who might say to you: "I've been writing a couple of little plays here in my notebook. What do you think?"

LONERGAN: Don't listen to anybody.

CORTHRON: Actually, I was going to say that seriously.

LONERGAN: I don't really say, "Don't listen to anybody." I say, "Find two or three people and listen to them if you think they know what they're talking about."

PARKS: Listen to no one and learn how to listen to yourself, which isn't just the process of not listening to anyone. It's tuning your ears.

GILMAN: I think that's really important for a playwright, because sometimes you lose the sense of who you were when you were, say, 8, and you wanted to tell stories. That's the person you've got to get back to.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The playwrights Suzan-Lori Parks, second from left, Kia Corthron, Rebecca Gilman and Kenneth Lonergan, with Pamela Renner, left, moderating, talking at the Joseph Papp Public Theater about their work. (Photographs by Nancy Siesel/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Midway Airport Is Undergoing a Major Expansion 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT SHAROFF 

DATELINE: CHICAGO 

 BODY:
MIDWAY AIRPORT, the very distant -- No. 2 airport in the Chicago area behind O'Hare International, is getting a $761 million makeover that includes a new terminal and a number of other improvements aimed at both increasing capacity and smoothing out the congestion that has been a growing problem in recent years.
 The city is also hoping that a revived Midway will act as a catalyst for new development on Chicago's southwest side, a depressed residential and industrial area that has largely missed out on the economic boom of the last decade, which has transformed a number of other inner-city neighborhoods. 
 "It's going to be a radical change both in terms of the look and feel of the facility," said Thomas Walker, the city's commissioner of aviation. "We're more than tripling in size and adding a lot of new services and amenities that will have a significant effect on the surrounding community."
John Tague, chief executive of Indianapolis-based Amtran Inc., the parent company of American Trans Air (ATA), which will be one of the largest tenants at the expanded facility, expects the airport improvements to be pronounced. "We're going," he said, "from what was probably the worst facility in the country to what will be one of the best." 
Midway, which occupies a square mile of land, has a history that stretches back to the dawn of commercial aviation. Dedicated in 1927 as Chicago Municipal Airport, it was, in its early years, the world's busiest airport. 
Renamed Midway in 1949 after the World War II naval battle in which planes played a decisive role, it was the leading airport between the coasts until the early 1960's, when the explosive growth of air travel led to the development of the much-larger O'Hare International Airport 20 miles to the north. 
Midway declined for most of the next two decades and by the early 1980's was almost abandoned. Then, in the early 1990's, it started to come back to life as a hub for value-priced airlines like Southwest Airlines and ATA.
"We provide a lot of service from Midway," said Peter Houghton, director of properties at Dallas-based Southwest Airlines. "The expansion will allow us to grow in a more orderly manner. Right now, we have 121 daily flights to 25 cities. The potential after the expansion is for 190 flights."
Midway's current terminal dates from 1947 and was designed to accommodate about 3 million passengers a year. Last year about 15 million passengers passed through the facility. (By contrast, O'Hare, which by some calculations is the busiest airport in the nation, handled 72 million passengers last year.)
The design of the new Midway facility -- which will open in phases starting next month and finishing in 2004 -- is unusual. It straddles Cicero Avenue, a broad commercial street, with a new check-in and ticketing area on the east side of the street and a food court and two new gate concourses on the west side. The two buildings -- which total just under a million square feet -- are connected by a covered pedestrian bridge. In terms of capacity, Midway will expand to 41 gates from 28. 
THE architect of the four-story, 939,000-square-foot facility is Steven Reiss, a principal with HNTB Architects and Engineers in Alexandria, Va. "Because of its location -- you can see downtown even on a foggy day -- we thought it was important for Midway to be an architectural extension of the city," Mr. Reiss said. "The main materials are brick, painted steel and glass, and the colors are a little warmer than is typical for an airport terminal." 
The old Midway was notably lacking in amenities. The new terminal will have 48,000 square feet of retail space, including a 23,000-square-foot food court with skylights. The city has decided to feature primarily local concessionaires. Of 10 restaurants in the food court, nine are branches of local establishments, including Harry Caray's, Gold Coast Dogs and Potbelly Sandwich Works. (The one exception is a Ben & Jerry's ice cream store.)
"We want Midway to show off the best of Chicago," said Eric Griggs, the department of aviation's deputy commissioner for concessions. He added that concessionaires are being offered 10-year leases at a rent of about 13.2 percent of gross sales. "Right now, Midway's concession sales are about $17 million," he said. "We expect that to jump to $38.9 million in the future."
Midway has always been an economic catalyst for the southwest side. According to Mr. Walker, the facility currently contributes about $2.5 billion to the local economy and is responsible for 50,000 jobs, both on and off site. After the expansion, however, that is expected to grow to $3.4 billion and 94,000 jobs.
"The area is very underutilized," said Christopher Hill, former commissioner of planning and development for the city and currently senior vice president of the suburban Northbrook office of the Grubb & Ellis Company, the real estate services concern. "Right now, there are a lot of warehouses and one-story buildings that are not the kind of thing you normally see around a major metropolitan airport. The opportunity at Midway is for ancillary services such as hotels, restaurants and meeting spaces."
To encourage new development in the surrounding area, the city recently established six tax increment financing districts along Cicero Avenue and other streets, and it is actively courting new businesses with promises of city assistance. Tax increment financing districts, within which owners of new developments receive rebates of part of their property taxes over a period of years, are used by many cities to encourage new development in blighted neighborhoods.
The first beneficiary of the program is ATA, which announced earlier this month that it would build a new 220,000-square-foot training center for pilots and other personnel and participate in constructing a 100-room hotel on about 10 acres of land just north of Midway on Archer Avenue.
"We'll be opening for the first time a facility that will consolidate all of our training in one place," Mr. Tague said.
The project will cost about $98 million -- of which $24.5 million is coming from the city -- and will involve both new construction and renovation of an existing industrial building.
According to Kenneth Wolff, ATA's chief financial officer, ATA would prefer to lease the facility, but Illinois tax laws may require the airline to own the property to qualify for the tax increment financing money. Either way, construction is expected to start later this year and be finished in 2003.
AS for Cicero Avenue, the area's main commercial street, the city recently completed an extensive streetscape renovation on the blocks that stretch from the Stevenson Expressway to Midway. The project installed islands and planters down the middle of the thoroughfare in an effort to make it more attractive to retailers. 
"We see it as an area with a lot of opportunity," said Alicia Mazur Berg, the city's commissioner of planning and development. "You don't just make a $761 million public investment and not have a substantial spinoff in the community."
In a move that many see as a barometer that the neighborhood is taking a turn for the better, the first new business to move onto the formerly blighted strip is a 1,700-square-foot drive-through Starbucks Coffee at the southeast corner of Cicero and 47th Street. The restaurant is one of two Starbucks in the Chicago area that are co-owned by the Johnson Development Corporation, a division of Magic Johnson Enterprises in Beverly Hills, Calif.
"We studied the traffic counts and realized it could be a very successful location," said Kenneth Lombard, president of Johnson Development. "The traffic counts we did prior to opening the store were very good even without the boost we'll get from the expansion of Midway. We always look for underserved inner-city markets, and Cicero Avenue is a good example of that."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The existing terminal at Midway Airport, right, is to be replaced with buildings on both sides of Cicero Avenue connected with a covered pedestrian bridge. (Photographs by Steve Kagan for The New York Times) Map of Chicago highlighting Midway Airport region.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/New Jersey; 
In Jersey City, an Industrial Park by the Hudson

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY 

 BODY:
IT may seem that every inch of the Hudson River waterfront in this old industrial city is filling with new office towers or apartment buildings. But a 50-acre patch overlooking the river on the far southern reaches of the shoreline is being returned, after a sluggish start, to the city's roots as an industrial park with up to a million square feet of commercial space.
 The park, Greenville Yards, was conceived in the late 1980's and is being built by Barrett Urban Renewal of Fort Lee, which was designated the redeveloper by the Jersey City Redevelopment Authority. It took nearly 10 years to gain clear title to the property, work through the environmental issues and bring utilities and roads to the park, which is not far from Exit 14A of the New Jersey Turnpike. It is also just south of the Port Liberte housing project and four miles south of the Newport mixed-use complex. 
 The first building, with 120,000 square feet on 10.2 acres, was completed in September for Summit Import Corporation, a distributor and importer of Asian foods. The company is using the building at 100 Summit Place for its corporate headquarters and a refrigerated warehouse distribution center. 
Construction is to start next month on a second building, with 137,000 square feet, on 8.5 acres that will be built for Preferred Freezer Services, a cold storage food distribution company in Perth Amboy that is expanding. Its president, John J. Galiher, said he is also negotiating for another building, of up to 60,000 square feet on three acres, for MCST Preferred Transportation and MCST Preferred Logistics, wholly-owned subsidiaries. 
In addition, Thomas Barrett, president of Barrett Urban Renewal, said that contracts are being or will soon be negotiated for three more buildings, with a total of 500,000 square feet, that will also be built for specific users. And he said that discussions are under way with tenants for the rest of the space, adding that the park would be completed in 16 months at a cost of more than $50 million.
Because of the recent boom economy and the "resurgence of development in the metropolitan area," Mr. Barrett said, there is need for distribution facilities close to markets like New York and northern New Jersey.
The activity reflects the strength of Jersey City's industrial market. At the end of 2000 its vacancy rate was 6.02 percent, down from 6.32 percent in 1999, according to Cushman & Wakefield, the commercial brokerage and real estate services company. During that same time the average annual per square foot rental rate rose to $6.15 from $5.85.
Many of the older existing buildings in the city have low ceilings and are considered unsuitable for some users, and there has been limited construction of new buildings, like those at Greenville Yards, with high ceilings, sprinkler fire-fighting systems and super-flat floors, which make it possible to stack products higher.
Jason Goldman, an associate director at the East Rutherford office of Cushman & Wakefield, said that while "the demand is there" for such buildings the supply is constrained by the lack of readily available land on which to build. 
ONE of the few other new construction projects is a 75,000 square foot addition being built for USCO Logistics at its existing 275,000 square foot building on Caven Point Road. And on 10 adjoining acres work is under way on a 172,000 square foot building. 
The developer of both projects is Hartz Mountain Industries of Secaucus, among the state's larger industrial landlords with 15 million square feet, 800,000 of it in Jersey City. 
Emanuel Stern, president of Hartz, said that with almost no vacancy in its industrial portfolio his company is "confident users will continue to chase a declining inventory." Hartz started the 172,000 square foot Jersey City building on speculation, he said, adding that discussions are under way with a food distribution company to lease the entire building.
The appeal of Jersey City's industrial market, like its office market, is its location. Industrial users that want quick access to Manhattan as well as nearby Newark International Airport and area seaports will choose Jersey City, said Bill Waxman, first vice president at the Paramus office of CB Richard Ellis, another commercial brokerage company. 
The area seaports have grown more attractive to some users, especially importers, since last June, when the governors of New York and New Jersey approved a 30-year lease that the Port Authority had signed with the Maersk-Sealand shipping line at the Elizabeth Marine Terminal.
Otherwise, Mr. Waxman said, potential tenants would travel to Exit 8 of the New Jersey Turnpike in the central part of the state, where new space is more readily available and less expensive. Rents in Jersey City are, however, lower than those in Manhattan, he added. 
Greenville Yards is meant to capitalize not only on that geography but its location within a federally designated foreign trade zone as well as in a state-designated urban enterprise zone. 
FOREIGN trade zones provide companies such benefits as decreased or delayed customs taxes; enterprise zones offer, among other things, a tax exemption on services and goods, including construction material, that companies buy to use in the zone. Mr. Barrett said there is at least a 7 percent cost saving to companies moving to Greenville Yards. 
Mr. Galiher, the president of Preferred Freezer Services. said that the tax incentives make the deal more cost-effective.
Sanford Greenberg, project coordinator at the Jersey City Redevelopment Authority, said that Greenville Yards is in the area south of Port Liberte that "Jersey City continues to see for industrial growth." In turn, he said, it will help meet the city's goal for balanced development, jobs and revenue.
Getting to this point has not been easy. The 50-acre site was part of a roughly 200-acre area once owned by Conrail and used as a train switching station until the early 1980's. Through the next decade the Port Authority developed about 110 of those acres for such uses as Tropicana's Northeast distribution center, and BMW's car-preparation facility. 
In that same period the authority contracted to sell the Greenville Yards site to the city with a deed restricting it to industrial use. Then the recession of the early 90's hit, dampening the industrial market in northern and central New Jersey and leaving it with a surfeit of space. 
Mr. Greenberg said there were other challenges, such as conducting an environmental investigation of the site, which "took a lot longer than anticipated." Ultimately, Mr. Barrett said, the site will be remediated as it is developed, with each building, landscaping or parking lot serving as a cap to seal in contaminants, including hydrocarbons, from the train operations. Ground water at the site must also be monitored.
It also took time to gain clear title to the property, part of which was still owned by Conrail and occupied by an active rail line. (That became more complicated when CSX Corporation along with Norfolk Southern Corporation began negotiating to acquire Conrail and take over its tracks and equipment, a deal that became final in 1999.) 
Finally, railroad tracks running through the center of the redevelopment site had to be relocated to its southern border, and another line on the northern side of the property was moved off site. That work was not completed until early 1999, Mr. Barrett said.
The annual asking rental rates for space at Greenville Yards are $7 to $8.50 a square foot -- but users so far are buying their buildings, Mr. Barrett said, noting that, in general, sale prices are $60 to $70 a square foot but could be higher depending on the use.
The first user at the park, Summit Import, distributes its food products mainly to Manhattan and the tri-state area. It relocated from Greenwich Street in TriBeCa in Manhattan and ultimately will employ about 100 people. 
Whiting Wu, Summit's president, said he had looked at other locations in New York, including Brooklyn, Long Island City and Staten Island, before settling on having a new building put up for his company at Greenville Yards. "We need to be near our customer base, so logistically it makes sense," he said, adding that retrofitting an existing building "would not have fit the bill." 
Mr. Greenberg of the Jersey City Redevelopment Authority said his agency is "planning other industrial developments on smaller areas in the city." He said those plans "could take off in the next few months."

GRAPHIC: Photo: First building at Greenville Yards was completed in September. It houses a distributor and importer of Asian foods. Site was once owned by Conrail and is adjacent to a Tropicana distribution center. (Richard Hunter) Map of Jersey City highlighting Greenville Yards.

HEADLINE: ART; 
Gallery Hopping Under a Single Roof

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM ZIMMER 

 BODY:
THE membership of the Silvermine Guild in New Canaan keeps growing, and one of the benefits of membership is an exhibition. The problem then is how to present a coherent display of disparate work by a lot of artists.
 The solution at the moment is to have five separate shows, each with a cogent theme decided on by the guild's exhibition committee. 
 The shows seem like disciplined vignettes. Two of them are on the small side. Lou Hicks, Juliet Holland, and Sharon Wandel are in "Winter White" a show that seems a harbinger of spring. 
Ms. Hicks and Ms. Holland are painters who complement each other. Ms. Hicks aims for subtlety and recession. Her color range here is grey and white, and the use of close values creates a Tonalist atmosphere that is deliberately ephemeral, just as a winter storm is. One painting is an exception: "Trees in Winter" employs outline, to make the trees distinct, and momentarily Ms. Hicks's contribution to the show loses the quality of reverie. 
On the other hand Ms. Holland adds extraneous materials to her paintings on wood to make them into reliefs. Her work is sere and viewers might be reminded of snow with a crust. But she also divides her paintings into sections reminiscent of Rothko's clouds, a factor that tames the innate aggressive quality of adding on material.
Ms. Wandel sculpts small stylized birds out of bronze. They are as small as robins but have the demeanor of falcons and, mounted on steel poles, act like sentries. If Ms. Hicks and Ms. Holland provide fleeting weather, Ms. Wandel contributes sharp actuality.
"Back Home Away from Home," the second small show, is characterized by a deliberate uniformity -- at least in size. All the photographs of both Nash Hyon, who works in Italy and Tertuliano Delgado, whose subject is his homeland, the Cape Verde Islands off the coast of West Africa, are postcard size.
In a bit of interaction with the audience, viewers are asked to draw their own postcards (materials are supplied) and to put pushpins on maps to identify their own home away from home. The relentless lineup of similarly sized images effectively reminds us of the old lesson: our one planet is one of splendid variety.
The first show encountered in the larger galleries, "Neo Madonna" contains some interesting images even though it is puzzling over all. "Where's the Madonna?" the literally minded might justifiably ask, or better in the current era, "What is a Madonna?" The inspiration of the Renaissance is hard to find and the contemporary singer isn't really here either.
Leslie Giuliani offers large charcoal drawings that are stately over all and small garish ones using encaustic that are more frenetic. Everything in this show addresses, sometimes obliquely, the issue of femaleness, but occasionally in the charcoal drawings the artist evokes the strangeness of Frida Kahlo.
Partick Maisano echoes Ms. Guiliani in his black and white diptychs. They contain figures with text written all over them. Mr. Maisano's inclusion here is daunting: a viewer can't quite make out the figures, and is hardly tempted to plow through the writing. Eve Stockton's marble and alabaster sculptures seem to be incipient figures, and her drawing, "Fertility Figure" underscores the theme of tentativeness by evoking conception. In the drawing a droplet seems to be touching a leaf.
Joan Wheeler, who used to stage narrative tableaux with toy dolls has moved on to larger, almost life-sized, but faceless figures freed from the box. But she has retained the creepiness inherent in her former work. Three of the figures seem to be penitents; they are dressed in coarse cloth and wear religious symbols. The fourth, a merry contrast, is made of flowers.
The fourth show, "Art Noir," is about darkness and intense light. David Boyajian tells the story of Persephone in the underworld and her rebirth in four stainless steel sculptures. Ann Chernow continues her interest in old movies, and in scumbled grisaille she recreates posters for lurid films of the 1830's and 1840's. Mitchell Friedman, who has mastered a black-and-white idiom, is a good complement to Ms. Chernow. If the atmosphere she resurrects is one of ominousness in basically urban or civilized settings, Mr. Friedman conjures up rural unease. His largest work is "Swamp."
"Industrial Archeology," the last show, is also the meatiest. In the middle of the last century the style called Precisionism chronicled and celebrated American industry and factories. Smoke from factory chimneys often served as a soft-edged counterpoint to the angular shapes of the buildings, silos and other structures. The inherent excitement of this is revived in watercolors by Alex McFarlane. While his watercolors are ideal -- they're named after elements such as copper and iron -- Christy Gallagher thoroughly examines the once-and-always industrial city of Bridgeport in 20 oil paintings and watercolors.
Jim Felice's tall cylindrical black steel "Smoke Stacks" are imposing; a lineup of them cuts across the gallery.
At the other end of the scale, Robert Dancik displays jewelry made of industrial materials on mannequins' wrists. Mr. McFarlane contributes sculptures representing streamlined industrial buildings, made from an unusual material: solid graphite.
 "5 Gallery Shows" runs through March 18 at the Silvermine Guild Art Center, 1037 Silvermine Road, New Canaan. Information: (203) 966-5617.

HEADLINE: The View From/Darien; 
Wanted: A Rink of Their Own Just a Stone's Throw Away

BYLINE:  By DARICE BAILER 

 BODY:
IN the Ardsley Curling Club's bright white rink, Anne Wiggins knelt behind a bull's-eye painted red, white and blue at one end of the ice while her teammate Jim Meinhold awaited instructions at the opposite end before attempting his next shot.
 In front of Ms. Wiggins, an opponent's granite stone rested on the bull's-eye in scoring position. 
 "Take it out," Ms. Wiggins said to Mr. Meinhold. 
Mr. Meinhold slid forward and released his 42-pound stone, which glided down the ice like a bowling ball. Two of his teammates on the Nutmeg Curling Club, Marianne Moore and Carleton Cleveland, furiously swept the ice in front of the stone to help smooth its path.
With its silver handle, Mr. Meinhold's stone looked like a whirling tea kettle. Takeout accomplished: he had whacked his opponent's stone off the scoring circle. But alas, Mr. Meinhold's stone sailed off, too.
It was a scoring dud.
"It's O.K.," Ms. Wiggins, who is from Redding and is the team's captain, said during the Sunday afternoon game. "If something doesn't go as you planned, you always look for Plan B."
And that is just what the Nutmeg Curling Club was forced to do after losing its home site at the Country Club of Darien, where the team had leased space from 1963 to 1998.
Mr. Meinhold, who is 53 and lives in Wilton, is part of an $800,000 fund-raising campaign by the curlers to build a facility in Fairfield County where over 95 percent of the club's 89 members reside. He is also the vice president of the Nutmeg Curling Club, which for the last three years has rented the rink at the Ardsley Country Club in Westchester County.
The Nutmeggers lost their home rink after the Darien club became concerned about the declining membership of the curlers and the lack of income generated from the group. For a prorated fee, curling members were granted winter membership at Darien during the curling season (October through March), including dining privileges.
Jill Owens, 47, of Bridgeport, who started curling at Nutmeg in 1968, estimated that in the early 1980's, the Nutmeg Curling club had around 220 curlers. But, as some members moved on, the club had trouble recruiting. The membership shrunk in half, and the country club began to take in less money from the dining room and the bar.
Ian Fetigan, the general manager at the Country Club of Darien from 1989 to 2000, said board members were reluctant to kick out the curlers because the sport is so uncommon, but they began to realize that "we had potentially better use of that space."
In 1997, when the lease was up, Mr. Fetigan said the curling club was given an ultimatum to bring in new members. But the membership increased by less than a handful, and in 1998 the Darien club began converting the area where the curling club played into locker rooms.
"Economically it made sense to them, but it left us out in the cold," said the 50-year-old Ms. Wiggins, who has a one-hour commute to Ardsley.
The Nutmeggers are not the only curlers asked to leave a country club site. It seems that participation in curling is leveling off across the country and the world.
In Chicago, for example, three to four clubs have suffered the same fate as the Nutmeggers, according to Rick Patzke, the communications director of the United States Curling Association, the sport's governing board.
Mr. Patzke said that curling participation swelled after World War II and in the 1970's "at a time there weren't so many sports competing with people's leisure time."
In the United States, there are 130 curling clubs (Connecticut also has the Norfolk Curling Club). The number of members in the United States, about 15,000, has remained stable for the last 10 years, Mr. Patzke said. 
There are 36 nations in the World Curling Federation with the United States membership ranking third behind Canada and Britain, Mr. Patzke said.
Canada has 800,000 curlers, said Warren Hansen, the Canadian Curling Association's manager of event operations and media. And, while Canadian interest in curling has increased based on television viewing audiences and attendance at the men's curling championship, membership is a different story. "I don't think it's changed so much since 1990," said Mr. Hansen said, who added that Canadian curling teams also had to work hard to keep their clubs going.
Even without a place to call home the last three years, the Nutmeggers keep rolling. And the club has not lost many members, despite the lengthy commutes to Ardsley.
"That's pretty impressive from my perspective," Brian Lawless, 44, a curler from New Fairfield, said. "It's a bigger time commitment to stay active."
The Nutmeggers have raised $450,000 through member donations. They have formed building and site committees to find a new home, which will require one and a half acres of land. The game is played on sheets of ice 15 feet 7 inches wide and 146 feet long. Mr. Cleveland, a past president of the club and a Darien resident, estimated that it would take one million dollars to build a new facility.
James O'Boyle, a club member from Norwalk, said that the major problem has been finding a piece of land in Fairfield County that is affordable. Deals to buy land in Wilton or lease space in Norwalk have fallen through. Club members are trying to lease land in South Wilton to build a rink.
Mr. O'Boyle said he would have a hard time even estimating the number of hours he had spent hunting for building sites.
"A lot of people put in a lot of hours," said Mr. O'Boyle, a Manhattan real estate lawyer. 
Curlers call the sport chess on ice because it involves strategy, and they liken it to golf because it is a sport where courtesy and good sportsmanship prevail. After a two-hour game, the winners buy the losers drinks, and then the losers reciprocate. Players linger in the lounge before a crackling fire discussing key shots like bridge players reviewing their hands.
"You never talk about bad shots; you only talk about good ones," Mr. O'Boyle said.
The players look forward to tournaments against other clubs, and their love for the sport bonds them with curlers around the world. "You can walk in any club in the world and instantly there are 50 people who are all your friends," Mr. Lawless said.
He hopes the club will soon find a home.
"You can only go so long with an organization before it finds a home or it falls apart," Mr. Lawless said. "Every organization, every church or synagogue, we all need homes."
To join the Nutmeg Curling Club call (203) 374-1559 or (203) 761-9305.
