HEADLINE: Rental Season For Summer Stays Hot 

BYLINE:  By NADINE BROZAN 

 BODY:
APPROACH David Jones, a broker with Prudential Connecticut Realty in Old Lyme, Conn. and tell him you have $15,000 to spend on the rental of a summer house on the coastline of Long Island Sound, and he will respond ever so politely, "That's nice, but I have nothing left."
 Make the same request across the sound on the North Fork of Long Island, and Suzanne Hahn, who owns two real estate agencies, will probably say: "Yes, I have a variety of rentals from seasonal cottages to waterfront estates. The summer rental market is just about starting now." 
 On the Jersey shore, Diane Turton, president of the real estate brokerage that bears her name, keeps a waiting list of hopeful renters for whom she has nothing at the moment. "We tell people houses are scarce and if something becomes available, we will show it to them," she said. Asked what advice she would give prospective renters facing empty inventories, she said, "I tell them to buy something -- and then rent it out." 
No matter how far along they are in depleting their summer inventories, brokers up and down the East Coast say business is thriving. Even as sales and rental prices for apartments in New York City have eased their angle of ascent somewhat, the quest for summer weekend and vacation rental houses shows no signs of abating, with prices up slightly from last year or at least constant.
Some landlords are content to get what they got last year, but others are asking for -- and getting -- increases that can fall anywhere between 3 and 30 percent, brokers say. In Saltaire on the western end of Fire Island, for example, Ali Beqaj, owner of Beqaj Real Estate, said, "Houses that went for $8,000 to $9,000 a month last year are $10,000 to $11,000, and houses on the ocean that were $30,000 for the season last year are getting $35,000 this year without even a question."
Nowhere are rents as stratospheric as they are in the Hamptons, with rentals for castles on the beach commanding $500,000 or more. A price tag of $30,000 a season -- Memorial Day through Labor Day -- is considered modest there. 
But, Jay Flagg, manager of the Southampton office of Prudential Long Island Realty, has detected a hint of restraint lately. "We're not seeing the increases in asking rents that we saw a year ago," he said the other day. "This year, landlords are not as ambitious for two reasons. The market was so hot last year that there were many sales, and some of them had increased their prices by such substantial amounts that they did not rent at all. This year they are more willing to negotiate." 
Mr. Flagg has one client now completing his second rental spec property in the Hamptons, a four-bedroom center hall colonial with pool and sunken tennis court in Sagaponack, which he has listed at $135,000 for the season. 
"He has bought two other lots with the same intention," Mr. Flagg said. "He will have spent $1.6 million per house by the time he's finished and will get $125,000 to $150,00 each per season, so as an investment he is making 10 percent. He exemplifies confidence in the rental market." 
How long rentals will continue to be impervious to the gyrations of the stock market, the demise of many dot-coms and the spreading wave of layoffs remains to be seen. But, for now at least, three months before Memorial Day, brokers up and down the East Coast from Kennebunkport, Me., to Kiawah Island, S.C., say they have sensed no surge in the number of owners seeking to recover from economic setbacks by renting out their houses nor any resistance among tenants to asking prices. In fact, demand has risen since last summer in many communities, and houses are being snapped up faster. 
"What is happening defies logic," said Jeff Akers, the general manager of Kiawah Island Villa Resorts, which handles rentals of 550 homes and condominiums on the barrier beach island off the coast of South Carolina near Charleston. "Last year was flat or maybe just a little bit up, but this year the forecast is terrific. Right now rentals are running 20 to 25 percent ahead of last year, and when you read the papers, you wonder why."
On Nantucket, Craig Hawkins, a broker with Maury People, a Resort Quest company and a Sotheby's affiliate, which has more than 1,000 rental houses on its roster, said the gross value of rentals had already outstripped those of last year by $100,000. 
"Last year at this time we were at $1,831,245," he said. "This year we are at $1,935,120." 
"I see no indication whatsoever of a slowdown and if we have a recession, rentals will continue to chug along full speed," he said. "They carried this and other companies through the last recession. People still go on vacation." 
IN fact, brokers agree that the uncertain economy is helping to fuel the rental market as prospective buyers wait to see what will happen to their portfolios or decide that renting offers a good holding pattern until sales prices decline. 
"If the sales market takes a downturn, that means more people will be renting," said Andrew Hart, managing broker in the East Hampton office of Cook Pony Farm, which has 11 offices spread over the Hamptons. "Judging by the leases I've seen coming through, we're probably doing the same volume of work as last year at this time and have done more high-end rentals early." 
Mr. Beqaj said he had few properties on Fire Island to show clients. 
"A lot of houses were sold over the last two years," said Mr. Beqaj, whose primary market is Saltaire, but who also does business in the less expensive communities of Kismet and Fair Harbor. "Now they are owner occupied and no longer rented."
Or if they continue to be available, "most are taken by the same people who keep coming back," he said. "And if they want a different house, they look in August or in the fall. Right now I have about a dozen houses available."
The same situation prevails in Ocean Beach, the island's most densely populated village and the hub of its night life. "A tremendous number of houses were sold in the last three years, and most of those had a history of renting for the full season," said Dana Wallace, owner of an agency there that bears his name. "Most new owners want to use them, so you're looking at a shrunken market. At the end of January, we had the full season's rental list done." 
However, people who envision themselves relaxing on a sandy beach or hiking up a mountain need not despair. But they may have to compromise about their expectations or be flexible about the time periods. 
"There is always some inventory," said Diane Saatchi, president of Dayton-Halstead in the Hamptons, which has offices in Bridgehampton, East Hampton and Sag Harbor. "There is always some property that comes on the market. We have rented houses in June that people have been very happy with."
But, she continued: "If someone came to me now and said they wanted to spend $50,000 for a four-bedroom house with air-conditioning, a heated pool and tennis court, I would say the few houses like that are already gone. For $50,000 we could probably get them a tennis court and three bedrooms or no tennis court and four bedrooms. Of course, there would be a pool at both."
On Long Beach Island off the New Jersey shore, John Franzoni, owner of Oceanside Realty, which has offices in Harvey Cedars and Surf City, offered much the same assessment. 
"It's not true that everything is gone," he said. "I might not be able to get you the oceanfront you want for the price you want in the first week in August, but the good houses are not all gone and we continue to get new authorizations as the season goes on."
In a typical year, Mr. Franzoni said: "We do about 2,500 leases, with the average lease for two weeks. We have an enormous range in rentals, from a two-bedroom duplex in a two-family home on the bay side of Surf City for $1,000 a week to a six-bedroom house with a pool on the beach in Loveladies for $30,000 a week."
On Long Island's North Fork, Ms. Hahn had a varied selection of houses to show a visitor recently as she drove around the nautical environs of Orient and Greenport and the farmlands and vineyards of Cutchogue.
"The summer rental market is different every year, and you can't make predictions until March," said Ms. Hahn, who owns Hahn Realty in Greenport and Marion R. King Realty in Cutchogue. "With President's Day weekend over, we are now starting the prime rental season," she said. "Over the weekend a lot of places were rented, but we still have a good amount available." Prices in her area range from $75,000 for a beachfront estate with four bedrooms, down through $25,000 to $35,000 for a waterfront home with three bedrooms and no pool or one off the water with a pool, and on down to two-bedroom cottage for $10,000 to $15,000 a season. 
As elsewhere, "the price of summer rentals varies with the proximity to water," she said. "The most desirable is sandy beach front and expansive Long Island Sound front. Houses located on creeks, of which we have a large variety, may offer docks or vistas over tranquil inlets and bay access."
Her agencies do not handle leases for less than a month's occupancy. Although she does have some monthly rentals listed now, Ms. Hahn said, "Sometimes if a house hasn't rented for the season, they split it up. But that doesn't usually happen until April." Monthly rentals on the North Fork tend to range from $5,000 to $25,000. 
In some communities, the successful search for a house is as much the product of good timing as anything else. In Bethany Beach, Del., Sue Cooper, rental manager of Crowley Associates, which handles 275 properties that rent mainly for week and two-week periods, said: 
"I am turning people away, one call after another. By Jan. 15 we had everything on the three blocks from the ocean from June 9 to the first week of September booked. Since then we have picked up about six new listings and have rented the majority of those. Now I have a few things that are within six blocks of the beach but not much else. And the few seasonal rentals we get, maybe 15 a summer, were gone by the first week in January. Normally that is not true until February." 
By contrast, it is still early in the hunting season in areas like Dutchess and Columbia Counties in New York.
Kevin Battistoni, principal broker with Leigh Ponvert Real Estate, a Christie's affiliate, which has offices in Millbrook and Rhinebeck, N.Y., did not get many inquiries until about two weeks ago. 
"The weather was an inhibition to people who want to come north and not a lot of people look in the dead of winter," he said. 
Of course, a good number of renters forgo looking altogether, in particular those who rerent houses they have already occupied or who rely on the Internet for photographs and description. 
REPEAT business is thriving in Montauk at the eastern tip of Long Island, where John Keeshan who has been in business for 30 years said: "Almost every rental that has been taken by one family for the last two years has been rerented by the same family. All we have to do is call the tenant from last year, who says, 'Yes, send me the lease and I'll send you the check.' "
But, he went on, "Fifty percent of the rentals for the season are still available at prices ranging from $18,500 to $25,000. There are also a few houses with pools on the ocean available by the month, starting at $100,000."
Procrastinators might find something as late as May 1, especially those seeking leases of two weeks. "No matter how good the market, not every one will rent and those people may be more amenable to short rentals then," Mr. Keeshan said. 
People who prefer inland countryside settings to the beach may find more meager choices.
"We do rentals on a limited basis because there are not a lot of them available," Mr. Battistoni said about northern Dutchess and southern Columbia Counties. "People who own properties here own them to use them during the summer. At the moment, there is so little rental inventory that it is scary."
When houses are available, he said, they tend to run from a low of $15,000 for the season to as much as $50,000, but the larger properties with acres of rolling grounds are rarely put up for rent. 
Farther south on the Hudson River, Nora Preusser, president of A. D. Preusser Real Estate in Garrison, Putnam County, said: "We have very few summer rentals, and many of what we have are repeat customers. If people don't buy, they just continue to rent. There are less than a dozen houses available, and people are looking at them right now."
Nor is there much to buy. "You have to wait for someone to die, divorce or change houses," she said. Rentals in Garrison range from $4,000 a month for what Ms. Preusser described as "an average American home" -- three bedrooms on two acres with no pool -- to $75,000 to $90,000 a season for four bedrooms with pool, tennis court and river view. 
Farther north, as ski areas are increasingly transformed into year-round destinations, more houses and condos for up for rent. 
"No more than 15 percent of the homes are used regularly by the owners," said Jim Collier, owner of Loon Reservation Service in Lincoln, N.H., that covers the Franconia Notch area. "People tend to use them either as ski houses or summer vacation homes, opting to rent them in the opposite season."
There are a number of programs that draw tourists to the White Mountains who subsequently become regular renters, Mr. Collier said.
Among the events he cited: the Inside Out Soul Festival, which is a Christian rock music festival; a Chevrolet Corvette rally; a trained bear show; and the New Hampshire Highland Games, which bring some 60,000 people of Scottish ancestry for cultural and athletic events, including the tossing of the caber, a large log. 
"Every time you get a new feature like that, you bring people to the area who have not been here before, and then they tend to return," he said. 
Noting that the average stay in his corner of New Hampshire is six days, Mr. Collier said the most expensive accommodation would be a four-bedroom house with sleeping space for 10 to 12 people at $1,469 a week. The least expensive would be a town house with a master bedroom and sleeping loft for $729 a week.
"We limit reservations to no more than a year ahead, and people start booking then," he said. "We probably have about 40 percent of the 240 homes we list booked so far, so there is still space left."
IN Manchester, Vt., Chester Kasnowski, owner of CondoHome Rentals, who has listings for 80 southern Vermont houses from restored farmhouses to cabins in the woods, said the pace of inquiries he was getting for summer rentals was stepping up. 
"In February and March we get calls from retirees from Florida, who make a straight track up here for July, August and September and are looking for high-quality condos. They come to Manchester for its designer outlets, music and dance programs and antiquing." 
But with prices half what they are in the winter, owners are more likely to occupy the premises themselves, so inventory can be tight. 
"A three-bedroom house within 10 minutes of Stratton Mountain would go for about $1,000 for two nights from November through April and even more on holidays," Mr. Kasnowski said. "In the summer, the same house goes to $2,000 a month."
"The clientele is completely different," he went on. "Skiers tend to be young, stockbroker guys in their 30's and 40's with more discretionary funds. The summer people are on fixed incomes and are looking for the $2,000 a month or less bargain." 
What they can find this year ranges from a five-bedroom restored farm house for $5,000 a month to mountainside condos for $2,300 a month to rustic chalets for $1,500. 
Whatever the economy brings, Mr. Kasnowski remains unflaggingly optimistic about his business. 
"Unfortunately, I do better when the economy gets worse because the population on the East Coast decides not to travel so far," he said. "They come to Vermont rather than going to Europe or Aspen. Even in a recession, you still have to have fun. You just don't spend as much -- or go as far."

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME; 
Rent Rules: Codification Or Stretch?

BYLINE:  By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
LAST December, the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal adopted numerous amendments to the rules enforcing rent laws in New York City and the rest of the state, and some details in the changes it made are causing heated debate. Lawyers who represent landlords say the amendments accurately reflect changes in the law passed by the State Legislature; tenant advocates contend that in some cases the housing division may have overstepped its authority.
 The changes, which took effect on Dec. 20, were adopted as amendments to the New York City Rent Stabilization Code (which governs rent-stabilized apartments in the city); the Emergency Tenant Protection Regulations (which govern stabilized apartments outside the city); the New York City Rent and Eviction Regulations (which govern rent-controlled apartments in the city); and the State Rent and Eviction Regulations (which govern rent-controlled apartments outside the city). 
 Rent control applies to apartments in buildings put up before Feb. 1, 1947, and occupied since before July 1, 1971, by the same tenants or their successors. Rent stabilization generally applies to apartments in buildings with six or more units built between 1947 and 1974 and to tenants who moved into pre-1947 buildings with six or more units after June 30, 1971. Post-1974 buildings that were built with various forms of government subsidy or tax relief may also be subject to rent stabilization. 
Officials say the amendments were adopted to bring the regulations in line with existing rent laws, judicial decisions and housing division interpretations of those laws. Some of the more contentious changes -- on base rents, vacancy allowances and roommates -- are examined in this column, and other provisions will be discussed next week.
Michael McKee, associate director of the New York State Tenants and Neighbors Coalition, a tenant advocacy organization, said that what he called one of the most "harmful" changes relates to the way the "legal rent" for an apartment is determined when a tenant files a rent-overcharge complaint. In the past, Mr. McKee said, the maximum allowable rent for an apartment would be calculated by taking the last rent registered with the housing division and adding to that any allowable increases that followed the registration.
Under the new regulations, however, Mr. McKee said, the "base date" for determining the rent used to calculate an overcharge claim is defined as the rent four years before the filing of the complaint. Thus, he said, the housing division will look back only four years from the complaint date, whether or not there was a registered rent on file at that time. 
So, even if the last rent registered for an apartment was filed, say, six years ago, the agency will now look back only four years -- to the rent that was actually being charged then -- to establish the last "legal regulated rent" for the apartment, whether or not the rent being charged at that time was, in fact, legal. In other words, Mr. McKee said, under the new regulations, an illegal rent would automatically become legal if no complaint had been filed within four years.
However, he said, since the Rent Stabilization Law provides that no base rent can be established unless the rent has been properly registered with the housing division, the agency appears to have exceeded its powers by creating what amounts to a new "base rent" based upon a four-year statute of limitations. Accordingly, Mr. McKee said, his organization intends to challenge the change in the regulations in court.
Sherwin Belkin, a Manhattan lawyer who represents landlords, countered that the four-year statute of limitations on rent-overcharge complaints had been created by the Legislature in the 1997 law. 
"All the D.H.C.R. has done was codify what the Legislature has already deemed to be an appropriate way to eliminate ancient record keeping," Mr. Belkin said. He added that while tenant advocates might argue otherwise, applying the four-year limitation to the calculation of the last legal rent was within the agency's power.
Debbie Del Pino, a spokeswoman for the housing division in Manhattan, said the amendments were a result of the Rent Regulation Reform Act of 1997, which requires the agency to update the codes to take into account changes in the law, judicial interpretations of existing law and various operational bulletins and policy statements issued by the division.
Ms. Del Pino said the agency believes the regulations contain "some of the strongest tenant protection provisions in the nation" and will withstand challenges in court.
Another amendment that disturbs tenant advocates is one that permits landlords to collect multiple vacancy allowances during a single "guidelines period. 
Mr. McKee explained that under the former regulations, when a rent-stabilized apartment became vacant, a landlord could obtain a 20 percent "vacancy allowance" if the new tenant signed a two-year lease or an 18 percent vacancy allowance if the tenant signed a one-year lease. Such increases, however, were limited to one increase per "guidelines period," the one-year time period between rent increases granted by the Rent Guidelines Board. 
Now, however, there is no limit on the number of vacancy-allowance increases a landlord can obtain during a guidelines period. And that, Mr. McKee said, will make it easier for some landlords to increase rents.
"It's no secret that the buildings with the highest turnovers are those in the worst condition," Mr. McKee said. "So what you're going to end up with now is higher and higher rents in the worst-maintained buildings."
Mr. Belkin argued that the potential increase in the number of vacancy allowances a landlord can obtain had also been addressed by the Legislature.
"The vacancy increase is now statutory," Mr. Belkin said, explaining that before the 1997 change in the law, the Rent Guidelines Board awarded such increases once each year. "The Legislature said that the vacancy increase is permitted every time a tenancy changes, and that is exactly what the D.H.C.R. regulations now provide," Mr. Belkin said. 
Another controversial amendment has to do with the rent a tenant can legally charge a roommate. 
Sandra Russo, housing law coordinator for Legal Services for New York City, a not-for-profit organization that represents poor clients in civil actions, said that in the past, financial arrangements between roommates were the business of only the roommates themselves. Under the new regulations, however, Ms. Russo said, a tenant may charge a roommate only for the roommate's "proportionate share of the rent."
Thus, she said, if a tenant living alone in an apartment takes in one roommate, the roommate cannot pay more than 50 percent of the rent.
"Not only does this interfere with the private relationships between individuals, but it allows the landlord to pry into their personal finances," Ms. Russo said, explaining that once a landlord discovers there is a roommate living in an apartment with a tenant, the landlord will then have the right to find out how much rent the roommate is paying. If a landlord learns a tenant is charging a roommate more than the proportional share of the rent, this could conceivably be grounds for eviction, but Ms. Russo said that the issue is so new, it has not yet been tested. 
"I've seen plenty of cases where an elderly person living on a fixed income takes in a roommate to help with the rent," Ms. Russo said. "And many times the roommate agrees to pay more than half the rent in exchange for the tenant keeping house and taking care of other chores. Why should the landlord be allowed to interfere with that kind of arrangement?"
Mr. Belkin said that concerns about the impact of allowing tenants to charge roommates only for their proportionate share of the rent seemed to ignore the impact that prior practice had on roommates.
"In a tight housing market, it is not unusual for roommates to be charged excessive rents by tenants," he said, adding that the original purpose of the law was to allow for companionship and shared expenses.
"All the D.H.C.R. has done with this amendment is ensure that a tenant's rent-stabilized apartment cannot be turned into a profit-making enterprise," he said. 
Mr. Belkin added that while there may be different views about the legitimacy of many of the amendments, "the courts will be the ultimate arbiter."

HEADLINE: N.J. & COMPANY; 
Fasten Seat Belts, But Expect a Soft Impact

BYLINE:  By GEORGE JAMES 

 BODY:
The slowdown in the economy isn't an abstraction for Oneil Taylor. A week and a half ago, it became very real. He was laid off, one of 10,000 employees -- 1,500 in New Jersey -- let go by Lucent Technologies. 
 But despite such highly publicized layoffs and a slowdown in the national economy, the New Jersey economy, which is finishing a ninth year of very robust growth, still appears to be healthy. 
 A report by the New Jersey Council of Economic Advisors completed last week says New Jersey just finished a boom year but can expect to experience slower growth this year and in 2002. Still, economists say, even with a big national downturn, the state is in position to land softly.
With unemployment still low, many companies are scrambling for skilled workers even as others like Lucent are laying them off. This dichotomy has not escaped Mr. Taylor, who until he was handed his pink slip Feb. 15 was a network systems engineer for Lucent just since September and before that a 19-year employee of AT&T.
"It is kind of strange," said Mr. Taylor, a 43-year-old father of two, from his home in Irvington. "I still think -- even though I know there is a downturn in the economy -- that there are still a lot of opportunities out there. I don't think the economy is at a point it's so bad folks can't find a job. I think for me it's finding the right one."
Nationally, manufacturing jobs have been disappearing, high-tech stocks have been dropping in value and the stock market in general has been in a funk. The gross domestic product registered its weakest growth rate in five years: 1.4 percent in the fourth quarter. And wholesale prices climbed 1.1. percent in January, the steepest monthly gain in more than 10 years. 
So in the midst of all this, how is New Jersey faring, and what is the outlook? Not bad, according to a number of experts.
"The slowdown is here, but we are well positioned to weather it and, when the national economy picks up again, to continue the strong growth we've seen over the years," said Joseph J. Seneca, an economist at Rutgers University who serves as chairman of the New Jersey Council of Economic Advisors. "The New Jersey economy has been so good for so long, any slowing feels like a shock, but we're still growing and our economy is fundamentally sound." 
James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, said, "The downturn or slowdown is going to be much softer in New Jersey than the nation as whole." He noted that New Jersey has become more diversified and less dependent on manufacturing, which accounts for 11.5 percent of jobs -- down from 33 percent in 1970 -- compared with 14 percent for the nation. 
Caren Franzini, executive director of the New Jersey Economic Development Authority, a state agency that provides financing for business development, said: "We have not seen a decline in businesses seeking finances. What we've seen is businesses being more cautious just in terms of their borrowing needs."
Christopher Biddle, a spokesman for the New Jersey Business and Industry Association, said, "While the layoffs are dramatic, the unemployment rate is still low -- so low that employers will have no difficulty finding work for people who have been laid off."
Noting that a survey released by the association found that 80 percent of businesses reported having trouble finding skilled workers, Mr. Biddle said, "Even with additional workers, employers are still going to have difficulty finding the workers they need to fulfill their business expansion plans."
Dr. Seneca's report cited a tight labor market as a problem area for the economy. Others include inflationary pressures like rising prices for fuel and homes, low office vacancies and declining retail spending.
On the plus side there is "a diversified portfolio of vibrant growth industries," so-called "growth clusters," including information technology, research and development, pharmaceuticals, finance/insurance, logistics and entertainment, which added jobs at a 2.3 percent annual rate.
The report says the economy should continue to grow because of continued economic gains in New York City, which affect the region, decreased reliance on manufacturing and a substantial backlog of nonresidential construction. Commenting on the construction, George Nagle, secretary of the Council of Economic Advisors, said, "It will provide a very good basis for continued investment in the state." 
The report says that employment last year grew by 61,000 jobs to a total of 3.9 million, an increase of 1.6 percent. It was the fourth consecutive year the number of new jobs exceeded 60,000. But the report also predicts job growth will dip somewhat, growing at a rate of 1.1 percent this year and 1.2 percent the next, by about 45,000 jobs a year. 
New Jersey ended the year with an unemployment rate of 3.8 percent, according to the New Jersey Department of Labor, the lowest since 1988. At year's end, the national rate was 4.0 percent; it is now at 4.2 percent. January figures for New Jersey are scheduled for release on Tuesday.
"There may be less fizz in the boom," Dr. Seneca said. "Certainly the national economy is slowing, particularly in manufacturing, but New Jersey completed a very good year. For 2000 there were over 60,000 jobs added, very strong retail sales, strong income growth, but certainly a slowing in all those numbers by the end of the year."
The report noted that the gross state product, the measure of all goods and services produced in New Jersey, grew 6.0 percent in 2000. The growth rate is expected to be lower, 4.8 percent this year and 5 percent in 2002. Personal income grew 5.8 percent last year but is expected to grow at more slowly in the next two years, 5.2 percent and 4.7 percent. 
The consumer price index, a measure of inflation, rose 3.1 percent last year, owing mainly to energy price increases, but the report foresees inflation remaining at 2.5 percent for the next two years.
Dean Hughes said the real danger was that fears of recession on the part of the public could become a self-fulfilling prophecy. "We can summarize that in a phrase," he said. "Can gloom doom the economy?"
Oneil Taylor, who lost his job at Lucent, is not planning to go the gloomy route. He sees the time he spent at AT&T and Lucent as giving him valuable experience he can build on and has faith he will find a job quickly.
"I can look at the negative and I can look at the positive," he said. "I tend to focus more on the positive aspects."

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS; 
When You're No. 3 (Maybe), It Pays to Take a Long View

BYLINE:  By Iver Peterson; Iver Peterson reports from New Jersey for The New York Times.

DATELINE: LAWRENCEVILLE 

 BODY:
Undaunted by a solid record of almost nonexistent election support, the Green Party has jumped back into state politics by recently nominating Jerry L. Coleman, a consultant, as its candidate for governor in this year's campaign. 
 Never mind that nobody who was not either a Democrat or a Republican has won the governorship of New Jersey since Charles S. Olden was elected in 1859 on the Opposition ticket, which combined Whig, Republican and Know-Nothing elements. On top of that daunting record of two-party dominance, no third party in New Jersey has yet managed to even become a minor player, either by winning a solid minority of votes or by forging mutually helpful ties to a big party, the way the Liberal and Right to Life parties in New York often ally themselves with the Democrats and Republicans. 
 If that weren't discouraging enough for an insurgent in New Jersey, the two parties this year are comfortably aligned in the way that leaves hardly any cracks to pry open since Jim McGreevey, the likely Democratic candidate, and Donald T. DiFrancesco, the Republican, largely agree on major issues like gun control, abortion rights, open space preservation and reducing the impact of property taxes. 
None of this discourages the many people who dislike having their choices limited to the Big Two, as the number of minor parties that fight their way onto the ballot each election cycle proves. They may not agree on much, but they all believe they are building a movement, and Joseph A. Fortunato, a Montclair attorney and the chairman of the Green Party, is no exception.
"Basically we're in this for the long haul," Mr. Fortunato said, "and it may take us 25 years to establish ourselves as other Green parties have around the world."
Mr. Coleman said, "Jim McGreevey didn't win the first time but he might this time, so who knows how I'll do the next time."
It's true that there is a tradition in New Jersey of "losing to win," or running once to get name recognition and again to win, but only if you're a member of the Big Two. Even if the Greens are willing to be patient, they are certainly off to a slow start, especially for a party claiming to motivate disaffected voters. 
In the last gubernatorial race Madelyn R. Hoffman, the Green candidate, got 10,700 votes, barely a third as many as Richard J. Pezzullo, the New Jersey Conservative Party candidate, and a fraction of the number won by the dominant "third" party candidate that year, Murray Sabrin, who won 114,000 votes in a race that Christie Whitman won with 1.13 million votes.
It's hard to motivate the unmotivated in times of general tranquillity, said Ross K. Baker, a Rutgers political science professor.
"Minor parties serve as a safety valve for people who have a 'curse on both your parties'," Dr. Baker said, "but in New Jersey there have not been a lot of issue around which minor parties can galvanize."
Insurgencies worked well for Ross Perot in 1992, when the economy was faltering and Mr. Perot was able to mobilize a lot of voters over his opposition to economic pacts like the North American Free Trade Agreement. But on other issues, notably taxes, the major parties have managed to usurp the terms of the debate and left the minor candidates jumping up and down at the fringe of the debate, waving their arms for attention.
The Greens face another problem this year, in the bitter aftermath of Ralph Nader's raid on Democratic votes in last year's presidential election. The resulting anger among rank and file Democrats, especially among key groups like union members and environmentalists, is going to work against the Greens this fall.
So far, Mr. McGreevey seems unconcerned about being Naderized by Mr. Coleman. His spokesman reacted to the announcement of Mr. Coleman's candidacy with a Zen-like yawn, saying that the Mayor of Woodbridge was working on an approach that went beyond party labels.
Still, it would be a mistake to regard the Greens as uniformly addlepated lefties who are unable to adopt more mainstream positions, since some of the party's candidates appear to have taken up causes that are downright appealing to New Jersey's famously middle-of-the-road voters.
Bruce I. Afran, a Princeton lawyer who was the Green candidate in last year's United State's Senate race, campaigned in part on maintaining a strong military and defense of Israel, and Mr. Coleman said he would steal a page directly from the Republican playbook by promising a tax cut, in his case, a one-third cut in the state sales tax, to 4 percent.
"I think we can live with a reduction in the sales tax," Mr. Coleman said, sounding a little bit like Christie Whitman in 1993. "The important thing is to run on the issues the people think are important."

Christina Maddi, Riaz Haidri

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BATTERY PARK CITY -- UPDATE; 
More Space for Children to Swing a Bat

BYLINE:  By DENNY LEE 

 BODY:
Little Leaguers celebrated an early victory two weeks ago when the Battery Park City Authority agreed to build two green ball fields with stadium lighting along Warren Street on the north end of Battery Park City.
 The authority, which is the state agency that oversees Battery Park City, has also agreed to set aside nearly twice as much indoor recreational space in nearby buildings as it had proposed last year. 
 Parents and children had pushed hard for the deal, in which a temporary playing field will be replaced by the two new permanent baseball and soccer fields. 
"I'm thrilled," said David Feiner, a Little League coach who is on Community Board 1's youth committee. "There are so many kids here that the league started turning some away."
Timothy S. Carey, the authority's chief executive, said the agreement balanced the needs of the community and economic realities.
Councilwoman Kathryn E. Freed, whose district includes the growing neighborhood, said the plan was expected to get the City Council's support on Tuesday. Financing for the project, which will cost $29 million, needs approval from the city. DENNY LEE

SECTION: Section 3; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 1483 words

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS; 
Quick Lessons in the Fine Old Art of Unwinding

BYLINE:  By ANDREA HIGBIE 

 BODY:
GOT stress?
 Of course you do. And you are in very good (and very crowded) company. Competition is driving many people to work harder and run faster -- in both good and not-so-good economic times. 
 While it is known that stress can make you ill -- causing heart, stomach and headache problems, along with sleeplessness, fatigue and depression -- not everyone may realize the heavy toll that it also takes on the economy.
Stress costs American businesses about $10,000 annually per employee, in absenteeism, lower productivity and increasing health and workers' compensation costs. That's an overall economic impact of about $300 billion, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. And the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health estimates that 40 percent of the nation's work force is affected by stress, making it the No. 1 reason for worker disability. 
In recent years, many employers have tried to roll back the tide by offering perks like stress-management classes, in-office massages, nap times during the workday and even laughter clubs. Well-meaning as they might be, not everyone can take advantage of them. (For some people, taking any time off from work or from responsibilities at home is, well, too stressful.) And not everyone is disciplined or knowledgeable enough to handle stress on his own by setting up a daily exercise regimen, learning to meditate or modifying a diet.
Solutions to the problem, as with so many others these days, can be found on the Internet. One self-help Web site, www.stressdirections.com, was created in 1999 by Alma Dell Smith and Lyle H. Miller, clinical psychologists who run the nonprofit Biobehavioral Institute and Treatment Center in Brookline, Mass., which each week counsels 150 clients, referred through corporations and physicians. They also head Stress Directions, a six-clinician consulting company. The Web site includes a "stress navigator" that measures a person's stress and helps to treat it by advising changes in behavior.
Dr. Smith and Dr. Miller offer an uncommon perspective on handling stress in both the workplace and at home. They have worked together over the last two decades, collaborating on the books "The Stress Solution" (Pocket Books, 1993) and "Stress and Marriage" (Pocket Books, 1996). And they have been married to each other for 16 years.
They also have their own way to relieve stress. "We love to dance, especially ballroom dancing, and that's very important to us," said Dr. Smith, 54. "Dancing is fun. It keeps me alert, on the ball and it feels good."
She and Dr. Miller, 73, said they spent 12 years developing the navigator. More than 500 companies, universities and government agencies have used it, including I.B.M., Gillette, BellSouth, AT&T, Polaroid, the Navy and the passport agency of the State Department, said Carolyn L. Krusinski, who founded Stress Directions with Dr. Smith and Dr. Miller. 
Dr. Smith describes stress management as a three-legged stool, with the legs representing work, family and community. If someone is stressed or burned out at work but has a solid home and community life, life goes on. If he has a good connection with his community but problems at work and home, things are getting shakier. When all three are amiss, get ready to topple. "That's a hard situation for anyone," Dr. Smith said.
More than 25,000 people have used the stress navigator online and 500,000 have taken the test in its original, pencil-and-paper format, Dr. Smith said. The navigator identifies sources of stress, susceptibilities and symptoms. It also provides specific suggestions as well as resources like books, other Web sites and organizations to help alleviate stress and treat its symptoms. "It's not like having a one-on-one talk with me," Dr. Smith said. "But it is tailored and relevant to the person taking it."
EMPLOYEES of participating companies can take the test at their desks. The responses and results are confidential, so employers receive only a group overview, not a specific employee's test results. "We give companies an organizational stress profile, saying 'out of your 1,000 people, X percent have this level of stress and here's why and here's what to do,' " Dr. Miller said. 
Stress is increasing over all, Dr. Miller said, with half of adults suffering negative effects and having trouble managing their stress levels. Ms. Krusinski says the highest stress levels are found among people who deal with the public, including police officers, teachers and social workers, and employees in financial services.
The navigator stress profile is intended to help businesses find the roots of stress in the workplace and to reduce its effects on the bottom line by lowering health benefits costs and employee turnover.
At BellSouth about five years ago, managers suspected that job-related stress was hurting productivity in certain departments. After the employees took the test, Dr. Smith and Dr. Miller pinpointed the stress as originating mostly at home instead of at work. They advised BellSouth to address the problem by offering workshops on family issues. Employees could participate at no cost but on their own time, Dr. Smith said. As a result, stress levels dropped and productivity rose; health care costs and absenteeism also declined. The company said it was unable to provide specific numbers.
I.B.M. has also found the program useful, said Jana Weatherbee, a vice president for corporate issues. "It's customized for I.B.M. and points you to I.B.M. resources that might help you," she said. "If you're experiencing financial stress, it might point you to the I.B.M. program that reimburses you up to $250 for financial planning assistance from Merrill Lynch or American Express. We've offered the program for about two and a half years, and the fact that it's a Web program works well because a large portion of our work force is remote or mobile."
Anyone can take the test on the Web site at a cost of $70. The 264 questions are divided into three sections: susceptibility to stress, or how well you take care of yourself; sources of stress, including job, financial or child-care problems; and symptoms, including headaches and sleep difficulties. After completing the test, clients receive an on-screen assessment with advice.
Correcting stress-related problems, however, takes time -- around six weeks for acute stress to a year for chronic stress -- whether through therapy, medical help, job training or the willingness of the stressed person to make changes, according to Dr. Miller. People often stay in stressful situations because the thought of changing is scarier than not changing.
ONE key to relieving stress, Dr. Miller and Dr. Smith say, is to have fun. Participation in at least one enjoyable activity a week helps to cancel out some of the week's stress and to build optimism. 
At least twice a month, without fail, the couple, who live in an 1850 Victorian town house in the South End of Boston, go ballroom dancing. "The music is beautiful," Dr. Smith said. "We laugh. We see our friends."
Dr. Miller also plays basketball and follows other sports in order to relax. Dr. Smith does gardening and yoga and refuses to work more than 30 hours a week. "I go off duty," she said.
"Perfectionism can be a major stressor," Dr. Smith added. "Change what you can. And avoid stresses like difficult individuals, even traffic jams, if you can. Having a good sense of humor is so important. Don't take things too seriously."
"I still get rattled," she said. "I just try to recover quicker."
What advice might they have for a mother of two school-age children who works full time, has next to no time for herself, is regularly sleep-deprived and is, coincidentally, facing a deadline for this article?
"Start with getting more sleep," Dr. Smith said. "Go to bed even 20 minutes earlier a night than you have been."
That may be easier said than done, but Dr. Smith and Dr. Miller say the best insurance against stress may be as simple, and complicated, as love.
"Giving and receiving love and affection," Dr. Miller said, "is powerful medicine for mind, body and soul."

Taming the Tension
A test from Stress Directions, a consulting company, includes a section on stress susceptibility. Test-takers respond to these sample statements on a 1-to-5 scale, with 1 meaning almost always, and 5 meaning never. The higher the score, the higher the susceptibility. 
* I eat at least one balanced, hot meal a day, and get at least seven hours of sleep a night.
* I am in good health.
* I exercise at least twice a week.
* I regularly give and receive affection.
* I have at least one relative within 50 miles on whom I can rely.
* Income meets basic expenses.
* I organize my time effectively.
* I get strength from my religious beliefs.
* I do something fun at least once a week.
* I speak openly about my feelings.
* I take quiet time for myself.
* I have an optimistic outlook on life.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY; 
Asking Americans To Build Their Savings

BYLINE:  By Vivian Marino 

 BODY:
There is no denying that the decade-long economic expansion has enriched many Americans. Yet huge numbers of people have little to show for those years of prosperity, other than the homes they own. 
 In fact, more than half of American households continue to live virtually from paycheck to paycheck, according to the Consumer Federation of America, which last week announced a campaign to encourage people to save and invest more. 
 The federation, a nonprofit group, released results of two studies showing the tenuous financial condition of many families. One of the studies, based on a federation-sponsored survey of 1,637 adults, found that 53 percent said they often lived from paycheck to paycheck. The percentage rose to 64 percent for households with annual incomes of $20,000 to $50,000 and to 79 percent for those with incomes of less than $20,000.
Over all, 60 percent said they needed to save more.
The other study analyzed the latest Federal Reserve survey of consumer finances and found that the typical American household had total net assets of $71,700 -- most of it in home equity. But net financial assets, or assets minus debt, totaled only $9,850 per household, including money in retirement savings plans. Among low- and moderate-income households, the median net financial assets amounted to less than $1,000.
Stephen Brobeck, executive director of the Consumer Federation, said he was concerned that a weakening economy would worsen the situation. "A slowdown will persuade many American families to make a greater effort to pay off consumer debts and increase their savings," he said. "But it will be more difficult."
The federation's campaign, partly financed by the Bank of America, is scheduled to begin in Cleveland next month and in Kansas City, Mo., in April. It will be expanded nationwide. Vivian Marino

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
What Brings A Bear Back to The Market

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
IN nature, bears hibernate in winter. But on Wall Street just now, it is hard to find many of them asleep.
 Pessimism and doubt have trumped irrational exuberance. Worries abound over corporate profits, stagflation and overleveraged consumers. Once clear and bright, the future of technology stocks is out of focus. 
 Bears prey on this sort of stuff. But now and then, they feel like shopping.
Steve Leuthold, president of Leuthold/ Weeden Capital Management in Minneapolis, has been a notable bear for years. But lately he has been buying a lot of stock. He took some time last week to talk about why he came out of his cave. Following are excerpts from the conversation:

Q. You have been a market pessimist for years, yet the fund you manage, the Leuthold Core Investment fund, invests in stocks. When did your equity holdings bottom out? And when did your attitude start to change?

A. My bias is to be a buyer, not a seller. But in April of last year, equities were down to 17 percent of the portfolio. The fund was up 23 percent in 2000, and that is one reason why. We were playing defensively.
Our attitude started to change around the first of the year. I feel more constructive about things. We are finally getting rid of some of the terrible excesses in technology and the Internet. The rest of the market is reasonably priced. 
We raised our stock exposure then, and increased it again at the beginning of February. Now the fund is 60 percent stocks.

Q. So you think the market is poised for a rally? Aren't you worried about a recession?

A. I am looking for a kind of bifurcated bull market, with not much action in the technology stocks but with a fairly decent market in many other areas, including consumer goods and health care.
I think the economy will probably contract this quarter and again in the second quarter, but I don't think things will get too bad. 

Q. So when do you expect stock averages to start turning up?

A. Normally, two cuts in the discount rate by the Federal Reserve Board has been a pretty good buy signal, and we have had that. Usually, the market bottoms out about midway through a recession. So you may be approaching the bottom toward the end of this quarter.

Q. What do you make of the fact that pessimism seems awfully deep right now?

A. One of the things that concerns me is that most Wall Street analysts have never dealt with a recession.
We just did a study from 1947 to date. During that period there were nine years where earnings on the Standard & Poor's 500 fell by 5 percent or more. In each of those nine years, the stock market was up. By contrast, there were nine years when S.& P. earnings were up 20 percent or more. Five of those years were up years in the market. Three were down years. 
One of the things younger people don't realize is that markets turn up in the middle of recessions. They have all become so earnings-momentum oriented they overlook that. You have to remember the market is a discounting mechanism, and you have to look ahead.

Q. You said that some of the excesses have been wrung out of technology. Do you expect prices in that sector to fall farther? Also, do you own any technology stocks?

A. Historically, the median price-earnings ratio for the tech sector, which includes 500 stocks, is 33 times earnings. Right now we are at about 47 times earnings. That is a lot closer to the norm than the 114 times earnings they were at the peak. Technology stocks are getting interesting. At the moment 4 or 5 percent of our portfolio is in some technology stocks that have been beaten up.
Avant is one; Park Electrochemical is another. Milacron, the old Cincinnati Milacron, is a third. 

Q. What have you been buying recently?

A. Earlier this month, we bought a package of department-store stocks, including Federated Department Stores, Nordstrom and Dillard's. An industry play.
A lot of our analytical work shows the stocks are selling at 50 percent of sales.

Q. Are there other areas of interest?

A. I think life insurance stocks look really cheap. They have been beaten down recently due to concerns that the estate tax will be abolished. People were saying estate planning represented 60 percent to 70 percent of their business. But it is really only about 10 percent. I don't think the estate tax is going to get eliminated. And stocks like Lincoln National and Torchmark look pretty cheap.

Q. Have you sold out of any positions?

A. We recently sold the drug stocks. We had been in them for a year and a half, and I am beginning to think there are going to be some interesting constraints put on the drug companies in terms of pricing.

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Subaru Outback H6-3.0 L. L. Bean Edition; 
A Melting Pot With All-Wheel Drive

BYLINE:  By BOB KNOLL 

 BODY:
WHEN Subaru introduced the Outback version of its midsize Legacy six years ago, the traditional station wagon seemed headed for oblivion, elbowed aside by the minivan and the sport utility. Who would have thought that all-wheel drive, an evocative Australian name and some rugged-looking trim could transform an innocuous Japanese wagon into a cult car for the Snow Belt?
 Whatever the reason, the Outback proved to be a tremendous hit, and it revived the formerly slumping automaker. Before long there was a whole range of Outbacks -- there are six variations for 2001 -- that account for the majority of Subaru sales. 
 A significant redesign of 2000-model Legacys and Legacy-derived Outbacks brought many improvements. (The smaller Outback Sport is a different animal, based on the compact Impreza.) The wagons grew three inches longer and became smoother and sleeker. A revised rear suspension added 5.2 inches to the width of the cargo hold. The familiar four-cylinder engine got more power and became more fuel-efficient. The ride was made smoother and the handling crisper. The brakes were enlarged and improved. And a Subaru trademark, full-time all-wheel drive, remained as functional and unobtrusive as ever. 
So for 2001, as Subaru faced the task of improving on a successful redesign, it did what car companies usually do: it added power and came up with a marketing gimmick. The power comes from a new six-cylinder engine -- the company's first six since it discontinued the sporty SVX coupe in 1996. The gimmick is an agreement with L. L. Bean, the Maine-based purveyor of outdoor gear, to use that company's name on a fancier Outback, the H6-3.0 L.L. Bean Edition.
This car is a cross-cultural experience: a station wagon designed by a Japanese company partly owned by General Motors; named for the Australian interior; built in the heartland of the United States (in Lafayette, Ind.); and embellished by the designer label of a Yankee outfitter from New England.
The 3-liter, 6-cylinder engine is all new, and at 212 horsepower it has 47 horses more than the four-cylinder power plant in lesser Outbacks. But like that engine, it is horizontally opposed, or "flat," an anomaly for a family car.
Subaru says the engine has inherently little vibration, and the six is indeed smoother and quieter than the four. The "chuffle" sound familiar to Subaru owners is gone, and the engine delivers smooth and powerful response, especially at medium speeds.
The new six is used in two new Outback models, the L. L. Bean Edition and the H6-3.0 VDC. The VDC has the company's first stability-control system, which it calls Vehicle Dynamics Control. The system applies the brakes at individual wheels to keep the car going where it is pointed -- potentially preventing a spinout -- but its operation could have interfered, under certain conditions, with the two existing all-wheel-drive systems (one for automatic transmissions and one for manuals). So Subaru developed a third drive system that operates as smoothly and easily as before and is also compatible with the stability control.
The L. L. Bean Edition has that retailer's logos affixed to each front fender, embossed on the leather seatbacks and embroidered on the floor mats. Ford has done essentially the same thing for years with its Eddie Bauer versions of the Explorer and Expedition. An association with an outdoor outfitter is a natural fit for a vehicle marketed as an enhancement to outdoor recreation; oddly, L. L. Bean's Web site includes only a brief mention of its namesake Subaru.
As befits its designer status, the $29,990 L. L. Bean wagon has a high level of standard equipment, including a power driver's seat, security system, auto-dimming rear-view mirror with compass, and air filtering for the cabin. Both the L. L. Bean and H6 VDC models have leather-and-mahogany steering wheels by Momo (which designed steering wheels for expensive racecars). One wonders how many Outback customers actually know or care about Momo.
The H6-3.0 VDC is priced above the Bean, at $32,390 including shipping. The Bean does not come with the VDC's stability control or its new drive system; it retains the excellent all-wheel-drive system previously used on Outbacks with automatic transmissions. The Bean also comes with free scheduled maintenance for three years, oil changes and tire rotations included.
All midsize Subarus have done very well in government and insurance industry crash tests. Safety improvements for 2001 include a front passenger air bag that inflates at one of two stages, depending on the severity of a crash; pretensioners and force-limiting features for the front seat belts; and attachments for new child-seat anchorages, which are easy to find because of labels right on the rear seatbacks.
Although the two new high-end Outbacks push Subaru prices into what the company calls "entry luxury" territory -- a land populated by the likes of Lexus and BMW -- less-expensive models are still around. Four-cylinder Legacy Outbacks run from $23,390, including shipping, for the base model with manual transmission, to $26,490 for the Limited with its standard automatic.
The two new six-cylinder Outbacks are nearly as expensive as several excellent all-wheel-drive wagons from Europe, including the Audi A4 Avant 2.8, the Volkswagen Passat 4Motion 2.8 and the Volvo Cross Country.
The L. L. Bean Edition that I tested felt familiar, since last year I drove a 2000 Outback Limited with the four-cylinder engine. The new six was most noticeable for its smoothness and silence on the highway. The extra horsepower was not all that evident, especially when not driving at full throttle, which I seldom do anyway. What was apparent, compared with four-cylinder Subarus, was the extra response at moderate speeds.
The fuel economy I achieved during my test drive was only about one mile a gallon less than with the smaller engine (about 23 m.p.g., compared with 24). According to the owner's manual, the six requires premium gasoline "for best performance," though regular may be used. When a manufacturer gives you that option -- another reason to read the manual -- I suggest that you take advantage of it, unless you think your wagon should behave like a racecar.
Ride and handling were the same as in the 2000 model: responsive and stable. The ride was especially impressive on secondary rural roads that tend to toss cars about unless their suspensions are well designed.
The automatic temperature setting for the heating and air-conditioning system worked quietly and unobtrusively, although I personally prefer to set the controls myself. The eight-way power seat was a welcome addition, allowing a comfortable fit behind the wheel.
Is the new H6 engine a significant step up that justifies the extra $2,400 to $4,800 over the four-cylinder Outback Limited equipped much the same way? Personally, I doubt it.
The lesser Outbacks can be dressed nicely, and they are worthy competitors. The L. L. Bean trim is so understated that the neighbors will have to look carefully to discern the status of your purchase. And the look of the H6 VDC is even more subtle.
Although a stability control is a wonderful device -- I think it should be mandatory on truck-based sport utilities, which need all the extra stability they can get -- it is hardly needed on a car as stable as an Outback. Unfortunately, the new government stability rating system gives no credit to manufacturers that equip their vehicles with this excellent equipment.

INSIDE TRACK: Crocodile Dundee goes Down East.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
A 'Miracle,' But Maybe Not Always A Blessing

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
RISING productivity is a wonderful thing. Income and living standards improve when companies find ways for their workers to produce more in each hour they spend on the job. But sometimes surges in productivity backfire, and this may be one of those times.
 The productivity miracle of the last five years takes for granted that people will buy the rising output of goods and services. Take away demand or reduce it, and the productivity payoff turns sour. The economy slows, as it is slowing today, and companies shed workers or cut hours, or both. Because they are more efficient, they need less labor, and unemployment becomes more of a problem than it would have been had productivity not surged. 
 "We are surely going to experience a pop-up in the unemployment rate," said Dale Jorgenson, a Harvard economist and expert on productivity. "The rise in January, to 4.2 percent from 4 percent in December, was just the beginning."
A pop-up in unemployment assumes that there really has been an enduring surge in productivity since 1995; that a new economy actually exists. Those who think so have concluded that widespread deployment of very fast computers and of innovative information technologies has raised permanently the level of corporate efficiency, in downturns as well as in booms. The unemployment rate will be a test, unfortunately, of the new economy's endurance. More endurance means fewer workers.
Productivity often rises in good times. Pressed to fill orders and to satisfy strong demand, employers push their employees to work harder and faster. Then, when the economy slows and demand eases, so does the extra effort and the productivity. The issue is how much easing. For many decades, there wasn't much. The productivity growth rate averaged nearly 3 percent a year. 
But then, in 1973, corporate America lost its knack for efficiency, and for more than two decades, productivity grew at an insipid 1.3 percent a year, on average, and the growth rate of the entire economy fell in tandem. The White House and the Federal Reserve shifted their focus. They stopped concerning themselves with ways to augment demand, so that it would keep up with the ever-rising supply of goods and services. Instead, they discouraged demand, usually through higher interest rates, so that it would not outstrip supply and increase inflation. Then, in 1995, productivity revived, to the old 3 percent level. 
Now the revival, a k a the new economy, is being tested in its first downturn. If the new economy proves its endurance, the unemployment rate is likely to jump -- by one or two percentage points more than it would have risen in the old, less-efficient economy. On the other hand, if the wonders of the new economy have been exaggerated, then we are in for another stretch of meager productivity growth and thus meager improvements in living standards for most Americans. 
The mathematics of this process are easily illustrated. A company employs 100 people to assemble 1,000 refrigerators an hour. By installing computerized machines or reorganizing the assembly line, the company raises the output to 1,030 refrigerators, a productivity growth rate of 3 percent. Through raises, the workers can share in the income from the sale of the extra 30 refrigerators. 
They are likely to keep their raises in a slowdown. But if demand falls back to 1,000 refrigerators an hour, and the assembly line maintains its newly acquired efficiency, then jobs disappear, often through layoffs. The company no longer needs 100 workers to assemble 1,000 refrigerators an hour. Five or six jobs are lost, and this process, multiplied across the economy, can help to turn a mild downturn into a very painful one. 
That happened during the Depression. Numerous innovations and market efficiencies raised the productivity growth rate in the 1920's and 1930's, and as unemployment rose so did the outcry about "the effects on employment of increased productivity and technological change," according to a history of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Under pressure, the bureau began to measure productivity and job displacement in many industries. The information was deemed by the unions of the day to be "necessary in collective bargaining for dealing with the problem of technological unemployment."
Public works projects in the 1930's eventually absorbed hundreds of thousands of displaced workers. That sort of government spending is out of fashion today, of course. The main tool for reviving the economy is concentrated in the Federal Reserve's power over interest rates. And the surge in productivity, which the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, has welcomed so joyously, is now, in the short run, a potential burden.

HEADLINE: Is a Battered Dell Ready to Rebound? 

BYLINE:  By CHRIS GAITHER 

 BODY:
AFTER years spent basking in the sun of booming sales, makers of personal computers are finding their industry to be a cold, cheerless place.
 Demand has plummeted as the market reaches saturation. With consumers and corporations less eager to spend money on new machines, the resulting price wars have cut into profits, making the PC business increasingly difficult. 
 But the industry's growing pains may prove profitable for bargain hunters. Looking for deals among the gloom, investors are starting to place bets on the company that many analysts consider the most likely to emerge a winner: Dell Computer. 
"I think what the investor gets is very good value with limited downside," said Don Young, an analyst at UBS Warburg, speaking of Dell stock. He has a strong buy recommendation and a 12-month target of $35 on the shares, which closed on Friday at $23.06.
"He won't be hurt if he's early, and he's going to miss a heck of a ride if he waits," Mr. Young added.
Dell's strength lies in the efficiency of its business model. The company, based in Austin, Tex., sells built-to-order computers directly to customers. That allows it to keep little inventory and to take advantage quickly of falling component prices. As a result, Dell can offer lower prices.
The company used this model to increase sales 30 percent to 40 percent a year during its glory days, as the Internet made the PC indispensable for millions of people. For the 1997-98 period, the company's stock outpaced competitors like Compaq and Gateway and was the No. 1 performer in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. Shares hit a high of $59.68 in March 2000.
By the end of last year, however, weakening demand for PC's, combined with a general economic slowdown, sent shares of most computer makers tumbling hard. Still, Dell and Hewlett-Packard were the only major producers to beat the industry's average unit-sales growth of 14.5 percent in 2000, according to the International Data Corporation.
Choosing to cut prices to gain market share, Dell has warned analysts to lower their profit expectations for the current quarter, the fourth warning in the last six quarters. Dell shares lost 66 percent of their value in eight months, hitting a low of $16.25 on Dec. 21, before rallying.
"We haven't executed over the last several quarters as crisply as we can," said T. R. Reid, a Dell spokesman.
Despite the general slowdown, which dragged down its shares more than those of most rivals, Dell has managed to strongly outsell many of its competitors. While the PC industry grew 10 percent in unit sales during the last quarter, compared with the year-earlier period, Dell said that its gain was 43 percent and that it increased market share in every part of the world and in every sector of the business.
Howard Ward, a portfolio manager at Gabelli Asset Management, which manages the $3.8 billion Gabelli Growth fund, attributed the stock's decline to a worldwide economic downturn, not to Dell's management. He praised the company as having "an impeccable balance sheet" and said it had used its buyback program to reduce outstanding shares by more than 300 million in five years. Mr. Ward has increased his stake to 2.5 million Dell shares, 1.4 percent of the fund's assets.
"You get the opportunity to buy the good stocks when the news is a little negative, a little cloudy and uncertain," he said. "If everything were rosy, we'd be talking about a $60 stock."
Many companies and industry experts have said they expect a general rebound in PC sales in the second half of the year, when Microsoft releases its new operating system and Intel distributes its new Pentium 4 chip more widely. Others warn that the year may end as dismally as it began.
Mr. Reid, the Dell spokesman, said desktop PC sales accounted for half of the company's revenue, which was $31.88 billion last year, and two-thirds of its operating profit of $2.77 billion. To lower risk in the face of the slowdown, Dell has pushed hard into more lucrative enterprise, or professional, markets, like servers and storage systems. Those sales rose 42 percent last quarter.
"Over time, we would like to continue to change our mix away from PC's," Mr. Reid said, though he said Dell would not abandon PC sales.
Richard Chu, a managing director at SG Cowen Securities, said he expected Dell's stock price to dip further before it recovered. It might slip into the high teens, he said, a level he suggested would be "a good entry point" for investors. "I think they have a fundamental strategy," Mr. Chu said of Dell, "that will result in them becoming more important, rather than less important, in the computer systems space."

CORRECTION-DATE: March 4, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about investing in the Dell Computer Corporation misstated the type of products that accounted for half of the company's revenue and two-thirds of its operating profit. They are nondesktop products, like servers, storage systems and laptops, not desktop personal computers.

SECTION: Section 3; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 4

HEADLINE: THE BUSINESS WORLD; 
At aFrench Factory, Culture is a Two-Way Street

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: VALENCIENNES, France 

 BODY:
FOR both Toyota and the workers at its new French plant, cross-cultural communication was a learning process.
 The French gave up red wine, a lunchtime staple, in the company cafeteria, while the Japanese, accustomed to docile company unions, accepted four trade union representatives on a company labor board. 
 And on Jan. 31, the first Yaris, a bulbous subcompact, rolled off the assembly line of the new, $570 million Toyota Motor factory near this northern French industrial city. The plant, designed to employ 2,000 workers, is Toyota's most modern and efficient factory, and its first on the Continent. 
The issue of wine arose when French labor ministry inspectors ordered Toyota to justify the ban. "We had to explain why -- health, working conditions," said Claude Boulle, a former labor ministry official who is now a Toyota vice president for administration. "This is a young generation; they drink to celebrate, not for nourishment." At ceremonies celebrating the production of the first Yaris, there was no Champagne, he said, a faux pas if there ever was one.
In addition to avoiding alcohol during the workday, employees gather for calisthenics -- at 8 each morning, before the first shift. The exercises are voluntary, but Georges Pierru, 35, a team leader, says he usually attends. "To avoid accidents, you don't start cold," he said, picking at a lunch of poached fish, rice and mineral water.
Mr. Pierru worked for Peugeot, the French automaker, before joining Toyota a year ago. Toyota, he says, is not Peugeot.
At Peugeot, there were early-morning meetings to discuss the day's production run. At Toyota, he said, there are meetings whenever a problem arises. Moreover, Toyota designed the Valenciennes factory to be 30 percent more compact than other factories with similar output, to curb building and operating costs and enhance communication. "Peugeot factories were bigger, so you were on the phone all the time," Mr. Pierru said. The Toyota factory's unusual layout, in which production lines meet at a central point, lets workers talk more easily.
Big stakes are riding on Toyota's getting it right here, as it struggles to increase its European market share, which, at 3.7 percent, is less than half its share in the United States.
The Toyota way differs from the French from the start. Unlike French companies, where diplomas and qualifications loom large, Toyota goes after unskilled workers, preferably with little or no auto industry experience, preferring to train them itself. And in a country where seniority is smart, at Toyota youth is king. The average age here is 27.
Cedrix Gut, 21, who has a degree in visual arts, works in the paint shop, after training for several weeks at Toyota's assembly plant at Burnaston, in central England. He had little trouble fitting in, except perhaps for the food. "There's an awful lot of rice," he said.
WHILE alcohol is absent, the cafeteria food is still largely French. On a recent day, there was steak, pizza, pasta, poached fish and a large selection of salads and cheeses -- as well as miso soup and steamed rice. There were few takers, though, for the chopsticks.
The cafeteria line was a wave of blue-and-gray windbreakers, with "Toyota" in red letters on the back and the employee's name on the front. Company attire is unusual for the French, who value individuality. Not even Toyota's offer, equally unusual for France, to supply free company work clothes has led most workers to accept more than the windbreaker. 
Toyota says the names on the clothing foster communication by making employees easily identifiable. But French workers, coveting privacy, shy from the practice.
If factory workers find names on clothing offensive, French executives find the lack of private office space equally intrusive. "It's very difficult, if you're not used to it, especially if you have to concentrate," said Mr. Boulle, 49, who sits at a low-slung desk in a large hall with dozens of other white-collar workers. Senior executives cluster in the center, with lower-ranking managers around the edges.
And Toyota, unlike French companies of its size, has no executive dining room. Managers dine in the same cafeteria as other employees do, but on a later shift.
Although much is at stake for Toyota here, the fate of the plant is also important for the Valenciennes area, a former coal and steel region of about 300,000 people where other heavy industry shut down in the 1980's. It now has an unemployment rate of 16 percent. Catherine Lenoir, who runs Toyota's hiring office, said that more than 30,000 people had applied for the factory's 2,000 jobs.
That has made relations with French unions, often cantankerous, more relaxed. Though the Communist union, the C.G.T., boycotted the labor-management council, other union leaders are conciliatory. "We want dialogue, to identify problems and put them on the table," said Pascal Honvault, 29, a team leader who represents the moderate C.F.D.T. labor federation. "Of course, we don't expect to resolve them all."
Hiroaki Watanabe, 59, who had managed plants in Canada and Britain, spent only 3 of the last 15 years in Japan before he was put in charge of the Valenciennes plant. "I thought this would be a very different experience," he said. But it wasn't really.
"I had knowledge of France," Mr. Watanabe said, "but in general more information is available in Japan about the English-speaking countries."
To prepare himself, he traveled to France as a tourist, discussed France with French Canadians at Toyota in Canada and even visited Toyota factories in Brazil and Argentina. "I came to the conclusion," he said, "that you had to learn French."
His first contact with the French, he said, was on trips to France to interview management candidates, meeting several dozen executives before choosing two vice presidents. "I was impressed," he said. "They were all very serious candidates."
WORKERS in northern France, he said, strike him as not very different from those in Britain and North America. "Perhaps more spontaneous, less inhibited," he said, adding: "That makes my work easier."
Like Mr. Pierru, Didier Leroy, 43, is an industry veteran. At Renault, he became the company's youngest assistant plant manager ever when he was 37, before Toyota made him vice president for manufacturing in 1998. For training, Toyota sent Mr. Leroy to visit its factories in Japan, North America and Britain. At Valenciennes, about 30 interpreters stand ready to interpret in French or Japanese. But much business is conducted in English, he said.
For the moment, about 200 Japanese are working at Valenciennes, including about 150 temporary trainers. When the plant is in full operation, by late next year, 24 Japanese executives will remain.
Toyota sent almost 400 newcomers to factories in Japan, Britain and Canada for training. Some knew bits of English, while others required interpreters. 
For his part, Mr. Watanabe, while fluent in English, insisted on conducting an interview in French, through an interpreter, to hone his comprehension. 
"I can understand most everything," he said, "but still find it difficult to express myself."
