SECTION: Section 3; Column 5; Money and Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 2798 words

HEADLINE: Business; 
Putting 'Hostile' Back Into Takeover

BYLINE:  By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN 

DATELINE: WEST BEND, Wis. 

 BODY:
ANNOYED by the biting questions hurled at him at an industrial technology conference last November, William D. Gehl cut his presentation short. He gathered his materials, stuffed them in his briefcase, bolted out the back door of the conference room and walked briskly toward the exit of the Four Seasons Hotel in Chicago.
 Behind him, two well-dressed men raced down the hall to catch up. Cutting him off at the escalators, Mark E. Schwarz introduced himself. "We're some of your biggest shareholders," he said. "We really should talk." 
 Mr. Gehl, the chairman and chief executive of a small manufacturer of construction equipment that bears his family's name, stopped. But he soon grew frustrated with the needling questions from Mr. Schwarz and his partner, Paul DeRobbio. 
"Gentlemen, this conversation is over," Mr. Gehl said he told them, shoving his way through the hotel's revolving door into the cold. 
A little more than a month later, the Gehl Company became the target of a fierce hostile takeover. In what may be a harbinger, with the stock market depressed, Mr. Gehl and his tiny $80 million company here are at the center of a takeover campaign not seen since the heyday of corporate raiders in the 1980's and early '90's. It features, besides shareholder attempts to oust Mr. Gehl and his board, a class action lawsuit, potential greenmail and, of course, bitter personal attacks.
Mr. Schwartz, 40, and Mr. DeRobbio, 41, were not just any shareholders. They had been quietly accumulating stock in the company since the summer. With more than 6 percent of Gehl -- which makes machines like forklift trucks and manure spreaders -- they had their own plans for it.
And they happened to hold an ace card: the backing of Harold C. Simmons, the Texas billionaire who made his name and at least some of his fortune taking on the management of Lockheed (now Lockheed Martin) and taking over NL Industries, a Houston chemicals company.
"This guy Gehl is a big fish in a small pond -- he's tapped out," said Mr. DeRobbio, chuckling as he sped around downtown Dallas on a recent Saturday, weaving between cars in his black Range Rover, the music blaring, after an interview at Mr. Simmons's office.
"We're Bill Gehl's worst nightmare," Mr. Schwarz said later. Mr. Schwarz, Mr. DeRobbio's more tempered alter ego, had been driving behind him -- though with more caution -- in a silver Jaguar.
How this small industrial company just north of Milwaukee could get caught in the cross hairs of one of Wall Street's most legendary raiders may appear odd. Odder, perhaps, this was not the first time.
Two years ago, the company became the target of another classic 1980's mover and shaker, James Dahl. Once a star salesman for Michael R. Milken's junk-bond operations, he later received immunity for testifying against him. Gehl bought out Mr. Dahl's 10 percent stake -- which he had bought on the open market -- for $14.9 million to send him on his way with a promise to keep quiet.
AND last summer, before Mr. Simmons, 69, decided to get hostile, he had teamed up with the investment fund of another Texas billionaire, David Bonderman, who years ago took Continental Airlines out of bankruptcy, to make an unsolicited offer for Gehl. But Mr. Bonderman's fund bowed out of the partnership in the fall, realizing that the takeover effort could get dirty.
Yet if any takeover fight brings back memories of the hard-charging, fist-pounding, corporate-raiding 1980's, it may well be the one for little Gehl. After expanding quickly to meet booming demand, last year Gehl found itself overextended and with too much capacity just as the economic cycle started to turn down.
"Are we corporate raiders or shareholder activists?" Mr. Schwarz asked rhetorically, his feet now propped up on a long mahogany boardroom table at Mr. Simmons's offices.
"These guys have every defense in the world," he said of Gehl. "He's got a fortress around him. It's the most egregious I've ever seen. They've got a poison pill. A staggered board. They've got it all."
In the lobby of Gehl's headquarters, a computer monitor flickers with the company's latest stock price of around $15 a share, up about $5 since Mr. Simmons made his buyout offer of $18 a share.
Mr. Gehl's office is on the second floor of the plain, two-story brick building, just off of Main Street in this town of about 28,000 people.
The wood-paneled office is modest; toy models of Gehl excavators and other equipment are proudly displayed on a shelf behind his desk.
"The approach to our business has been very studious," he said, seated with his suit jacket still buttoned. He took over the company in 1992, he said, when it was on the brink of collapse, saddled with $90 million in debt and wounded from $18 million in losses the previous year. "It was definitely a turnaround job," he said.
Indeed, Wall Street largely credits Mr. Gehl, 54, not only with saving the company from ruin, but also with reinvigorating the business for which his grandfather, Michael Gehl, worked as a sales manager and helped to build. Mr. Gehl refinanced the debt, hired managers, added plants and developed new products. He also made an acquisition of his own in 1997: the Mustang Manufacturing Corporation, for $28 million. A graduate of the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, he is not naive. 
During his tenure at the company, Mr. Gehl, who commutes to West Bend from Milwaukee's North Shore suburbs, has become a town hero. Besides participating in civic events and making donations to local charities, he -- unlike his father, who was a dentist -- is the first Gehl family member to work at the company since his grandfather retired in the late 1940's. 
And at a time when West Bend's other major employer, Amity Leather, was being bought out and broken up, Mr. Gehl managed to keep Gehl afloat. The company, with roots here dating to 1859, employs a more than 1,100 people at its various operations. Some 450 of the employees work in West Bend.
Still, in early 1998, the company began to feel pressure to sell out.
Mr. Dahl, who now operates his own private investment firm in Jacksonville, Fla., bought 5 percent of Gehl in mid-1997, starting when the stock was trading at $10.50 a share. Almost immediately, in an effort to drive the stock price higher, he began pushing Mr. Gehl to sell the company to the highest bidder. At one point, he tried to be appointed to the company's board, an idea that Mr. Gehl summarily rejected.
Upset at Mr. Gehl's refusal to consider selling the company, Mr. Dahl went on the offensive, speaking out against him and his motives. "If Bill were a rational, smart businessman -- he'd received enough overtures to know -- the big guys out there are willing to pay big prices," Mr. Dahl told The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel then. "It's his own fiefdom."
At the time, his industry was in a consolidating frenzy, and Gehl was facing new competition from the likes of Caterpillar and Deere & Company, both of which announced plans to compete in Gehl's markets. Komatsu, one of the industry's giants, was seeking an alliance with, or outright acquisition of, Gehl, and Mr. Gehl traveled to Tokyo for talks. He came back to West Bend empty-handed, however, having rejected Komatsu's offers.
As the rumors spread that there were offers for the company, other shareholders also wanted Gehl to consider selling out. At the company's annual meeting in April 1999, James S. Schmitt, a Gehl shareholder, silenced the auditorium when he shouted out to Mr. Gehl, "Have you ever played musical chairs?"
"Yes," Mr. Gehl responded, irritated.
"Have you ever lost?" Mr. Schmitt shot back. 
Pausing, Mr. Gehl grinned. "No," he said.
But Mr. Gehl was under the gun. By the summer of 1999, Mr. Dahl had pressed Mr. Gehl's buttons so hard -- threatening to unload his entire position in the company -- that Mr. Gehl had to come to the bargaining table. Gehl's stock is thinly traded; only 5,000 shares change hands on an average day. If Mr. Dahl had tried to sell even half his position at once, there clearly would not have been enough demand, and the stock price would have dropped sharply.
GIVING into Mr. Dahl, Gehl bought out his stake at the market price of $20.50 a share, or $14.9 million. In exchange, Mr. Dahl agreed not to buy stock in Gehl for 10 years and not to speak publicly about the company.
So did Mr. Gehl get taken? Was he "greenmailed"? "They call it that," he said. "But we felt it was in the best interest of the shareholders. Jim Dahl decided he wanted to liquidate his position. He's history."
Other shareholders, though, were not as happy about the deal with Mr. Dahl as Mr. Gehl was. "He hasn't offered to buy back my shares," said William J. Nasgovitz, president and chief executive of Heartland Advisors, whose value fund started investing in Gehl in 1994 and has 330,400 shares. The value of his stake has dropped by about 25 percent in the last year. "I believed in Bill Gehl," Mr. Nasgovitz said.
Mr. Gehl countered, "He's had opportunities to make money and sell at higher prices."
The same summer, Mr. Nasgovitz began applying his own pressure on Mr. Gehl to consider selling the company. In July, Mr. Nasgovitz sent a critical letter with a proposal: he wanted the company to elect a committee, independent of Gehl's management or board, to explore selling the company. The letter also asked Mr. Gehl to relinquish his role as chairman -- arguing that he was unfairly controlling the fate of Gehl for his own benefit.
"Requiring a corporation's chairman of the board to be independent of its management ensures the independent judgment that applicable legal standards require of a board," Mr. Nasgovitz wrote. He received no response.
Gehl marched on, its stock price hovering at about $20. The company appeared on Forbes's list of the 200 best small-capitalization companies. It also made Fortune's undervalued businesses list of "Big Bargains in Small Companies." Then the market started to plummet. Gehl was overextended; its debt level jumped from about $30 million to about $60 million. Its stock began to drop.
"Heck, if I had my name on the door, I wouldn't want anyone to mess with my deal, either," Harold Simmons said of Mr. Gehl last weekend, as he stood in the lobby of his Dallas office with his golf spikes still on. "It's just human nature."
Mr. Simmons was paging through Fortune last year when he spotted Gehl on the undervalued list. He wrote away for the company's annual report. Coincidentally, Mr. DeRobbio, just two doors down, had already began researching the possibility of buying it. Mr. DeRobbio, a muscular, 6-foot-4 inch deal maker, went to Mr. Simmons with his idea. 
"When Harold and I got this harebrained scheme, I didn't know where it would take us," he said, sipping a 7Up in the kitchen of Mr. Simmons's office complex.
Last summer, they decided to approach the company. The plan would be to try to buy the company and then to resell it for even more to a competitor in the industry. With the backing of one of Mr. Bonderman's investment funds, Halifax, they contacted a banker at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette (now a unit of Credit Suisse First Boston) to help set up an introduction. A brief meeting with Mr. Gehl proved fruitless. The company would not entertain an offer.
Undaunted, Mr. Simmons and Mr. DeRobbio, through their company, CIC Equity Partners, started buying stock in Gehl in bulk; the price was then about $18 a share. Mr. DeRobbio also called on Mr. Schwarz, the president of a Dallas hedge fund called Newcastle Partners, who is known for his feisty approach to waging proxy contests against obstinate management. Mr. Schwarz, too, began buying Gehl shares.
"Nobody in power owns stock at Gehl; that's the primary problem," said Mr. Schwarz, a boyish-looking 40-year-old dressed in a blue blazer, jeans and loafers. "You've got a chairman who's got his name out in the front and he only owns 1 percent of the company. He likes to match his initials on his shirt to the outside of the building." Indeed, Mr. Gehl only owns a small portion of the company, though a slightly higher figure than Mr. Schwarz stated -- 3.4 percent.
Mr. DeRobbio and Mr. Schwarz approached Gehl, sending a letter seeking to buy the company; they had planned to even offer Mr. Gehl a chance to continue running it.
They sent the letter to Mr. Gehl and to the company's eight-member board. "There was a concern that the directors weren't being informed, that Bill was acting as a gatekeeper," Mr. Schwarz said.
They waited for a reply. "He won't return my phone call," Mr. DeRobbio said, playing with a toy model of a Gehl earthmover. "By the way, that's the first thing I'd cut," he joked about the toy. "How much are they wasting on that?"
The last week of December, they decided to go all the way. They named a price: $18 a share in cash, a premium of 57 percent. On Dec. 22, a formal offer was on the table and made public.
Within four hours, Gehl's board publicly rejected the offer, deriding it on more than a half-dozen points. 
Mr. Nasgovitz of Heartland Advisors went ballistic. In a letter to Mr. Gehl and its board, he wrote, "It is difficult to comprehend how the board and management could have convened and given due consideration to an offer in a four-hour period on a Friday evening before a holiday." He asked: "Were all board members fully informed of the offer? Were any shareholders consulted? We certainly were not!" 
He added, "A board is elected to represent shareholders, not management."
Within weeks, two shareholders filed a class action lawsuit on behalf of all Gehl shareholders. The group accused the company of failing to duly examine the offer. And some shareholders accused the company of trying to later cover its tracks by saying it had commissioned a fairness opinion from an outside adviser, Robert W. Baird & Company, a Milwaukee brokerage firm.
MR. GEHL defended the action. "First of all, their move was not unexpected," he said. "This was not a knee-jerk decision. We were fully prepared. It is a ploy to put the company in play," he said of the offer. 
"We're under no obligation to sell," he added. "Our interest is not in satisfying vocal shareholders. We have the entire shareholder base to consider."
Mr. Schwarz begs to differ about Gehl's quick response to their offer. "They're trying to paper it over," he said. "Three weeks ago, I got a call from Steven Booth at Robert Baird," he said. "They said they were just hired to examine our proposal," he added. "It was a new engagement for them. Don't you think it's a little odd that they dismissed the offer and then hired the bankers after?"
Mr. DeRobbio and Mr. Schwarz are preparing to wage a proxy fight against Gehl. A typical proxy fight for control of Gehl would be almost impossible because of the many protection mechanisms that the company has set up under its corporate governance structure. Among them are a poison pill, which makes a traditional hostile takeover prohibitively expensive, and a staggered board, which prolongs proxy fights.
Instead, Mr. DeRobbio and Mr. Schwarz hope to take control of the company from the inside -- by trying to have themselves elected to Gehl's board at the next annual meeting in April and to vote Mr. Gehl off the board. Coincidentally, Mr. Gehl's three-year term ends this year. Mr. DeRobbio and Mr. Schwarz have filed their intentions to seek election.
"The board's not as independent as it might seem," Mr. DeRobbio said. "The blood runs thick in Milwaukee." 
But before the Texas buyout clan has a chance to get its way, analysts speculate that Gehl may resort to a common defensive measure: making a big acquisition of its own, to become less attractive. In its announcement of its fourth-quarter results, Gehl made a point of discussing such a possibility. Mr. Gehl went even further in an interview, hinting at doing a deal in Europe.
But he made one thing very clear. "The company is not for sale," he said. "Period."
As for the jabs thrown at his character, Mr. Gehl said nonchalantly: "I don't take these things personally. I don't view it as a personal attack. If you're operating a public company it comes with the territory."
What will happen to Gehl? An analyst at Credit Suisse, J. Blair Brumely, said in a recent report, "We are not entirely sure that the stalemate the company seeks to construct with this strategy will materialize, nor do we think an eventual sale of the company is guaranteed because of the management's deep-seated desire to remain independent."
His take on the situation: "We continue to find our greatest comfort on the sidelines as this piece of theatre unfolds."
On Friday, Gehl's stock closed at $14.63, up 37 percent since the offer was placed on the table. The market seems to be siding with -- or perhaps cheering for -- Mr. Simmons.

SECTION: Section 3; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 1

HEADLINE: TALKING MONEY WITH: MONICA SELES; 
Dual Focus: The Ball, the Nest Egg

BYLINE:  By GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

DATELINE: SARASOTA, Fla. 

 BODY:
ANGER can be a destructive force, but for Monica Seles, rage over an attempt on her life eight years ago had a hidden benefit. It brought home to her the value of money.
 In 1993, at 19, she was already the No. 1 professional female tennis player in the world. That spring, Gunther Parche, a fan of her rival, Steffi Graff, stabbed Ms. Seles at a tennis tournament in Hamburg, in full view of the stunned crowd. 
 The wound sidelined her for two years, cost her the No. 1 ranking and led to severe depression. It also cost her more than $1 million. 
Today, Ms. Seles, now 27, is recovered and in control of her life. But the experience made her aware that she could suddenly lose the ability to earn money and left her determined that her earnings would be invested to provide financial security. These days, she watches her spending, monitors her investments closely and, occasionally, even suggests investment strategies -- like the "Dogs of the Dow" theory -- to her advisers.
At a recent interview over lunch at a country club near her home here, she wore a blue-jean skirt and a cotton blouse and carried a Kate Spade handbag, projecting the image of the generally cool, businesslike and somewhat distant woman that even her friends describe as "private."
In the mid-1980's, at the age of 13, she left Yugoslavia for the United States, armed with killer strokes and her trademark hefty grunts. There was no time then to think about investing. Ms. Seles's older brother, Zoltan, handled the family's funds conservatively, watching the contracts that she signed and investing her winnings safely. That was fine with her.
"I never asked about the finances," Ms. Seles recalled. "I wouldn't dare." When it came to spending, she was similarly uninvolved, just wanting enough money, she said, "to get the teddy bears that I liked." Mostly, she added, "I just wanted to play tennis." 
The stabbing halted both her playing and her income. Under German law, when she sued the German Tennis Federation for lost income and damages, she had to post a percentage of the $16 million she was seeking. Then, when she lost the case, Ms. Seles had to forfeit the money she posted and pay the federation's legal fees. (She also brought a suit against Mr. Parche, who was given a two-year suspended sentence on the assault charge.) 
The experience hit Ms. Seles hard. "I realized: 'Grow up here. Money talks at the end of the day,' " she said with a trace of a Hungarian accent -- reflecting her upbringing as part of the Hungarian minority in northern Serbia.
"From that point, I just wanted to know where every dollar goes." Ms. Seles added in a soft but firm voice.
The trauma -- and the gradual realization that Mr. Parche would never be punished -- also proved emotionally devastating. Ms. Seles experienced a series of severe depressions over nearly two years. Only psychiatric help and the support of her family brought her back to competitive tennis, she said.
During her long physical and psychological recovery, however, she had both the desire and the time to consider her financial affairs more closely. "I realized that there is no justice in it at all, and I thought I better look into everything," she said.
Ms. Seles certainly did not want for money. At the time of the stabbing, she was worth several million dollars. Today, her lifetime tour winnings total about $13 million, and there have been many product endorsements, including a five-year, $25 million promotional contract with Nike that just ended and an $18 million deal from Yonex, which makes sports equipment. She also earns an estimated $1 million a year from exhibition matches and appearances. All told, Ms. Seles is probably worth about $40 million, several people close to her estimate. 
Of that, roughly $5 million is invested in real estate: her walled, 5,500-square-foot, French chateau-style home, complete with a tennis court, in a gated community here; a beach house in another Florida city and an apartment in Europe. (For security reasons, Ms. Seles declined to provide locations.)
MS. SELES is usually a cautious consumer, too, friends say. Tony Decello, the financial account executive who handles Ms. Seles's investments at McCormack Advisors International of Cleveland, said: "She is fastidious about what she spends. Many athletes look at how much they make and how their investments are doing, but they ignore budgeting and lifestyle. They end up growing into a lifestyle that they can't sustain. It is a very slippery slope.
"Monica is not like that," he added. "She is always asking about inflation, about whether she will be able to maintain her lifestyle. She's aware that her income is coming down."
Ms. Seles is now the fourth-ranked woman tennis player in the world, and will compete next month in the Ericsson Open in Miami.
"Ever since she came back from the attack, she has wanted data on her total tennis income and off-court income, and her expenses and receipts," Mr. Decello said. "She tracks things in a very strict fashion -- what she spends and what she makes."
In fact, he added, "she is just like the people in 'The Millionaire Next Door' who drive old cars and save money," referring to the best-selling book by Thomas J. Stanley and William D. Danko. 
Martina Navratilova, a longtime friend, says the same cautious attitude is evident in Ms. Seles's tennis game. "She is not necessarily a risk taker," Ms. Navratilova said. "She plays her points as aggressively as possible while being as safe as possible."
And Mr. Decello, who has known his client since 1988, added, "In a world where many athletes have three cars or more, and lust after private jets, she is unusual." Ms. Seles drives a Toyota Land Cruiser that she won in a 1998 tournament in Japan. The only car she has ever bought was a Ford Explorer, which she has since sold.
Her investments are equally conservative. Following Mr. Decello's advice, Ms. Seles has placed 44 percent of her approximately $35 million in liquid assets in stocks. An additional 29 percent is in tax-free bonds, 8 percent in real estate investments and the remainder in cash. Her stock portfolio includes large-capitalization, blue-chip stocks like General Electric, Coca-Cola, American International Group, Home Depot and AOL Time Warner. The average annual return of the equity portion since 1996, counting dividends, was 19.03 percent through 2000, Mr. Decello said. In 2000, when the market was down sharply, it declined 20 percent. 
Ms. Seles has an overall goal for that portfolio: "What I put in the stock market, I don't have to touch in my lifetime," she said. "I want to live off my bonds. I want to be that safe." 
That means that she has about $450,000 a year -- the income generated by her tax-free bonds -- for her personal life. She keeps well within that limit, spending about $360,000 a year on her homes and private expenses. 
Mr. Decello says Ms. Seles calls him more than most of his other clients do. "We send her a monthly check, and she will ask questions about things like the interest rate on her bank account or her retirement plan and how it works for her," he said.
Ms. Seles says she asks other questions, like: "Why we are picking stocks right now? And, why we are buying more shares of the same stock when it is so high? Why don't we sell some shares and buy real estate?" 
To educate herself, Ms. Seles said, she has read some books on finance, including "What They Don't Teach You at Harvard Business School" by Mark H. McCormack, "One Up on Wall Street" by Peter Lynch and John Rothchild, and "Only The Paranoid Survive," by Andrew S. Grove, the Intel chairman. "I read that because he is also from Hungarian descent," she explained, "so it made me see how these people came out of a very difficult time."
Ms. Seles, whose father, Karolj, died of cancer in 1998, said she has developed a close relationship with Mr. McCormack, who heads IMG, the sports marketing firm that is a co-owner, with Merrill Lynch, of McCormack Advisors International. 
She can sound almost childish in her deference to him. "I get to pick a certain amount of stocks out of my portfolio," she said. "The rest of them Mr. McCormack picks. I am lucky to have advisers whom I trust." Mr. Decello, working with the firm's investment team, actually picks the stocks, which Mr. McCormack approves. Ms. Seles also talks about her finances with Jerry Glauser, a family friend in Sarasota. 
A year ago, she grew interested in the Dogs of the Dow theory, an investment strategy that picks the 10 stocks of the Dow Jones industrial average that begin the year with the highest yields, typically because their prices have lagged behind those of other Dow stocks. "If the dividend yield is high, that means the share price is down," Mr. Decello said. "The theory is that it will go up."
Under Mr. Decello's direction, Ms. Seles has bought ExxonMobil, Kodak, J. P. Morgan Chase, 3M and others. "It is 3 percent or 4 percent of her portfolio," Mr. Decello said. "We usually recommend that you do a little investing with your own money." 
Currently, that group of 10 stocks is down 1.75 percent. 
Typically, investors who use the theory swap those stocks for the new "dogs" at the start of each year. "We are starting to do that now," Mr. Decello said. 
Sometimes, Mr. Decello has to talk his famous client out of an investment. "They hear stuff in the locker room," he said of athletes. "A lot of our time is spent telling them not to do things." He talked her out of Transmeta, a chip maker that went public last year. It began trading last November at $45 a share, failed to rise and is now trading at $30.94 a share. 
But that was unusual. Usually, Ms. Seles tends to err on the side of caution, in large part because of her upbringing. 
She was born in Novi Sad, in northern Serbia. Her father was a well-known cartoonist for a local newspaper, Magyar Szo, and did freelance work. Her mother, Ester, did office work for a government agency.
ALTHOUGH not wealthy by American standards, her family was part of Yugoslavia's upper middle class; it even had a small summer house in Croatia. 
But she soon learned that living standards were far higher in the West. When her brother Zoltan decided, after seeing Bjorn Borg play on television, that he wanted to learn tennis, her father drove 10 hours to Italy to buy his son a tennis racket -- children's rackets were not available in Yugoslavia. Later, he did the same for his daughter.
The children practiced in a parking lot behind their apartment building, guided by their father, who had found a 20-year-old book on tennis at a local bookstore. To make practice amusing, Mr. Seles, who would remain his daughter's trusted coach for years, painted cartoon characters' faces on the tennis balls. 
When it came to spending, her father "was into nice things," Ms. Seles recalled. It was her mother, who still lives with Ms. Seles, who worried about budgets. "She was the bookkeeper and a big saver," Ms. Seles said. "She taught that money didn't grow on trees, and you have to sensible." 
Ms. Seles played in her first tournament when she was 6, and soon began winning tournaments across Europe. Later, she made the plane reservations for her trips because she spoke the best English in the household. She always found the cheapest fares, having learned quickly that her family's finances did not go far in other countries. 
That awareness deepened after she arrived in the United States. Nick Bollettieri, who runs the Bollettieri Tennis Academy in Bradenton, Fla., invited her to train there in 1986. The school's roster of stars includes Jim Courier, Anna Kournikova and Andre Agassi.
There she found how frugally she would need to live. "It was different when I came to the States," she said softly. "If I wanted a blanket, I couldn't get it because the dollar is so different. Plus, at the academy there were very wealthy kids. It was different for me. 
"I had to think: 'Gosh, we can't have this. We can't afford this right now.' "
But money was not her driving force. What Ms. Seles wanted was to win, and she said she realized that "back home in Yugoslavia, in December and January, you couldn't practice; I would take Florida any day."
Even after she started winning big money in 1989, she never became a big spender, though she has had her share of indulgences. There is the green Chanel suit that she bought for herself after defeating Ms. Graf in the 1992 French Open. "I think it cost about $2,500 then," she said. She tried it on the day before the match, promised herself she would get it if she won, and went right back to Chanel the morning after her victory to fetch her reward. But she has worn it only once. "I felt it looked too grown-up for me," she explained.
A friend, Mary Joe Fernandez, a former professional tennis player, says Ms. Seles likes to shop, especially for jewelry ("We like to go to Tiffany's"), handbags (Kate Spade), and shoes (her current preference being is J. P. Tods). Ms. Seles said she used to be a "Manolos" addict, referring to Manolo Blahniks, the super high heels favored by the fashion-conscious. In fact, she accumulated more than 30 pairs. But no more. "I don't have anyplace to go in them," she said, "and they destroy my feet." 
When it comes to big-ticket expenses like travel and homes, Ms. Seles watches costs assiduously. Even today, she keeps a "tickler" file to remind her of her totals of frequent-flier miles, which she uses to drive down air travel costs.
When she travels for matches, she always takes along a small entourage, including her mother.
"I have to worry about expenses: my coach, my trainer, my physical therapist, airlines and hotels," Ms. Seles said. "That adds up to a huge number. I will fly coach and I will fly first. You don't want to get too comfortable. No matter what people say, you do get spoiled. If I am going on a trip and I am not doing anything for five days, then I always fly coach. My people fly business or coach -- never first." (Her mother sits next to her.)
Perhaps it is her mother's influence, but the staff at the Sarasota home does not include a housekeeper or a gardener. Ms. Seles and her mother clean the house themselves, and they employ a groundskeeping company to care for the property.
HER desire to hold on to capital is deeply ingrained. "For me, the biggest thing with money has always been independence -- just the biggest," Ms. Seles said. "It has always been freedom. I don't care about anything else. If I find the person that I love, it is because I love them, not because I will be dependent on them."
She does not necessarily view this obsession with independence as positive.
"My mom asks me about it," she acknowledged. "I am trying to an extreme to be independent. I know it is too much and I am trying to change it and let people in." 
Her only public romance was with Paul Allen, the billionaire co-founder of Microsoft. One friend of his, who requested anonymity, said the pair appeared very happy together at Mr. Allen's birthday party in Venice in 1998, but that romance is long over.
The death of her father, and her role as the sole support for herself and her mother, clearly weigh on her. After all, she competes in a sport in which most players retire in their early 30's. 
"I don't know how long I'll play," she said. "Part of me would like to fall into business," she said, "and part of me would like to do something with kids. Maybe I will do an internship at some company that I really admire." For now, she acknowledges, "I don't know where life will take me."
Her parents always taught her that "money comes and goes," she said, and that "you've got to be the same person regardless of whether or not you have it." 
She also lives by the words on a plaque that Mr. Glauser gave her, a financial take on the Ten Commandments. "The first commandment is, 'Never underestimate the value of money,' " she said. "and the second is, 'Never overestimate the value of money.' "

HEADLINE: Fighting AIDS in Africa 

 BODY:
The recent announcement by the Indian drug company Cipla that it would sell AIDS therapy for $600 a year or less to African countries is a step toward commuting the death sentences now hanging over the 25 million Africans infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. A year and a half ago, few people even dreamed that the citizens of poor nations would be able to get the antiretroviral drugs that have turned AIDS into a manageable disease in rich countries. Now, each week brings new developments on fighting AIDS in poor nations, and a stronger international consensus that poor countries can provide treatment to those infected and improve their prevention campaigns to slow the spread of the virus. None of this will be possible, however, without leadership from the Bush administration, which must take a more aggressive role in combatting AIDS abroad than its predecessor.
 One reason for the worldwide movement on AIDS is that the dimensions of the apocalypse are beginning to sink in. The AIDS virus is a plague that now afflicts one in five adults in South Africa. Throughout Africa, it is eroding economic growth and killing the most productive people. It could bring about the social collapse of many countries, creating instability and humanitarian crises. 
 Bush administration officials recognize that AIDS has become a foreign policy issue for the United States. Secretary of State Colin Powell has called AIDS an economic and national security problem and said Congress has been generous. But Congress's allocation amounts to only $315 million this year for all AIDS programs worldwide -- vastly inadequate to prevent the catastrophic scenarios looming in Africa. An effective prevention program throughout Africa -- the very minimum necessary -- would cost $1.5 billion, according to the United Nations program on AIDS. Relieving the pain of AIDS sufferers and treating their infections would cost a similar amount, and providing drugs to attack the AIDS virus would cost even more.
The Cipla offer has greatly increased the possibility that poor nations will be able to treat AIDS, especially if it provokes brand-name drug makers to lower their prices, as it seems to be doing. A year of therapy costs $10,000 or more in the United States, but several multinational drug companies have negotiated far lower prices with some African countries, as low as $1,000 a year, and now Cipla will sell generic drug cocktails for less. But even at $600 a year, these drugs are out of reach for most Africans. Wealthy nations are going to have to pay for the drugs -- which could initially cost $3 billion a year for Africa, and more as a greater number of patients are reached. The West must help African nations improve their health care delivery systems so they can properly administer these drugs -- an effort that would reap many other health benefits as well.
America need not take on this financial burden alone, but it must assume part of the responsibility. That will require the Bush administration to multiply its allocation for AIDS in the third world substantially. Just as important, the administration must abandon its predecessors' policies that blocked access to cheap drugs in poor countries in the name of protecting the patent rights of American drug companies. 
The pharmaceutical industry, whose donations favor Republicans, is likely to be even more influential with this president than it was with Bill Clinton. But the first sign from the Bush administration is encouraging. Trade officials indicated last week that Washington will not use trade to pressure poor nations that seek to make or buy generic AIDS drugs, as long as their efforts fall within world trade rules. The Clinton administration had used such tactics but abandoned them after criticism from AIDS activists. Many feared they would now be revived. The Bush administration should also work with Unaids and the World Health Organization to improve access to needed medicines. The means now exist to treat the sick, if America will help.

HEADLINE: The World; 
Firm Foundations for Disaster

BYLINE:  By JUAN FORERO 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia 

 BODY:
THE number of killings in this country's grinding civil conflict tops 5,000 a year. Paramilitary gunmen, once shadowy killers who operated in a few regions, have spread across the country. And rebels, despite agreeing to resume peace talks, continue to threaten the state.
 To many in America, Colombia's problems can be summed up in one word: cocaine. But the strife tearing at Colombia has roots that predate the drug trade, anchored in festering, decades-old disputes over land, worsened by the lawlessness of Colombia's vast countryside. 
 They reach back into the 19th century, when land-owning strongmen ruled like feudal lords. Indians were pushed off tribal lands; whole communities were driven into the Andes. 
In the 20th century, the problems solidified and spread, with peasants driven from their plots as demand rose for the commercial production of coffee and other crops. Land struggles evolved into the country's greatest blood-letting, La Violencia, a 10-year orgy of violence in the 1950's that pitted members from the traditional Liberal and Conservative parties against each other. It started here in Bogota, with the 1948 murder of a populist Liberal presidential candidate, and quickly moved out to the countryside. 
Today's rebel movements began then, as did early versions of today's right-wing paramilitaries, who worked at the pleasure of the land owners. In the end, some 200,000 people died -- all decades before Colombia became the center of cocaine trafficking. 
And though the power-sharing agreement that officially ended La Violencia greatly diminished the conflict, it created a deeply flawed political system that excluded millions. These problems afflict every corner of Colombia by virtue of the simple fact that the central government has never really governed much of this country, a land of towering mountains, jungles and wide-open plains twice the size of France. In hundreds of towns, government officials have been inefficient or corrupt. In others, government is completely absent.
The result has been economic stagnation, poverty and violence in much of the countryside, leaving millions stuck in a feudal world in which coca farming, or membership in one of many armed bands, makes perfect sense. In cities, too, violence has increased since the 1980's, when cocaine kings began rising to prominence and drug gangs battled for the spoils. 
"We live under a state that has no presence," said Ivan Marin, a historian at Javeriana University in Bogota. 
"You can attack the problems of narco-trafficking and make a case for it, but the problem of narco-trafficking isn't just the illicit activity or the coca crop," he added. "It's also finding a suitable economic activity for peasant farmers that gives them enough earnings to have social benefits, like education, health care, communication, justice."
Human rights activists point out that Colombia is awash in conflict-related violence, massacres and selective assassinations. The deaths are often said to have their roots in the drug war; the reality is that most are political. 
And the numbers keep rising, mostly in the countryside. The Colombian Commission of Jurists, a respected human rights group, says the number of conflict-related deaths now exceeds 5,000 annually, possibly nearing 6,000. On average, only 4 of the 14 daily conflict-related deaths occur in combat. Most, they note, are perpetrated by right-wing paramilitary groups, run by one Carlos Castano, groups that have long drawn support from big land-owners. And there is another terrible statistic: criminal homicides, most of them drug-related, number at least four times the conflict slayings.
Colombia experts say American policy would be better if it was informed by the complex history and culture of Colombia, everything from the roots of rural violence to its rich literature and political intrigue, topics often as hard to decipher as the fog-shrouded Andes. 
"People just look at the slices of Colombia's complex reality that they want to look at," said Mr. Shifter, who works at the Inter-American Dialogue, a Washington research group. "The real challenge, it seems to me, is to get off this inability to see beyond the drugs. It requires a real understanding of magical realism, of the complexities and subtleties. That is not exactly the strength of United States policy toward Colombia." 
AND even if the Bush administration moves toward addressing Colombia's problems more comprehensively, many here find deeply offensive the idea that Colombia -- a country that, despite its problems, has modern, functioning cities, a large middle class and a rich cultural life -- is in need of nation building. 
And yet some try to sidestep that term while hoping for the kind of aid that falls under it: help rebuilding its battered judicial system, economy and government. 
"What preoccupies the United States is drugs, but they should focus on being a good neighbor, in other words showing concern for the other side," said Luis Felipe Gomez, director of the Program for Peace, an organization that works on peace issues in conflict zones. "By de-narcotizing the relationship, we would recognize each other as equals, with dignity for each state."

HEADLINE: INVESTING: FUNDS WATCH; 
With a Focus on Israel, It's Business as Usual

BYLINE:  By Robert D. Hershey Jr. 

 BODY:
The combination of acute political tension in the Mideast and a meltdown of the Nasdaq composite index has not dissuaded the sponsors of a new mutual fund that invests in small Israeli technology companies that trade on Nasdaq.
 "You'd imagine we're at a pretty tenuous point," said Cliff Goldstein, president of Amidex Mutual Funds in New York. 
But prospects are actually bright, he contended, citing virtually nonexistent Israeli inflation, healthy inflows of venture capital and the type of stocks -- "no dot-coms, telecom companies with earnings" -- in which the new fund, Amidex Israel Technology, invests. 
 The fund, which has no load, or sales charge, opened to the public on Feb. 15. It is linked to an index of 35 Israeli companies with market capitalizations of less than $1 billion.
Unlike the firm's first Israeli fund, the two-year-old, $30 million Amidex35, which buys large-cap Israeli issues trading in both Tel Aviv and the United States, the new one will have no exposure to the shekel. Expenses run 1.45 percent a year.
But Amidex, founded in 1998, also has its eye on market niches other than Israel. The next entries are to be a fund that will concentrate on companies engaged in the detection and treatment of cancer and a fund to invest in brokerage houses and mutual fund managers, Mr. Goldstein said. Robert D. Hershey Jr.

HEADLINE: DATABANK: FEBRUARY 19-23; 
Singing Those Technology Blues, Again

BYLINE:  By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN 

 BODY:
The stock market was pounded last week, with two major indexes ending at or near their lowest levels since the market highs last March. But investors managed to limit the damage with a rally late Friday as rumors circulated that the Federal Reserve might cut interest rates even before its next policy meeting in late March. 
 In what has become a regular feature of the market slide, there was a steady beat of bad news in technology. Motorola said it would likely record its first loss in 15 years in the first quarter. Sun Microsystems, Brocade Communications and EMC also issued profit warnings. 
 By Friday afternoon, though, speculation grew that the slowing economy would make the Fed cut rates as early as next week.
 The Nasdaq ended the week at 2,262.51, down 162.87, or 6.7 percent. The Standard & Poor's 500 finished at 1,245.86, off 55.67, or 4.2 percent. The Dow Jones industrial average ended at 10,441.90, down 357.92, or 3.3 percent. 
 The sell-off in the equity markets and the rate-cut rumors bolstered the bond markets on Friday, but the yield on the 10-year bond still finished at 5.09 percent, unchanged for the week. DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

HEADLINE: Maryland Farmers Turn From Tobacco to Flowers 

BYLINE:  By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: PRINCE FREDERICK, Md. 

 BODY:
More than three centuries after Maryland took root as a lush English tobacco colony, the last tobacco farmers are renouncing "the money crop," as it long reigned, to take a bittersweet state buyout that guarantees them an income for 10 years. 
 In return for swearing off tobacco, the farmers will be subsidized as they look for ways to survive by growing crops like flowers and organic vegetables for the fancy restaurants just over the suburbanized horizon. They are raising hay and horses, too, for the new country homeowners arriving in this region bordering Chesapeake Bay, about 50 miles southeast of Washington, at a record pace. 
 "No farmer wants to see houses growing on his fields," said Buddy Hance, standing in his barn recently with the last tobacco crop to be raised by four generations of tobacco-growing Hances. It will go to market next month. 
Mr. Hance will become an experimental farmer looking to strawberries and hothouse flowers, having taken the buyout to join the 70 percent of the state's remaining 950 tobacco farmers who have submitted applications in this opening year of the offer.
"By next year, I expect we'll have just about all of them," said Mr. Hance, a leader of the Tri-County Council for Southern Maryland, a regional planning group covering Maryland's three tobacco-growing counties, Calvert, Charles and St. Mary's. 
Perplexed by a shifting world tobacco market and helped by the cigarette industry's mammoth damage settlements with the states, tobacco farmers in the United States have begun trying an assortment of strategies for adapting to new markets, with official help. Virginia and North Carolina, for example, have set up foundations with money from the settlements to help farm communities look for industry and to offer college scholarships to the children of farmers so they can learn new occupations.
"But no other state has anything similar to Maryland's program," said Lee Dixon, who tracks health policy changes for the National Conference of State Legislatures. Maryland's tobacco crop has been dwindling for the last 20 years, Mr. Dixon noted, leaving a smaller group of tobacco farmers more open to sweeping innovation than in the larger tobacco states.
Gov. Parris N. Glendening decided on the buyout approach last year, viewing tobacco as a product without a future in Maryland. With the agreement of legislative leaders, he is tapping 5 percent of the tobacco industry settlement in an effort to keep farmers on the land as part of what he calls a "smart growth" strategy of protecting rustic traditions in development areas. The rest of the state's $4.5 billion settlement is paying for medical research and education programs to ween smokers from cigarettes. 
"I worked barefoot behind a horse in the tobacco fields when I was 12 years old," said Hagner R. Mister, a tobacco farmer who quit two years ago when Mr. Glendening made him state agriculture secretary. Since then, Mr. Mister has helped farmers shape the only direct buyout program for tobacco farmers. It offers guaranteed income for a decade based on each farmer's crop volume for the 1998 season, at a three-year average of recent market prices, which is $1 a pound. 
Those with the largest farms, approaching 100 acres, will receive $60,000 or more a year in the buyout, says Christine L. Bergmark, development director for the Tri-County Council. But the average buyout will be about $10,000 yearly, Ms. Bergmark says, since many farmers were already part-time tobacco growers forced to work multiple jobs after a 1982 drought. 
Since then, with land and labor costs rising, the state's tobacco crop of 35 million pounds has slipped to about 11 million pounds. Nationally, tobacco farms have declined to 89,700 from 188,650 since 1987.
"Farming is a lifestyle but it's also a business," said Mr. Hance, explaining why farmers are accepting the state offer. Tobacco farmers who do not accept the offer immediately will have later opportunities to do so, but for smaller amounts. 
"There are a lot of advantages in knowing you have an income stream for 10 years while you experiment on new things," Mr. Hance said. 
"But the bad part is we've given up the right to ever grow tobacco again," Mr. Hance said, "and we have so many people signing up that we're going to lose our state market. If we don't find anything to replace it, what do we do?"
Historically, the buyout is a major turn from Maryland's heritage as the source of the once-prized air-cured tobacco that the cigarette industry needed for its steady, slow-burning properties, until modern chemical additives. Along with religious tolerance, tobacco was rated the signature virtue of colonial Maryland.
"Tobacco is our meat, drink, clothing and monies, being the standard of trade not only with the merchants but with ourselves," Hugh Jones, rector of Christ Church in Calvert County, declared in 1698.
The attraction of the buyout is strong, although tobacco continues to be the single most profitable crop a farmer can raise in this region, Mr. Hance said. "The labor issue is the No. 1 reason why farmers are signing up for the buyout," he said, referring to the increasing problems of maintaining a reliable flow of seasonal fieldworkers for the crop, which must be cut, stored and stripped by hand. 
The "absolute best" workers, Mexican immigrants who are paid $10 an hour during the summer-to-fall tobacco season, found better opportunities in the booming economy, Mr. Hance said. Now, tobacco is being produced abroad by workers who are paid far less. 
"In the old days, we'd wait for those autumn nights with the big harvest moon when we finished cutting tobacco and you'd walk around the barn and smell that stuff," Mr. Mister recalled. "You'd pick up two tobacco bundles and shake them and the prime stuff rattled like money. Tobacco was everywhere. Now you have to search for it around here." 
One reason the buyout is working is that the average age of tobacco farmers is 62 and the 10-year payout is seen by some as a retirement windfall. But not by Earl Griffith, who is in his 60's but sticking with tobacco -- though his 40-year-old son, Jack, a successful grower, is taking the buyout because his future seems more uncertain. "My Dad's already tried growing everything under the sun, but nothing replaces the profit margin of tobacco," Jack Griffith said. "It's a sin they ever messed with tobacco, the crop this country was built on. Since I was big enough to walk I knew what I wanted: work the tobacco fields with my dad and granddad."

HEADLINE: Palestinians, Hit by Curbs, Foiled in Use Of U.S. Aid 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM A. ORME Jr. 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Feb. 24 

 BODY:
Israel's increasingly strict controls on the movement of Palestinian goods and people are paralyzing United States government economic development projects in the Palestinian territories, American officials here said as Secretary of State Colin L. Powell arrived in the region today. 
 Building projects have been paralyzed by Israeli import restrictions, and local participants in economic training programs cannot travel freely to courses within the territories or abroad, diplomats said. The United States has been investing more than $100 million yearly in development projects in Palestinian areas. 
 American aid officials here were especially irked this week when Israel refused to let a high-level delegation of Palestinian economic officials and private business leaders travel to a long planned series of seminars at an American-run economic institute in Rome and the World Trade Organization in Geneva. Financed and organized by the United States Agency for International Development, the seminars were intended to foster Palestinian compliance with international norms regarding intellectual property rights and foreign trade policies. 
"We urge the Israelis to cease their policies of economic pressure against the Palestinians, including limitations on the movement of people involved in important economic or business activity," Larry Shartz, the spokesman for the American Embassy in Tel Aviv, said today.
The delegation needed special Israeli exit permits for 17 of its 21 Palestinian members -- the others held American passports or were residents of Israeli-ruled East Jerusalem -- in order to travel to Ben Gurion International Airport, outside Tel Aviv. Though told initially by Israeli military authorities that the once routine permits would be granted, the delegation was informed shortly before the scheduled departure that all 17 applications had been denied. 
"It would defy logic to identify any legitimate security concerns for the State of Israel to justify its illegal actions in this matter," said Maher Masri, the Palestinian minister of economy and trade, who organized the delegation in collaboration with American aid consultants. 
The seminars were needed to help "the Palestinian Authority's efforts to move the Palestinian economy into the era of globalization," Mr. Masri said. "This will entail a great deal of preparatory work that must be addressed through partnership efforts by the public and private sectors, through the empowerment of a technical advisory team of experts" on World Trade Organization norms and regulations.
Officials in the Israeli prime minister's office said they could not comment on the specific reasons for the decision to deny travel permits to the group, referring questions to the office of the Israeli Army, which handles civilian affairs in the Palestinian territories. 
Spokesmen for the Israeli military's Civil Administration Office said Israeli government policy now is to reject virtually all travel applications from Palestinians, even when there is no indication that applicants pose a security risk, unless high-level Israeli officials specifically endorse the request. 

CORRECTION-DATE: February 28, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sunday about Israel's strict controls on Palestinians on United States economic development projects misstated the surname of the spokesman for the American Embassay in Tel Aviv, who urged Israel to end its economic pressure. He is Larry Schwartz, not Shartz.

HEADLINE: White Flight, This Time Toward Harlem; 
Newcomers and Good Times Bring Hope, and Fears of Displacement

BYLINE:  By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
Few people doubted in recent decades that Harlem needed change. Now change has come -- and it is being met not simply with hope but with unease. Residents voice a complex tangle of aspirations and anxieties about class and culture and race that at least in some ways echoes fears expressed by whites during an earlier chapter of racial change in the neighborhood.
 In the restored buildings and new businesses of a reviving Harlem, many see encouraging signs of economic life; in the immigrants and other new arrivals, a welcome energy and flux. But there is also apprehension, talk of displacement, and what some perceive as a threat from outsiders moving in, a small but growing number of whom happen to be white. 
 Gentrification in Harlem is generating a byproduct: some measure of racial integration, although in a reverse form in a country in which integration has for the most part meant blacks moving into white areas. The process has renewed discussion of the virtues and limitations of gentrification and integration, and has exposed ambivalence about each. 
Long seen by most Americans at least in the abstract as a social good, racial integration is getting a mixed reception in Harlem. Arriving hand in hand with gentrification, it has kindled what one scholar called a kind of cultural nervousness that is somewhat reminiscent of the mix of class anxiety, cultural discomfort and racial fear seen in white ethnic communities that resisted integration in the past.
"African-Americans -- especially economically impoverished and socially vulnerable African-Americans -- can be motivated by the same mix of motives when they look at what's happening with intrusions into their neighborhoods," said Jonathan Rieder, a sociologist at Barnard College who specializes in race and identity and in the 1980's wrote a book about black-white conflict in Canarsie, Brooklyn. "And African-Americans, with their long memory of exclusion from white neighborhoods, have much invested in a feeling of comfort with their own kind."
Monique Taylor, an associate professor of sociology at Occidental College in Los Angeles who is working on a book on recent gentrification by blacks in Harlem, said: "The mistake that people make sometimes in these gentrification battles is to simplify who are the insiders and the outsiders and who are the good guys and the bad guys. In the case of Harlem, I think everybody wanted to see whites as being outsiders and as bad guys. Once you get there and realize there are white and black outsiders and white and black insiders, it's a more complicated thing."
Harlem is in some ways unique because of its history and symbolic importance in black culture, a fact that seems to heighten the response to change there. But similar changes have been playing out in varying degrees in neighborhoods elsewhere, from Fort Greene in Brooklyn to parts of the South Side of Chicago and sections of Detroit. George Galster, a professor of urban affairs at Wayne State University in Detroit, said that in that city, "You hear black community leaders literally saying the following thing: 'Now that we have made the city worth something, they want it back.' "
During the 1960's, 70's and 80's, he said, "Blacks saw whites fleeing a sinking ship. But, by golly, it near completely sunk, and in the 1990's it has actually started to rise in the water. And blacks take pride in that. And now they say, 'Gee, wouldn't you know it? Now the rats want back on board the ship.' "
Attitudes in Harlem vary from household to household, individual to individual. It is impossible to generalize about the opinions of homeowners and renters, old timers and newcomers, business owners and customers. All that can be said is that views about the implications of Harlem's revival are widely mixed.
"Some feel if it's not overwhelming, it is good because it does bring some diversity to the community," said Lionel McIntyre, director of the Urban Technical Assistance Project, part of the urban planning program at Columbia University. "Some feel that black folks just can't have anything: 'Every time you look around, they want it' -- that kind of sentiment. Then there is cautiousness about what is the real intent. Does it stop at reaching a racial mix or go to one group taking over the other?"
Mary Pattillo, an assistant professor of sociology and African-American studies at Northwestern University in Evanston, Ill., and a former Harlem resident, said: "If Harlem becomes integrated, is it still Harlem in the way everybody says Harlem and has a vision of it? My personal opinion is, I would like Harlem to stay a black neighborhood and a strong black cultural space. But my political and policy opinion is that I know that segregation allows neighborhoods to be strangled."
What is happening in Harlem differs in several ways from integration of the more familiar black-to-white form. For example, when black people moved into white neighborhoods, there were in most cases little income or class differences between the two groups. But when middle- or upper-middle-class people move into lower-income, minority communities, what takes place is as much class -- as racial -- integration.
Whereas whites may have feared that the arrival of black neighbors would provoke white flight and depress property values, residents of gentrifying neighborhoods fear rising property values will force them out. If they do not believe they are under the risk of actual displacement, they may worry about a loss of political control and the erosion of customs, rituals and institutions -- what Monique Taylor calls "a way of living in black communities." 
Setha Low, an urban anthropologist at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, said, "I think the anxiety you're interpreting as fear of integration has more to do with the community, the people who have been there and made their neighborhoods their own for long periods of time, and who have close social relationships, losing the power and control they have over their own community." 
Representative Charles B. Rangel of Harlem said bluntly: "It's not a white and black thing. It's a dollar thing."
Gentrification raises questions even when race is not involved. It has reclaimed deteriorating neighborhoods and brought local economies back to life. But its benefits may be spread unevenly. As Mr. McIntyre wondered, can it be called community improvement if, amid gentrification, the schools and hospitals on which longtime lower-income residents depend continue to decline?
Communities want two contradictory things, said John M. Yinger, a professor of economics and public administration at the Maxwell School of Citizenship and Public Affairs at Syracuse University. They seek higher-income people to improve their neighborhoods, but want their neighborhoods affordable, to retain existing residents.
"The same conflict plays out probably with even more power when there's race or ethnicity involved," Professor Yinger said. "So if you have an established community of lower-middle-income blacks, for example, and higher income whites are moving in, then all of the feelings that come even without race get magnified."
Integration, too, is seen with some ambivalence. Americans say they believe in principle in equal housing opportunity, surveys show, but in practice, they seem less sure. Many studies have shown that white Americans stop moving into communities once a certain proportion -- roughly 10 to 30 percent -- of residents are black. 
"The current reaction of the African-American community in Harlem is like the reaction of many African-Americans who since the 80's have begun to question the goal of integration for integration's sake alone," said John Goering, a professor of public affairs at Baruch College and the City University of New York Graduate Center who has written about housing segregation and desegregation. "There is a fair amount of uncertainty as to what the African-American community, middle-income or lower-income, actually gets out of it and what the benefits of it are."
For those reasons and others, it has not been easy to maintain stable neighborhoods that are racially and economically mixed. Some believe the examples, though few, are increasing. Others find encouraging evidence in Los Angeles that the dynamics change when there are more than two racial groups in an area and no group dominates.
As for Harlem, Monique Taylor said: "Harlem is a great place to show America that integration can work. But it's not just about 'We move here and you move there.' You have to show people who you are, and be neighborly."

HEADLINE: More Sunshine for Japan's Overworked Students 

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 24 

 BODY:
Daichi Zaitsu, a seventh grader, has so much studying to do that he has precious little time to devote to his favorite hobbies: researching passenger jets on the Internet and playing tennis. Still, the 13-year-old thinks that plans to reduce school hours are a horrible idea. 
 "In Japan, the scholastic ability of people is not so high right now, and it seems to be decreasing, so I worry about the future of our country," said the teenager, who puts on a sober navy blue uniform and lugs a heavy book bag back and forth to his central Tokyo junior high school each day, including many Saturdays. 
 "Having more free time is not a particular concern of mine," he said. "I would rather school stay open on the weekend." 
Like it or not, the teenager's class schedule is about to change drastically as Japan undertakes its most dramatic educational reform effort in a generation. Starting next year, instead of piling on yet more work for its famously hard-studying students, Japan will let its young take a rest. 
The changes are in striking contrast to the most recent trends in New York, California and elsewhere in the United States, where schools are considering lengthening the school day or year in order to help children learn -- and to try to keep them out of trouble.
In recent decades, Japanese schools have developed a system that in some respects is what some American schools are talking about now: long hours, emphasis on basics rather than electives, school uniforms and a premium on order rather than on creativity. Yet just as some American schools are taking tentative steps toward such a system, Japan is talking about dismantling it. 
The reason is a growing concern that an orderly and unimaginative school system excels at producing pliant, disciplined workers, which the nation needed for its rebuilding effort after World War II, but is failing to produce the problem solvers and innovators needed for the future.
Japan has been floundering economically for more than a decade, and the change is meant in part to help ensure the country's ability to compete. Somewhat paradoxically, the drive to give millions of students more electives and unstructured time out of school for their personal use comes as public anxiety over dropouts, adolescent crime and what is perceived here as an epidemic of underachievement among the young is higher than ever. 
Some parents oppose the shortened hours for this reason, while many others fear that a lightening of the curriculum by an estimated 30 percent will make it harder, rather than easier, for Japan to compete with its rivals in Asia and the West. 
"The direction that New York City is taking is exactly the right direction," said Ryoko Zaitsu, Daichi's mother. "I wonder why this change is being made in Japan."
She speculated that the all powerful Ministry of Education was trying to remedy the problems of rough schools -- from elementary through high school -- by "trying to reduce everyone to the same level." 
Officials at the Education Ministry acknowledge that the problems of disaffected and poorly performing students enter into the thinking behind the changes. But they say the main issue is that year after year of overworking students has left people exhausted, and destroyed creativity and individual initiative, qualities officials say the country sorely needs. 
"Our current system, just telling kids to study, study, study, has been a failure," said Ken Terawaki, a senior Education Ministry official who nonetheless dismissed the idea that Japan and school systems in places like New York City were going in opposite directions on the scholastic escalator. Instead, he insisted, Japanese reformers were responding to features of their own country's culture and history that had no parallels in America.
"Endless studying worked in the past," he said, "when there were many kids in the school system, Japan was rebuilding and the competition was very fierce. But that is no longer the case, and the kids are far fewer, things are not as competitive anymore, and just telling them to study more will no longer work. 
"Now we are going to try the sunshine approach, giving them more chances to play sports, or read books. We would like to give them some free time and the psychological freedom to do things that they are interested in. In other words, we want to give them some time to think, rather than force everybody to stay in school to study the same thing."
Noboyuki Tose, a professor of mathematics at Keio University in Tokyo, is a prominent critic of Japan's education system, but opposes the planned changes because he fears that they will further drag down performance. 
About two years ago he began testing students at some elite colleges for basic mathematics aptitude and was shocked -- as was the nation when the results were widely publicized -- to find that many students were incapable even of elementary level mathematics. 
Mr. Tose said he traced the inability to Japan's traditional style of learning -- cramming -- and to a subtle shift that began more than 20 years ago that allowed high school students some electives and lighter classroom workloads.
Standardized mathematics tests suggest, he said, that Japanese students are among the best in the world in junior high school, when such classes are obligatory. But by high school, when the students already have more options, their performance in mathematics has already become mediocre.
"What is happening in Japan happened a long time ago in the U.S.," Mr. Tose said. Referring to an American white paper of the early 1980's that warned of a "nation at risk," because of falling educational achievement, he added: "There are a lot of similarities between the two countries, only a time delay of 20 years. 
"Twenty years ago the education in America was like eating in a cafeteria: high school students just chose what they wanted, avoiding mathematics and science and other difficult subjects. Japanese schools at this moment have exactly the same system. We don't need to increase students' free time. We need to reduce it."
At the secondary school level, however, many educators seem more enthusiastic about the changes, even if they harbor doubts about whether the announced restructuring alone would transform Japanese education.
"This reform is almost like an expression of remorse for the way Japanese people had to live after the war," said Eiko Iwatani, the principal of Daichi Zaitsu's Bunkyo Ward Junior High School No. 6, an almost antique seeming but colorfully decorated middle school of about 270 students in the shadow of Japan's most prestigious college, Tokyo University. 
"After the war," Ms. Iwatani said, "education was so important to our reconstruction that we resorted to cramming, education became automatic, and people didn't need to think for themselves. Nowadays, people are feeling that we are lacking in the faculty of creative thinking and problem solving."
The theory seems to have taken little account of parents' penchant for sending children to private after-school classes known as juku. However much bureaucrats plan to increase the free time of students and give them more freedom over their time, anxious parents continue to send their children to the juku, and many students, mindful of keeping up, are themselves eager to go.
Ms. Zaitsu sends Daichi to a juku three times a week, and a private tutor also goes to their home sometimes. All this costs the family about $400 a month, but they see it as a requirement.
"It shouldn't be necessary, but other parents will keep sending their children, so you feel that you have to, too," Ms. Zaitsu said. "Frankly speaking, I would like to start a revolt. But not everyone feels that way, so we are left with a feeling of helplessness. You want to do something but you can't move. In the end, you feel that you just have to take care of yourself."
