HEADLINE: As Hopes Wither, Africans Turn on Leaders 

BYLINE:  By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

DATELINE: VICTORIA FALLS, Zimbabwe, Feb. 24 

 BODY:
The rain burst from the heavens and drenched the faces of the jubilant supporters who serenaded the old man at his birthday bash here today. All across town, young women celebrated the leadership of their longtime president, singing, "South Africa will follow you, Mugabe, Namibia will follow you." 
 But after two decades in power, President Robert Mugabe turned 77 this week with his popularity dwindling and his country in political and economic turmoil. The high hopes vested in him when white rule ended in 1980 have soured; at home and abroad, some who lauded him as a liberator say he is turning to autocracy to cling to power and to realize long-cherished goals, such as giving land to blacks. 
 And as they watch Zimbabwe and its leader, the men and the movements who helped end colonialism in this region are shuddering, worrying that they, too, may fall from their people's graces. 
It has been seven years since the last all-white government -- the apartheid regime in South Africa -- was finally voted out of existence. As euphoria at the triumph fades, many countries in this relatively stable corner of Africa are feeling similar strains. Voter apathy is rising; there is a struggle to deliver promised jobs and land to the poor; and opposition parties with large white memberships are wooing black converts.
In recent days, Mr. Mugabe has acknowledged his party's failure to inspire young blacks, who tired of his talk of revolution and flocked last year to an opposition party that promised to ease unemployment, even though it was partly financed by whites who once supported minority rule.
This morning, Mr. Mugabe announced that southern African leaders would soon meet to plot strategy and to rekindle the passion for their parties and ideals. "We feel threatened at the moment, and not just here," he said earlier this week. "In South Africa and Mozambique."
No one is seriously predicting that South Africa or the other law-abiding countries here will go the way of Zimbabwe, where Mr. Mugabe and his followers have been assailed by the United Nations, the State Department and human rights groups for arresting critics, harassing journalists and threatening judges.
And some in the region and abroad view the budding pluralism across southern Africa as a sign of progress in a place where one-party politics is still largely the order of the day.
But there is no doubt that the parties in power, which supported each other when all were battling to end colonial or white minority rule, are seeking new solutions now that putting black faces in City Hall no longer satisfies poor blacks seeking advancement.
"People cannot eat slogans, rhetoric or history; liberty must bring tangible benefits to the oppressed," warned Zwelinzima Vavi, head of the Congress of South African Trade Unions, at a seminar in Johannesburg last week, assessing the lessons of Zimbabwe for its neighbors. "This is also relevant in South Africa."
Mr. Vavi, whose group is closely allied with South Africa's governing African National Congress and with the Communist Party, described Mr. Mugabe's government as a "promising transformation project turned horrible." In the sharpest condemnation of recent developments in Zimbabwe by a South African leader, Mr. Vavi placed the blame for its troubles on the repression of critics and "near-dictatorial governance."
But even South Africa's leaders, who won 60 percent of the popular vote in recent elections, are nervous. A white-led opposition party won slivers of the black vote in that poll.
Officials in South Africa have vowed to root out corruption and to narrow the gap between officialdom and the masses. In Namibia, party members are talking about rallying alienated young people. In Mozambique, officials are warning about the threats posed by opposition parties with links to their old enemies. 
In October, top officials of what were once the parties of liberation gathered to discuss these issues. Today, Mr. Mugabe urged young activists from across southern Africa to stick with their governing parties to guarantee more black economic empowerment.
"We're asking ourselves, 'What lessons can we learn from each other?' " Jeremy Cronin, the deputy general secretary of the South African Communist Party, said in an interview. "It's very important for all of us to start to do that." 
Mr. Cronin noted the low turnout among blacks, especially the young, in last year's local elections in South Africa. "We can't simply expect people to vote because the A.N.C. fought a heroic struggle as if we were some kind of museum piece. Young people say, 'What is that freedom? I'm unemployed and I can't get a job.' And that's a fair question."
These are still burning issues in southern Africa, where the aging guerrillas who were beaten, imprisoned or exiled for demanding the right to vote are still running most governments. Unlike other parts of Africa, where colonial rule ended in in the 1960's, most countries here did not start casting off white rule until 1975, when Mozambique and Angola won independence from Portugal. 
Zimbabwe, then known as Rhodesia, followed in 1980 when the first democratic elections propelled Mr. Mugabe to power. Namibia was next in 1990, then South Africa in 1994.
The governments of South Africa, Namibia and Mozambique are still popular with voters and respected abroad. But Zimbabwe, heralded in the 1980's for building schools and clinics, has become increasingly associated with a contracting economy, corruption and repression.
This week, Mr. Mugabe's face was plastered on billboards here along with the date of his birthday, Feb. 21, just like old times. A special birthday edition of the state newspaper carried more than 45 photographs of him. But, although he reiterated today that he would continue with much-criticized policies of giving land to blacks even if "the white men cry," Mr. Mugabe knows he no longer commands universal respect. His decision not to hold a birthday gala in the capital, Harare, which gave him a hero's welcome in 1980, was a bow to change, for Harare is an opposition stronghold now.
Last year, urban voters here voted for a new, interracial opposition party and ended Mr. Mugabe's overwhelming control of Parliament. And with presidential elections due next year, the authorities have stepped up efforts to silence critics.
Last month, the printing press of Zimbabwe's only independent daily newspaper was bombed after government officials had condemned its coverage. This month, officials expelled two foreign journalists who had been critical of the government and arrested several members of the opposition. The authorities also forced the chief justice of the Supreme Court to resign, saying they could not guarantee his safety from government-backed militants.
The militants have threatened to remove the judges forcibly for ordering black squatters to end their invasions of white-owned farms.
In South Africa and Namibia, where whites still own most fertile land, officials have said they will never tolerate such farm invasions. But the region has still been criticized, especially in the West, for not condemning events in Zimbabwe more forcefully. The countries say they prefer private diplomacy, not public rebukes.
But it is also clear that some officials look askance at the new opposition because these emerging parties have links to supporters of the all-white governments of old.
Zimbabwe's Movement for Democratic Change is bankrolled by white businessmen and farmers -- a tiny minority, which owns more than half of the country's fertile land. South Africa's main opposition party, the Democratic Alliance, includes members of the former apartheid government. Both parties emphatically deny that they have any desire to roll back the clock. 
But for years the apartheid government financed black opposition movements in Mozambique and Angola to thwart the struggle for black empowerment, and that memory makes veterans of the struggle suspicious now.
"These are the avenues used by the former occupiers to frustrate the independence struggle," Alpheus Narused, the secretary for information for the ruling South-West Africa People's Organization, said of the opposition parties in a telephone interview from Windhoek, Namibia. "In our view all those things are aimed at destroying the gains of independence."
Not everyone takes such an ominous view. In South Africa, Mr. Cronin, for instance, sees Zimbabwe's opposition front as a progressive, popular party. Mr. Vavi and others argue that officials here simply want to mask an ugly struggle for power.
Nicholas McNally, a Zimbabwe Supreme Court justice who has resisted pressure to resign, and in the past opposed the all-white government of Ian Smith, expressed sorrow at his country's woes. "I understand the frustration of people who see whites still sitting pretty," he said. "But I'm very sad that this model jewel state that we had is being destroyed."

HEADLINE: Pataki Is Man Behind Curtain, Trying to Keep The Bills Down 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 24 

 BODY:
As sharply higher electric bills have hit New Yorkers over the last year, Gov. George E. Pataki has taken a number of steps behind the scenes to address the problem. But he has largely avoided discussing the issue publicly.
 That has prompted criticism from Democrats, environmentalists and consumer advocates that Mr. Pataki -- the person most responsible for shaping New York's new, deregulated power market -- is missing a chance to prepare New Yorkers for the likelihood that higher prices and a tight electric supply lie ahead, and to make the case to the public for new power plants and energy conservation. 
 In his State of the State address last month, Mr. Pataki made one brief reference to New York's power problems, saying that the federal government should give the states back some market controls they gave up in deregulating their electric industries.
Mr. Pataki says that New York's recent problems are partly deregulation's growing pains and will ease as the market becomes more competitive. In the long run, he insists, deregulation will result in lower energy costs to consumers.
The governor says he has used his bully pulpit, pointing to ads in which he promotes the federal Energy Star program. But those ads, which encourage people to buy energy-efficient appliances, say nothing about conservation generally or high prices, or even suggest there is a problem.
New York's power troubles are already generating a haze of accusations that is remarkably thick, and Democrats want to pin the troubles on the Republican governor, who says he is likely to run for a third term next year. Viewing high rates as a potent issue, Comptroller H. Carl McCall, a Democrat who is running for governor, has accused Mr. Pataki of bungling deregulation.
State officials say Mr. Pataki is very much in charge of the state's efforts to head off an electricity crisis, and this month he granted a long interview to The New York Times on the state's power woes.
The state-owned New York Power Authority is hurrying to install 11 small generators in and around New York City before summer. That would raise the city's power supply by 4 percent, take some of the edge off price spikes and lessen the risk, however remote, of blackouts.
The State Public Service Commission, which oversees New York's power industry, voted last month to double its spending, to $150 million a year, on energy conservation measures. It also plans to petition the federal government for more control over wholesale power prices. And several state agencies have accelerated efforts to approve construction of power plants.
"We understand that deregulation is in a transition period right now," Mr. Pataki said. "We don't have the wholesale markets the way they should be, not just in New York, but across the nation, so we have to take steps to make sure the consumer is protected, and we've been doing that."
Each of the state's steps has met with criticism. Some environmental groups have sued to block the Power Authority's generators because they would bypass air quality regulations, and they note that even with the recent increases the state is spending less on conservation than it did when Mr. Pataki took office.
Democrats and consumer advocates say the Pataki administration should have sought wholesale price controls last year, under the Clinton administration, which was inclined to grant them, rather than waiting until the Bush administration, which is not.
Mr. Pataki's handling of the electricity problem is characteristic of his approach to many thorny issues, from transit fare increases to campaign finance reform. He prefers to work behind the scenes until he can emerge with a popular resolution.
Some Democrats, however, accuse Mr. Pataki of avoiding responsibility on the power issue. "The governor wants to pretend this has nothing to do with him," said Assemblyman Paul D. Tonko, a Democrat who is chairman of the Energy Committee. "This whole situation is his creation."
The governor's office counters that Mr. Tonko is a poor judge because he once cited California as an example New York should follow in deregulating electricity.
Ashok Gupta, an economist and energy specialist at the Natural Resources Defense Council, said the governor could have won over the public and his critics on the need for new power plants, in part by committing to more conservation. All the plants proposed in the last several years have encountered organized opposition.
"If the administration had only led an effort that brought together business, environmental and community leaders in support of a balanced energy policy," Mr. Gupta said, "we would be in much better shape today."

HEADLINE: Inside Inspiration; 
Get The Picture?

BYLINE:  By William Norwich; William Norwich is the entertaining editor of The New York Times Magazine.

 BODY:
The last thing I expected when I telephoned Slim Aarons was to end up arrested. 
A mutual friend had given me the photographer's phone number in Bedford, N.Y. 
 "I should have you arrested for invading my privacy!" he growled. 
 "Did you know that New York State has made it against the law to call someone who does not wish to be telephoned? Where've you been?"
Humor is good, I thought. "London. I just got back." 
Aarons sighed. "What do you want with me?" he asked wearily. "I'm against personal publicity. I'm not in the fast lane." 
I tried to recap, without sounding too oily, the recent praise heaped on his work. That his handsome 1974 book, "A Wonderful Time: An Intimate Portrait of the Good Life," has become, in its out-of-print, highly collectible state -- fetching upward of $1,200 a copy -- the reference point du jour for the fashion and design community. That Steven Meisel had surely paid homage to him in his Versace 2000 advertising campaign, with his photographs of leisurely ladies sitting splendidly in their living rooms. That Kinsey Marable, the Manhattan dealer who specializes in hard-to-find style and decorating books, has said that "A Wonderful Time" was one of the two greatest fashion books ever published. (The second, he claims, is Vogue's "Book of Houses, Gardens, People.")
"My book?" he responded. "One of the great fashion books? That's ridiculous."
He added with disdain: "I was a journalist, I was a Life photographer, not a fashion photographer. These are not 'glamour' people in my book. These are not 'style' people. They were just a group of people who had gone through the war. The girls had just come out of boarding school, and the men from the Army. What Tom Brokaw calls 'the greatest generation."' 
I said, "I mean, how the book influences the fashion world nowadays, sir."
"Don't call me sir. That was my father's name."
At least we were talking.
Aarons's "A Wonderful Time" chronicles mostly an American elite, including just a few Hollywood people, as it emerged after World War II, in cities and jet-set watering holes. He documented a time when optimism, not irony, was the driving force of international capitalism.
Aarons shot for Holiday, Town & Country, Vogue, Harper's Bazaar, Travel & Leisure and Life. These magazines, especially Town & Country, provided the mother lode for "A Wonderful Time." Because television had not yet made every image except the most shocking seem familiar and repetitious, magazines back then had tremendous energy and offered the sort of intimacy and surprise that you find in Aarons's.
"I believe in fairy tales," 
Aarons wrote in the introduction to his book. "For two decades I have concentrated on photographing attractive people who were doing attractive things in attractive places."
I would later discover that this phrase, "attractive people doing attractive things in attractive places," is Aarons's mantra. 
Maybe "fabulous" is the faster and fleshier superlative now, but "attractive" used to be the chic commendation. Babe Paley made fond use of it. Diana Vreeland did too. "Attractive people doing attractive things in attractive places" is language from a different world. Say it aloud. It connotes something quite different than if you said, "fabulous people doing fabulous things in fabulous places." 
"At some point, Slim fell in love with beauty and had the eyes to see it, whether it was women or places or clothes," said the photographer's friend and former Town & Country colleague Nancy Holmes. "That's why the book is so good, and why he could gather all those people together."
Holmes and Aarons met in Paris in 1949. Having spent the war years shooting for Yank magazine, Aarons was now on assignment in the City of Light, and Holmes was modeling for the couturier Balmain. They were euphoric times. Balmain had gone to Washington, where Holmes lived, to show his first collection after the war. One of the models keeled over with the flu. It was discovered that Holmes fit the clothes. "So Balmain brought me to Paris," Holmes recalled.
She first encountered Aarons one afternoon in the lobby of the Lancaster hotel, where Holmes was having tea with the photographer Robert Capa and the film director Anatole Litvak. As Holmes remembers it, Aarons, the 6 foot 4 inch former soldier from New Hampshire, rushed in "yakking his head off" about a hot, new American model in Paris. "Finally, Capa stood up and pointed his finger at Slim and said: 'Sit down, Slim. You're looking at her.' "
Holmes laughed. "Slim at heart is still a hick from New Hampshire, but he's chic as hell. His dress shirts have a little monogram on them written in Chinese. You know what the monogram says when you translate it? 'No starch, please.' That's Slim."
In the 1960's, when a friend of mine learned from her mother that Aarons was coming to their rarefied town on the North Shore of Long Island to photograph a story for Town & Country, she rushed out and bought a can of white paint. While her Social Registered mother was asleep, she ran to the end of the driveway and painted the two blackamoors white. 
My friend was embarrassed by her family's wealth and politics. She was ambivalent about their pedigree. Her skin would crawl when her mother described something, or someone, as "attractive." As in: "Have you met his people, dear? Are they attractive?" 
The essential world of "A Wonderful Time" was not just jolly and expensive. It was exclusive, if not outright restricted in some communities, against blacks, Jews and gays without long pedigrees or thick closets. But it's not nostalgia for this world of rank and breeding that's made "A Wonderful Time" so popular among fashion people. 
The fashion people who respond to Aarons's "A Wonderful Time" are unlikely to rush out and paint white the faces of the blackamoors that turn up regularly in their favorite antique shops. Or challenge the nostalgic images of Aarons's women, who, 15 to 25 years ago, wandered lost and confused at the threshold of feminism. No, they are more likely to respond by surfing eBay for the Lilly Pulitzer shifts they see in the Palm Beach photographs, or see if they can track down the cool suede jacket that Senator Barry Goldwater is wearing in the chapter on the Southwest. Dizzied by changing trends and the frivolity of consuming, fashion people -- the fans and the practitioners -- hunger for new inspiration, instruction and, mostly, something sacred in shopping.
Aarons decided not to have me arrested and instead agreed to an interview. 
"I'm telling you I don't have any answers," he said. "I was just doing my job."
"Me, too."
Fashion's devotion to Slim Aarons hit its stride about four years ago when word got out that "society girls were back." Park Avenue princesses and sister acts starring siblings with names like Miller, Herrera and Boardman. The pendulum had swung and celebrity worship felt tired. Sort of. 
Of course, society people have always been a subject for photographers. 
"The bigger question became, is this a good thing or a bad thing, are we regressing, or is it just a sign that we are mixing it up?" said Ingrid Sischy, the editor of Interview magazine and a contributing editor to Vanity Fair, where she writes about photography and art.
"Meanwhile, for photographers, the question was how to take this moment and make it stylish and cool. Slim Aarons is the king of that. Otherwise, you should just go around photographing banks, or doormen."
On the appointed morning I got myself to Grand Central Terminal and boarded a train scheduled to arrive just a few minutes before 9 a.m. in Katonah, N.Y. Aarons said he would meet me at the station. How would I know him?
"You'll figure it out," he said.
And just as Nancy Holmes said, Aarons, age 80, was "chic as hell." He wore a red and white cotton scarf around his neck, a red-checked shirt, a Swiss cardigan, denim-style cotton jeans custom made for him nearly 25 years ago by Brioni in Italy and brown loafers made by the shoemaker across the way from the Grand Hotel Quisisana on Capri, where Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis and Lee Radziwill bought their summer sandals. Aarons's automobile, driven by a young woman who assists him with office work in the mornings, was an imported economy number filled with newspapers and grocery store circulars.
"Come on," Aarons said as we drove away from the station. "I'll show you the house and tell you the story. Shouldn't take long. I don't have many pictures around anymore. I used to keep all my pictures in the attic, but Mark Getty has them all now. Getty's picture archive owns everything. Wonderful guy. Grandson of the old man himself. Direct line right down. He came out here to the house about three or four years ago. He was wearing this little windbreaker and I thought he was a guy looking for a landscaping job."
The sale of his archive to Getty, for an undisclosed sum, meant that Aarons could take it easy. "I highly recommend it," he said.
On the way to the house, Aarons extolled the virtues of Bedford, where he has lived since 1953. Near his house there are Vanderbilts and Morgans "and other old families you don't hear about because they don't want you to." Not too far away, a techno-potentate one hears about quite often recently closed on 20 acres of expensive gentleman's farmland. "Got himself lots of manure. Get the picture?" Aarons said, and laughed. 
The car turned up the road that led to his place, a farmhouse built in 1782. "I married a girl from the picture department of Life magazine. When I got married, all the Life photographers chipped in and gave me the money to buy the house." The memory of their generosity is still very sweet to him. 
"I'm a pack rat," he warned as we entered the dining room just to the right of the front door. The sunny room was painted with a wraparound trompe l'oeil mural celebrating the country life of the Aarons family and their favorite neighbors. The photographer's wife, Rita, was not at home today. Their daughter, Mary, works for Horticulture magazine in Boston. 
Off the dining room was a small greenhouse where the photographer likes to sit on winter afternoons and answer his mail. Bougainvillea grew there with considerable success. A long bench in the front hall held piles of magazines, including old numbers of Life, and on the wall you rather quickly notice a Picasso drawing showing Rita pregnant with Mary in 1958 and a thank-you note for a photo Aarons took of the painter. You also notice the framed note from Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis thanking Aarons for helping her with one of her projects. 
We headed into the living room lined with bookcases and trompe l'oeil cabinets that hide the television and the bar. All houses in Bedford have bars, but Aarons said he doesn't drink. "If you can get through a war without drinking, you don't need it. I smoked, photographer's habit."
A video of Madonna's "Truth or Dare" was on top of one pile. "No, I stayed in my own pew," he answered when asked if he ever had ambitions to make documentaries. The apartment he kept across from the Ritz Tower on Park Avenue many years ago -- "a walk-up, full-floor, $32-a-month, get the picture?"- did, however, prompt Alfred Hitchcock to change Jimmy Stewart's character in "Rear Window" from a writer to a photographer. Aarons did some scouting photography for the movie.
I said how much I liked his house. Would he ever have it photographed for a magazine?
"You nuts?" he answered.
Aarons sat down. "Sit," the photographer ordered. "You must be tired of looking up my nostrils."
He opened a Manila folder filled with papers. "Here's why I don't shoot anymore." He passed me a 1999 cover of San Francisco magazine showing Robin Williams, his back to the camera, urinating into a body of water. "That's considered witty," he said. 
The next picture he handed to me was a photograph Steven Meisel took of Madonna for a Versace campaign that was torn from the pages of The New York Times Magazine. Madonna was wearing an evening dress, one foot perched on a chair. "I think Meisel is great, to tell you the truth," Aarons said, "but I didn't like this picture. 
What is she doing? Her shoe is on a good piece of furniture!"
If Meisel's advertising work, also including his recent Valentino campaign, was inspired by "A Wonderful Time," Aarons said he was "flattered." He added, "Listen, I've been ripped off for years." He looked for something in his file. "I even ripped myself off. I did some of the first ads for Ralph Lauren in the 1970's and Ralph, who is a neighbor, by the way, told me to 'rip myself off,' and shoot the model like the polo shot of Laddie Sanford in the Palm Beach chapter in the book."
Upset once when an ad campaign by Barneys New York felt too reminiscent of his work, Aarons telephoned the store. "Went right to the top man," he said. "Always do. Got Mr. Pressman on the phone. Said, 'You're copying me.' He said: 'Oh, Slim Aarons? We have three copies of your book and we rip you off every day.' "
Aarons laughed. "At least he was honest."
Aarons is confounded by magazines today. "There's no place I want to put my work," he said. 
"I don't want to shoot a story for a magazine with cover lines like, 'How to Have Multiple Orgasms While You're Camping With Him."' 
The trouble with magazines today, Aarons said, "is the women in the business." He added: "There aren't any Carmel Snows or Diana Vreelands anymore.* At least men had mothers. Get the picture? Women think like Dad. They think like a bunch of men in saloons, the lowest common denominator."
Aarons told me he recently received a phone call from someone writing a piece on Babe Paley. The writer asked the photographer if he ever had eaten with Paley. "Yes, I can manage a fork and a spoon," he responded. "You see, I was one with everybody I photographed. We were basically the same age. I never wore a black T-shirt. I dressed appropriately. I never arrived with a crew of people. I used natural lighting. If it was good enough for Rembrandt, it was good enough for me. Young photographers always ask me how to make it. I say, 'Go to the museums and look.' But I'm not interested in young photographers, although I like Bruce Weber a lot. Good guy. Have a few letters from him. And another thing: I never had a stylist or hair and makeup people. You going to tell Babe Paley what to wear or how to make up?"
Aarons employed only one assistant. "A beautiful girl, always a racehorse from a good family, prettier than anyone you were going to photograph," he said. "Someone who refuses you will change his mind when he sees a beautiful girl. 'Come in, come in, have a drink,' he'd say. 'Mind if I look around?' I'd ask. While everyone was looking at the beautiful girl, I could look around and make decisions about how I was going to do the job." 
When he was 18, Aarons enlisted in the Army. He left New Hampshire "to make my way in the world" and arrived at Governor's Island. He was interested in photography, and volunteered to help in the photo lab. "Know how to dip hypo?" the head of the lab asked.
Aarons learned. War was imminent, and the man running the lab was made a major. Aarons replaced him. Soon he was shooting the cadets' official photographs. "And if a guy committed suicide, I took that picture, too," he remembered, putting the photograph of Madonna back in the Manila folder.
"Frank Capra came through looking for people to help on a magazine called Yank, which was like the Stars and Stripes, and I was off for Africa on the Pan Am Clipper with an attachment to the Eighth Army Division." Slim Aarons received the Purple Heart when he left the Army. "I gave it to a girlfriend of mine at the time. It's all bull, you see."
He rested in New Hampshire for a while and then drove across country to Hollywood with his friend Bill Mauldin, the cartoonist. The war had been hard. "I was really beat by the time I got back to the States," he said. Aarons felt he had paid his dues and decided it was all right to turn his camera away from misery. He chased beauty now. "Attractive people in attractive places doing attractive things," he repeated. 
In Hollywood, through his Yank connections, he started shooting for Life while some friends tried to turn him into a movie star. He appeared in a total of four films. "They wanted to make a cowboy out of me." His only line in the movie "Up Front With Mauldin" was, "Put the chicken in the stew, Willy." 
"That's what they're laughing about in my picture 'Kings of Hollywood,' Louis Auchincloss's favorite photograph of mine," he said. "I'm at Mike Romanoff's joint and Gary Cooper is telling Clark Gable, Van Heflin and Jimmy Stewart how I flubbed my one and only line." He looked away and remembered more. 
Aarons met Jean Howard in Hollywood. The former Ziegfeld showgirl, MGM contract player and Hollywood wife was turning pro as a photographer. Her husband at the time, the legendary agent and producer Charles Feldman, asked Aarons to help her out. Howard ended up going with Aarons to Rome, where Life was opening a new bureau. Although her book, "Jean Howard's Hollywood," does not talk about their relationship, in her second book, "Travels With Cole Porter," she published a letter from Porter that included the remembrance, "Love to Slim." 
"I helped Jean with her flash," Aarons said slowly. 
His beat in Rome was "the pope, movie stars and gangsters." "I shot Lucky Luciano for Life because he owed me a favor and gangsters always pay back," he said. "Remember, I'm not a moralist," Aarons added, and smiled. "When he was in jail he didn't like anyone to call him Lucky because he didn't think it was lucky. So everybody called him Charlie."
Aarons's Christian name is George.
Leland Hayward admired Aarons's Life photographs from Italy and asked him to come back and shoot his theater productions in New York. "Leland Hayward was my role model, a wonderful guy," Aarons said. "I shot Broadway productions for Hayward, Joshua Logan and Mrs. Selznick."
Aarons got up and walked to the kitchen. "I designed the kitchen," he said proudly. He owns a red dishwasher. "Why not? Whimsy is good." He opened a cupboard drawer and out popped an ironing board on a spring. "Everything in life should have form and design," he said. But Aarons doesn't own a computer. "Everyone is trying to get online," he said. "I'm trying to get offline."
We ate tuna fish sandwiches on white bread and drank Canada Dry ginger ale, Aarons's favorite drink. Next to the kitchen table was the photographer's "spike" -- "Like the name?" -- a piece of metal on which he pins notes and invitations, a dinner with Graydon Carter at Diane Von Furstenberg's in TriBeCa and a reminder that he was to dine with Fleur Cowles and Dominick Dunne in town. 
Lunch was over. Slim Aarons had no intention of keeping me from catching the next train. 
Before we left for the station, he opened a Kodak box with prints that were shown recently in a retrospective at the Overseas Press Club of America in New York. He rested a photograph of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis on the kitchen counter. It was the one where she is in her early 20's and she is wearing pearls and elbow-length white gloves and there is a scarlet wrap in her lap and she is looking up into the world and smiling like she had just seen a beautiful horse.
"In so many of her photographs Jackie looks hard," Aarons said. "Not here. Like any good photograph, it's all in the eyes. 
You see a young girl who sees a friend and she likes him and it tells you the whole story about how this young girl thinks when she's happy."
I slid into the passenger seat, and Aarons backed the car out of the narrow two-car garage. I couldn't have done it.
"Thank you for today," I said. 
"I had a wonderful time."
"Yeah, yeah," Aarons responded. "Do you know who de Beistegui was?" 
I did. Carlos de Beistegui was a noted host and arbiter who gave marvelous costume balls in places like Venice or at his house, the Chateau de Groussay, near Paris. Particularly famous was the ball de Beistegui gave in Venice in 1951 that convened international society after World War II.
"I think about de Beistegui sometimes," Aarons said as he drove. "I do a thing, and everyone mocks it. But if you don't have the people like the ones I photographed, then your capitalism is shot." 
He then explained how the communist papers in Europe wrote tirelessly about de Beistegui's extravagances. "So de Beistegui finally stopped giving his dances," Aarons said. "Then guess what the newspapers wrote? 
They wrote how terrible it was that de Beistegui and all his rich friends were putting poor people out of work by not having their extravagant parties."
He laughed. "You can't win," Slim Aarons said, "because it's all bull."

HEADLINE: Rally Round the Flag 

BYLINE:  By Charles B. Dew <BLB>A historian examines the popular literature of the Civil War.; Charles B. Dew teaches Southern history at Williams College. His newest book is the forthcoming "Apostles of Disunion: Southern Secession Commissioners and the Causes of the Civil War."

 BODY:
 The Imagined Civil War
Popular Literature of the North and South,
1861-1865.
By Alice Fahs.
Illustrated. 410 pp. Chapel Hill:
The University of North Carolina Press. $39.95.
"Is this tremendous epic we are now living to bring forth naught but trash unutterable and bombast?" asked the editor of The Round Table, a New York periodical, in 1864. It was a good question, and one that has, by and large, stood the test of time. The great mass of poetry and fiction produced in both the North and the South during the Civil War has found virtually no place in the history of the era because most scholars have agreed with that observer of 1864. Indeed, Daniel Aaron entitled his influential study of American writers during these years "The Unwritten War," and Edmund Wilson opened his "Patriotic Gore" with the comment that "The period of the American Civil War was not one in which belles-lettres flourished."
But there was another literature -- that "trash" and "bombast" -- that Alice Fahs believes merits our attention. The incredible outpouring of war poetry, sentimental stories, sensational novels, humor, juvenile fiction and war histories that gushed forth between 1861 and 1865 has its own tale to tell, she insists, and by the end of her fascinating book "The Imagined Civil War," we are inclined to agree with her.
Fahs, who teaches history at the University of California, Irvine, opens by looking at the war poetry that filled column after column of both Northern and Southern newspapers and magazines. The initial poetic concentration on the flag, spread-eagle patriotism and the virile manhood of the troops soon gave way to a much more personal focus. The individual experience of war, soldier by soldier, mother by mother, became the dominant theme of both poetry and popular fiction as the civilian population struggled to make sense of the massive bloodletting. The "sentimental soldier," imagining his home and family at the moment of death, or suffering in stoic silence on his hospital bed, provided "an icon of heroism" that linked the experience of combat with the lives of those behind the lines. "A much repeated trope in the North during the war," Fahs writes, "was the idea that every bullet killed or wounded twice, once on the battlefield and once on the home front."
The war also became increasingly "feminized" in the popular literature of both regions, albeit with significant differences. In the North, a "moral economy" emerged that placed the suffering of women on the same plane as that of their soldier husbands, sons, fathers and brothers. In many ways, "women's wounds" became "the emotional center of the nation," Fahs writes -- dramatic vindication of the role Northern women were playing in sustaining the struggle. South of the Potomac, however, the prewar cult of domesticity reigned. Women were expected to sacrifice all for the sake of their new nation, to stand steadfast and unquestioning in the face of terrible loss -- and to do so within the confines of their own homes. Outside work, even nursing, received scant mention and little praise from Southern writers during the war.
Not surprisingly, regional differences emerged most clearly on matters of race. Certainly one of the major strengths of this fine book is Fah's insightful discussion of the changing image of black people in Northern popular literature. Racist stereotypes persisted in the North throughout the war years, but significant new themes emerged. In the summer and fall of 1862, for example, Northern popular writers began to argue that blacks deserved a chance to fight for their freedom. The point might be made with incredible crudeness and insensitivity -- one poem was entitled "Sambo's Right to Be Kilt" -- or it might focus on a man like Robert Smalls, a South Carolinian who, with his crew of fellow slaves, commandeered a Confederate vessel in June 1862 and sailed into Union-controlled waters. But the case for black enlistment emerged just as Abraham Lincoln was making his first moves in the direction of Emancipation, and the argument grew stronger in the summer of 1863. In July of that year, the 54th Massachusetts, the most famous black regiment in the Union Army, stormed Fort Wagner near Charleston, S.C. The 54th established black courage and black manhood in unmistakable terms in Unionist popular literature, but Northern writers ultimately could not come to grips with the full implications of black military service. Almost invariably, Fahs points out, tales of black heroism in battle ended with the death of the hero -- a trajectory that celebrated black bravery without having to imagine the full participation of black veterans in American life. The cultural landscape of the North was already being prepared for the postwar denial of black claims to full citizenship.
Southern writers presented a much different picture of the Negro, of course. In their view, the once happy slave, kidnapped by the vile Yankees and forced into the ranks, only wanted to get back to his former home so that he could "belong to somebody," a return to the Negro's supposed natural state. Poems like "The Contraband's Return" insisted, as paradoxical as it may seem to our ears, that "only slavery allowed true freedom" to black people -- a persistent theme of Lost Cause fiction well into the 20th century. Accompanying this picture of slave loyalty, confusion and docility was a much less benign portrait of the black as a man-child easily corrupted by "Yankee abolitionists" and turned loose on the "fair, unprotected females" of the South. As Fahs notes, "even in the crucible of war, an immutable and intertwined Southern racial and sexual order survived unscathed." Here was a literary tradition that postwar Southern writers like Thomas Dixon Jr. could embrace with unalloyed enthusiasm and popularize across the nation in novels like "The Clansman" and movies like "Birth of a Nation."
Fahs has worked her way through an extraordinary amount of popular poetry and fiction in her effort to illuminate the cultural landscape of these years. Her light shines brightest on the North, it must be said, but this concentration seems unavoidable. Only in one genre -- poetry -- did the volume of Southern literary production come close to rivaling the North, and this was only because newspapers were the principal outlet for Confederate verse. The South did not have the publishing houses, the printing presses or even adequate amounts of paper to sustain a vigorous commercial literary culture. But Fahs has still managed to give us new and valuable insights into the wartime South, and her treatment of Northern popular literature is a signal contribution to our understanding of Civil War America.

HEADLINE: The Close Reader; 
The Romance of Real Estate

BYLINE:  By Judith Shulevitz <BLB>Good real estate novelists drive us out to parts of town we've never seen before. 

 BODY:
Certain subjects change the way we read fiction. Sex is one, which is why some authors are reluctant to write about it directly. Real estate is another, at least for anyone who has ever ridden the heart-stopping roller coaster of the contemporary housing market. The allure of both comes dangerously close to that of pornography or of books about people you know: your prurient interest in the subject matter threatens to overwhelm your attention to anything else.
 I'm not the first to observe that sex and real estate arouse feelings of similar intensity. In a recent book titled "Sex and Real Estate: Why We Love Houses," Marjorie Garber, a Harvard English professor, makes the same point. Garber seems more intent, though, on showing that domesticity is often described in the language of physical passion than in explaining how such desires are put to literary use. On one level, it's simple. Good real estate novelists do what good real estate agents do. They drive us out to parts of town we've never seen before and offer us alternate ways of being in the world. 
 That's what all fiction does, of course, but the appeal of real estate fiction is that it does so in a particular way -- by letting us in on the sometimes sordid secrets of the trade. Countless works of Western literature, from Exodus and the "Odyssey" down to "Paradise Lost" and the entire oeuvre of Marcel Proust, have involved the search for a home, a thing of incomparable value. A real estate novelist can pull out the comparables and tell you its price within minutes. He or she even has data on how long characters should spend looking for it. According to Frank Bascombe, the agent in Richard Ford's "Independence Day," statistics show that it is best to stop after 45 houses: "Clients, after this point, frequently don't buy a house but shove off to other locales." 
It is the relentless commodification of landscapes, exterior and interior, that gives "Babbitt" its comic tone. Sinclair Lewis's 1922 novel about a real estate agent and developer -- call it the founding text of the genre, at least in American literature -- is filled with deadpan inventories of the objects in George F. Babbitt's world, all of which are described in the jarring adspeak of the day. His office building downtown is "as fireproof as a rock and as efficient as a typewriter." His Dutch Colonial house in the suburb of Floral Heights has, to Babbitt's pride, the same appointments and amenities as every other house in Floral Heights, "the best of taste, the best of inexpensive rugs, a simple and laudable architecture and the latest conveniences." 
There's just one thing wrong with the Babbitt house, Lewis says: "It was not a home." This is a perfect summary of Babbitt's spiritual condition. He is ethically, emotionally, at one point almost physically homeless, largely because he can't see through his commercial appraisals of people and things to their true value. He falters and flounders, a victim of his own con man's boosterism. (Babbitt is not a crook, exactly, but he specializes in the surreptitious purchase of land that he flips for an enormous profit.) Though he's Presbyterian, Lewis's Realtor -- a word that by a fluke of trademark law must be suggestively capitalized -- bears a certain resemblance to the type of social-climbing Jew (like Balzac's Baron de Nucingen or Wharton's Rosedale) whose speculations distorted the moral economies of so many 19th- and early 20th-century novels. 
By 1995, when "Independence Day" was published, real estate had clearly lost much of its stigma. The novel is the most thorough examination of the industry I know, and its hero, Frank Bascombe, an agent in the smallish town of Haddam, N.J., is nothing if not an honest broker. He exhibits a high degree of social consciousness -- he buys houses in a black neighborhood in hopes of preserving it -- and a local historian's sense of place. He has a straight-shooting sales technique. He never pushes or exaggerates. He is blunt about the compromises and trade-offs his buyers may have to make. His efforts to sell a house to a couple with unreasonable expectations is a masterly exercise in what Saul Bellow calls reality instruction. 
And yet Bascombe seems as badly anchored as Babbitt. This is partly a function of his rootless times, but there's more to it than that. It's as if Bascombe's psychologically subtle salesmanship had come at the cost of a deeper intimacy. Like the therapist who can't solve his own problems, Bascombe is brilliant at helping his clients figure out where and how to live but can't feel his way into viable relationships with his ex-wife, girlfriend and troubled son. It is not a coincidence that half the action in the novel takes place on the Interstate, from which Bascombe calls in frequently for messages. 
Why is the Realtor such a troubled figure? Perhaps, in part, because he or she has become a stand-in for the author, who uses the real estate profession to raise questions about the literary one. In Ford's case the comparison is explicit: Bascombe used to write fiction. In "Off Keck Road," Mona Simpson's new contribution to the genre, the analogy is implied. Showing a house is like telling a story because both involve sleight of hand and little acts of betrayal. 
Bea Maxwell, one of Simpson's two heroines, is a smart, handsome woman who leaves her job as a copywriter in Chicago in the 1950's to care for her ailing mother in Green Bay, Wis. For lack of anything better to do, Bea becomes a real estate agent, which allows Simpson to give her readers an overview of Green Bay, its old-money downtown, its dirt-poor outlying areas, and their decay or development over the years, facilitated by local agents like Bea. Bea herself winds up in her mother's once glamorous house, unable to maintain it and utterly alone. Her only enduring relationship is a platonic friendship with the boss of her agency.
Bea does have a gift, though, for something that resembles domesticity. The technical term for her art is "staging" -- cleaning and fluffing a house for show -- but she so excels at it that her colleagues coin the verb "to One-Hour Maxwellize" (on the model of "One-Hour Martinizing"). So how could this competent professional get trapped inside a slowly moldering house? The novelist hints at an answer, a note of self-accusation, even self-pity, audible in her voice. There is something soul-destroying about the manufacture of illusions, she seems to suggest, particularly when they are made of material as dear to us as a home. Or, to put it in Simpson's words: "Every so often, Bea wanted to One-Hour Maxwellize her house. She too wanted that clean, chemical, mint quality. But maybe, she thought, houses were ruined for her. She knew too much about the stagecraft of improvement. Perhaps selling anything eventually spoils it for you."

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER; 
A Night's Stay For $80 or Less

BYLINE:  By BETSY WADE 

 BODY:
ALONG America's roads today, drivers seeking modestly priced places to stay can encounter a bewildering variety of chains. There are 120 different chain names in the economy and midscale categories, as ranked by Smith Travel Research in Hendersonville, Tenn., which monitors the hospitality industry. The two categories combined have average rates under $80 a night.
 The total of such lodgings is really far larger, in fact; Smith has a separate category for 48 midscale chains with restaurants attached that also have daily rates under $80 a night, and it encompasses some biggies: Clarion, Holiday Inn, Holiday Inn Select, Howard Johnson's, Ramada and Quality Inn. 
 The trade magazine Hotel & Motel Management published a chart this month that showed there were 14,500 properties bearing the names of the 55 biggest chains in the two Smith categories, economy and midscale without restaurants. As has been true for several years, Days Inn was at the top of the list; its sun-up signs have been hung out by franchise-holders at 1,800 United States properties with 152,000 rooms. That is about as far as you can get from a boutique hotel. 
The next four on the list were Comfort Inn and Suites, Super 8, Hampton Inn and Suites, and Motel 6. At the opposite end is Cambridge Suites, a brand name used by the Candlewood Hotel Company of Wichita, Kan., for a chain of one, as of December -- a 64-room property in Wichita.
In this vast marketplace, what separates one brand from another? Most limited-service places, for example, provide free Continental breakfast, but others depend on adjacent fast-food places, and this is worth asking about. Also, when a motel company has taken over many properties with other affiliations, the bedroom design cannot be consistent, although there may be a minimum size.
Here is a scorecard of what a few of the bigger chains offer.

Giant Franchiser
The giant, Days Inns of America Inc., a division of the Cendant Corporation in Parsippany, N.J., owns none of the places bearing its name. Like all other franchisers, it grants rights to its name and reservation service to owners who apply, qualify and pay the required fees. Among the requirements are bedrooms of 288 square feet, about average for motels.
In the 1990's, according to Joseph R. Kane Jr., the company president, the name expanded widely through "conversions" -- transfers by owners from other affiliations. One result is a variety of building designs that meet the bedroom size minimum. Many of the inns are older motels; Mr. Kane said 60 percent have exterior corridors. The safety of this design is disputed in the industry, and as a result, few new motels are built this way.
Last year, the average paid for a night at a Days Inn was $55, which included a Continental breakfast at 80 to 85 percent of the properties. A free breakfast is a requirement for new franchises. Half the chain's guests were business travelers. Mr. Kane said that suites were being built into the new places to encourage travelers who were willing to spend more. In the last five years, he said, the company has dropped 400 motels whose owners were allowing the properties to "languish."
Comfort Inn, No. 2 on the list, is part of Choice Hotels, a franchiser with seven brand names: Comfort Inn and Comfort Suites, Sleep Inn, MainStay Suites, Quality, Clarion, Econo Lodge and Rodeway Inn. The Comfort name appears on more than 1,400 United States properties with 115,300 rooms. The minimum size for a Comfort Inn room is 288 square feet and for a suite room, 396 square feet.
Steven Schultz, Choice's executive vice president for domestic hotels, said that under a recent reorganization, a lot of "reimaging" was planned, with new signs for some brands and other cosmetic shifts. Sixty percent of Comfort's guests, he said, are business travelers. The average rate for both Comfort categories combined, he said, was in the low 60's, but Comfort Suites, all newly built, commanded $10 to $12 more a night. Free Continental breakfast is provided at both. Comfort labels appear on new and converted properties; 80 to 85 percent have interior corridors, a spokeswoman said.
Sleep Inn, another Choice brand, ranked No. 13 with 280 properties. Sleep Inns have all been built to the company's plans in the last 10 years or so, with interior corridors. Rooms have 256 square feet. These motels, with an average rate last year in the high 50's, provide free Continental breakfast.
Mr. Schultz said that for all brands, Choice dropped franchises for 170 operators last year and 200 in 1999.

'Clean and Reasonable'
Super 8, No. 3 in size, another Cendant brand, says it has 1,965 motels. Its average daily rate for 1999 -- Super 8 does not release the previous year's figures until March -- was $44.55. "We focus on offering a clean room with friendly service at a reasonable price," Evy Apostolatos, a spokeswoman, said. She said that 80 to 90 percent of Super 8's provided Continental breakfasts; after April 1, all will be required to do it. The minimum room size is 240 square feet. Two-thirds of guests are men averaging 45 years old with a $50,000 income -- probably travelers in sales, or entrepreneurs. Senior citizens represent a quarter of the market. Motels with exterior corridors constitute 15 to 20 percent of the properties, mainly in the Southeast and California, Ms. Apostolatos said.
Another motel chain with properties built to order is Hampton Inn and Suites, a division of Hilton Hotels. It ranks fourth on the list; the Hampton name, which appeared in 1985, is used by 1,080 places that are either franchised or owned by the company. Judy Christa-Cathey, vice president for the Hampton brand, said that last year's average daily rate was $73 for inns, in the low 90's for suites. The average inn room is 324 square feet; the average two-room suite is 470. She said that 10 percent of Hampton's inns were built with exterior corridors and that 51 percent of its guests were vacationers. "The majority of our business travelers are men," she said, "and they rely on our consistency." Hampton was an early starter with free Continental breakfast, and all its inns offer it.
Last year, Ms. Christa-Cathey said, eight motels were dropped for failure to meet standards, and she said the company monitored a rather large list of places that had been warned about performance. 
Microtel Inns and Suites is a franchise brand with 213 domestic motels, all built to the company's specifications with interior corridors. The average daily rate last year was $46. "It's the same hotel wherever you go," said Microtel's president, Michael A. Leven. "Sameness is very important at the lower end of the price scale." He called the chain "the Volkswagen" of the business, with virtually no amenities. For example, there is no shampoo in Microtel rooms, he said, although the front desk stocks it along with other items that guests might have forgotten. The small Continental breakfast is designed for those who "grab and go." The rooms can also be small: the one designated as a "single" is 192 square feet; the "queen" 288 square feet, and the single-room "suite" -- it has a bed and a sleeper sofa, with a kitchenette on an island between the two -- 372 square feet.
Microtel provides HBO free.
Ninety-five percent of Country Inns and Suites, a division of Carlson Hospitality Worldwide, which owns hotels, a cruise line, restaurants and other travel businesses, is newly built, according to its president, Paul Kirwin. It gets 60 percent business travelers at its 246 properties. Mr. Kirwin said Country Inns' units were designed "to feel like a B & B," with a homey feel, although the motels provide computer hookups, exercise rooms and other amenities not common at bed-and-breakfasts.
Country Inns are popular with "early seniors and empty-nesters," Mr. Kirwin said. The average room is 312 square feet; a suite room is 384 square feet, and a free Continental breakfast is provided. The average daily rate last year was $70, and Mr. Kirwin said the inns got many middle-management people, technicians and other business travelers, as well as upper-middle-income vacationers. The properties are 99 percent interior-corridor design, he said.
Motel 6's average daily rate last year was in the high 30's and low 40's. Eric Studer, senior vice president for marketing, said studies of national chains had found Motel 6 to be the lowest-priced, and "price is our focus." Few, if any, Motel 6's provide Continental breakfast; "we don't encourage it," a spokeswoman said. A room with one bed averages 212 square feet; a room with two, 276 square feet. Mr. Studer said that the chain, owned by the French Accor group, had 816 properties in the United States, of which 109 were franchised. He said the chain was growing "methodically" and turned away 1,300 applicants last year because they were not willing to invest in renovations.
The Smith category omits Howard Johnson's but might just as well include it because it straddles the restaurant-no restaurant border. Of the 420 Howard Johnson's in the United States, 200 are now Howard Johnson Express Inns, which have no restaurants but provide free Continental breakfast. Mary Mahoney, president of Howard Johnson's, said this tier was begun in 1997 because the chain, another part of Cendant, found applicants for franchises did not want to operate restaurants and the chain wanted to continue to grow. The target market is still families with children. Two-thirds of Howard Johnson's properties have exterior corridors. The minimum room size is 245 square feet. Andrew Miller, a spokesman for the chain, would not supply an average daily rate, citing the wide disparity of the chain's markets.

Inside or Outside Corridors
The dispute over the safety of exterior corridors is complex. Ms. Mahoney said that women who traveled did not mind exterior corridors provided the parking lot was well lighted. Mr. Kirwin of Country Inns said women would not stay at places with exterior corridors and his company therefore no longer accepted them.
Anthony Marshall, president of the Educational Institute of the American Hotel and Motel Association, recently wrote in the group's magazine that he felt uneasy after dark going into a motel with room entrances on the outside. But Greg Plank, president of Suburban Lodges, which ranked 12th on the association's list, said his company might continue to build outside-corridor lodgings because they were popular.
A number of executives interviewed for this article said that salespeople liked to back their cars up to their rooms and keep an eye on the contents. Yet no executives interviewed said they were building motels with exterior corridors, so where these are found, they are likely to be older.
"The hotel business is very location-oriented, and the fact is that exterior-corridor properties are in prime locations throughout the country," Mr. Plank noted. "They got there first, and providing they maintain their quality, they will continue to thrive regardless of their flag affiliation."
Travelers who are picking their motels by brand name because they do not welcome surprises may therefore want to add a new question about exterior corridors to the ones they usually ask.

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN; 
Natchez

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER MOSES; JENNIFER MOSES, the author of "Food and Whine" (Fireside), lives in Baton Rouge.

 BODY:
Mainly what I love about Natchez is its fairy-tale quality of having been suspended in time. And the fact that it's small enough to explore on foot, which gives you a chance, if you're nosy, to peer behind picket fences into private gardens, gaze through antique-glass windows into living rooms, and daydream about a slower, prettier and perhaps more romantic era.
 Yes, there is the occasional sport-utility vehicle, the odd blast of rap music from an open window, and universal air-conditioning -- not to mention an outer ring of strip malls and fast-food outlets. But Natchez, largely because its economy never recovered from the devastating boll weevil infestation of 1908, was nearly overlooked by the developers who changed the landscape of the South. 
 More to the point, its citizens didn't have the cash to install modern kitchens, affix two-car garages, or upgrade in any way. So, to this day, visitors to one of the oldest settlements on the Mississippi can see it much as it was during its heyday before the Civil War (or the War Between the States as it's still called here) when -- thanks to King Cotton -- Natchez was home to over half the millionaires in the United States. It goes without saying that their vast fortunes were wrenched from the most hideous injustice, and yet the palatial homes -- in a range of styles from Federal to Southern Planter, handsome churches and imposing public buildings that cotton made possible are glorious to behold.
More than 500 of these magnificent structures still stand, their architectural integrity intact, because Natchez was miraculously nearly unscathed in the Civil War. And some 30 of them -- many privately owned -- are on display twice a year during the Spring and Fall Pilgrimages. 
You want the Old South? Dressed in period costume, guides are sure to give visitors plenty of "y'alls" as well as history; mint juleps, an art form in Natchez, are sure to flow; and the gardens will be bursting with azaleas, sweet olive, camellias, tulip poppies, jasmine and dogwood.

Events
This year's Spring Pilgrimage will be March 7 through April 7 (the Fall Pilgrimage will be Oct. 10 to 27). Each tour this spring stops at four houses, and costs $24 a person, half that for ages 6 to 17. There are morning and afternoon tours, eight in all. Morning-tour houses are open 9 to 1, afternoon houses 1:30 to 5:30. Some of the houses are open year-round, but not the ones that are privately owned. A bus runs to three of the four houses on each tour for $26 from any hotel in town.
Pilgrimage information is available from Natchez Pilgrimage Tours, (800) 647-6742, or at www .natchezpilgrimage.com. 
Besides the houses themselves, the Pilgrimage season includes three evening entertainments. The most famous of these is the Historic Natchez Pageant (formerly the Confederate Pageant), during which local performers, again dressed in period costume, dance and sing in a show worthy of "Gone With the Wind." Performances are at the Natchez City Auditorium, 207 Jefferson Street (at Canal), at 8:30 p.m. on Monday, Wednesday, Friday and Saturday; tickets are $12. 
Gospel and comedy are featured in the other two shows during Pilgrimage season. The Holy Family Gospel Choir will perform a musical tribute to the African-American struggle, "Southern Road to Freedom." It is presented Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday nights at 8:30 at the First Presbyterian Church, 117 South Pearl Street. Tickets: $10.
"Southern Exposure," a satire about the Pilgrimage, will be presented at the Natchez Little Theater Playhouse Tuesday, Thursday, Saturday and Sunday nights at 8:30. Tickets: $12. Reservations for all three shows can be made through Natchez Pilgrimage Tours, (800) 647-6742.
On April 20 to 22, the Natchez Bluff Blues Fest, will bring bands from all over the South to Memorial Park, next to St. Mary Minor Basilica, and 13 clubs and restaurants around town. There will be plenty of red beans, rice and other regional foods, too. General admission, $7 at the park, most other shows free; information: (601) 442-2988.
The Natchez Opera Festival, including performances of "H.M.S. Pinafore," "Carmen" and "La Boheme," is held throughout May. Concerts and recitals are in the New Covenant Presbyterian Church, St. Mary Minor and the Margaret Martin Performing Arts Center. Tickets are $20 to $45. There are also free outdoor concerts, and recitals in historic homes; (800) 647-6724 or www2 .bkbank.com/ncvb. 

Sightseeing
The Grand Village of the Natchez Indians, a prehistoric site that includes three ceremonial mounds, a ceremonial plaza and a visitors center, is at 400 Jefferson Davis Boulevard, southeast of downtown. Open daily, free; call (601) 446-6502.
Now a museum, Jefferson College, some 10 minutes' drive northeast of Natchez on Highway 61 in Washington, was chartered in 1802 as the first educational institution in Mississippi. Jefferson Davis, among other notables, was a student there. A visitor reception area tells the story of the college, and a nature trail winds through the woods and past the college cemetery. Free; (601) 442-2901.
The neo-Classical Temple B'nai Israel, 213 South Commerce Street, opened in 1905, is the oldest functioning synagogue in Mississippi. It has stained-glass windows, an ark of Italian marble, and a historic Henry Pilcher's Sons pipe organ. The basement contains a satellite of the Museum of the Southern Jewish Experience, with photographic exhibit. Donations are welcome. Information: (601) 362-6357. 
A permanent exhibit, "Natchez in Historic Photographs," is on display at the First Presbyterian Church, 117 South Pearl, (the lovely wooden church, dating to 1829, with soaring ceilings and wooden pews with doors, is itself worth a trip). Suggested donation, $3; (601) 442-2581.
The walking path that was once Clifton Avenue has magnificent views of the river on the one side and Victorian gems on the other. 
A half-mile north, on Cemetery Road, is the Historic Natchez Cemetery, (601) 445-5051. It includes Jewish Hill, where members of Natchez's once-thriving Jewish community are buried. A quarter-mile farther is the Natchez National Cemetery, established by the Union during the Civil War. Information: (601) 445-4981.

Where to Stay
The Guest House Historic Inn, an antebellum mansion at Pearl and Franklin Streets, (601) 442-1054, fax (601) 442-1374, members.aol .com/gsthous/gsthous.htm, has 17 comfortable rooms with private bath, each decorated individually with reproductions. A two-story veranda wraps around the front and sides, and balconies overlook an inner courtyard. All rooms are $114.94 in the off-season (until the Pilgrimage), then $125, including Continental breakfast. 
Celebrate Victorian excess at the Riverside Bed and Breakfast, 211 Clifton Avenue; (601) 446-5730. Wine-red tones are found throughout the home, which was begun in 1858 and has magnificent views of the Mississippi. There are a suite and two doubles furnished with tester beds and antiques. Rates, $85 to $150, include a full Southern breakfast. 
The 132-room Radisson, in the handsome 1927 Eola Hotel on the corner of Pearl and Main Streets, (601) 445-6000, fax (601) 446-5310, offers standard rooms for $99 during Pilgrimage, $89 in off-season. The hotel's restaurant, Julep's, serves a good Sunday Champagne brunch for under $10. 
Budget: A bluff overlooking the Mississippi is the site of the Ramada Hilltop Inn, 130 John R. Junkin Drive, (800) 256-6311, fax (601) 446-6321. Many of the 162 rooms have views; there is also a swimming pool and restaurant. Doubles are $80. 
Luxury: The queen of luxury inns in Natchez is the seriously lovely Monmouth Plantation, 36 Melrose Avenue, (800) 828-4531, fax (601) 446-7762, www.monmouthplantation .com. The 31 rooms are spread among eight buildings, including the original mansion (1818), on 26 acres with a formal rose garden, duck pond, pebble paths, statuary and moss-draped live oaks. A big Southern breakfast is included in the price of the large, romantic, ornate bedrooms. Rates are $190 to $205 for a double and $365 to $380 for suites; the mint juleps are extra. 
Another lovely old place is the Briars Inn, 31 Irving Lane, (800) 634-1818, fax (601) 445-6037, www .thebriarsinn.com, on 19 acres above the Mississippi. The Briars, built around 1814, was the home where Jefferson Davis married Varina Howell in 1845. The 12 spacious guest rooms and 3 suites are tastefully decorated with antiques, upholstered furniture, framed prints and quilts. Rates, $150 to $245, include a full breakfast, after which guests may want to stroll through the gardens, with magnolias, pecan trees, and thousands of daffodils and azaleas. 

Where to Eat
The talk of the town is the recently opened Castle Restaurant, 84 Homochitto Street, (800) 433-2445, in what was once the carriage house at Dunleith Plantation. The walls are exposed brick, the floors made of fine wide floorboards, the furnishings elegant, the service first rate -- and the breads are out of this world. The food is upscale and quite good, with the pretty, colorful entrees -- like grilled filet mignon on creamed potatoes surrounded by grilled vegetables, and topped by a port wine bordelaise -- framed by big white plates. Dinner for two with wine: about $70. 
Another stylish restaurant is John Martin's, on Silver Street in Natchez-Under-the-Hill; (601) 445-0605, extension 2116. The surroundings are starkly elegant, and simply reading the menu is enticing. Sauteed jumbo crab cakes with Creole mustard lemon hollandaise is just one of more than a dozen appetizers; sauteed shrimp with apple smoked bacon, red onions, roasted garlic, leeks, sun-dried tomato and arugula tossed with penne and extra virgin basil olive oil is one of 15 entrees (not including specials.) Dinner for two with wine: $80. Closed Monday. 
The Pig Out Inn, 116 South Canal Street, (601) 442-8050, is a down-home barbecue joint filled with an aroma so yummy you get hungry even if you aren't. A dinner plate of, for example, barbecued chicken or ribs with baked beans and corn on the cob, costs $10.25. Desserts include pecan and sweet potato pies. Tables have rolls of paper towels for sticky hands. A meal for two with beers will be less than $25. Closed Sunday, except during Pilgrimage. 
Nothing costs more than $8 at lunch at Pearl Street Pasta, 105 South Pearl Street, (601) 442-9284, which serves soups, salads and homemade desserts as well as big bowls of pasta, in a small, pleasant sunlit room. Dinner, with a glass of wine, is about $30.
It's so modest, it's easy to miss the Fare, 109 North Pearl, (601) 442-5299. Those who do are passing up a great breakfast. The Jimmy Carter Special -- eggs, grits, toast, a choice of sausage, ham or bacon, and coffee -- is $5.50. The Fare will also box up a lunch for you -- triple-decker sandwiches, roast beef po'boys, burgers, Reubens and salads. Sandwiches are $5 to $6. Closed Sunday. 
The Downtown Deli, 408 Main Street, (601) 445-7799, is also straightforward, serving po'boys, inventive sandwiches and salads. But it also offers an assortment of sophisticated whole bean coffees, as well as breakfast, in the coffee bar. Sandwiches are $4 to $6; salads are $6.95. Closed Sunday, except during Pilgrimage.
