HEADLINE: Turkey's Precarious Success 

BYLINE:  By Robert D. Kaplan; Robert D. Kaplan, a senior fellow at the New America Foundation, is author of "Eastward to Tartary: Travels in the Balkans, the Middle East and the Caucasus."

DATELINE: STOCKBRIDGE, Mass. 

 BODY:
Late last week in Turkey, the stock market declined by 18 percent and the lira lost a third of its value. Interest rates have soared to several thousand percent, and inflation is around 30 percent. What reportedly scared away investors was a publicized argument between President Ahmet Necdet Sezer and Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit, whom the president had accused of being too lenient toward corrupt politicians. But that was merely the beginning of the crisis, not its underlying cause.
 The cause was the very fragility of Turkey's recent economic reforms and the boomlet they had created, sending market indexes up from 5,000 to nearly 20,000 points in 1999 and early 2000. Turkey is building modern democratic and financial institutions that provide stability, but building such institutions can be destabilizing in its own right. Turkey's problems are those of success, but that does not make its problems any less dangerous to American interests. 
 Turkey, along with Brazil, perhaps, is now the world's foremost example of a state whose institutions are struggling to keep up with modernization. The government bureaucracy remains mired in Ottoman lethargy. Some banks, burdened by foreign-currency debts and murky dealings, are close to collapse. Tax revenues are insufficiently distributed to the provinces where they are needed.
Meanwhile, the dramatic liberalization of the Turkish economy begun in 1983 by Turgut Ozal, the late prime minister, has created a vast new population of urban middle-class Turks, who are pressing for better public services.
Stability has so far been maintained by the National Security Council, a mixed regime of military officers and civilian ministers. For decades, this council has prevented Turkey from slipping into the anarchy of new democracies like Indonesia or the stifling autocracy of many nearby Arab states. Nevertheless, that stability has come at an increasing cost, especially as Turkey's society and class structure have become more complex.
The problem is this, simply put: No one in the system is accountable. Turkey's needs for responsive, transparent banking and taxation systems have grown. But who would establish them?
The military has no logical role, and anyway, avoids political responsibility for many problems.
But the politicians also avoid responsibility. They know that in a crisis the military will bail them out through subtle interventions that Turks have come to call "soft, post-modern coups." Such ultimate reliance on the military is what keeps Turkish politics immature, as evinced by the kind of temper tantrums thrown by the president and prime minister last week. 
Another reason that both violence and political breakdown have been avoided in Turkey is the very corruption that is partly responsible for the current crisis in the first place. As Samuel P. Huntington explains in his 1968 classic, "Political Order in Changing Societies," high levels of corruption are endemic to societies undergoing the stress of rapid modernization. Corruption greases the wheels of creaky, unresponsive bureaucracies, creates informal networks of power so that things get done when they otherwise wouldn't, and allows people to purchase power in third world systems that they would otherwise violently revolt against.
Turkey, however, is at the point where such corruption has outlived its usefulness and threatens an Asian-style financial meltdown. Any meltdown in Turkey, however, would be far more serious than an economic meltdown in, say, Indonesia. That's because a Turkish economic disaster would have geopolitical consequences for the United States far more severe than the various economic crises that have affected East Asia in recent years.
Turkey is the political organizing principle of the greater Middle East. It controls the headwaters of the Tigris and Euphrates Rivers that supply Syria and Iraq, and it is the economic lifeline for new democracies in the Caucasus. Any weakening of Turkey's borders would open up the entire nest of questions -- dormant since the end of World War I -- regarding the real frontiers of Syria, Iraq and other countries, all of which were artificially created in postwar peace agreements.
Indeed, the Turkish military has been a fundamental element in the Middle East balance of power. For instance, a new Turkish-Israeli military alliance helped pressure Syria into peace negotiations with Israel in the late 1990's.
A strong, stable Turkish government would be even more needed if Saddam Hussein were to fall. Without Mr. Hussein, Iraq would have few ways to damp down divisive tribal and sectarian conflict, and the country could fall into civil strife. In that event, a stable Turkey would be necessary to safeguard Iraq's northern border with the Kurds. 
Turkey, in other words, is not a country like Thailand, where an economic crisis has only financial repercussions for the United States. Turkey is more in the category of an Israel or Mexico: a place whose strategic importance is too great to allow the White House to trust the International Monetary Fund and other international bodies with the cleanup operation.
The Reagan administration did not leave Israel, when it was ridden with inflation, to its own devices; the United States intervened to restructure the Israeli economy. The Clinton administration took aggressive action, at significant political cost, to bail out Mexico.
Both policies were successes. The Bush administration has stated its reluctance to prop up countries in economic turmoil. But in the case of Turkey, it may find it has no choice but to directly chaperone the Turkish political system toward further modernization, so that the current financial crisis does not expand into a geopolitical one. In short, the Bush administration should see the Turkish financial crisis less as a financial crisis than as a political and strategic one.

HEADLINE: Home Resales Slump in January 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 

 BODY:
Sales of previously owned homes fell sharply for a second consecutive month in January, the National Association of Realtors said today.
 Saying that the numbers are a sign that the Federal Reserve needs to cut interest rates further to keep the economy healthy, the association said existing-home sales plunged 6.6 percent in January, to an annual rate of 4.65 million units. 
That is the slowest sales rate since the 4.54 million in January 2000 and well below the 4.98 million level forecast by economists. 
 January's decline came after a similar 6.6 percent drop in December, when existing homes sold at a revised rate of 4.98 million units. The December figure was originally reported as 4.87 million.
David Lereah, chief economist at the association, said that he was concerned about the declines in existing-home sales, which make up about 80 percent of the overall housing market, and that aggressive interest rate reductions by the Fed earlier this year were not enough to halt the slide. In January, the Fed lowered its target for the federal funds rate on overnight loans between banks a full percentage point.
"Further declines in mortgage rates are now necessary," Mr. Lereah said.
"The performance of the housing sector is critical to whether this economy, generally speaking, slips into a recession or not."
The association said the median home price fell to $136,600 in January -- the lowest since $136,100 last April -- from $139,700 in December.

HEADLINE: Happy Skies of Continental; 
Satisfaction Is Up. Morale Is Up. So Is Profit.

BYLINE:  By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

DATELINE: HOUSTON 

 BODY:
Kevin Nguyen, a Continental Airlines flight attendant, was worried that he had done something wrong when he was called into the cockpit on a flight from Newark to Las Vegas. After Mr. Nguyen squeezed through the narrow door, one of the pilots told him that Gordon M. Bethune, Continental's chairman, was on the line.
 "Then I really thought I was in trouble," Mr. Nguyen recalled. 
 But Mr. Bethune had good news. Mr. Nguyen had won a new Ford Explorer, one of eight that Continental raffles off twice a year to workers with perfect job attendance for the previous six months. 
"I couldn't believe it," said Mr. Nguyen, who emigrated from Vietnam in 1981 and has worked at Continental since 1997.
Neither could Wendy Pignataro, a Tampa reservations agent, who had been car pooling to work since 1993. Or Fred Miller, a 757 pilot. They and the five other winners received their prizes last month before hundreds of fellow employees at a raucous ceremony at the airline's headquarters here. "All I did was come to work like I'm supposed to, and they gave me a car," Mr. Miller said. "I am so impressed with that."
These are not happy times for most workers in the airline industry. All four of the country's largest carriers -- United Airlines, American Airlines, Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines -- are facing possible strikes in the coming months by pilots, flight attendants or mechanics. Many workers are so frustrated with management that they have deliberately upset their airline's operations, inconveniencing passengers, to express their irritation. 
By contrast, at Continental, the nation's fifth-largest airline, it is a season of celebration. And one big reason for the turnaround is that the company, once a prime symbol of labor strife, can now lay claim to having the industry's highest morale.
A week before the Explorer giveaway, Continental declared Jan. 22 to be Independence Day. Each of its 54,000 employees received $100 to celebrate the airline's purchase of a controlling stake that had been held by Northwest. On Feb. 14, Mr. Bethune and Greg Brenneman, Continental's president, were handing out checks again, this time a share of Continental's profits equal to about 4 percent of every worker's salary.
Then there are the countless company picnics, ice cream parties, barbecues, and turkey and fried chicken dinners that dot the calendar throughout the year.
The benefits, which add little to the airline's costs, translate directly to the bottom line. Last year, Continental turned a profit for the sixth consecutive year. At the same time, Continental ranked first last year in the Transportation Department's on-time rankings and it consistently scores high in customer satisfaction surveys.
"It is not an accident that the best places to work are also the places that make the most money," Mr. Bethune said.
But only a few years ago, managers at United and Northwest were singing much the same song about their relations with employees. Today, they are widely considered to be the two carriers with the biggest labor headaches.
Executives at rival airlines say Continental's management -- for all its Mr. Nice Guy approach today -- has actually been coasting on the legacy of Frank Lorenzo, the former chief executive who abrogated Continental's union contracts in the early 1980's. Mr. Lorenzo got rid of most of the airline's unionized workers before hiring some back at greatly reduced salaries and benefits. As a result, Continental today enjoys much more flexible work rules and lower wage rates than its rivals.
"That honeymoon in the next two or three years is going to be over," said an executive at a competing carrier, noting that Continental may be experiencing a lull now because its labor contracts come up for renewal after everyone else's.
The airline industry's long boom may also be coming to an end as the economy weakens. Continental's profits, while still better than the industry average, declined last year after five consecutive years of increases.
Continental's pilots are already complaining that their wages and pension benefits have fallen far behind their peers at other airlines and they are looking for big gains when they begin contract negotiations next year. 
"Gordon has done a great job," said Pat Burke, president of the pilots union. "But before he got here, for 17 years since 1983, the pilots have been carrying this company. 
"There might be turmoil if they don't come up to bat," he added. "But I hope that won't happen."
The Lorenzo years have certainly been a boon to Continental's current managers, if only as a point of comparison. Because seniority is so important for many airline workers, few change companies. Many of Continental's current workers remember the lean years of the 1980's and early 1990's, when the airline filed for bankruptcy twice and appeared to be headed for oblivion.
"I started the week we went into bankruptcy 10 years ago," said Gayle Schulze, a crew pay analyst who came to watch the Explorer winners receive their keys from Mr. Bethune and Mr. Brenneman. "It is now 300 times better. What helps a lot is Gordon and Greg. Their personalities enthuse everybody. They're funny. I love listening to them speak."
Happier, more motivated workers, have produced more contented passengers in an industry not known for pleasing its customers. Continental ranked first in the latest customer satisfaction survey conducted by J. D. Power & Associates for both short- and long-haul flights. 
Michael Taylor, director of travel services at J. D. Power, said Continental had won the top rating among more than 6,000 frequent fliers surveyed -- even with one of its three hubs, at Newark, being among the most delay-prone airports in the country. "That is strictly due to the hustle of their people," Mr. Taylor said.
And Continental has won these plaudits despite not adding more legroom in coach, as American and United have done recently. Mr. Bethune, with characteristic bite, said Continental already offered a section with more legroom: "It's called first class."
A former Navy airplane mechanic who can press the flesh as well as any politician, Mr. Bethune delights in being the airline's chief cheerleader. He grew up in San Antonio and landed at Continental in 1994 after working as an executive at Piedmont Airlines and Boeing.
Continental had recently emerged from bankruptcy and was in danger of going broke yet again. After a rocky start, Mr. Bethune, now 59, and Mr. Brenneman, 39, a former management consultant, put together a successful strategy to expand Continental's presence at Newark and Houston and turn around morale. Today, the two men, along with Larry Kellner, 42, Continental's chief financial officer, are considered by Wall Street to be one of the top executive teams in the airline industry. They are also among the highest paid.
Not long after arriving, Mr. Bethune said he realized Continental's workers wanted to succeed but were beaten down by years of cost-cutting and management by fear. To this weary group, he announced that he was going to make Continental an enjoyable place to work.
"It didn't take much," said Mr. Burke, the pilot leader, who was in the habit of changing out of his uniform before leaving the airport in the early 1990's because he was ashamed of working for Continental. "Just a little dignity and respect and some pats on the back."
Cash and prizes did not hurt, either.
Every employee now receives at least $65 for each month that Continental ranks among the top three on-time airlines by the Transportation Department, or completes at least 80 percent of its flights on schedule. (The prize rises to $100 for every month that Continental ranks first.) Over the last six years, the bonuses have totaled $157 million, half of what the airline said delayed flights would cost in terms of hotels and other passenger compensation.
By the same token, the 83 Ford sport utility vehicles Continental has given away since 1996 have saved about $20 million by reducing the airline's rate of absenteeism, Jo Richard, Continental's director of human resources, said.
Mr. Kellner, the chief financial officer, said: "Three to four celebrations a year cost us $20 an employee. Compare that to our payroll, and you can't find it. But those are the things people remember."
Indeed, the Explorer giveaway has been a huge hit with employees. More than 14,000, or about one-third of Continental's employees, qualified in the most recent six-month period.
At Mr. Bethune's instance, the Explorers are the special Eddie Bauer edition with leather interiors and lots of extras. He did not want any worker to doubt that Continental would offer them the top of the line.
He also insisted that the airline pay all the taxes and license fees so that the winners, many of whom make modest salaries, could afford to keep the car. When United offered workers the choice of a Jeep Cherokee or $25,000 in cash in a similar contest a few years ago, not a single worker took the car.
"I want all their friends to see it," Mr. Bethune said of the Explorers, each of which bears a special Continental identification plate. "And when they ask, 'How can I win a car like that?' the answer is, all you have to do is show up for work."
Workers with perfect attendance who are not lucky enough to win an Explorer receive a $50 gift certificate. The amount of the gift increases with each consecutive six-month period that workers go without missing a day of work, peaking at $300 after three years.
When not handing out cash and S.U.V.'s, Mr. Bethune works hard at communicating with employees. He and Mr. Brenneman hold monthly open houses where workers can come and ask questions. They hand out chicken dinners, help load bags on the busiest holidays and generally make the rounds. Every Friday, Mr. Bethune records a voice mail message to employees.
As a result, Mr. Bethune is one of the most visible airline chief executives in the industry. Walking through Bush International Airport in Houston recently, he stopped frequently for dozens of employees who wanted to shake his hand or who called out greetings. A ramp supervisor asked if Mr. Bethune would break away from an interview for a few minutes to meet his crew. He happily obliged.
A master of the down-home aphorism, Mr. Bethune likes to boil things down to simple metaphors, often sprinkling his comments with obscenities. "If your watch stopped every other day, would you wear it?" he asked a new class of flight attendants, many of whom eagerly snapped his picture when he got up to speak. "You would throw it away. It's of no value to you. We cannot be good one day and lousy the next."
Mr. Bethune is confident that Continental's employee relations will not sour the way they have at the other major airlines. He has said repeatedly that he is willing to negotiate a new contract giving his mechanics and pilots what their peers are getting at competing carriers. That is all the unions say they want; the test is still to come. But Mr. Bethune clearly understands what is at stake.
"It's easier to run a good airline than a lousy one," he said. "Why wouldn't we want to keep it up?"

HEADLINE: Cash Crunch Imperils High School Football 

BYLINE:  By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: MOBILE, Ala., Feb. 22 

 BODY:
Harold W. Dodge, the superintendent of the Mobile County school system, is a brave man. At least, that is one way to look at it.
 Facing state-imposed budget cuts because of plummeting tax collections, Dr. Dodge proposed a series of measures last week to bring his $430 million budget into balance. Some were predictable, like not filling vacancies, canceling textbook orders and selling surplus property. Others were not, like delaying the opening of school until Oct. 1, the start of the county's fiscal year, in order to ease the system's cash-flow problems. 
 But one proposal has set this community on fire, making some residents question whether Dr. Dodge has any idea where he lives. To save $1.3 million in supplemental salaries paid each year to coaches and band directors, Dr. Dodge has proposed eliminating all extracurricular activities, including football and other sports. 
That would be a radical notion in any state. In Alabama, it is closer to sacrilege.
Friday nights without high school football in sports-crazed Mobile "would be like having Catholicism without the pope," said Bonnie Hebert, a math teacher at Ben C. Rain High School.
Paul H. Christopher, the manager of Ladd-Peebles Stadium, the city-owned field where Friday night games can attract close to 20,000 fans, said the entire community was up in arms. "Football in this part of the country is more than a sport," Mr. Christopher explained, noting that a dozen active professional players came from the area. "It's first cousin to a religion."
Dr. Dodge's proposal to cut football and other programs starkly illustrates the consequences of the declining revenues that have started to plague state and local governments as the economy softens, particularly in the South and Midwest. Revenues from the sales tax and income tax that support Alabama's education trust fund fell $266 million behind projections in the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30, and dropped another $72 million in the first quarter of the current year.
Though his cuts have not been enacted, Dr. Dodge insists that he is not bluffing. But he also hopes that the prospect of a fall without football will startle Mobile into raising school taxes -- an idea voters rejected two years ago by a 3-to-1 ratio. 
Clearly, he has succeeded in getting people's attention, although not all of it is welcome.
His nervous security detail has stepped up its patrols of his house. His wife has tired of donning her nicest gowns for the city's famous Mardi Gras balls, only to spend her evenings listening to other partygoers berate her husband. After giving up cigarettes for five weeks, Dr. Dodge has started smoking again. It was the stress, he said.
"I knew it might be superintendent suicide," he acknowledged in an interview. "My secretary's fielded more calls than you can imagine from people saying, 'You've lost your damn mind.' "
But feeling that he has few alternatives, Dr. Dodge has proceeded anyway. Indeed, even after a Circuit Court judge in Montgomery ruled that Gov. Don Siegelman's education cuts were unconstitutional, the Mobile superintendent has continued to press his plan. The court ruling, he reasoned, was simply the first shot in what will surely become a drawn-out legal and political battle.
A state law required Governor Siegelman, a Democrat from Mobile, to impose a 6.2 percent midyear cut in education spending to match the drop in the trust fund. Under that law, the state has little discretion in how to make the cuts, and Mr. Siegelman has called a special legislative session to seek more flexibility.
But the state financial crisis is only part of the problem in Mobile. With 66,000 students, Mobile has the largest school system in the state. In 1999, the county spent $640 per student in local money, almost a third less than the state average, according to state figures.
Simply raising the local contribution to the state average would more than close this year's shortfall of $15 million. But residents of this Gulf Coast city have long resisted the local tax increases needed to finance their schools adequately. Voters have rejected tax increases for the schools three times since 1988. 
Many here hold the school system accountable for a two-decade-old corruption scandal that led to the conviction of several county and school system leaders for malfeasance. 
And though some here disagree, Dr. Dodge says he believes that many white property owners are reluctant to raise taxes to support a public school system that is about half black.
Without a tax increase, Dr. Dodge maintains, his options are limited. Nearly 90 percent of his budget goes to salaries and benefits and cannot be touched because of contracts. In his three years as superintendent, he has cut his budget by nearly $11 million. The school system finished the last fiscal year with only $161,000 in the bank, not enough to support even a single day's operations. 
The county commission has proposed a referendum for May 1 to consider a 69 percent increase in the property tax rate for schools, a larger increase than the one rejected two years ago. The referendum is first subject to the approval of the State Legislature, where passage is far from guaranteed. 
At least, Dr. Dodge said, his proposals seem to have focused the county's attention on the realities of the school system's financial needs. Students and teachers have helped make the case. To illustrate the impact of Dr. Dodge's proposed cuts, the county's music directors pulled their marching bands out of Mardi Gras parades.
"What's incredible to me is that you have to disassemble something to get people to believe you," Dr. Dodge said. "People thought I was the Antichrist when I proposed to cut athletics. But when I said the F-word -- in Alabama that's football -- it was like I had finally hit the mule on the right end."
That provides little solace at the moment to Jamarcus T. Russell, a 15-year-old sophomore quarterback for Williamson High School who is considered one of the most promising athletes ever to play here. In his first two years, Mr. Russell passed for 5,299 yards and 40 touchdowns, leading his Lions once to the state championship game and once to the semifinals.
He has received letters from dozens of major collegiate programs, including Florida State, Tennessee and Notre Dame. But he assumes their interest will wane if he cannot play his final two years. 
Without a football scholarship, Mr. Russell might manage to attend a local college. But even by taking on extra work, his mother, Zina L. Russell-Anderson, a machine operator in a furniture factory, said she would not be able to send her son out of state. 
"They're stealing something that I want to become," Mr. Russell said.
Johnny L. Keith, the quarterback at Murphy High School, said his father would send him to college if he did not receive a scholarship. "But it's just that dream," Mr. Keith said, "of getting that scholarship and taking that burden off of your parents."
Last year, Mobile County students won college athletic scholarships worth $2.4 million. 
But there are other consequences. Teachers and parents here say that football and other sports give students an incentive to make the grades needed to play in college, and that they keep youths off the streets in the afternoon. "The crime rate is going to go sky high," said Kathy C. Dyess, a technology aide at Ben C. Rain High School.
Some parents are considering sending their children to private school. Others have talked about moving to neighboring Baldwin County, where the fiscal problems are less severe.
Ms. Dyess, though committed to her county and to the public schools, is one of them. "I'm thinking about leaving, really," she said. "I've only got a third grader, but he's very sports-oriented and I've got to plan for the future."

HEADLINE: Israel's Unity Government 

 BODY:
Israel's Labor Party acted responsibly yesterday by voting to join a national unity government under the Likud Party leader, Ariel Sharon. Crucial details are yet to be worked out, including Labor's new leadership and the identity of its cabinet nominees. But the important portfolios Labor will hold, including the Defense and Foreign Ministries, should permit it to exert a moderating influence on the new government's policies. 
 This will be particularly important on issues like military tactics against Palestinian unrest and future relations with Yasir Arafat and other Arab leaders. Already Labor has secured a commitment to the principle of trading land for peace and an affirmation of existing agreements like the 1993 Oslo accords with the Palestinians. 
 Labor's decision frees Mr. Sharon from dependence on the narrow coalition of right-wing and religious parties that he would otherwise have needed for a parliamentary majority. Neither he nor Israeli voters wanted to see the new government beholden from the start to these fractious and ideological groups. By joining with Labor, Mr. Sharon commits himself to a broadly centrist course. But for a national unity government to be effective, it must be more than a facade. Labor ministers must be consulted on important policies and given authority to run their departments. 
The new Israeli government will inherit a difficult situation when it takes office next month. Peace talks with the Palestinians have collapsed. Violent unrest in the West Bank and Gaza Strip is about to enter its sixth month. Anti-Israeli rhetoric from Syria, Iraq and Iran is becoming increasingly belligerent. Mr. Sharon and his ministers must protect Israel's security while looking for ways to renew the search for peace to which both Labor and Likud have made major contributions over the years. 
To this end, Israel should give serious consideration to Secretary of State Colin Powell's suggestion over the weekend that it look for ways to ease economic pressures on the Palestinians. In a welcome early response to this American suggestion, Israel agreed to dismantle the military checkpoints that had briefly cut Gaza in two. Further Israeli steps, like a release of tax revenues to the Palestinian Authority, would be more likely if Mr. Arafat began living up to his commitments to discourage further violence.
Some Labor leaders argued for remaining outside the Sharon government, so that the party could rebuild its public support and re-energize its strategy for peace negotiations. But they were decisively outvoted by those who felt that forcing Mr. Sharon to form a narrow right-wing coalition would be dangerous for Israel at a particularly difficult moment in its history. That wiser view has now prevailed.

HEADLINE: Chiang Mai Journal; 
A Courageous Editor's Lonely Quest

BYLINE:  By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: CHIANG MAI, Thailand 

 BODY:
It's not much of a newspaper office three little computers and an ailing 30-year-old printing press squeezed into a converted beauty salon. But it's a pretty good bunker.
 In a tiny inner office, a black .38-caliber pistol lies on the editor's desk near a handful of hollow-tip bullets. A bulletproof vest is slung over the back of a chair. The small, thick-walled press room is just a step away. 
 "If they come after me again," said the editor, Amnat Jongyotying, 46, "there's not much chance they'll walk out of here. I don't care how many times I'm hit; if I can take just one of them with me I'll be satisfied. They know I'm ready for them. I'm a dangerous person now." 
Despite his bravado, Mr. Amnat admits that he is terrified. Last spring, four gunmen almost killed him with a bullet through his abdomen after he refused to stop his relentless newspaper attacks on the local political kingpin.
Now, despite bribery attempts and threats to him and his family, he is going after his attackers in court as well as in print. What was once a journalistic mission of investigative reporting has become a personal vendetta. Mr. Amnat is convinced that he is in a fight to the death.
"I don't have any choice," he said. "If I win I die, and if I lose I die. In Thailand we have a saying: 'If you break the back of a snake, make sure you kill it or it will come back and bite you.' I'm like the snake. Their big mistake was that they didn't kill me."
Thailand has some of the freest news media in Asia. But as in many developing countries, the life of a provincial journalist can be dangerous, far from the sight of the outside world and a long way from the reach of the law. There are two choices: bow to the power of the local politician or go to war.
"My sense of it is that most provincial reporters stay away from that kind of warlord story because they know what is at stake and what they risk," said A. Lin Neumann, the Asia consultant for the New York-based Committee to Protect Journalists.
"Amnat, for whatever reason, is one of those unusual fellows who is absolutely bound and determined to do the kind of journalism he thinks is right," Mr. Neumann said. "He's not a nut. He is just particularly driven to make that little newspaper of his into something that can change Chiang Mai. And as a result he almost died, and he still could die."
Mr. Amnat said he had told his children, "If I can make Chiang Mai a better place, even a little bit, that is something you should be proud of."
Mr. Amnat's wife, Phongpan, who sold her land, gave up her beauty business and took journalism courses to help him open the paper 11 years ago, is risking her life as well.
"After he was shot, I tried to make him stop," said Mrs. Phongpan, who runs the business side of the newspaper. "When he got out of the hospital, he was afraid. He wouldn't hold me at night. He would only hold his gun and his bulletproof vest."
All but a handful of his staff members quit. The local kingpin spread the word and advertisers withdrew their business. His teenage son and daughter were receiving threatening calls on the office telephone.
"I tried not working and not bringing any money in, but he went ahead and did everything himself," Mrs. Phongpan said. "I stood there and watched him, in his shorts, doing the layout by himself, putting out all 12 pages without staff. That's when I realized I couldn't stop him. His life is the paper. And I said to myself, 'I give in.' "
She smiled at her husband. "Sometimes I joke with him," she said. "He sits in the back office and I'm out front. I'll probably be the one to take the bullet."
But no matter how hard they both work, the little newspaper, called The Northern Daily, may not survive. The paper is deeply in debt and losing money with every issue. It has shrunk from 16 pages, eliminated color and reduced its frequency from every day to once every three days.
Squeezed by Thailand's economic recession three years ago, the paper's circulation in this northern city of 300,000 people dropped from a high of 10,000 to just 1,000. With the attack on Mr. Amnat, demand suddenly rose. "When I was shot, I was hurt, yes," he said. "But it was great for circulation."
But still his print run is limited to 2,000 copies; he cannot afford the cost of paper to print more.
Some of the staff members who have stayed with him now carry guns too, he said, adding, "My reporters are also my bodyguards." Everybody does a bit of everything, gathering in the press room on print days to fold the newspaper by hand.
As he struggles to keep his newspaper alive, Mr. Amnat continues to publish the critical articles other papers leave alone, including the twists and turns of his own case.
"I want people to know what is going on in Chiang Mai," he said. "We have to keep an eye on our politicians, see what they are up to, see how they cheat. During the last election I ran a headline: 'It's Cheaper to Buy a Vote Than to Buy a Dog.' People liked that article."
Chiang Mai is ruled by the kind of old-style clique -- Mr. Amnat calls it a mafia -- that still holds influence throughout much of Thailand. From the start, Mr. Amnat said, he was determined to do the kind of probing journalism that is generally found only in big, powerful national papers.
Although his newspaper may be popular enough, few people want to have anything to do with him. Insurance companies have declined to cover him. People are afraid to sit near him in restaurants. Even his sister and brother refuse to travel in the same car with him. 
"They say, 'If you're going to die, don't take us with you,' " he said.
He is conspicuous around town, looking a bit like a penguin with his oversize shirts buttoned over his bulletproof vest. His fellow journalists have turned their backs, he said, asking him, "Why do you have to make such a big deal out of this?"
In an effort to put pressure on a reluctant prosecutor to proceed, he took 20 local reporters with him last year to demand that charges of attempted murder be brought against the four gunmen. But, bribed or threatened, none of the local newspapers -- apart from The Northern Daily -- reported on his demand.
The assassination attempt itself was a big one-day story in the national press and was condemned by the Thai Journalists Association. But it passed almost unnoticed here in Chiang Mai.
As someone who was a police reporter 28 years ago, Mr. Amnat has high-ranking friends on the force, and some of them are providing protection for him. On the day of the shooting, the police arrested the four gunmen as they waited by their pickup truck, confident of their impunity, at a local carwash.
But that is about as far as things have gone.
Mr. Amnat gathered 30 witnesses who had seen the shooting or could recount the movements of the gunmen. But only two -- one of them his 18-year-old daughter -- are now willing to testify. And like his fellow reporters, his former advertisers, his family members and his witnesses, Mr. Amnat said, local lawyers have shied away from him.
"At the first hearing, the court assigned a lawyer to the case," Mr. Amnat said, "but when he found out who is behind it, he said, 'Well, I'll just stay behind the scenes.' "
Mr. Amnat is still pushing the case in the courts, but he guesses that it may take three years or more to reach any kind of resolution. Even then, it is unlikely that the man he holds responsible will ever be charged.
"It is the rule of gunmen never to disclose the person who hired them," said Thongbai Thongpao, a human rights lawyer in Bangkok who is familiar with the case. "They are also afraid. The hand of the law can never touch the mastermind who is behind hired gunmen."
Mr. Amnat knows that, but it no longer seems to matter.
"Maybe I'm a little crazy," he said. "I've never been afraid of powerful people. Some of my friends say: 'Don't you love your wife and kids? If you love them you should stop all this.' I do love them, but I can't stop."
Mr. Amnat has never confronted the man he believes wanted him killed, but he cherishes a little fantasy about meeting him.
"When I see him in a public place," he said, "I just want to go step on his toe and ask him, 'Why did you have me shot?' But if I did that, I'd probably be dead."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Amnat Jongyotying, editor of The Northern Daily, with his wife, Phongpan. A crusading journalist, Mr. Amnat was almost killed. (Seth Mydans/The New York Times) Map of Thailand highlights Chiang Mai: Far from the outside world's sight, Chiang Mai is ruled by a clique.

HEADLINE: U.S. Finds Rights Abuses in China, Colombia and Israel 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 

 BODY:
The State Department concluded today that despite seven years of deepening American economic engagement with China, the human rights situation there had worsened significantly, with "intensified crackdowns" on religious organizations, political dissenters and "any person or group perceived to threaten the government."
 The department's annual review of human rights in 195 countries and territories, the Bush administration's first, also offered a harsh assessment of how Israel dealt with Palestinian uprisings last year. It described Indonesia as a nation increasingly out of control, where random killings and lawlessness are becoming the norms. 
 And the report concluded that Colombia, whose president, Andres Pastrana, is to meet Mr. Bush in the White House on Tuesday, is far from bringing paramilitary groups under control. 
In what could prove a particularly sensitive section, the report concludes that in Colombia, where the United States is providing a $1.3 billion, two-year aid package, mostly military, "paramilitary forces find a ready support base within the military and police, as well as among local civilian elites in many areas." 
While the report praises President Pastrana, it denounces massacres and abuses by private and government security forces in the struggle against leftist rebels.
The department's report was assembled and drafted largely during the Clinton administration. But Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and the national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, had time to review the findings and in a few sensitive chapters, particularly on Israel, to alter some wording, Bush administration officials said.
Today the administration, as expected, announced that the United States would pursue a resolution condemning China's record at the United Nations Human Rights Commission, which is to meet in Geneva next month. The Clinton administration never succeeded in getting enough countries to join in the annual resolution to win passage, and it is unclear how much political capital the Bush administration is willing to expend to win support for a resolution that is almost certain to be defeated once again.
But the report poses a deeper problem for Mr. Bush: He must now choose the best path for influencing the rights records of other nations, a issue that vexed his predecessor for eight years.
Mr. Clinton insisted that over time, economic engagement with China would force the government to loosen its control over the political process. There is little evidence yet that the strategy is working, though the acting assistant secretary for human rights, Michael Parmly, noted today that "the Internet has resulted in some improvements" in China, "largely in spite of government actions to control it."
But he noted that in dealings in Tibet and in the crackdown on the Falun Gong and other religious groups, "the situation has worsened in significant areas."
At the same time, the report is also harshly critical of conditions in three countries where the United States has maintained nearly a full economic embargo: Cuba, Myanmar and North Korea. In each, the report found conditions were no better, and in some cases were worse.
Critics of both approaches -- engagement and isolation -- will find ammunition in the voluminous report (so voluminous that the State Department now publishes it only on a CD-ROM and on its Web site, www .state.gov).
"Their dilemma is the same as the one Clinton faced," said Mike Jendrzejczyk, who follows Asia for Human Rights Watch. "It hasn't changed one iota. The issue hasn't been whether to engage, but how."
An early test of whether the administration plans to turn the findings into new policy may come as General Powell pursues the resolution against China. 
He and Mr. Bush could press Mexico, or European allies, to support the resolution, or they could save their political influence for another issue. Diplomats at the State Department said it is too early to know how far General Powell is willing to go. 
Clinton administration officials who worked on the early drafts of the report said today that after their brief review of it on the Internet, it appears largely unchanged. 
"The key was Israel," one said, "and there they left the main conclusion, which is that there was excessive force on the Israeli side, and human rights violations on the Palestinian side as well."
On Colombia, the report concluded that while "the government's human rights record remained poor," still "there were some improvements in the legal framework and in institutional mechanisms." 
The report for the first time explicitly discussed links between the United States-backed Colombian security forces and paramilitary groups, whose attacks are increasing, saying such collusion ranged from allowing the militia members to pass through roadblocks to sharing intelligence and ammunition.
President Pastrana, who was in Washington today, said his government was developing a strategy to crack down on such groups, including efforts to disrupt their financing. He said conditions "are improving, though there is still much work to be done in this area."
Despite a similarly grim portrait of conditions in Colombia last year, President Clinton waived a series of human rights benchmarks mandated by Congress in order for the military aid to flow. 
Bush officials say their Colombia policy is still under review.

HEADLINE: The Citibank Connection: Real Money, Shadow Banks 

BYLINE:  By TIM GOLDEN 

 BODY:
At the climax of one of the biggest undercover money-laundering investigation in United States history, federal agents seized $1.8 million in 1998 from Citibank accounts in New York that were held by a mysterious Cayman Islands bank that had no corporate offices anywhere in the world.
 But despite indications that the money had come from drug dealers in Mexico, Citibank continued to do business with the Caymans bank for almost two years, moving another $300 million through the accounts before they were finally closed by Citibank. 
 Officials of Citibank and its parent company, Citigroup Inc., said they had not realized that anything might be amiss with the Caymans bank, which was tied to a financial group in Argentina led by the former treasury secretary there. And they emphasized that they have since developed a system for processing official seizures to avoid such mistakes. 
Yet interviews with government investigators and a new study of the case by the Democratic staff of a Senate subcommittee raise questions about Citibank's slow response to the indications that something was wrong with the operations of the Caymans bank, M. A. Bank Ltd.
"They weren't just asleep at the switch -- they were in a deep sleep on this one," Senator Carl Levin, a Michigan Democrat who oversaw the Senate inquiry, said of Citibank. "Even after the seizure warrant, they continued to accept deposits from M. A. Bank without due diligence."
Both the government investigators and money-laundering experts said the case was striking evidence of how criminals have been able to move illicit funds surreptitiously through accounts that offshore banks keep at big institutions in the United States.
Those so-called correspondent accounts provide tiny foreign banks that are subject to little government regulation with access to the American financial system. As many as 2,000 such banks are scattered around the world, mostly in small island nations in the Caribbean, the South Pacific and elsewhere.
M. A. Bank, which was licensed in 1991, was a classic shell: It never had so much as an office in the Caymans, and its supposed administrative headquarters in Uruguay was nothing more than the address of an accounting firm that processed its correspondence, the Senate report said. At least part of the millions of dollars wired into its accounts in New York were then paid out in cash in Argentina to a local real estate agent later identified by American officials as a representative of the Mexican drug traffickers.
To bankers at Citigroup, however, M. A. Bank drew legitimacy from being part of the Mercado Abierto Group, a financial group based in Buenos Aires that had been a Citibank client since 1989. The group is owned by three well-known economic officials of the military governments that ruled that country until the early 1980's, the most prominent of whom, Aldo Luis Ducler, served as treasury secretary then and is now the group's president.
Federal and Senate investigators suggested that Citibank officials had considerable reason to grow suspicious of M. A. Bank after May 18, 1998, when they were ordered to seize the $1.8 million -- all that was left of $7.7 million that Mexican drug traffickers had funneled through the account. The warrant presented to Citibank cited federal money-laundering laws as grounds for the confiscation. 
The warrant was also delivered just as the Clinton administration was presenting what it called Operation Casablanca, in which Customs agents uncovered a network of Mexican and Venezuelan banks that were helping Mexico's biggest drug traffickers to hide their profits.
The affidavit filed in federal court in Los Angeles in support of the Citibank seizure clearly tied it to the undercover investigation.
Nonetheless, Citibank officials told Senate staff members that it was only when the investigators approached them with questions about their handling of the M. A. Bank account -- 17 months after the seizure -- that they finally linked the seizure to drug trafficking.
Several American officials asserted that the Customs agents who ran the Casablanca investigation could have been more aggressive in pursuing the Argentine connection.
The Argentine real estate agent to whom Citibank paid the money in Buenos Aires had been put in touch with undercover agents by the man then considered Mexico's biggest drug trafficker, Amado Carrillo Fuentes, the American officials said.
And according to a forfeiture complaint filed by the federal government, the real estate agent and Mr. Ducler, of the Mercado Abierto Group, set up the accounts on behalf of a former Mexican federal police official convicted in the United States of drug smuggling.
In a telephone interview from Buenos Aires, Mr. Ducler denied ever having met the former police official, and said he never had any clue that the real estate agent, now a fugitive from Argentine justice, was representing Mexican traffickers. 
He emphasized that about one-third of the $1.8 million seized was later returned in a settlement, and that the illegal funds wired to M. A. Bank's account with Citibank had originated in an undercover Customs Service account at Bank of America. 
"No illicit money could ever have come into our bank had it not come in an undercover operation, and from an institution of the first rank, like the Bank of America," he said. "Not only did we not infect the financial system of the United States, but it was the United States' undercover operation that infected us with illicit funds."

HEADLINE: Daimler Anticipates A Hard Year, LosingPerhaps $1.5 Billion 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: STUTTGART, Germany, Feb. 26 

 BODY:
With his career and the fate of the world's biggest auto merger hanging in the balance, the chairman and chief executive of DaimlerChrysler A.G. announced his plans for a turnaround today but forecast a grim year ahead.
 The executive, Jurgen E. Schrempp, warned that Chrysler's American car and truck business would lose $2 billion to $2.5 billion this year and would not break even until some time in 2002. 
 Today's announcement came about four months after Chrysler, in sharp contrast to Mr. Schrempp's ebullient forecasts, startled investors with its huge losses. The presentation today also reinforced that DaimlerChrysler is now a fully German-run company. 
As a light snow fell outside the packed conference hall here, Mr. Schrempp seemed determined to get all the bad news out. To pay for the costs of reducing the Chrysler unit's work force by 26,000, DaimlerChrysler will take a charge against earnings of nearly $3 billion and will report a first-quarter operating loss of about $4 billion. For the full year, executives estimated that the parent company could lose $1.5 billion or so.
But aside from saying that "a few things have not worked out," Mr. Schrempp brushed aside suggestions that his strategy of forming a global company was flawed.
And the tone today was markedly different from that in past presentations. When Mr. Schrempp proudly announced the merger between the former Daimler-Benz and Chrysler nearly three years ago, he declared that the company's official language would be English and he relished switching between English and German as he answered questions.
Today, he and all other executives on the podium spoke only German. There were no American executives on hand. A newly created automotive management committee will be headed by Mr. Schrempp and five other longtime Daimler executives from Stuttgart.
Saying repeatedly that Chrysler's financial troubles stemmed in part from "internal factors," Mr. Schrempp said that "a new competent leadership has been put in place." Indeed, since late in October, he has ousted most of Chrysler's top American managers and installed a trusted lieutenant, Dieter Zetsche, as Chrysler's president and chief executive.
Mr. Schrempp and Mr. Zetsche had already announced the main components of their turnaround plan. They include the 26,000 job reductions over the next two years, demands for immediate price cuts from suppliers, pushing ahead with the introduction of new Chrysler vehicles including a successor to the Jeep and the sharing of more of the underlying auto components among Mercedes, Chrysler and Mitsubishi Motors of Japan, one-third owned by Daimler.
But Mr. Schrempp is fighting fires on several fronts. Industry executives, at Chrysler as well as its rivals, predict that vehicle sales in the United States will decline by slightly more than 10 percent this year, to about 16 million. Deep discounting and other financial incentives can easily cut into revenue.
DaimlerChrysler is also wrestling with problems at Mitsubishi, which announced its own turnaround program today.
And the American truck subsidiary, Freightliner, started losing money in the second half of 2000 amid a downturn in the American truck market similar to Chrysler's problems in auto sales.
Mr. Schrempp seems to be running short on time. DaimlerChrysler's share price has declined by more than half from its peak in January 1999. In New York today, the company's American-listed shares closed down 68 cents at $48.12.
Deutsche Bank, DaimlerChrysler's biggest shareholder, with a 12 percent stake, again said today that it stood behind Mr. Schrempp. But even that statement had a backhanded chilliness, emphasizing the bank's confidence that Mr. Schrempp would begin to produce a turnaround "in the next 12 months."
Earlier this month, DaimlerChrysler hired Deutsche Bank and J. P. Morgan Chase to advise it on potential defense strategies if it became the target of a hostile takeover attempt.
For the moment, there are few signs that any rival is interested in a hostile takeover. But the old security that once characterized Germany's network of cross-shareholdings has largely evaporated, and even Deutsche Bank has said it wants to reduce its industrial company holdings.
Daimler executives took pains today to set cautious expectations. "The year 2000 was very difficult," said Manfred Gentz, the chief financial officer. "We have an even more difficult year ahead of us."
The company predicted that operating profit would decline to a level between 1.2 billion and 1.7 billion euros from about 5.2 billion euros in 2000, or $4.74 billion at current exchange rates. And that estimate does not include a Chrysler restructuring charge of $3 billion. Mr. Gentz, when pressed, said the final operating loss -- including the restructuring charge and possible one-time gains -- could be about 1.7 billion euros, or $1.55 billion.
A big question is whether DaimlerChrysler can make good on the unfulfilled promise of sharing components between Mercedes and Chrysler. So far, executives at Mercedes have been reluctant or downright hostile to sharing important components with Chrysler, fearing that the Mercedes brand might be cheapened.
Today, Mr. Zetsche and others listed a number of areas for greater sharing: electronic controls from seat warmers to monitoring systems, rear axles, transmissions and steering systems. 
Daimler has also said that it will put Mercedes diesel engines into a few Chrysler vehicles, like the PT Cruiser, but only in those sold in Europe.
There will be much more sharing between Chrysler and Mitsubishi. Chrysler already uses a Mitsubishi platform -- the unseen components beneath the body of the car -- for its Sebring and Dodge Stratus sedans. The plan now is to team up in building a new version of the compact Neon. Mitsubishi and Mercedes, separate from Chrysler, plan to cooperate on a new version of Mercedes' quirky subcompact, the Smart car.
But Mercedes' chief executive, Jurgen Hubbert, made clear that he had no intention of going beyond the sharing of components that are largely invisible to the typical car buyer. Mr. Hubbert said the company saw no need yet to supply Mercedes engines for use in American Chrysler cars. As for Mercedes platforms in Chrysler's American cars, he dismissed the idea as "kein thema" -- not a topic of discussion.

HEADLINE: Bitter Strike At Domino Finally Ends 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
Strikers at the mammoth Domino Sugar refinery in Brooklyn agreed yesterday to return to work, ending the city's longest labor battle in what even union leaders acknowledged was a stinging loss.
 The 20-month strike had become a major test for the local labor movement, with 284 workers holding out on the picket line for nine months at one of Brooklyn's few remaining large manufacturing operations. 
 But the strikers gradually started crossing the picket line, feeling abandoned by their parent union and the labor movement at large.
"It's a complete loss," acknowledged Joe Crimi, the chief negotiator for the strikers, who work at the 143-year-old refinery, a symbol of New York's onetime manufacturing might. 
Under the new contract, approved on Friday in a ratification vote by members of Local 1814 of the International Longshoremen's Association, Domino will be allowed to cut 110 jobs at the refinery. The three-year contract, union officials said, also provides for a one-time 5 percent raise on top of the workers' average weekly base pay of about $600.
For the first nine months of the strike, the 284 unionized workers showed extraordinary solidarity, without anyone crossing the picket line. But then they cracked, with workers crossing the picket line in fives and tens because their unemployment insurance had expired and because, they said, they were convinced that the walkout was making little headway. 
By last weekend, 104 former strikers had crossed the picket line, and the company insisted that production had long been back to normal. The workers who remained on strike felt so little hope that they voted 56 to 48 to approve the contract, which was little different from a management proposal that they unanimously rejected four months ago.
The strikers blamed their parent union for doing little for them -- it did not even provide strike benefits. They blamed the labor movement for turning its back on them by not rallying to their cause. They blamed their co-workers for crossing the picket line. And they accused the president of their union local of selling them out to put this embarrassing fight behind them.
"We got shafted," said Charles Milan, who has worked for 37 years in the refinery's packaging department. "We got stabbed in the back."
Domino Sugar, a division of Tate & Lyle, a British company that is one of the world's largest sweetener producers, praised the workers' decision to approve the contract.
In a news release, the company said the new agreement "provides substantial improvement in wages and benefits for union employees, and it also contains the operating flexibility which the company sought to improve competitiveness in the volatile U.S. cane sugar market."
The company repeatedly told the workers that it needed to reduce its work force because profits were down and because the company was starting to ship semiprocessed sugar to the Brooklyn refinery, rather than the traditional unrefined sugar.
"The resulting loss of some Brooklyn processing jobs has been eased by a generous enhanced severance package," the company said.
Jim McNamara, a spokesman for the International Longshoremen's Association, defended the role of the parent union, saying it gave the strikers generous support and even paid for union officials to travel to England to protest at a Tate & Lyle board meeting.
While company officials said it was time for union and management to work together, some workers acknowledged there would inevitably be tensions between those who crossed the picket line and those who remained on strike to the end. 
Charles Sekera, a machine operator, said he crossed the picket line last April, after being on strike for 10 months, because the strike was costing him a lot of money and because he was getting little information from his union.
"The union lost big-time," he said. "The union was out for more than a year and a half for nothing."
Denis Hughes, president of the New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O., said the strike seemed doomed from the start.
"It bothered me from the beginning that the union wasn't strong enough to put this together," he said. "It shows that even in the best of situations management has an enormous amount of power. One of the things we have to do better in the trade union movement is to develop strategies at the beginning of a dispute, instead of midway through."
Yesterday afternoon, the trailer that served as the center of the strike activities looked as if a hurricane had hit it. Empty Coke cans were everywhere, and the workers were tearing from the walls solidarity statements from other unions.
Hernando Gallego, a sugar boiler, conceded that he voted to approve management's proposal, saying, "I don't like the contract at all, but there's nothing to hold out for anymore."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Corrie Ann Daniels and other union members dismantled their strike headquarters outside the Domino Sugar refinery in Brooklyn yesterday. (Justin Lane for The New York Times)(pg. B6)

HEADLINE: Elizabeth Police Say Man Shot by Officers Wanted to Be Killed 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 26 

 BODY:
 A man who yelled that he was armed but was only holding a Bible -- was fatally shot here this weekend by a police officer, the authorities said. They said they believed he wanted the police to kill him. 
 The man, Mark Frederick Venuti, 36, was shot twice and was pronounced dead at 1:39 a.m. Sunday at University Hospital in Newark. 
The Elizabeth Police said they had received three calls about 10 p.m. on Saturday, one of them possibly made by Mr. Venuti, from a building at 819 Canton Street, where he lived in a basement apartment.
When two officers went to the address, Mr. Venuti yelled at them from behind his apartment door that he was armed, the police said. He then opened the door, and, holding a dark object above his head, charged one of the officers, who shot him once, they said. The wounded man then turned to the other officer, the police said, and demanded to be shot. When the officer refused, Mr. Venuti again charged the first officer, who shot him a second time. He fell to the floor, and the officers saw for the first time that the object in his hand was a Bible, the police said.
Robert O'Leary, first assistant Union County prosecutor, said the officers' actions were being reviewed. 
The authorities said Mr. Venuti had a history of depression and may have wanted the officers to kill him. 
One of the callers, Paul Korkidas, 60, a neighbor, said Mr. Venuti tried to break down his door only moments before the police arrived. Another neighbor, Doreen Navarro, 42, an unemployed day care worker, said she had seen Mr. Venuti walking into the building wearing only shorts and T-shirt just before the incident, asking no one in particular to call the police. "He looked upset," she said. 
Mr. Venuti's wife of 10 years, April Anthony Venuti, who was at a wedding when the shooting occurred, said her husband was unemployed and received disability payments for depression. She said the couple had decided to look for a new home.
"Mark did not do suicide by cop," she said. "We had plans."

HEADLINE: As Taxes Rise, Suburbs Work to Keep Elderly 

BYLINE:  By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: WEST WINDSOR, N.J., Feb. 26 

 BODY:
Suburbs have always had one big idea, to be comfortable and safe places for families with children. But local politicians here and around the country are working hard these days to cater to a new generation of suburban V.I.P.'s -- those retired couples in the three- or four-bedroom houses down the street. People like Fred and Mary Froehlich.
 The Froehlichs love the Cape that Mr. Froehlich built with his own hands 46 years ago, when West Windsor was mostly farmland and not the vast plain of expensive houses it has become. They love the way their five grown children still come home for family gatherings. What they do not love are the taxes, $6,000 a year, which happen to be the same as Mrs. Froehlich's annual Social Security benefit. 
 So like a lot of suburban retirees, Mr. Froelich is trying to persuade his wife to move, in their case to a spot in Delaware where taxes are a tenth of what they are here. But Mrs. Froehlich is resisting, and although she may not yet know it, she has an ally in Carole Carson, the mayor of West Windsor. 
For Ms. Carson has done the math and knows what it means when retirees move out and a new generation of families with children move in. It means more children swelling enrollment at local schools, more garbage to pick up, more cars on the road, more services generally.
Since it costs an average of $9,599 a year to send a child to the West Windsor-Plainsboro public schools -- up nearly 28 percent in the past five years -- even with state aid, one new child in the Froehlich's house would more than eat up the taxes the house produces. Two more would present the school district with a $20,000 annual education bill.
The impact of enrollment growth is especially severe in growing suburbs like West Windsor, a bedroom community of 20,000 near Princeton that has seen enrollment increase to 8,500 from about 5,000 10 years ago. While a small increase in enrollment might easily be absorbed in existing classrooms, the growth here has required two school construction referendums, in 1993 and again in 1996, in which voters approved spending a total of $114.7 million to build two new elementary schools, a new high school and an addition to an existing middle school.
So like other communities around the country, West Windsor is scrambling to find ways to keep as many elderly residents in their homes as long as possible. As the population ages, the development is already changing the face of suburbia. 
"It's a matter of cost-effectiveness, especially in a community like ours," said Ms. Carson. "The seniors are a tremendous asset to any community, and if you are not able to retain them, you end up, one, without the values they represent, and, two, with services that are much more expensive than if they stayed. So we need to do what we can to keep our seniors from moving away."
So Ms. Carson is leading a statewide drive to encourage retirees to stay in their family homes by reducing the punishing level of property taxation that, in conversation after conversation with retirees here, emerged as the No. 1 complaint of empty-nesters. 
In November, the New Jersey State League of Municipalities took up her cause and is now lobbying the State Legislature to increase the income eligibility for a state program that freezes the taxes for people over 65. A version of this idea has been introduced by Jack Collins, the speaker of the Assembly, that would double the income eligibility to $44,000, from $22,000. 
Earlier this month, Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco proposed raising the property tax rebate for the elderly, a separate program, to $750, from $500, while urging the Legislature to consider Mr. Collins's legislation without quite endorsing it. This afternoon, the Senate budget committee approved Mr. DiFrancesco's proposal.
In New York, Gov. George E. Pataki has similarly proposed expanding the state's property tax rebate system for the elderly. For married homeowners earning as much as $60,000, he would raise the average benefit by an average of about $300 a year over the next five years.
In Connecticut earlier this month, Gov. John G. Rowland devoted a large part of his budget message to the need to provide more generous in-home care for the elderly, saying that the longer they are able to remain self-sufficient, the less time they will spend in state-subsidized nursing homes.
Efforts like these, plus, perhaps, a waning appeal of Sunbelt retirement communities for some elderly people, have created a new suburban phenomenon some call the N.O.R.C., for "naturally occurring retirement community," said Elinor Ginzler, manager of the Long Term and Independent Living office of AARP, the association for middle-aged and elderly Americans.
"It is a setting where folks have aged in place," Ms. Ginzler said. "And people who live there recognize that in order to encourage that, you have to address the issues like taxes that accompany that development." 
Property tax abatements are hardly the only incentive to stay put that are being offered to the suburban elderly these days. Free or discounted public transportation, free medical screening and the opportunity to audit local college courses for little or no charge are also aimed at keeping them in place.
So are the "senior centers" -- combination social clubs, gyms and clinics -- that according to the National Council on the Aging have become ubiquitous in the suburbs. There are now 16,000 around the country, double the number in 1980, and most of them are in the suburbs. 
Still, here at the leading edge of suburban sprawl, the comforts, convenience and companionship offered by such amenities do not entirely overcome the problem that high taxes present to retirees.
"Taxes are the only expenses that keep going up for them," Mayor Carson said. "Their car insurance stays the same, their houses are paid for and they don't use a lot of electricity. But taxes keep going up, and it makes it hard for them to stay in their homes." 
In 1996, the taxes on a $250,000 home in West Windsor were $6,975, including $4,300 in school taxes, said Kay Reed, the township tax collector. In 2000, the taxes on the same house had risen to $8,450, with school taxes accounting for $5,550. 
For newcomers, West Windsor's well-regarded schools and their high test scores are a source of pride, but to Dick Harbourt and his wife, Marion, the resulting taxes are unbearable. He and Mrs. Harbourt live on $22,000 a year, and even though they qualified to have their taxes frozen in 1998, nearly a quarter of their income goes to pay the $5,000 annual bill. 
"When we built our house in '55, our taxes were less than $200," said Mr. Harbourt, 69, who used to have a small trucking company. "We expanded to raise five kids, and every room I added has a memory, a history. And I feel that all the new citizens moving in here are just confiscating our home to pay for their schools." 
Sitting around a big table at West Windsor's senior center, a clapboard structure designed to look a little like a traditional farmhouse, Mr. Harbourt and a dozen friends acknowledged that an earlier generation of residents, including retirees, had helped put their own children through school 30 or 40 years ago. They said they recognized that they have a similar obligation to today's children. In addition, the quality of the schools has greatly increased the values of their homes.
That said, as communities try to cater to longtime residents, some parents are mindful of empty-nesters' reputation as consistent "no" voters on local school bonds. Indeed, almost all the people at the senior center said they regularly voted against school budgets.
Acknowledging that others had helped support schools for their children, many longtime residents say that things are different now. To begin with, the cost of education has increased much faster than inflation or their incomes.
But also, they say, the newcomers who have doubled West Windsor's population in the last 15 years are too often professional couples whose transient, corporate careers in New York and Philadelphia keep them from developing the kind of commitment to the place, to the volunteer work and to the town boards that people like the Froehlichs and the Harbourts brought in their child-rearing days. 
"You talk to the people who move in and it's always the same" said Oliver Hilpot, who has lived here with his wife, Bette, for 45 years. "They move in for the schools, and as soon as their kids are out of high school, they're gone, because they don't want to pay the taxes. Well, if they don't like the taxes, why should we?" 
A few years ago, the Hilpots gave up their big house and moved to an upscale retirement condominium in West Windsor. A young family with one child bought their house, and now a second baby is on the way. 
At their spotless home on Cubberley Road, the Froehlichs think about the $115 a week it costs them just to stay in their house and wonder. 
"I'm ready to go," Mr. Froehlich, a retired construction supervisor, said. "But she" -- a nod to his wife -- "she's still on the fence."

BYLINE:  Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:
 NEW YORK

MINEOLA: BUDGET SURPLUS PLANS -- Republican lawmakers in Nassau County want to reserve additional money to pay down debt and interest. More than half of the $48.3 million surplus from 2000 has been set aside, and Peter J. Schmitt, the Republican minority leader of the County Legislature, said that an additional $11.3 million in 2002 should be used to pay debt. Judith A. Jacobs, the Democratic majority leader, said the idea was "not new." A spokesman for County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta said most of the suggestions were already in the county's four-year plan. Al Baker (NYT)

MANHATTAN: KERIK MAKES ANOTHER ARREST -- For the third time since becoming the police commissioner less than a year ago, Bernard B. Kerik, left, took part in a street arrest. Mr. Kerik told reporters yesterday that he was driving around the Hamilton Heights section of Harlem on Sunday with his security detail when they noticed one man chasing another. When one man got into a van on West 142nd Street, Commissioner Kerik and others detained both men. They found that the van had been reported carjacked and arrested the two men on various charges, including unauthorized use of a motor vehicle. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

WHITE PLAINS: CELL PHONE BILL APPROVED -- The Westchester County Legislature, deciding not to wait for a statewide law, voted unanimously last night to prohibit drivers from talking on hand-held cellular phones. "We as local officials have an obligation to protect our own citizenry if we can't get the state to do it for us," said Louis Mosiello, the Republican sponsor of the bill. The measure would authorize fines of up to $150 for using a phone while driving unless it can be operated hands-free or is used in an emergency. The law would go into effect 45 days after the bill was signed by County Executive Andrew J. Spano, who says he supports it. (AP)

EAST ISLIP: ARRAIGNMENT IN ANIMAL SACRIFICE -- Six people were arraigned yesterday on charges that they illegally sacrificed a pig late Sunday during a religious rite at the East Islip Marina. Officials said the six were practicing a religion similar to Santeria. Although a Supreme Court ruling protects animal sacrifices when performed as part of religious practice, law enforcement officials said the pig was not killed swiftly and cleanly, but slowly and painfully. The participants were therefore charged with a misdemeanor violation of the state's agriculture and markets law. Michael Cooper (NYT)

MANHATTAN: TOUR BUS DEMISE CHEERS MAYOR Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said good riddance yesterday to New York Apple Tours, the tour bus company that announced its permanent shutdown on Sunday. "It's a good idea that they went out of business," Mr. Giuliani said. "They were a very, very difficult operation." The red double-decker buses had been cited for more than 1,000 traffic violations. Last May, one of the company's buses struck and killed a man.
 Elisabeth Bumiller (NYT)

CONNECTICUT

HARTFORD: STATE ECONOMY SLOWS -- University of Connecticut professors said yesterday that reduced job growth, falling consumer confidence and higher energy prices are slowing the state's 10-year economic expansion. In a report, the economists criticized what they called an anachronistic government that made statewide strategies for managing growth more difficult. But they said the state's two casinos had produced many new jobs. (NYT)

STAMFORD: SKAKEL HEARING DELAYED -- A hearing on whether to move the murder trial of Michael Skakel, left, has been pushed back a day, to Thursday, State Superior Court announced yesterday. Judge John F. Kavanewsky Jr. is to hear arguments from prosecutors, who want the trial moved to Bridgeport, and from the defense, which is opposed. (AP)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Inventory Problem Leads To Profit Warning at Nike
Nike said that its third-quarter profit would fall short of forecasts because of problems with an inventory system that led to shortages and late deliveries.
 To compensate for the shortages, the company said, it ordered so many shoes that it will be trying to work through excess inventory for months to come. Nike now expects to earn 34 to 38 cents a share for the quarter -- far below its previous estimate of 50 to 55 cents a share. In after-hours trading, shares of Nike fell as low as $40.30 after closing at $49.17. Page C2. 

Judges Scrutinize Microsoft Ruling
Federal appeals judges sharply questioned the decision that found that Microsoft had repeatedly violated antitrust law. The questioning suggested that many elements of the decision were vulnerable to reversal. A1.

P.& G. Cites Turkey in a Warning
Citing the economic crisis in Turkey, Procter & Gamble warned that its profits would fall as much as 4 percent in the third quarter and about 1.5 percent for the entire year. Because Procter has repeatedly warned Wall Street over the last year to scale back its expectations, some analysts questioned whether the company may have over-emphasized the effect of the Turkish currency crisis. Shares of Procter fell $3.92, to $71.11. C9.

Stocks Gain on Hopes of Rate Cut
Stocks jumped as investors bet that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates again soon. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 200.63 points, or 1.9 percent, to 10,642.53. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 21.79 points, or 1.8 percent, to 1,267.65. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 45.99 points, or 2 percent, to 2,308.50. C10.

Bush Alters Debate on U.S. Debt
President Bush plans to say that bringing the national debt below $1.2 trillion in a decade, much less wiping it out, will be all but impossible, White House officials said. The reasons are technical, but the political and economic repercussions could be substantial. A1.

Revamped Energy Policy Proposed
Senate Republicans introduced the first major bill in a decade to overhaul energy policy and spur domestic oil exploration. A1.

3Com Plans to Cut 1,200 Jobs
3Com, the struggling maker of computer networking equipment, announced that it would eliminate 1,200 jobs. C4.

Reverse Psychology From Kathi
ESPN is sponsoring a humorous campaign centered on a faux Web site that asks visitors to avoid ESPN's site. The fake site is ostensibly run by a young woman named Kathi, portrayed by an actress, Lorri Bagley. It is dedicated to Kathi's supposed daily life and is interspersed with diatribes against ESPN.com. The jest is that her mentions of ESPN.com double as links, so that visitors can be delivered to the very place Kathi does not want them to go. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C6.

Top Talent Agent Switches Firms
Patrick Whitesell, co-head of the talent department at Creative Artists Agency, left unexpectedly and joined Endeavor, a rapidly growing agency that opened in 1995. C8.

Sales of previously owned homes fell 6.6 percent in January, the second consecutive monthly decline, an industry group said. C15.
