HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Inventory Problem Leads To Profit Warning at Nike
Nike said that its third-quarter profit would fall short of forecasts because of problems with an inventory system that led to shortages and late deliveries.
 To compensate for the shortages, the company said, it ordered so many shoes that it will be trying to work through excess inventory for months to come. Nike now expects to earn 34 to 38 cents a share for the quarter -- far below its previous estimate of 50 to 55 cents a share. In after-hours trading, shares of Nike fell as low as $40.30 after closing at $49.17. Page C2. 

Judges Scrutinize Microsoft Ruling
Federal appeals judges sharply questioned the decision that found that Microsoft had repeatedly violated antitrust law. The questioning suggested that many elements of the decision were vulnerable to reversal. A1.

P.& G. Cites Turkey in a Warning
Citing the economic crisis in Turkey, Procter & Gamble warned that its profits would fall as much as 4 percent in the third quarter and about 1.5 percent for the entire year. Because Procter has repeatedly warned Wall Street over the last year to scale back its expectations, some analysts questioned whether the company may have over-emphasized the effect of the Turkish currency crisis. Shares of Procter fell $3.92, to $71.11. C9.

Stocks Gain on Hopes of Rate Cut
Stocks jumped as investors bet that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates again soon. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 200.63 points, or 1.9 percent, to 10,642.53. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 21.79 points, or 1.8 percent, to 1,267.65. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 45.99 points, or 2 percent, to 2,308.50. C10.

Bush Alters Debate on U.S. Debt
President Bush plans to say that bringing the national debt below $1.2 trillion in a decade, much less wiping it out, will be all but impossible, White House officials said. The reasons are technical, but the political and economic repercussions could be substantial. A1.

Revamped Energy Policy Proposed
Senate Republicans introduced the first major bill in a decade to overhaul energy policy and spur domestic oil exploration. A1.

3Com Plans to Cut 1,200 Jobs
3Com, the struggling maker of computer networking equipment, announced that it would eliminate 1,200 jobs. C4.

HEADLINE: HSBC Reports Hobbled Profit For Last Year 

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE KAPNER 

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 26 

 BODY:
HSBC Holdings reported a full-year profit today that was marred by weakened trading income and undercut by the muted recovery in Asia. The results, below many analysts' expectations, were more disheartening because of HSBC's near-term forecast.
 Sir John Bond, HSBC's chairman, warned that "the outlook for 2001 is challenging." He cited the prospect of an economic slowdown in the United States and stiffer competition in Britain and the deregulation of interest rates in Hong Kong. 
 Keith Whitson, group chief executive, said a slowdown in the United States could "have a widespread knock-on effect in many, many countries," Agence France-Presse reported.
HSBC's stock, which had been trading at a premium compared with most of its peers, fell 7 percent today in London, to 955 pence ($13.90).
Pretax profit for 2000 was $10.3 billion. Though up sharply from the 1999 figure of $8 billion, it was at the bottom of the range of forecasts. 
"Over all, the results were pretty flat, punctuated by areas that were quite poor," said Chris Ellerton of UBS Warburg. He lowered his rating on HSBC today to hold from buy.
Mr. Ellerton plans to trim his profit forecast for 2001 up to 10 percent given the storm clouds and the lack of lift in the equity markets.
Though HSBC mainly focuses on selling asset-management and other products to wealthy individuals and gets more than two-thirds of its operating profit that way, it is not immune from the vagaries of the capital markets. Its profits from trading fell 25 percent in 2000, to $1.6 billion. HSBC made $213 million trading stocks in the first half of the year but only $110 million in the second half.
Soft patches appeared in demand for loans, especially in Asia, which has come back more slowly than hoped from the economic meltdowns of the late 90's. In Hong Kong, where HSBC earns 29 percent of its interest income, loan demand grew just 7 percent last year.
Still, Asia's recovery has allowed HSBC to set aside $932 million less than it expected for problem loans, Adrian Russell, an HSBC spokesman, said.
Most of HSBC's recent growth, though, has come from acquisitions. It has spent $20 billion since 1999 to buy Credit Commercial de France and Republic New York, which together added $1.73 billion in net interest income in 2000. Sooner or later, analysts say, HSBC needs to show that it can deliver growth from existing operations.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Keith Whitson, the group chief executive of HSBC Holdings. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Public Interests; 
A Man With A Plan

BYLINE:  By GAIL COLLINS 

 BODY:
George W. Bush is making his big budget speech tonight. You remember. The president.
 While the nation has been watching the Clintons in fascinated, gaping horror, things have been going great, in an under-the-radar kind of way, for the current incumbent, a Republican who was formerly the governor of Texas. 
 Mr. Bush, whose father once served as president of the United States, lives in a sunny land of low expectations, full of triumphant meet-and-greets. And he looks like a statesman every time he gets through a day without pardoning anybody. 
(PARDON NEWS BULLETIN: Robert Wendell Walker Jr., a bank robber who was pardoned by Ronald Reagan in 1981, is currently on trial on charges of killing his wife and dismembering and burning her body. We now take you back to the previously scheduled column.)
As we were saying, the members of Congress turn out to have exactly the same reaction to Mr. Bush as the country at large. They like everything about him except his ideas. His Medicare drug plan elicited an energetic bipartisan response, with both parties stomping on it until there was nothing left but a thin legislative grease spot.
The voucher part of his education initiative is D.O.A., and the Republicans are probably going to water down the testing part to meaningless gibberish. There is still the spending-more-money part, which turns out to be a spending-less-money part if you compare it with what Congress did in the Clinton administration.
Over the past month Mr. Bush has also come up with a plan to funnel more money to religious groups, which the Scientologists love and Pat Robertson hates. And he bombed Iraq, using ultra-modern precision-guided weapons, which generally missed.
But then, he didn't pardon anybody. And I hear some people he really likes are getting two or even three nicknames.
Tonight Mr. Bush, the father of two whose wife is a former librarian, is going to officially ask Congress to approve his $1.6 trillion tax cut. He says we need it because "a warning light is flashing on the dashboard of our economy," and there will be perilous times ahead unless the consumer confidence cruise control is completely operational.
The president has been selling this plan forever. During the campaign he went all around the nation, announcing that one of his top priorities was to cut the 39 percent marginal tax rate for extremely high-income Americans. When people asked why, he always said, "We don't believe anybody should ever pay more than 33 percent." Amazingly, nobody once yelled back, "Say what?"
No wonder he thought he had a winner. Still, there is not enough support in the Senate right now to pass it, even though the Democrats have not come up with a specific alternative. When the opposition held a press conference the other day to denounce the Bush plan, somebody asked the minority leader, Tom Daschle, what his followers wanted the tax cut to be.
"We want it to be fair," he said helpfully.
But the most interesting part of the tax fight has been the long parade of rich people who've been marching to the Capitol to beg Congress not to give them any more money. Warren Buffett, George Soros, Bill Gates's father -- sometimes it seemed as if the only obscenely rich people in Washington who liked tax cuts were in Mr. Bush's cabinet. "Frankly, I don't need a break," said Senator Jon Corzine, the New Jersey Democrat who estimated that the Bush tax cut plan would save him $1 million a year.
Congress is going to pass a big whopping tax cut, but Mr. Bush has been pretty clear that he wants his version, the one that gives Jon Corzine a million bucks, not some scrawny $800 billion sop to the middle class. "The president wants to see passed the bill he ran on and was elected on," said the chief economic adviser, Lawrence Lindsey, beaming with the sort of confidence normally associated only with chief executives who won the popular vote.
Tonight we'll begin to find out if Mr. Bush, a graduate of Yale and the owner of a dog named Spot, can talk the nation into believing that tax relief "pumps adrenaline into troubled economies," multiplying the endorphins of economic growth and increasing the insulin of employment. Not to mention fixing that darned light on the dashboard.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Energy Bill Is Likely to Set Off Fierce Policy Fight 

BYLINE:  By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 

 BODY:
Declaring that the nation faced an energy crisis threatening its security and economy, Senate Republicans today proposed the first major bill in a decade to overhaul energy policy and spur domestic oil exploration.
 The bill, presented by Senator Frank H. Murkowski of Alaska, the chairman of the Energy and Natural Resources Committee, is expected to unleash one of the year's fiercest policy debates pitting business groups led by the oil industry against conservationists. The measure's introduction comes after rolling power cutbacks in California, a problem Republicans say will give their bill fresh momentum. 
 Central to Mr. Murkowski's bill is a provision to permit oil drilling inside the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, a wilderness area in Alaska's north slope. That proposal has met with strong resistance in Congress in the past and is vehemently opposed by many Democrats and some Republicans, who say it would needlessly disrupt the refuge. 
"American dependence on foreign oil threatens our national security and our freedom, and we need to recognize that," Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, said today on the Senate floor in support of drilling in the refuge.
Supporters of the drilling proposal say high natural gas prices are the legacy of the country's failure to adopt a comprehensive energy policy. Still, they acknowledge that opening the wildlife refuge to drilling would not produce benefits for consumers for at least five years.
Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, has threatened to filibuster any bill that would permit drilling in the refuge. And in the Senate, any pro-oil industry measure is certain to face legislative hurdles raised by Democrats.
President Bush, a former oil executive, is a strong supporter of drilling in Alaska, but the package of tax breaks intended to encourage exploration goes far beyond the tax credits Mr. Bush mentioned in his own energy plan on the campaign trail. The Senate package could also run into conflict with Mr. Bush's vow to push through in his $1.6 trillion tax cut plan with no changes.
Mr. Bush has directed Vice President Dick Cheney to create a task force on energy policy and to work with Congress on steering a bill through Congress by this summer.
The White House press secretary, Ari Fleischer, said Mr. Murkowski's bill was off to "a very good start."
Mr. Murkowski's 300-page bill is intended to reduce the nation's use of foreign oil to 50 percent, down from the current 56 percent, by opening up new tracts of land for oil exploration. The bill would also promote the production of natural gas, coal and nuclear energy and increase home-heating assistance for the poor.
The bill includes numerous tax breaks to spur oil and natural gas production, promote solar and wind energy and encourage nuclear power plants to produce more electricity. Some of the provisions are intended to attract Democrats by offering tax breaks for people who buy energy-saving cars and appliances.
But some Democrats instantly cited the bill as an example of the kind of frenzy for tax cuts that could take place this year, calling it an ornament on the Christmas tree," as one Democratic aide put it. Mr. Bush used similar language last week in saying he would resist demands to add more tax breaks to his plan.
Taxpayer groups immediately attacked the bill today as a boon to oil and utility companies, industries that contribute heavily to the Republican Party, and said the bill would cost taxpayers at least $21 billion in subsidies and tax breaks to energy companies. The total cost of the bill is still being calculated by the Congressional Budget Office.
"The bill will not solve the energy crisis, but will make already profitable companies even wealthier," said Cena Swisher, program director for Taxpayers for Common Sense, a group in Washington that monitors federal spending.
The legislation, for example, would benefit big oil companies by reducing the federal royalties they pay when the price of oil falls below $18 a barrel and natural gas prices drop below $2.30 per thousand cubic feet for 90 straight days.
Oil companies that deal with small-scale wells would be awarded tax credits when prices fall as a way to provide an incentive to keep such wells operating. Owners of so-called stripper wells would get a tax credit of $3 per barrel when oil prices fall below $15 a barrel and a 50 cent tax credit on each 1,000 cubic feet of gas produced when gas prices drop below $2 per thousand cubic feet.
Mr. Murkowski said he sought to balance the need for a sound energy policy and the concerns of environmental groups and conservationists. 
But Mr. Murkowski, along with other Republican leaders, emphasized that his chief aim was to increase oil production in the United States and reduce the country's reliance on oil imported from "unstable nations" like Iraq and Iran. The United States imports 750,000 barrels of oil a day from Iraq.
For this reason, he said, drilling in the Alaskan refuge, which is often referred to by its initials, A.N.W.R., makes sense. "The reality of A.N.W.R. is that if you are looking to increase supply, you look at where you are mostly likely to find it."
The federal government estimates that the refuge's coastal plain could hold from 3.2 billion to 16 billion barrels of extractable oil. Mr. Murkowski said oil drilling technology had vastly improved over the years and would do little harm to the refuge and the migrating caribou.
"It can replace the oil we buy from Saudi Arabia for the next 30 years," he said.
In 1980, President Jimmy Carter signed a bill that made Alaskan land a refuge of 19 million acres, an area the size of North Carolina. Mr. Carter carved out 1.5 million acres for possible oil exploration if Congress voted to authorize the drilling.
In an interview today, Mr. Carter said that he opposed Mr. Murkowski's bill just as most major environmental groups do. "I feel that this is ill-advised legislation that would despoil a precious area of our country for a very small and trenchant amount of oil," Mr. Carter said. "Just imagine this happening on the edge of Yellowstone National Park or Yosemite."
Mr. Carter and other Democrats also said the bill failed to address fuel consumption by including restrictions on the number of sport utility vehicles and light trucks. 
"We can't even talk about a comprehensive energy policy without concrete policies to reduce oil demand," said Senator Jeff Bingaman of New Mexico, the ranking Democrat on the committee. "We cannot produce our way to independence from foreign oil supplies."
All day today, Republicans took to the Senate floor and issued news releases to promote their energy bill, saying that California's problems are a harbinger for the rest of the nation. They all cast the debate as a foreign policy issue, raising the possibility that foreign nations could manipulate the United States by withholding supplies or pushing up crude oil prices. 
For decades, Republicans have pushed to open up broad swaths of the United States to further oil and natural gas exploration, only to be stymied by Democrats and environmental groups.
"We have allowed this drift to go on too long," said Senator Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska. "We can't leave this country subject to international blackmail because of our reliance on foreign oil. It's far too dangerous."

HEADLINE: HSBC Reports Hobbled Profit For Last Year 

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE KAPNER

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 26 

 BODY:
HSBC Holdings reported a full-year profit today that was marred by weakened trading income and undercut by the muted recovery in Asia. The results, below many analysts' expectations, were more disheartening because of HSBC's near-term forecast.
 Sir John Bond, HSBC's chairman, warned that "the outlook for 2001 is challenging." He cited the prospect of an economic slowdown in the United States and stiffer competition in Britain and the deregulation of interest rates in Hong Kong. 
 Keith Whitson, group chief executive, said a slowdown in the United States could "have a widespread knock-on effect in many, many countries," Agence France-Presse reported.
HSBC's stock, which had been trading at a premium compared with most of its peers, fell 7 percent today in London, to 955 pence ($13.90).
Pretax profit for 2000 was $10.3 billion. Though up sharply from the 1999 figure of $8 billion, it was at the bottom of the range of forecasts. 
"Over all, the results were pretty flat, punctuated by areas that were quite poor," said Chris Ellerton of UBS Warburg. He lowered his rating on HSBC today to hold from buy.
Mr. Ellerton plans to trim his profit forecast for 2001 up to 10 percent given the storm clouds and the lack of lift in the equity markets.
Though HSBC mainly focuses on selling asset-management and other products to wealthy individuals and gets more than two-thirds of its operating profit that way, it is not immune from the vagaries of the capital markets. Its profits from trading fell 25 percent in 2000, to $1.6 billion. HSBC made $213 million trading stocks in the first half of the year but only $110 million in the second half.
Soft patches appeared in demand for loans, especially in Asia, which has come back more slowly than hoped from the economic meltdowns of the late 90's. In Hong Kong, where HSBC earns 29 percent of its interest income, loan demand grew just 7 percent last year.
Still, Asia's recovery has allowed HSBC to set aside $932 million less than it expected for problem loans, Adrian Russell, an HSBC spokesman, said.
Most of HSBC's recent growth, though, has come from acquisitions. It has spent $20 billion since 1999 to buy Credit Commercial de France and Republic New York, which together added $1.73 billion in net interest income in 2000. Sooner or later, analysts say, HSBC needs to show that it can deliver growth from existing operations.

HEADLINE: A New Script For Greenspan At House Panel 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, will offer revised testimony on the United States economy and monetary policy when he appears before the House Financial Services Committee on Wednesday, a Fed spokesman said today.
 Mr. Greenspan testified before the Senate Banking Committee on Feb. 13, as part of his semiannual briefings to Congress. 
 "Some time has passed since the last testimony," the spokesman, David Skidmore, said. "The chairman is updating the text."
Mr. Greenspan typically repeats the text of his monetary policy report in the Senate and House committee appearances. His statement is supposed to reflect the views of all members of the central bank's policy-making Open Market Committee, not just his own.
Under a law passed last year, the chairman is required to appear before only one of the two Congressional panels, with the House and Senate taking turns. While this year his House appearance was not required, members of the Financial Services Committee -- the former House Banking Committee with additional securities and insurance jurisdiction -- requested that he appear.
Diane Swonk, chief economist at Bank One in Chicago, called the Fed chief's forthcoming remarks "an important development."
"It shows how responsive they are to economic conditions," she said. "They haven't predetermined policy. They want to make it clear they're willing to do whatever's necessary for the economy."
Speaking to the senators two weeks ago, Mr. Greenspan said the United States would probably avoid recession this year as businesses reduced their stockpiles of unsold goods and continued to invest in technology that promoted productivity. "If the forces contributing to long-term productivity growth remain intact," he said, "the degree of retrenchment will presumably be limited."
Since then, the Fed has received mixed signals on the economy, with confidence strengthening but still weak and prices rising faster than expected.

HEADLINE: Supreme Court Roundup; 
Justices Press for Clarity in a Property Rights Dispute

BYLINE:  By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 

 BODY:
The Supreme Court has struggled for years over how and when to apply the Fifth Amendment's injunction that private property shall not be "taken for public use without just compensation," and an argument today over whether an environmental regulation that barred development on 18 acres of oceanfront wetlands in Rhode Island amounted to a "taking" did not necessarily bring the justices any closer to a clear answer.
 Like nearly all such cases, this 30-year-old land-use dispute reached the court in a tangled procedural state presenting numerous obstacles to a broad, clarifying ruling. 
 But it has drawn wide attention in property-rights and environmental circles because it offers a vehicle for the court finally to create the kind of expansive takings doctrine that recent cases have been inching toward. An expansive definition of a taking would make land-use regulation much more expensive for all levels of government. 
One major question in the case today was whether a property owner who acquired land after a regulation was in place was "on notice" of the development restrictions and therefore barred from claiming entitlement for compensation for a taking.
While there is some dispute about the chronology in this case, the landowner, Anthony Palazzolo, became sole owner of the waterfront property in 1978, several years after both Rhode Island and the federal government began to regulate the filling of coastal wetlands. Mr. Palazzolo and his corporate partners acquired the land, in the town of Westerly, in the late 1950's and early 1960's for about $13,000.
Mr. Palazzolo's lawyer argued that because waterfront owners in Rhode Island historically enjoyed the right to fill wetlands on their property without government regulation, the state could not curb that freedom today, even for landowners who acquired the land with knowledge of the regulations, without paying compensation for a taking.
Several justices found this assertion startling. "If the rights to land use pass from owner to owner, how far back does it go?" Justice David H. Souter asked. "There is no logical stopping place until you get back to Roger Williams and the 17th-century settlement." 
James S. Burling, Mr. Palazzolo's lawyer, replied that a current landowner's rights date "as far back as before the existence of pervasive regulation." A landowner retains the right to development even after acquiring the property with knowledge of modern regulations, Mr. Burling said, explaining that a new regulation "doesn't affect the background principles of the very property itself" like the historic right to fill waterfront land.
"If the background principle of filling wetlands cannot be tampered with," Justice Souter persisted, how about "the background principle of building to the property line?" Could an ordinary zoning setback requirement amount to a taking? he asked.
Mr. Burling replied that "reasonable" zoning requirements would not necessarily be a taking. Leaping forcibly into the argument, Justice Antonin Scalia, the court's leading advocate of a broad theory of takings, expressed alarm that Mr. Burling's answer was not firm enough.
A 60-foot setback might sound reasonable, Justice Scalia said, but wouldn't it be a taking if the property was only 61 feet deep?
"I'd better define 'reasonable,' " Mr. Burling replied, a bit sheepishly. If the regulation "destroys the economically viable use of the property," it is a taking, he said.
Justice Souter found this unsatisfactory. "So it's simply the economics of what came before and what came after?" he asked. "I don't think you want to take that position. Do you look to the reasons for the state regulation? You're going to have to come up with some criteria of what passes muster and what does not."
The Rhode Island Supreme Court rejected Mr. Palazzolo's taking claim on the ground that his lawsuit was not "ripe." In his lawsuit, filed in 1988, he was seeking more than $3 million in damages to make up for the profit he said he would have made by subdividing his property and building 74 single-family homes. 
But he had not sought permission to build the houses. Instead he had filed one application to fill in the land for unspecified purposes and another to use the land for a beach club. Both were denied. One question in the case, Palazzolo v. Rhode Island, No. 99-2047, is how precise a land-use application must be in order for its rejection to be considered a sufficient basis for a takings lawsuit.
Specificity was essential, Attorney General Sheldon Whitehouse of Rhode Island told the justices, because the takings claim must be evaluated in light of whatever economic value remained in the land after one specific use was rejected. "There is value in this property," Mr. Whitehouse said, "perhaps a good deal."
Denial of the landfill permit left Mr. Palazzolo free to build a single family house on a dry "upland" part of the property, with an estimated value of $200,000. A court must evaluate the entire parcel in any takings case, Mr. Whitehouse said, or else a takings claim "is ipso facto always going to be 100 percent as to the burdened portion," the part where development has been rejected.
Mr. Palazzolo's legal representation was provided by the Pacific Legal Foundation, an organization, based in Sacramento, that specializes in property rights and has brought several takings cases to the Supreme Court. The Clinton administration, in its waning weeks, filed a brief on Rhode Island's behalf, and Malcolm L. Stewart, an assistant solicitor general, argued on Rhode Island's side today.
While the Justice Department in the Bush administration is likely to be more sympathetic to the property-rights side of the takings argument, it may find itself constrained by the financial consequences of a broad takings doctrine. Signing briefs on Rhode Island's side were the National Conference of State Legislatures, the National League of Cities, the National Governors Association and 18 states, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

Disability Act Cases
In other action today, the justices stepped back temporarily from the federalism debate and, without comment, turned down nine cases that presented to the states a variety of issues concerning the application of the Americans With Disabilities Act.
While several of these were essentially identical to the case the court decided last week, immunizing states from discrimination suits by their disabled employees, others posed new questions under the statute, like the validity of extra fees that some states charge for handicapped parking stickers. New cases under the disability act are likely to reach the court soon, prompted by last week's ruling in Board of Trustees of the University of Alabama v. Garrett.

Abortion Practices Law
Also without comment, the court turned down a constitutional challenge to a South Carolina law imposing a variety of special staffing, administrative and physical requirements on the offices of doctors who perform five or more first-trimester abortions a month. The regulations were upheld by a 2-to-1 decision of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond. Several doctors and abortion clinics had objected that the regulations were medically unnecessary and would raise costs, making safe, early abortions less available. The case was Greenville Women's Clinic v. Bryant, No. 00-798.

HEADLINE: Public Interests; 
A Man With A Plan

BYLINE:  By GAIL COLLINS

 BODY:
George W. Bush is making his big budget speech tonight. You remember. The president.
 While the nation has been watching the Clintons in fascinated, gaping horror, things have been going great, in an under-the-radar kind of way, for the current incumbent, a Republican who was formerly the governor of Texas. 
 Mr. Bush, whose father once served as president of the United States, lives in a sunny land of low expectations, full of triumphant meet-and-greets. And he looks like a statesman every time he gets through a day without pardoning anybody. 
(PARDON NEWS BULLETIN: Robert Wendell Walker Jr., a bank robber who was pardoned by Ronald Reagan in 1981, is currently on trial on charges of killing his wife and dismembering and burning her body. We now take you back to the previously scheduled column.)
As we were saying, the members of Congress turn out to have exactly the same reaction to Mr. Bush as the country at large. They like everything about him except his ideas. His Medicare drug plan elicited an energetic bipartisan response, with both parties stomping on it until there was nothing left but a thin legislative grease spot.
The voucher part of his education initiative is D.O.A., and the Republicans are probably going to water down the testing part to meaningless gibberish. There is still the spending-more-money part, which turns out to be a spending-less-money part if you compare it with what Congress did in the Clinton administration.
Over the past month Mr. Bush has also come up with a plan to funnel more money to religious groups, which the Scientologists love and Pat Robertson hates. And he bombed Iraq, using ultra-modern precision-guided weapons, which generally missed.
But then, he didn't pardon anybody. And I hear some people he really likes are getting two or even three nicknames.
Tonight Mr. Bush, the father of two whose wife is a former librarian, is going to officially ask Congress to approve his $1.6 trillion tax cut. He says we need it because "a warning light is flashing on the dashboard of our economy," and there will be perilous times ahead unless the consumer confidence cruise control is completely operational.
The president has been selling this plan forever. During the campaign he went all around the nation, announcing that one of his top priorities was to cut the 39 percent marginal tax rate for extremely high-income Americans. When people asked why, he always said, "We don't believe anybody should ever pay more than 33 percent." Amazingly, nobody once yelled back, "Say what?"
No wonder he thought he had a winner. Still, there is not enough support in the Senate right now to pass it, even though the Democrats have not come up with a specific alternative. When the opposition held a press conference the other day to denounce the Bush plan, somebody asked the minority leader, Tom Daschle, what his followers wanted the tax cut to be.
"We want it to be fair," he said helpfully.
But the most interesting part of the tax fight has been the long parade of rich people who've been marching to the Capitol to beg Congress not to give them any more money. Warren Buffett, George Soros, Bill Gates's father -- sometimes it seemed as if the only obscenely rich people in Washington who liked tax cuts were in Mr. Bush's cabinet. "Frankly, I don't need a break," said Senator Jon Corzine, the New Jersey Democrat who estimated that the Bush tax cut plan would save him $1 million a year.
Congress is going to pass a big whopping tax cut, but Mr. Bush has been pretty clear that he wants his version, the one that gives Jon Corzine a million bucks, not some scrawny $800 billion sop to the middle class. "The president wants to see passed the bill he ran on and was elected on," said the chief economic adviser, Lawrence Lindsey, beaming with the sort of confidence normally associated only with chief executives who won the popular vote.
Tonight we'll begin to find out if Mr. Bush, a graduate of Yale and the owner of a dog named Spot, can talk the nation into believing that tax relief "pumps adrenaline into troubled economies," multiplying the endorphins of economic growth and increasing the insulin of employment. Not to mention fixing that darned light on the dashboard.

Powell Plan Would Shift Focus of Iraq Sanctions

HEADLINE: POWELL PROPOSES EASING SANCTIONS ON IRAQI CIVILIANS 

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Tuesday, Feb. 27 

 BODY:
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said on Monday that he had won agreement from Arab nations on a plan to modify sanctions on Iraq by letting in more civilian supplies but sharpening controls on strategic items sought by President Saddam Hussein.
 Some American allies in the Middle East and Europe have been calling for a change of the sanctions, but now that his tour of the Middle East is over, General Powell faces a fierce debate in the Bush administration on Iraq policy. He acknowledged that there would be many questions about his plan from hard-liners in Washington. 
 General Powell said none of the Arab leaders he met with in the last three days, including President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, whom he saw on Monday, disagreed with his strategy. "Everyone I spoke to said you've got to go down this track; it's the right thing to do," General Powell said. 
"The message I've consistently heard is that overdoing it with the sanctions gives him a tool that he is using against us -- and really is not weakening him," General Powell said of President Hussein. 
But he said his outline of a plan would be criticized in Washington. "The charges will come that it is weakening," he said. "There will be a lot of people who will want to hear more."
Some hard-liners in Congress and the administration want tougher action, including the arming of Iraqi opposition groups, in an attempt to overthrow Mr. Hussein.
General Powell, speaking to reporters as he flew from Damascus to Brussels late on Monday, seemed to be setting up a test of strength in the administration's foreign policy apparatus, which includes Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld, Vice President Dick Cheney and the national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice. Mr. Rumsfeld and Mr. Cheney are believed to be more favorably disposed to arming the opposition groups. Mr. Rumsfeld's newly nominated deputy, Paul D. Wolfowitz, has publicly advocated that policy.
There are others in the administration who agree, believing that the unfinished business of the Persian Gulf war 10 years ago should be completed by the ouster of Mr. Hussein. At ceremonies in Kuwait City today, former President George Bush, General H. Norman Schwarzkopf, General Powell and other leaders of the war commemorated the coalition victory against the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.
General Powell spent his three days in the Middle East soliciting support for his sanctions plan, which he said would tighten restrictions on Iraq so that Mr. Hussein would not be able to arm his nation with weapons of mass destruction.
As part of his new strategy, Mr. Powell said he had won agreement from Syria to place into a United Nations escrow account revenues that Mr. Hussein was receiving from oil flowing through Syrian pipelines. In the last few months, those revenues have been going into Mr. Hussein's pockets, illustrating the fraying of the sanctions. 
The commitment from the Syrian was so firm -- Mr. Assad stated it three times during the meeting, General Powell said -- that the secretary said he had telephoned President Bush to tell him. 
In another development in Syria, General Powell said Mr. Assad had agreed to an American suggestion that peace talks between Syria and Israel could proceed on a parallel track with Palestinian-Israeli talks, if the occasion arose. Talks between Israel and Syria broke down last year during the Clinton administration, which held to the idea that it was possible to conduct only one track of peace talks at a time. 
In outlining his plan, General Powell said a lot still needed to be worked out before an Arab League summit meeting in late March in Amman, Jordan, where he said he would like to see a formal consensus. He said he also wanted to take the plan to Kofi Annan, the United Nations secretary general, and the five permanent members of the Security Council. Two of them, Russia and France, have acted in the past to soften the sanctions. 
Among the details that need to be sorted out, General Powell said, was how to better seal the borders into Iraq in order to control the smuggling of items that could help the Iraqi leader make powerful weapons. He also said he wanted to review items like refrigerated trucks, water pumps and other items with dual uses that have been blocked by the United States and other nations in the United Nations sanctions committee.
As General Powell took his argument to five Arab countries -- Egypt, Jordan, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia and Syria -- his mission was helped by his personal stature as the top commander in the gulf war, and his ability to renew friendships in the region, senior Arab diplomats said. General Powell is close to King Fahd and Crown Prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia, and is well known to the Kuwaitis. 
He was received as a "secretary of state plus," a diplomat said. Another said he was greeted as an "old friend." 
Those two diplomats said they believed that General Powell's trip as the first representative of the new Bush administration to visit the Middle East would strengthen his hand in the coming debate among Bush foreign policy officials. 
"He is the only one who can say, 'I have been out there,' " said one of the diplomats, alluding to General Powell's skepticism about arming Iraqi opposition movements. Other administration officials have said they favor that course of action, which would be very unpopular in the region.
In his confirmation hearings last month, General Powell expressed strong skepticism about arming opposition groups, saying it would be very difficult for the United States to do so with any degree of success. In contrast, Dr. Wolfowitz wrote in Foreign Affairs magazine in the spring of 1999 that "the United States, should be prepared to commit ground forces to protect a sanctuary in southern Iraq where the opposition could safely mobilize."
Enthusiasm for the General Powell's ideas varied by country. 
The reception was the coolest in Egypt, an important American ally where President Hosni Mubarak has upgraded diplomatic relations with Iraq and is considering a trade policy with Mr. Hussein. After General Powell's meeting there, a senior State Department official said, the Egyptians offered no ideas.
In Jordan, General Powell said King Abdullah, who rules over the most pro-Iraqi population in the region, wanted to help. But Jordan would need financial assistance in securing its border with Iraq and does not want to be discriminated against as the only bordering state to have to tighten up, the secretary said. 
As he moved form capital to capital, General Powell brought military precision to usually phlegmatic diplomatic schedules. Some meetings with leaders lasted only an hour, and his aircraft often took off ahead of schedule.
Unlike his predecessor, Madeleine K. Albright, General Powell talked frequently on the record to reporters traveling with him as he aggressively pushed his sanctions plan.
 --------------------

Extensive Talks at U.N.
 UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 26 (Reuters) -- Despite harsh statements from Iraq, Secretary General Annan said today that officials from Baghdad were looking for a way to work through the deadlock over trade sanctions.
He made the comment through a spokesman at the end of the first of two days of talks between a high-level delegation from Baghdad and United Nations officials trying to resolve the breach, which is linked to allowing arms inspectors back into Iraq.
"The Iraqis made a comprehensive case in long discussions with the secretary general," said a United Nations spokesman, Fred Eckhard. "The secretary general described the atmosphere as good, and said the Iraqis shared his perspective that we should look for a way out of the current impasse."
The two sides, which reviewed disarmament and relief issues today, will meet again on Tuesday, with Mr. Annan hoping that the Iraqis will share their views "on where we go from here," Mr. Eckhard added.
Publicly, statements by the Iraqi foreign minister, Muhammad Saeed al-Sahaf, appeared harsher than what may have evolved during the meeting. Mr. Sahaf told reporters that no inspectors would return to Iraq even if the sanctions were abolished. If they did, they had to visit all countries in the region and "first Israel because they have atomic arsenals and all other arsenals."
Western diplomats said the meetings would be considered a success if Iraq acknowledged that the sessions were a prelude to further discussions.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
U.S. STEEL TO RAISE PRICES, CITING RISE IN DEMAND

BYLINE:  Reuters 

 BODY:
 USX-U.S. Steel, a division of the USX Corporation, said yesterday that it would raise prices $30 to $40 a ton beginning Thursday on most of its steel products in anticipation of an economic recovery. U.S. Steel, based in Pittsburgh, said it would increase its prices for hot-rolled steel by 20 percent, or $40 a ton, and those for cold-rolled and coated steel by $30 a ton. The company also said it had raised prices on Feb. 11 for its plate steel products by $10 to $15 a ton. Hot-rolled steel now sells for $200 a ton and cold-rolled steel sells for $380 to $440 a ton, said Waldo Best, a steel analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. U.S. Steel said it had seen signs, like a small but fluctuating increase in demand, to justify a price increase.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Energy Bill Is Likely to Set Off Fierce Policy Fight 

BYLINE:  By LIZETTE ALVAREZ

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 

 BODY:
Declaring that the nation faced an energy crisis threatening its security and economy, Senate Republicans today proposed the first major bill in a decade to overhaul energy policy and spur domestic oil exploration.
 The bill, presented by Senator Frank H. Murkowski of Alaska, the chairman of the Energy and Natural Resources Committee, is expected to unleash one of the year's fiercest policy debates pitting business groups led by the oil industry against conservationists. The measure's introduction comes after rolling power cutbacks in California, a problem Republicans say will give their bill fresh momentum. 
 Central to Mr. Murkowski's bill is a provision to permit oil drilling inside the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, a wilderness area in Alaska's north slope. That proposal has met with strong resistance in Congress in the past and is vehemently opposed by many Democrats and some Republicans, who say it would needlessly disrupt the refuge. 
"American dependence on foreign oil threatens our national security and our freedom, and we need to recognize that," Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, said today on the Senate floor in support of drilling in the refuge.
Supporters of the drilling proposal say high natural gas prices are the legacy of the country's failure to adopt a comprehensive energy policy. Still, they acknowledge that opening the wildlife refuge to drilling would not produce benefits for consumers for at least five years.
Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, has threatened to filibuster any bill that would permit drilling in the refuge. And in the Senate, any pro-oil industry measure is certain to face legislative hurdles raised by Democrats.
President Bush, a former oil executive, is a strong supporter of drilling in Alaska, but the package of tax breaks intended to encourage exploration goes far beyond the tax credits Mr. Bush mentioned in his own energy plan on the campaign trail. The Senate package could also run into conflict with Mr. Bush's vow to push through in his $1.6 trillion tax cut plan with no changes.
Mr. Bush has directed Vice President Dick Cheney to create a task force on energy policy and to work with Congress on steering a bill through Congress by this summer.
The White House press secretary, Ari Fleischer, said Mr. Murkowski's bill was off to "a very good start."
Mr. Murkowski's 300-page bill is intended to reduce the nation's use of foreign oil to 50 percent, down from the current 56 percent, by opening up new tracts of land for oil exploration. The bill would also promote the production of natural gas, coal and nuclear energy and increase home-heating assistance for the poor.
The bill includes numerous tax breaks to spur oil and natural gas production, promote solar and wind energy and encourage nuclear power plants to produce more electricity. Some of the provisions are intended to attract Democrats by offering tax breaks for people who buy energy-saving cars and appliances.
But some Democrats instantly cited the bill as an example of the kind of frenzy for tax cuts that could take place this year, calling it an ornament on the Christmas tree," as one Democratic aide put it. Mr. Bush used similar language last week in saying he would resist demands to add more tax breaks to his plan.
Taxpayer groups immediately attacked the bill today as a boon to oil and utility companies, industries that contribute heavily to the Republican Party, and said the bill would cost taxpayers at least $21 billion in subsidies and tax breaks to energy companies. The total cost of the bill is still being calculated by the Congressional Budget Office.
"The bill will not solve the energy crisis, but will make already profitable companies even wealthier," said Cena Swisher, program director for Taxpayers for Common Sense, a group in Washington that monitors federal spending.
The legislation, for example, would benefit big oil companies by reducing the federal royalties they pay when the price of oil falls below $18 a barrel and natural gas prices drop below $2.30 per thousand cubic feet for 90 straight days.
Oil companies that deal with small-scale wells would be awarded tax credits when prices fall as a way to provide an incentive to keep such wells operating. Owners of so-called stripper wells would get a tax credit of $3 per barrel when oil prices fall below $15 a barrel and a 50 cent tax credit on each 1,000 cubic feet of gas produced when gas prices drop below $2 per thousand cubic feet.
Mr. Murkowski said he sought to balance the need for a sound energy policy and the concerns of environmental groups and conservationists. 
But Mr. Murkowski, along with other Republican leaders, emphasized that his chief aim was to increase oil production in the United States and reduce the country's reliance on oil imported from "unstable nations" like Iraq and Iran. The United States imports 750,000 barrels of oil a day from Iraq.
For this reason, he said, drilling in the Alaskan refuge, which is often referred to by its initials, A.N.W.R., makes sense. "The reality of A.N.W.R. is that if you are looking to increase supply, you look at where you are mostly likely to find it."
The federal government estimates that the refuge's coastal plain could hold from 3.2 billion to 16 billion barrels of extractable oil. Mr. Murkowski said oil drilling technology had vastly improved over the years and would do little harm to the refuge and the migrating caribou.
"It can replace the oil we buy from Saudi Arabia for the next 30 years," he said.
In 1980, President Jimmy Carter signed a bill that made Alaskan land a refuge of 19 million acres, an area the size of North Carolina. Mr. Carter carved out 1.5 million acres for possible oil exploration if Congress voted to authorize the drilling.
In an interview today, Mr. Carter said that he opposed Mr. Murkowski's bill just as most major environmental groups do. "I feel that this is ill-advised legislation that would despoil a precious area of our country for a very small and trenchant amount of oil," Mr. Carter said. "Just imagine this happening on the edge of Yellowstone National Park or Yosemite."
Mr. Carter and other Democrats also said the bill failed to address fuel consumption by including restrictions on the number of sport utility vehicles and light trucks. 
"We can't even talk about a comprehensive energy policy without concrete policies to reduce oil demand," said Senator Jeff Bingaman of New Mexico, the ranking Democrat on the committee. "We cannot produce our way to independence from foreign oil supplies."
All day today, Republicans took to the Senate floor and issued news releases to promote their energy bill, saying that California's problems are a harbinger for the rest of the nation. They all cast the debate as a foreign policy issue, raising the possibility that foreign nations could manipulate the United States by withholding supplies or pushing up crude oil prices. 
For decades, Republicans have pushed to open up broad swaths of the United States to further oil and natural gas exploration, only to be stymied by Democrats and environmental groups.
"We have allowed this drift to go on too long," said Senator Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska. "We can't leave this country subject to international blackmail because of our reliance on foreign oil. It's far too dangerous."

HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO SEEK CUTS OF $2 TRILLION OF DEBT IN DECADE 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 

 BODY:
In his address to Congress on Tuesday night and in the budget plan he will unveil on Wednesday, President Bush will seek to put the nation on a course to pay off $2 trillion of the national debt over the next 10 years, leaving $1.2 trillion of debt at the end of that period. 
 After several years of bipartisan consensus about the desirability of extinguishing as much debt as quickly as possible, with the goal of bringing it to zero in a decade or a little longer, Mr. Bush will say that bringing it below $1.2 trillion in that period, much less wiping it out entirely, will be all but impossible, White House officials said today. 
 The reasons are technical. But the political and economic repercussions could be substantial, affecting both this year's battle over tax cuts and spending and long-range problems like the dire financial outlook for Social Security. The president is also expected to announce the creation of a commission to make recommendations on how to deal with Social Security's long-term problems. 
The debt issue has been raised in recent months by economists including Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and by budget analysts at the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office.
But by highlighting it in his first budget, Mr. Bush is starting a new chapter in the debate over how the nation can best use the projected federal budget surplus, estimated at $5.6 trillion over the next decade.
Mr. Bush's budget plan will conclude that the national debt held by the public, which is projected to decline by the next fiscal year in October to just under $3.2 trillion, can be cut by $2 trillion over the subsequent decade, leaving $1.2 trillion in debt at the end of the 10-year period covered by the budget. The debt held by the public is currently $3.4 trillion.
White House officials said their position is not the result of a political or a policy decision, but a reflection of the fact that a portion of the debt in the form of a variety of bonds is not easily redeemable, either because it would be too expensive to do so or because its holders would be unwilling to part with it.
Debt reduction has proven extremely popular with voters, somewhat to the surprise of both parties. Democrats have made it a central element of their economic agenda and a first line of defense against calls by Mr. Bush and other Republicans for a big tax cut. In the presidential campaign, Mr. Bush's opponent, Al Gore, said he would seek to eliminate the debt by 2012.
Although the White House said today that it remains committed to reducing as much of the debt as possible, Republicans generally have been less convinced that debt reduction is any more potent an economic tool than tax cuts. And although economists tend to favor debt reduction as an efficient way of offsetting the nation's anemic savings rate, there is considerable debate among them about whether eliminating the debt should be the policy goal.
"The only debt that remains would be debt that it's not in the interest of the country or the taxpayers or the bondholders to have paid off," said Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman.
Democrats said the administration was exaggerating the scale of the problem and undermining one of the pillars of economic progress in recent years. They called the approach a budgetary ploy by the White House to make more room for Mr. Bush's long list of campaign promises, from a $1.6 trillion tax cut to a new generation of weaponry for the Pentagon and private investment accounts for all workers.
"A remarkable consensus emerged at the end of President Clinton's second term to use the Medicare and Social Security surpluses to completely pay off our national debt," said Gene Sperling, who was Mr. Clinton's economic policy adviser and is now a fellow at the Brookings Institution. "The new administration is seeking to up-end that consensus with a very questionable and misleading budget presentation to make their tax cut seem more responsible than it is."
White House officials said the $1.2 trillion in debt that cannot readily be extinguished includes a variety of government securities. Among them are savings bonds, bonds held by other nations, long-term bonds that do not mature until after 2011, and special bonds held by state and local governments. To buy back the nonredeemable debt would require paying more than the value of the bonds.
The administration's budget anticipates paying down $2 trillion in public debt that matures no later than 2011 out of the part of the projected surplus coming from Social Security -- about $2.5 trillion out of the total surplus of $5.6 trillion. The debt held by the public excludes $2.5 trillion the government owes to itself, largely in the form of promises to pay future Social Security benefits. 
"The maximum amount of debt the government could repurchase by 2011 without paying a premium is $2 trillion," said Lawrence B. Lindsey, Mr. Bush's chief economic adviser. "To buy any of the additional debt would cost the taxpayer more than one dollar for every dollar of debt retired. We'd have to pay a penalty." 
The approach would leave $500 billion or so of excess Social Security surpluses over the next decade. Administration officials said the president's budget would not formally allocate the $500 billion for a particular purpose. But they said it and perhaps other money could be used to help establish private investment accounts within Social Security.
The two parties have agreed in recent years that this surplus should go only to debt reduction or to shoring up the retirement system's finances for the baby boom generation. Administration officials said they would not support using the $500 billion for tax cuts or new spending.
Mr. Bush's plan to create private investment accounts in Social Security has generated intense opposition from most Democrats, who have questioned where the president would find the money to establish the accounts while continuing to pay benefits to current retirees.
"They're talking about raiding the Social Security trust fund to fund privatization in part," said Senator Kent Conrad of North Dakota, the senior Democrat on the Senate Budget Committee. "We say, 'No, no raid on the Social Security trust fund.' "
Gary Gensler, the Treasury Department official who oversaw the government debt markets during the Clinton administration, said the level of debt that could be paid off in the next decade was higher than Mr. Bush's team is suggesting.
He said no more than about $500 billion of the debt would be difficult to buy back, less than half of what the administration said was realistic. As a result, he said, the entire Social Security surplus could be used to retire debt over the next decade.

HEADLINE: Bush Selects An Economist From Columbia 

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
After weeks of trying to fill the job of chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, President Bush yesterday nominated Robert Glenn Hubbard, a Columbia University economist and an outspoken advocate of tax cuts. 
 The council chairman was once the president's chief economic adviser. That role has shifted over the last decade directly to the White House, where Lawrence Lindsey has emerged as the chief adviser, as head of the National Economic Council. That council was created during the Clinton administration. 
 "I am Larry Lindsey's very good friend," said Mr. Hubbard, who has known Mr. Lindsey since their graduate school days at Harvard. "You have to see how these things evolve, but my hope for the Council of Economic Advisers is that it plays a very strong participatory role in developing economic policy."
Mr. Hubbard, who is 42, was a deputy assistant secretary in the Treasury Department in 1990 and 1991, during the administration of President Bush's father, and he joined the Bush campaign in 1999, helping to develop the president's economic policies.
Another member of President Bush's economics team, John B. Taylor of Stanford, was the front-runner to be chairman of the council, several economists said, but he declined the post rather than have his access to the White House controlled by Mr. Lindsey.
Mr. Taylor is now the front-runner to be named under secretary for international affairs at the Treasury Department, where his boss would be Paul H. O'Neill, the Treasury secretary. 
Mr. Hubbard, a prolific researcher, is professor of economics and finance at Columbia's Graduate School of Business. Tax law is a specialty. He has argued that high marginal tax rates discourage work effort and also entrepreneurial activity, which he says is mostly undertaken by the wealthy.
"We tend to think of the rich as getting rich by saving their money," Mr. Hubbard said in an interview yesterday. "But the rich get rich by taking risks, and you don't want tax policy that discourages risk taking" by taxing away the gains when the risk-taking pays off.
In other research, he has delved into the obstacles corporations encounter obtaining loans, even for potentially profitable investments, when their cash flow deteriorates. Similarly, he found, creditors become reluctant to lend to farmers, even successful farmers, when their farmland declines in value as land prices fall.
Family savings is another specialty. Mr. Hubbard's research has explored what makes people save or resist saving. 
"Glenn is a pragmatic conservative; he believes in markets, but he is not theological," said Kevin Hassett, a co-author with Mr. Hubbard on several projects and a senior fellow, as is Mr. Hubbard, at the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative research center in Washington.
Mr. Hubbard's work is known mainly among economists. But one study, published while he was a Treasury official, brought him considerable public attention. Income inequality had risen through the 1980's, while Republicans controlled the White House, and the growing disparity between rich and poor had become a political issue.
Many economists had accepted a finding that the richest 1 percent of Americans had reaped 70 percent of the growth in average family incomes from 1977 through 1988. Government data showed that the gap had widened alarmingly between low-income and high-income families. In his study, Mr. Hubbard countered that the data was misleading. The right approach, he said, was to measure income over a lifetime, not at a particular moment. From that vantage point, income inequality was less than it seemed, he said. People often moved from low incomes as young people to higher incomes in later years, Mr. Hubbard concluded.
His findings and his research were widely challenged, and Mr. Hubbard has given a bit of ground. "There is a great deal of income inequality," he acknowledged yesterday, "but there is also a great deal of mobility."
Born and raised in Florida, Mr. Hubbard earned an undergraduate degree in 1979 from the University of Central Florida and a doctorate from Harvard in 1983. He taught at Northwestern until 1988, when he shifted to Columbia. Since 1997, he has also held a joint appointment as an economics professor in Columbia's Faculty of Arts and Sciences.
"Hubbard is a first-class economist," said Martin Feldstein, a chairman himself of the Council of Economic Advisers, in the Reagan administration, and the thesis adviser at Harvard of both Mr. Hubbard and Mr. Lindsey. But being chairman of a council that once formulated policy and is now more focused on research no longer guarantees influence at the White House.
"What it will actually mean for Hubbard to be chairman will have to be worked out," Mr. Feldstein said. "As long as he is at all the top-level meetings, he can bring his personal views to the table and the analytic work of the council."

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Arguments in the Appeal of the Antitrust Case 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 

 BODY:
 Following are excerpts from oral arguments today in the Microsoft antitrust case before the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, as transcribed by the Federal Document Clearing House, a private transcription service. Representing Microsoft was Richard J. Urowsky; John G. Roberts Jr. presented arguments for the 19 state attorneys general who have sued Microsoft along with the Justice Department.

FOR MICROSOFT

MR. UROWSKY -- These are appeals from a final judgment finding Microsoft liable under Sections 1 and 2 of the Sherman Act and ordering a breakup of the company as well as other extreme relief.
 Before turning directly to the government's monopoly maintenance claim, I'd like to make one point that lies at the heart of this case and cuts across all claims asserted in the complaints: Nothing Microsoft did foreclosed Netscape from any portion of the marketplace.
The district court found that Netscape distributed 160 million copies of Navigator in 1998 alone. This was sufficient to saturate the entire marketplace, which consisted of approximately 100 million Internet users at the time. The district court also found that between 1996 and 1998, the period at issue in this case, Netscape's installed base of users increased from 15 million to 33 million. In other words, millions of people chose to use Navigator despite the fact that Internet Explorer was included in every copy of Windows.
In fact, James Barksdale, Netscape C.E.O., testified that Netscape had between 40 and 70 million users at the time of trial, and internal Netscape documents from October of 1997, a year before the commencement of trial, estimate that Navigator's installed base was 65 million, up from 40 million the year before. That's an increase of 25 million users during the very period when the alleged restraints were supposed to be in effect.
This evidence shows that Netscape had unfettered access to consumers. Indeed, Microsoft's inclusion of Internet Explorer in Windows may have facilitated Nagivator's distribution by providing a convenient means of downloading the program from the Internet. The absence of any foreclosure from any part of the marketplace undermines every claim in this case.
I'd like to turn ----

JUDGE JUDITH W. ROGERS -- Foreclosure means more than simply impeding access?

MR. UROWSKY -- It means preventing access, typically in cases like this, by either locking up customers, which is not an issue in this case, or effectively foreclosing all channels of distribution. . . .

CHIEF JUSTICE HARRY T. EDWARDS -- Mr. Urowsky, let me take you back to some threshold questions and make sure that there's nothing the court's supposed to be agonizing over on your theory of the case, save what you've put in the brief. But some of what you're arguing here, I think we're going to assume, are your pressing points of greatest concern. Do you have anything that we need worry about a lot on your arguments with respect to market share or the definition of the relevant market?

MR. UROWSKY -- I think that our position is set out comprehensively in the briefs. Our position on market share is that market share, in and of itself, is not a significant element here. What's significant is whether the market share has been achieved effortlessly because of control of elements of supply or whether market share has been achieved as a result of relentless, unremitting and ferocious competition.

JUDGE EDWARDS -- All right. So that will take us to the conduct questions. What about definition of the relevant market, about which you say some things. Are there any things you think are important that we ought to know now?

MR. UROWSKY -- I think the position, again, is set forth in the brief, but in very summary form, there is a great and not benign contradiction underlying the government's case. On the one hand, the theory of liability is that the most significant forms of competition confronting the Windows operating system are nonoperating system software technologies.

JUDGE EDWARDS -- They're looking to victims in the middleware or alleged middleware market, and you're saying that's excluded from the definition of the relevant market ----

MR. UROWSKY -- Precisely.

JUDGE EDWARDS -- That is ironic, but so what? What do we do with it? Forgetting the causation questions, what do we do with it with respect to the definition of the relevant market, other than observe that it's ironic?

MR. UROWSKY -- I think that we need to take the next step and say that essentially the theory of liability impeaches the market definition. The purpose of defining a market is to identify the locus of effective competition.

JUDGE EDWARDS -- Well, let's assume that we changed the market definition and included the middleware or alleged middleware group, the prospective platform that we're arguing about, and we even included a Mac. What happens to your theory of the case? How does that change our analysis in any important way?

MR. UROWSKY -- I think what it then tells you is that the court cannot rely on a structural analysis to establish market power, because now we have no idea of what market shares any of these participants have, and because, in this case, there is an extraordinary heterogeneity to the participants who are competing to be successful software platforms. Being a successful software platform is a very desirable thing. That's why so many of these companies are investing so heavily in this area of technology.

JUDGE EDWARDS -- Well, let me be more pointed, to see whether we move on or there's something that I should worry about here. You make the claim that the definition of the relevant market is incorrect.

MR. UROWSKY -- Yes, Your Honor.

JUDGE EDWARDS -- Let's assume we agree with you, it is incorrect. If you were writing the opinion, you would say, and therefore, what?

MR. UROWSKY -- I would say and therefore the district court's determination as to monopoly power cannot stand, because there's no analysis of all of the elements that ought to be included in the market which are constraints on Microsoft's ----

JUDGE EDWARDS -- . . . in your argument as well, because while you want the Middleware included in the relevant market, you allow, as we all must, that it is only a hope, it is not an existing market at this point.

MR. UROWSKY -- And then, that brings us ----

MR. EDWARDS -- That isn't going to change the analysis very much. And if you add Mac in, you still have a share that's in the 80's.

MR. UROWSKY -- With great respect, Your Honor, I don't agree with that.

JUDGE EDWARDS -- Which?

MR. UROWSKY -- I don't agree with the part about the inclusion of other technologies in the marketplace not having an impact on the analysis.

JUDGE EDWARDS -- All right, well, then, tell me how?

MR. UROWSKY -- Because in this business, even a competitor who has not achieved mass market success -- and clearly whether some of these technologies have already achieved what borders on mass market success -- I'm thinking particularly at this point of Linux, certainly Apple and Java as well. But even without achieving mass market success, because of the economics of the business, they represent incredible threats. And the reason they -- incredible threats and, consequently, incredible restraints on behavior, on pricing behavior, on research and development, on the initiation of new products ----

JUDGE EDWARDS -- I think we could agree with you that they represent constraints, without saying that they are severe enough to refute the claim of market power.
Surely Microsoft does have a certain amount of freedom to choose its prices, right? I'm not sure that that makes it all that different from most other leading software makers in their particular field, but it does have that.

MR. UROWSKY -- There is no question that like almost every other supplier of a successful software product or any other intellectual property product, Microsoft has some market power and some -- some -- discretion in pricing, but that is not equivalent to monopoly power.

FOR THE ATTORNEYS GENERAL

MR. ROBERTS -- Your Honor, may it please the court, let's begin with the basic question of which test controls, the test articulated by the panel in the consent decree appeal or the test articulated by the Supreme Court in Jefferson Parish and Eastman Kodak.
The panel majority in Microsoft II, the consent decree appeal, stated no fewer than four times in its opinion, that it was construing a consent decree and not interpreting a statute. We think the court meant that. In footnote 14, the panel majority in Microsoft II said that the consent decree does not bar an action under the Sherman Act. We think the court meant that. The particular provision that the court was called upon to construe in Microsoft II referred to integrated products. It was, therefore, natural for the court to attempt to develop a test for integrated products. Under Jefferson Parish and Eastman Kodak that is not the pertinent question. The question is whether there is sufficient consumer demand so that it is efficient for a firm to offer the products separately.
The panel in Microsoft II, because it was construing a consent decree, was not bound by Jefferson Parish or Eastman Kodak. This court, today, confronting the question of the Sherman Act, is.
In addition, the panel in Microsoft II recognized that it was dealing with a very incomplete factual record. It was dealing with an improperly noticed preliminary injunction, and it specifically said that its conclusions were, quote, "subject to reconsideration on a more complete factual record." We now have that more complete factual record, and in a number of very particular respects, that factual record calls into question some of the assumptions that were made by the panel majority in Microsoft II. No fault of theirs; it was an incomplete factual record. I'll take one example to start with.
The panel in Microsoft II addressed the question of separating the browser, Internet Explorer, from the operating system, and said, "If you do that, really all you're doing is taking out four lines of code." That doesn't look like a separate product. It looks like a key to get into Internet Explorer.
Finding of Fact 185 explains that if you run the Felton program to remove browser functionality, it's not just four lines that are left behind. What is left is sufficient code that doesn't have to be loaded when you boot up Windows from the hard drive to the RAM to have Windows 98 take up 20 percent less RAM when it's booted up. So that may start to look like enough to be considered a separate product.
The court, in Microsoft II, focused on how Internet Explorer code was shared with operating system code.

JUDGE EDWARDS -- Mr. Roberts, can you reasonably argue that there is a separate market for browserless operating systems?

MR. ROBERTS -- Findings of Fact 149 to 154 ----

JUDGE EDWARDS -- I'm looking at them right now, and I've read them over and over again. And maybe I'm thinking too much about what I think I know, as opposed to focusing on the record, so I'm being honest with you, all right? It seems to me -- I won't say it's an absurd proposition -- it's a highly questionable proposition for anyone to now suggest that there is a separate market for a browserless operating system, in part because all operating systems include browsers and for lots of other reasons. It's a fairly absurd proposition.
So I was very curious to figure out what the district court opinion had to say about that. And I must say, as I traced what I think are a number of speculative observations about the district court, I can't find any underlying hard information to back up the inference. There's no clear finding. There's some speculation about inconvenience and employers don't like to have the Internet available to employees. There's no data that I can find.
Now, maybe it's there and you can point me to it.

MR. ROBERTS -- Well, there are two separate points, and I want to distinguish between them. The first is the precise question you asked: Is there a market for a browserless operating system?

JUDGE EDWARDS -- Right, and where's the data to support that?

MR. ROBERTS -- But the second point, which is related, and they follow sequentially in the findings, do consumers want to choose their operating systems separately from choosing their browser? And there was the testimony, for example, of the representative from Boeing, that they use different operating systems, they want a standard browser, so they don't want to buy them together; they want to choose them separately.
Now the district court did find that there's sufficient consumer demand for a browserless operating system, particularly referring, as Your Honor did, to companies that their employees have no business surfing the Web or they may, in some circumstances and not other circumstances, so they want some without a browser.

JUDGE STEPHEN F. WILLIAMS -- The makers of operating systems who were willing to remove the browser, did they offer any discount?

MR. ROBERTS -- I'm not aware of that, Your Honor. I do know ----

JUDGE WILLIAMS -- I think that inaudible contention on that has no rebuttal; that the government has done nothing to call my attention to any rebuttal material.

MR. ROBERTS -- First of all, those companies -- that constitutes every other company besides Windows.

JUDGE WILLIAMS -- That's right.

MR. ROBERTS -- Besides Microsoft. Microsoft was the only company that forced the tie.
