HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Revving Up the Search Engines to Keep the E-Aisles Clear

BYLINE:  By LISA GUERNSEY 

 BODY:
IN the real world, the search for something like a red medium-size women's sweater hardly ranks as a shopping challenge. Just go to a clothing store, head for the women's section, scan the sweater aisles or ask for help. 
 Online, the situation is altogether different. Searching for a specific product becomes akin to a quest for the holy grail with the wrong map. You are convinced that the product is out there. But you must rely on the site's search engine to find it -- and the results are either messages about "no matches" or a jumble of irrelevant links. 
 More than two-thirds of online retail sites tested last spring by Forrester Research failed to list the most relevant content in the first page of search results. No wonder sites have suffered from an inability to convert browsers into buyers. Customers are literally being driven away by weak search technology. 
To overcome the problem, some online shops have introduced a search tool that was designed to provide smarter, more relevant answers to queries. Traditional search software retrieves pages of information and then creates indexes using tools like a thesaurus, which ensures that when people type the word "sweater" they also receive results that contain the word "pullover." The new search tool goes a step further by directly searching a company's catalog databases, pulling information into tables and categories that are useful to the customer.
"Search becomes a matter of slicing and dicing your catalog in as many different ways as you want," said Paul R. Hagen, a senior analyst at Forrester.
The technology's strength, analysts say, is that it notes the relationships between columns and rows in the company's databases. This means that a search engine can find a medium-size cashmere cardigan with shell buttons by, say, scanning a table about sweaters, homing in on the rows that feature cardigans with the requested fabric and buttons, and, lastly, checking to see whether they are available in medium. By exploiting that underlying database structure, they say, information can be retrieved more precisely than if the search engine was simply combing through Web pages for some version of the searcher's words.
"If you are missing the structure, you are lost," said Yaron Dycian, director of product marketing for Mercado Software in Fremont, Calif., which provides database search tools.
The approach has another advantage. Because the search results are being pulled out of a company's database, Mr. Hagen said, a company can let its customers re-sort the results by a range of details, like a product's availability. 
Larry R. Harris, the founder and chairman of EasyAsk, a database-search company in Littleton, Mass., considers this the best way of assuring that customers find out when an item is out of stock.
"A text-based search engine would still be displaying those products and letting people try to order them," Mr. Harris said, because many of those engines comb through a premade index of information that might have been compiled hours, if not days, before. 
Other companies that develop database-oriented technology include Fact City in Waltham, Mass., iPhrase in Cambridge, Mass., and Requisite Technology, in Westminster, Colo. 
According to Mr. Hagen's analysis, the cost of buying and putting together sophisticated search systems is about $520,000 for a 20,000-page Web site, the size of online retailers like CDNow and Compaq.
WebVan, the online grocery service, has been using the Mercado system since last fall. To get started, WebVan allowed Mercado to scan its database and build a search tool that understood the categories and levels in its underlying structure. 
Now when a person searches WebVan's site for, say, "Vidalia onions," the search engine pulls up several options, including "Vidalia sweet onions," as well as frozen burgers and ketchup with Vidalia onions. After the user clicks on a photo of the onions, an interactive chart shows how the database was searched. 
A similar strategy appears to be working for Tower Records, another Mercado client. Before using the company's software, Tower officials said 2.5 percent of visitors who browsed the Web site bought something. In 1999, after installing a database-oriented search service, the conversion rate of browsers to buyers jumped to at least twice that. 
Still, not everyone is convinced that continually searching a company's database is the answer to a Web site's search problems. 
Verity, a software developer in Sunnyvale, Calif., that has been creating search tools since 1987, has focused on engines that dig into multilayered indexes of the information in databases instead of extracting data from the database itself. About 25 percent of its customers are applying the search engines to e-commerce sites, including CDNow, Home Depot and the Sharper Image.
"What we hear from customers is, 'Don't probe our database,' " said Prabhakar Raghavan, chief scientist and vice president for emerging technologies at Verity. Some of its clients worry that the performance of the database will suffer or that the search time will increase. 
Mr. Hagen, the Forrester analyst, said he had not seen any evidence that database searching was any slower than other methods. But regardless, he urges Web retailers to take a look at the options for improving the search process. 
When he wrote his latest report on e-tailers' search technology in June, he titled it Must Search Stink? Too often, he said, the tools required searchers to try keyword after keyword to find what they were looking for. Now, he said, he is more encouraged as he sees companies trying to figure out how to make their search engines more sophisticated instead of relying on searchers to become more sophisticated.
"You can choose to blame the user" and lose sales, he said. "Or you can make a smarter tool."

To Guide Hunt, Follow Context
AS Web sites improve their search engines, one question inevitably comes up: Although no one really expects search engines to read minds, is it too much to ask that they at least understand the context behind the queries? 
Any relatively educated person can see that keywords like "tiger" and "woods" mean different things to a zoologist and a golf fan. Could search technology someday make the same distinction?
Maybe so, according to search companies driven by the idea that even though searchers may use only one or two keywords, they provide clues that can be used to make search engines smarter. Here are some examples of how such contextual hints are being used:
WHERE YOU ARE -- "Where the users are searching from has a lot to do with what they are looking for," said Jud Bowman, president and chief executive of Pinpoint.com, a search-engine company in Durham, N.C.
If people are visiting Cancer.org, Mr. Bowman said, and they type "survivor" into its search engine, they probably do not want to see sites about "Survivor," the television program. 
Pinpoint's technology filters out irrelevant links by finding sites that fit a specific profile. The profiles are created by a program that scans a preselected set of Web pages that have been considered relevant to a specific topic.
The software notes the placement and pattern of words and then sends a "crawler" -- an Internet-based software agent -- onto the Web to find pages that match. 
In addition to Cancer.org, Pinpoint's clients include Golf.com and MotorWRX.com, a portal for car enthusiasts.
WHERE YOU'VE BEEN -- Most sites are able to make note of the sites their visitors are coming from. So when a Web user types the word "screwdriver" into a search engine after visiting a home renovation site, it could pull up references to screwdriver, the tool, and play down links to screwdriver, the mixed drink. 
Verity, a search-engine company in Sunnyvale, Calif., has been studying how this strategy can enhance its products, said Prabhakar Raghavan, chief scientist and vice president for emerging technologies. 
"One of the strongest indicators of what a consumer will buy is the site they came from," Mr. Raghavan said.
HELP ALONG THE WAY -- If words can be meaningless when taken out of context, why take them out of context? That is the philosophy behind search services that enable people to highlight a keyword in its natural environment, in a sentence or paragraph, and then hit a "search" button. With the help of those surrounding words, search tools can do a more educated search. 
Using downloaded software, the service kicks in whenever a person highlights a word (whether it is a Web site, e-mail message or word-processing document) and then right-clicks with the mouse.
Some examples of these tools can be found at Zapper.com, Annotate.net and FlySwat.com. 
GETTING TO KNOW YOU -- What if a search engine could get to know its user so well that it knew which results would be most relevant?
David Lowe, an engineering and information-retrieval professor at Southern Cross University in Australia, is interested in developing a system that develops profiles by tracking users over time. That kind of search engine could know that a doctor who often reads medical journals online is probably trying to find more medical journals.
At least one company is developing such a system: PurpleYogi, of Mountain View, Calif. Over time, Purple Yogi learns what its users like and serves up similar pages, avoiding those sites about Bengali tigers that might otherwise pop up in a search for information on golf's top player. LISA GUERNSEY

HEADLINE: FINANCE; 
Putting 401(k)'s Online: Add Choice, Save Trees

BYLINE:  By ANDREA ADELSON 

 BODY:
TO broaden retirement benefits for his 125 employees, John Maultsby Jr., the president of Florida Plywood Inc. in Greenwood, Fla., began offering a 401(k) plan in 1999. Employee payroll deductions were partly matched by the company, and employees could invest among eight mutual funds managed by First Union Bank of Charlotte, N.C.
 Many of the workers were inexperienced at investing and bewildered by their choices. "You could see on their faces," Mr. Maultsby said, "that they wanted help to make their pick." 
 His solution was to offer online financial advice from mPower Advisors, a San Francisco company that recommends investment allocations to workers at 130 companies. The cost for the service, which is tailored to the employer's funds, is $20 to $50 a worker annually.
To help employees use the site, Mr. Maultsby and another supervisor tutored them personally. A few people made portfolio picks on their own, but most took their cues from mPower, which tailors recommendations according to information supplied by the employee.
Both old and new economy employers are relying more on the Internet to help deliver and manage employee benefits. According to a report by Forrester Research, a third of employers are using Web-based benefit management systems, and more than half of them plan to abandon their paper systems in the next five years.
The reasons for the shift to the Web are many: it eliminates annual printing costs and simplifies the administration of benefits. In addition, as with Florida Plywood, Web-based systems give employees more choices. The systems also serve business owners by shifting the decision-making to employees and taking the employers out of the middleman role.
In response to demand, new online companies that offer benefit networks are moving to compete with established consultants like Marsh & McLennan and Hewitt Associates.
Among the start-ups is Myhealthbank in Portland, Ore., which is partnered with Regence BlueCross BlueShield of Oregon, the state's largest insurer. Aiming to meet the needs of small and midsize employers, Myhealthbank uses a "defined benefit" approach that gives employees discretion over how to spend a set amount of money budgeted by the employer for health care. This approach to health care parallels the self-directed strategies that 401(k) plans offer to retirement savings.
Myhealthbank displays an employer's health benefit in a dollar value in an online account. By choosing different premium levels or "co-pays" for office visits, prescription drugs, dental or vision care, employees can buy the plan that suits their needs.
Last October, Jerry Thenell, the owner of Shelton-Turnbull Printers, a 110-employee union print shop in Eugene, Ore., dropped his insurer for Myhealthbank to avoid a 16 percent increase in health care premiums. Besides keeping costs steady, the service has had another result.
"All of a sudden, they have a choice," Mr. Thenell said of his employees, who were coached by Myhealthbank's staff on how to use its site and enroll for benefits. "Our people totally love that." 
ABOUT 30 younger print-shop workers chose less coverage, thus lowering their premiums and increasing their take-home pay. Four employees with families did the reverse, preferring to pay an additional $50 a month in premiums to eliminate co-payments at the doctor's office.
Large employers, especially ones with intranets, are pushing benefit consultants to provide Web-based services that decrease the paperwork required for each annual employee enrollment period, as well as streamline the continuous bill paying and reconciliation process with insurance carriers.
Hewitt Associates, a benefits consulting firm in Lincolnshire, Ill., has spent millions of dollars creating an online benefits platform, called Sageo.com. Sageo offers employers a standard format for electronic health-and-welfare benefit enrollment that is less costly to administer than a paper system. 
"By using the Web, it puts more at people's fingertips," said Robert A. Toohey, a vice president of Genuity Inc., a computer network builder and servicing company in Woburn, Mass., and a Sageo client. Mr. Toohey said that the majority of Genuity's 4,800 employees across several states made this year's benefit adjustments through Sageo's password-protected Web site.
Putting benefits management online also conveys a message about a company's culture. 
"It would be hard to portray us as a cutting-edge company if we are delivering a phone book to everyone's mailbox," said the company's corporate communications director, Vaughn F. Harring, referring to employee benefit directories.
The gorilla of the benefits business is the Fidelity Employer Services Company, a unit of Fidelity Investments in Boston. Besides managing funds for its eight million retail customers, Fidelity manages 401(k) funds for another eight million people at 7,000 large companies. Using Fidelity's Internet site, 401k.com, employees can obtain portfolio guidance -- for example, calculate their risk tolerance or how a change in income will affect retirement.
"The trend now is to bundle it all in one place," said Peter J. Smail, the president of Fidelity's employer-services unit which, besides providing retirement information, offers payroll and health benefits through intranet portals for clients like the Mead Corporation, a forest products manufacturer in Dayton, Ohio. 
Last year, Mr. Smail said, twice as many companies sought their services than in the year before. "Benefits administration isn't a core business," he said. "It's harder for them to justify the heavy investment."

HEADLINE: What the Web Means In Tougher Times 

BYLINE:  By JOHN SCHWARTZ 

 BODY:
LAST year, even before dot-coms started to splat all over Silicon Valley sidewalks, wise watchers of the Internet liked to say that the real action was elsewhere -- in the hundreds of millions of dollars that old-economy companies were spending to improve their efficiency. These transformations, while less than glamorous, would allow them to grow faster than ever.
 But growth is not a word heard often in any context these days, and companies are reassessing their Web strategies in light of the sudden economic slowdown. Some are pulling back, while others are speeding up spending, hoping to find even greater savings in everything from purchasing to training workers. And some companies are acting on this discovery: a technology that lets you do more with the same number of people also lets you do the same amount of business with fewer people. 
 In other words, Americans who have become used to getting mail, books and even cars online may now be receiving pink slips as a result of the Internet. 
When the mutual fund giant Janus announced earlier this month that it was cutting 468 jobs, it said that part of the reason was the company's successful customer service Web site. Just as automated teller machines have replaced armies of bank workers, Web-based customer service has put the squeeze on Janus's phone staff. "Like many companies, Janus has embraced technology to deliver the kind of service our shareholders want," Margie Hurd, the president of the company's customer-support subsidiary, said in a statement. "We've started to realize significant operating efficiencies, which has inevitably resulted in the elimination of some positions."
Janus acknowledged that some of the job cuts were due to a drop-off in customer calls. But the success of the company's Web site has left those who answer the phone with idle time as well: 62 percent of the investors who contacted the company in December 2000 did so online, compared with just 34 percent in January 1999. Even the time-consuming process of opening accounts is migrating online, with 20 percent of all new accounts being opened on the company's Web site, www.janus.com, since the company began offering that choice.
Technological change has always led to shifts in the workplace, including layoffs. But what is different about the new-economy environment is that automation is reaching higher up the employment hierarchy than before, replacing workers like stock analysts and purchasing-department employees.
Such cuts, to be sure, are only one option that companies are choosing to weather the slowdown, and many economists rate them among the least appealing uses of the Web. Andrew Whinston, the director of the Center for Research in Electronic Commerce at the McCombs School of Business at the University of Texas, said that the companies making the smartest use of the Internet to prepare for a possible recession were those that are introducing efficiencies at many levels.
That does allow companies to cut their job rolls, either through dismissals or attrition -- "You're substituting Internet technology for labor," Mr. Whinston said. But the point should be cutting waste, not workers, he added.
Similarly, Robert E. Litan, an economist at the Brookings Institution, said that companies should be reluctant to lay off people in light of the struggle in recent years to find good employees in an overheated labor market. Instead, "they'll try to think smarter," he said. "They'll try to think of ways to save money on paper clips, reorganize their office."
But that could change. "If the downturn gets really bad, companies don't care about that," he said. "They'll say, 'Look, we can't pay you.' "
The newest way of saving money on paper clips, of course, is buying them through the Internet, and, in particular, buying them on the Internet through an overhaul of the supply chain. As a result, many companies appear to be willing to continue to spend money to save money, even though companies generally put off making investments like new computer systems during hard times.
This is true even in companies not associated with high technology. The Dana Corporation, an auto parts supplier, for instance, is continuing to put its money down, expecting a payoff in savings over time. "What we're doing is actually accelerating our efforts" to move to electronic purchasing, sales and auctions, said Douglas J. Grimm, the vice president for global strategic sourcing at Dana. The company, based in Toledo, Ohio, will spend "tens of millions" of dollars to complete plans to marry its processes with Internet technology, he said.
Dana announced earlier this month that bad times for automakers had hurt the company's earnings, with its annual net income dropping to $334 million from $513 million the year before. Dana said it would lay off 10,000 people and close 10 plants. But the company also announced that it would try to wring more savings for the company by increasing its use of the Internet. The real focus, Mr. Grimm said, is finding common ground for the 140 companies that Dana has bought in the last 40 years and its scores of incompatible data systems. Connecting all its operations and making them accessible through the Web is transforming the company, Mr. Grimm said. "All of a sudden, my buyers in Taiwan, Germany and Indiana can suddenly see the same data live."
On a larger scale, industry leaders like General Electric say that downturns are the best time to increase spending on information technology.
"Our competitive advantage is in belt-tightening times; we like to throw more money" at information technology investment, said Pam Wickham, a G.E. spokeswoman. "It's good for us if our competition is not increasing spending."
Several companies that sell the tools others use on the Internet are pointing to possibilities that include reduced work forces. The Oracle Corporation has built its current marketing campaign around the money it says it has saved on its operations by using its own software, which helps companies centralize and shrink their information technology departments. The company predicts that by later this year it will have cut the 1,500 people on its information technology staff to 900.
At Cisco, the company that sells much of the hardware that makes the Internet work, its leading e-business consultant said that a slowing economy made companies look more closely at the money they spend on Internet-based efficiency.
"When there's a period of economic uncertainty, all of us become more aware of where we're spending our money," said Susan L. Bostrom, a senior vice president for the company's Internet business solutions group. Ms. Bostrom helps Cisco's customers determine how to make online technologies work.
Most companies, she said, are neither plunging in nor giving up but taking a more cautious, focused approach to technology purchases. Because of such watchfulness, she said, "I see a higher involvement level of the C.E.O. and business executives" in making sure that the companies make the most effective purchases -- a situation that Ms. Bostrom said helped ensure a successful technology initiative.
Two insurance companies that Ms. Bostrom has worked with recently, Farmers and Allianz, focused heavily on improving customer service and training their thousands of agents. Baxter Healthcare, the medical devices giant, invested heavily in improving the company's internal communications so that workers could simplify functions like filing expenses -- initiatives that produce savings relatively quickly and pave the way for broader changes down the road, she said. 
Stephen N. David, the chief information officer at Procter & Gamble, said that he thought that Internet spending by corporations was not slowing down, but "there is certainly a lot more pressure for 'what can this do for me now.' "
"Over the last 18 to 24 months, industries have focused more on activities, not outcomes," he said. "I think right now what we're trying to do is focus on what we're trying to achieve and how to do it faster."
Some initiatives, like simplifying the way employees find information within the company, "certainly could lead to redeployment or downsizing," he said. But there are more important tasks, he said, like reducing the time needed to process orders, making more information available to consumers and speeding up product development. Consumer reaction to new product concepts that used to take two months to gather now takes a day or two to collect on the Web, he said. Sometimes new ideas are tested on one set of customers in the morning, revised and shown to another the same day.
Mr. David also said that concern for speeding up cost-cutting was putting more pressure on the technical groups that are writing the standards that would allow many of the hypothetical efficiencies to actually take place.
New-economy efficiencies are being sought by all kinds of companies. Businesses in the construction trades -- literally brick-and-mortar companies -- are turning to business-to-business marketplaces that are provided by companies like Equalfooting, which automate bidding and buying for half a million products. James F. Fox, a co-founder of Equalfooting, said that his 200,000 member companies realized savings in two ways: by attracting more bidders on sales of everything from hinges and screws to gloves to air compressors, which tends to drive prices down, and by more efficient use of purchasing agents' time. The transition to online bidding from calling suppliers individually for price quotes on an item like work gloves, he said, means "Going from two hours to -- no kidding -- two minutes."
He acknowledged that large corporations might be tempted to take the second kind of savings and use it to cut jobs, but he said that for most midsize and small companies, it did not make good sense unless the country slides into a true recession.
"The cost of hiring good people is so expensive that you really have to be loath to let somebody go," Mr. Fox said. "What you want to do during this time is not have to incur the cost of hiring someone."
Makers of e-commerce software don't brag that their products can put people out of work. But they don't deny reality, either.
"If you make a proposition that says, 'I'm going to make you more efficient,' you are by definition saying, 'I'm going to help you cut people,' " said Shikhar Ghosh, the chief executive of Verilytics, a company that creates software that automates the work of stock analysts.
He describes a meeting with a consultant who was helping the company prepare for pitching its products to a major financial institution. When Mr. Ghosh explained that the company's software, which scours Web sites for financial data and performs calculations, can do in minutes what it takes human portfolio managers hours to do, the consultant saw the light. "He said, 'Therefore, they're going to need half the number of people to do what they did before.' "
Mr. Ghosh insists, though, that the best use of his software is to introduce efficiencies that allow companies to expand without adding jobs. "They'll use the same number of people to do twice as much as they did before," he said. Ideally, Mr. Ghosh added, his products give his customer a competitive advantage. "This company grows faster than another company, and that company fires a portfolio manager."
So productivity, then, can be a double-edged sword. A more efficient economy does, in the long run, spread a measure of prosperity around, and no one gains from economic bloat for long. And Mr. Ghosh argues that even in hard times, the most productive companies grow and add jobs.
Even with unemployment levels still low, someone who has been told to clean out his desk is not exactly going to salute the efficiencies of the new economy on the way out the door.
As Shelly Petersen, a spokeswoman for Janus, said of laid-off call center workers: "Unfortunately, you can't turn these people into servers."

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; 
How Staunch Republicans Became a Dictator's Pals

BYLINE:  By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
NAPOLEON AND HIS COLLABORATORS
The Making of a Dictatorship
By Isser Woloch
281 pages. W. W. Norton & Company. $29.95.
 The French Revolution was of course a stupendous event, one that formed a template for subsequent political earthquakes, or at least a basis for comparison. There is a school of thought that sees the revolution's descent from the overthrow of royalist tyranny in 1789 to the Terror of 1793 as a strangely inevitable and tragic trajectory repeated in other upheavals, most notably the Russian Revolution of 1917. Then there is the emergence of Napoleon and the resurrection of a hereditary monarchy presided over by a tyrant not all that different from those who preceded him. 
 In his thoughtful and learned new book, "Napoleon and His Collaborators," the Columbia University historian Isser Woloch examines the implications of Napoleon's emergence as a new kind of strongman. Mr. Woloch shows, step by step, the manner by which Napoleon recreated a hereditary monarchy. Mr. Woloch's chief interest, however, is in the former moderates who had spent their lives in the service of a more liberal order but then chose to cooperate with the restored dictatorship. He calls them the collaborators, and they serve as points of reference for later figures who, in their own times and places, did much the same thing. 
"Napoleon did not vault onto the imperial throne but moved toward dictatorship gradually," Mr. Woloch writes, in a partial explanation for the complicity of others. "Each assertion of new power came gilded with a veneer of legality and a rhetoric of commitment to the principles of 1789."
In making his case, Mr. Woloch speaks more to readers with a special interest in the revolution and a good deal of knowledge about it than to those coming relatively uninformed to the subject. His writing is clear but often dry, and his focus is rather narrow, on political developments in France from 1799, when Napoleon was named first consul, to the decade following 1804, when, as Mr. Woloch puts it, "Napoleon placed the imperial crown on his own head."
The larger context for this event -- France's foreign relations, Napoleon's military campaigns, social and economic life -- are treated very skimpily here. Napoleon himself, his character, his loves, his generalship, what he was like, do not get extensive attention.
The question Mr. Woloch seeks to answer is why and how men who had devoted themselves to the cause of revolutionary liberty yielded to the ambitions of a new dictator. He begins by examining the group of moderate republican legislators who, tiring of factionalism and of the threat of resurgent Jacobin radicalism, engineered the coup that brought Napoleon to power.
Chief among them was Emmanuel-Joseph Sieyes, one of the theoreticians of 1789 who had largely withdrawn from the political scene. Sieyes, in Mr. Woloch's view, believed that the solution to French instability was a strong executive, represented by Napoleon, a parliament, and what he called a "third force," a body to mediate between the two of them. Though wary of Napoleon's ambitions, he nonetheless believed, as did many others, that only Napoleon could lead France out of its difficulties, and he therefore supported him. 
Still, the men who made Napoleon first consul in a new government created the method that was to be followed as Napoleon steadily increased his power and reduced French liberties. That method was "to cloak their constitutional coup in an aura of pseudo-legality," as Mr. Woloch puts it. 
Napoleon governed with a Senate and a Tribunate and, after he was named emperor, with constitutional bodies designed to curb abuses of power. But these institutions largely, if not entirely, gave the dictatorship that semi-legal gloss. Except in a few circumstances, Mr. Woloch shows, Napoleon was able to control the membership of the legislative bodies and essentially to turn them into rubber stamps. 
The men who allowed that to happen were, as Mr. Woloch shows, rather faceless in subsequent centuries even though their historical role was crucial. Among them was Jean-Jacques-Regis Cambaceres, to whom Mr. Woloch devotes a fascinating chapter. Cambaceres was the second most powerful figure in France, and a devoted servant to Napoleon, a position he maintained, Mr. Woloch argues, out of a mixture of motives: money, a genuine sense that there was no alternative, prestige, even a love of good food and wine, of which his status gave him a steady supply. 
Mr. Woloch goes on to trace the steady growth of the dictatorship and to assess the extent to which it was moderated by remaining revolutionary liberalism. Here he teases a complicated picture out of the historical record, one in which the Napoleonic bureaucracy had little success in curbing the imperial power. 
Napoleon's police minister, the intelligent and sinister Joseph Fouche, resorted frequently to preventive detention to crush popular discontent, a method, as Mr. Woloch points out, that restored practices of the old regime eliminated in the revolution. Built into the Napoleonic constitution was a senatorial commission empowered to investigate complaints of abuse of power, and Mr. Woloch shows that it succeeded in getting some prisoners released, but not very many. A similar commission charged with protecting freedom of the press and of publishing was even less effective.
Mr. Woloch concludes with some thoughtful observations on another time when senior government officials opposed to their leader's policies remained in office rather than resigning, in the United States during the Vietnam War. He concludes with no thundering moral judgments but rather an appreciation of how difficult the question is, of whether to work for something better within the system or to leave it. As Mr. Woloch shows, the issue as it presented itself more than 200 years ago still has a modern and even an urgent feel.

HEADLINE: When California Lights Dim; 
Utilities' Turmoil Also Hits Program That Aids Concerns Owned by Women And Minorities

BYLINE:  By BARBARA WHITAKER 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 27 

 BODY:
For years, the engineering company that Oscar Ocampo helped to found has benefited from a California program that pushed private utilities to increase contracts with minority- and women-owned businesses.
 Since 1986 when the company, the Ocampo Esta Corporation, was formed, it has grown from a company with three employees that grossed about $300,000 into one with 55 employees grossing more than $3 million last year. But with the energy crisis threatening the solvency of Pacific Gas and Electric and Southern California Edison, which account for 90 percent of its business, Ocampo Esta is also facing uncertainty. 
 The company, which specializes in designing power plants and substations, has laid off 15 engineers and designers since December, and has scaled back the workweek for others.
"If they don't send out additional work soon, most of us will be unemployed," said Mr. Ocampo, who is Filipino. 
Ocampo Esta, based in Vallejo, Calif., is one of thousands of businesses participating in a state-directed, voluntary contracting program that for more than a decade has fostered relationships between California's investor-owned utilities and women- and minority-owned businesses. And some of these companies are now getting a very personal look at the reverse side of such relationships.
While companies doing business with the two utilities are being hurt across the board, participants in the state's supplier diversity program are typically small businesses and therefore highly vulnerable to fluctuations in the economy. And the more narrowly a company's services are tied to the utilities, the harder they seem to be hit. Pacific Gas and Southern California Edison faltered under deregulation when their retail rates were capped as wholesale energy prices soared.
The program, the Women, Minority and Disabled Veterans Business Enterprises Program for Public Utilities, grew out of legislation that made the California Public Utilities Commission responsible for carrying out guidelines to encourage the use of such enterprises.
Despite challenges over the years from opponents of affirmative action, the program has made California's utilities a national model for minority contracting efforts, and the heads of PG&E and Southern California Edison -- the state's biggest utilities -- have been in large part responsible for making it a success.
"Today, California's regulated utilities have the best record in the nation, not only among utilities, but all corporations in America," said Robert Gnaizda, general counsel for the Greenlining Institute, the economic development and minority advancement organization that monitors the program.
The turmoil driven by the energy crisis, however, is providing fodder for critics of affirmative action.
"The chickens have come home to roost," said Ward Connerly, chairman of the American Civil Rights Institute, a California-based nonprofit organization fighting race- and gender-based preference programs. "We're all at the mercy of our marketplace no matter what business we're in. When your marketplace is the preference pot and that preference pot dries up, you're in trouble."
The situation illustrates what he sees as a major flaw in affirmative action programs. Although they were created as a way of helping businesses to grow so they could better compete, all too often, Mr. Connerly said, the businesses became overly dependent on those revenue sources and "they fail to grow up."
In response to such comments by critics of the programs, Mr. Gnaizda replied: "Have you asked any of them if they've criticized any of the top 10 defense contractors who rely on government contracts?"
He and other advocates say that the state's program offers opportunities without establishing preferences or set-asides.
When it began 13 years ago, said Mr. Gnaizda, who represented civil rights groups pushing for the change, minority contracts were virtually nonexistent.
In 1988, six of the state's largest utilities, including PG&E and Southern California Edison, agreed to a goal of giving 20 percent of the dollar value of all contracts to minority- and women-owned companies, with three-quarters of that to the former and one-quarter to the latter. A stipulation that an additional 1.5 percent of contracts should go to companies owned by disabled veterans was added later.
In 1999, according to Public Utilities Commission figures, there were 14 participating utilities, reporting total procurement contracts of $5.9 billion. Nearly $1.7 billion, or more than 28 percent, of that was spent with companies owned by women, members of minority groups or disabled veterans.
Figures for 2000 are scheduled to be released Thursday, and both PG&E and Southern California Edison said they would meet or surpass the goal.
For James Espinosa, who opened Orange Coast Electrical Supply 20 years ago, minority contracting programs and government contracts helped keep him in business when he found himself in trouble just a few months after starting his business.
He had intended to provide electrical supplies to contractors in new construction. But when interest rates skyrocketed soon after he opened his doors, Mr. Espinosa, who is Hispanic, turned to minority trade shows to help cultivate business with industrial companies.
He soon began working with Southern California Edison, which already had a special minority businesses program, and later found work in the aerospace industry through government programs.
Asked what he thought would have happened without such programs Mr. Espinosa said, "I don't like to think about it." But today, he says, his business, based in Irvine, has outgrown the need for them.
"The premise we've always worked on is we're going to operate a good business that happens to be a minority-owned business," he said. "Right now, if all these minority programs were to go away, I don't think we would lose any business" over all.
While his sales to Southern California Edison are down 25 percent since December, Mr. Espinosa, who over the years expanded his product line and dropped the "Electrical" from the company's name, has been able to avoid layoffs by concentrating on serving the construction industry, which is still going strong in Southern California, and focusing on sales of janitorial supplies, hardware and safety equipment.
Mr. Espinosa notes that his relationship with Southern California Edison has at times been a demanding one, forcing him to compete for its business. In 1994, the utility began a program of strategic sourcing to reduce costs. As part of the bidding process, Southern California Edison asked vendors not just the price of a material, but for suggestions on how the bidder could reduce the company's cost of acquiring and handling it. Mr. Espinosa's company was among the winners, and he instituted many of the ideas throughout his business.
From there his business grew rapidly, and, although Southern California Edison has typically accounted for 40 percent of his business, overall sales have tripled over the last five years, and the business, which has continued to serve builders and the aerospace industry, has continued to grow.
For Mr. Ocampo, such a shift is a bigger undertaking. His engineering company specializes in serving the utilities, he said, not unlike a doctor who specializes in internal medicine. In fact, it was at PG&E's suggestion that he left his engineering job at Bechtel to go out on his own. .
After the hardships of the last few months, "we will change the way we do business," he said, noting that the remaining 10 percent of his work is with AT&T. "But it will be a little bit harder."
Should the utilities he deals with go bankrupt, he said, "we will be hit very hard."
The directors of the utilities' supplier diversity programs acknowledge that the future is uncertain.
Both they and the contractors are " just riding this wave," said Bonnie K. Wells, who directs the PG&E program. "No one is going to avoid the eventual impact."
Joseph F. Alderete, who runs Southern California Edison's program, said there had been a 10 percent cutback across the board in December. And beyond the cutbacks, he said, some of his contractors were confronted by banks that no longer wanted to lend them money. "They were kind of getting squeezed from both ends."
The Greenlining Institute has begun pushing for $1.2 billion in disaster relief funds to assist small businesses affected by the current situation.
But Mr. Connerly, the outspoken critic of affirmative action programs, said that if the state should step in to bail out the utilities he would be "first in line" to challenge the program under Proposition 209, which amended the state Constitution in 1996 to prohibit state and local governments from granting preferential treatment based on race or gender.
Mr. Gnaizda said he thought that the utilities program would continue to withstand challenges under the proposition, since the companies were private entities and there were no mandated goals or sanctions. He added, however, that he feared for the program should PG&E and Southern California Edison be replaced by other utilities that might not have the same commitment to it.
So far, at least, there are some participants in the program that are not experiencing any drop in business. Among them is Kimberly King, owner of King Security Services in San Francisco, whose contract with PG&E accounts for 10 to 15 percent of her business.
"We're in kind of a recession-proof industry," Ms. King said, adding that with PG&E under fire as a result of the energy crisis it needs her security services more than ever.
Even some owners of companies that are being hurt say they can extract some good from the energy debacle.
Pete Varma, who is Asian-Pacific and owns Intraline Inc., a Burlingame, Calif., company that supplies utility poles, line hardware and electrical products, said he his monthly sales had dropped $200,000 to $300,000 to an average of $120,000 a month. Since 80 percent of his sales are with PG&E and Southern California Edison, he is scrambling. While trying to cultivate business with high-technology companies, he is focusing on sales of energy-efficiency items, like fluorescent bulbs, since the crisis has highlighted the need for conservation.
"I always look for opportunity where there is a crisis," he said.

HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT; 
As Antidote to Slowdown, Intel Will Spend, Not Cut

BYLINE:  By CHRIS GAITHER 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif., Feb. 27 

 BODY:
Intel, the world's leading maker of computer chips, said today that it would try to spend its way through the troubled economic times.
 Craig R. Barrett, the company's chief executive, told 5,000 people at the semiannual Intel Developer Forum here that he had seen a sharp slowdown in American manufacturing. The downturn prompted Intel last week to delay raises for employees and limit new hiring. 
 But Mr. Barrett rebutted a report from a Salomon Smith Barney analyst saying that Intel would reduce its spending budget, which calls for a $12 billion investment in research, development and production this year.
"You never save your way out of a recession," Mr. Barrett said. "The only way to get out of a recession stronger than you went into it is to have great new products." 
Last year was a difficult one for Intel. Competitors like Advanced Micro Devices, which produces chips for desktop personal computers, and Transmeta, a maker of fast chips for notebooks, brought new products to market. Intel faced shortages of components and could not hold off competitors as well as it had hoped.
Paul Otellini, an executive vice president and general manager of the Intel Architecture Group, acknowledged "missteps." But with several long-awaited products scheduled to reach the market, he and other executives view 2001 as a year to regain ground. 
Intel said its Itanium line of 64-bit chips, designed for high-end server systems, is on schedule for release in the second quarter. Production of the Pentium 4, intended for multimedia uses on desktop PC's, is expected to increase sharply in the second half of the year. Intel also said its lower-heat, lower-energy 0.13 micron chip would be available then.
Joseph A. Osha, director of securities research at Merrill Lynch, said Intel was trying to perform a balancing act. As its core business of desktop computer products slows, he said, Intel is pressing more urgently into chip products for faster-growing businesses like mobile and server systems. "In the context of that challenge, they are doing as good a job as can be done," Mr. Osha said. "They have handled the downturn as well as anyone in the industry."
Intel executives also said they had no plans to slow their pace of acquisitions. Intel bought 16 companies last year, at a total cost of $2.7 billion. With smaller companies running out of money, Intel's ability to buy has only increased. "Cash is king," Mr. Barrett said in an interview on Monday night. "We have cash."
Intel will use some of that cash to help Samsung Electronics of South Korea, a maker of memory chip sets, increase production of the Rambus dynamic random access memory, or D-RAM. These chip sets support Intel's semiconductors. Intel said it was offering financial assistance to Samsung, but would not say how much or disclose other terms. 
Mr. Otellini said Intel expects no shortages of D-RAM's as it increases production of the Pentium 4.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY BRIEFING: E-COMMERCE; 
ALLSTATE PLANS ONLINE SALES

BYLINE:  By Joseph B. Treaster 

 BODY:
 The No. 1 auto insurer, State Farm, tried it. Now, No. 2, Allstate, is having a go at selling policies through one of the first online markets for insurance, a California site called InsWeb. 
And this time, analysts say that they think the chances for success are good. "State Farm couldn't make money with InsWeb," said Todd Eyler, a senior analyst at Forrester Research, "but Allstate's agents are much more Internet friendly and enabled." InsWeb distinguishes itself by providing customers with comparative prices for insurance from several companies. But customers who wanted to buy from State Farm had to contact the insurer and then wait, often to no avail, for an agent to reply by telephone or an e-mail message. Allstate says that it will send a quote via an e-mail message within 30 seconds, along with a toll-free phone number to call to complete the purchase of a policy. Joseph B. Treaster

HEADLINE: Bush Promises Colombia Help on Trade but Refuses Peace Role 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 

 BODY:
In his first meeting with President Andres Pastrana of Colombia, President Bush agreed today to press for expanding trade preferences to Colombia, but refused a request to take part in peace talks with leftist guerrillas, officials said.
 Mr. Bush told Mr. Pastrana that he would work with lawmakers to renew the Andean Trade Preference Act, a decade-old accord that expires in December, and seek to increase the categories of Colombian goods that may enter the American market under reduced tariffs, a senior official told reporters after the meeting. 
 But Mr. Bush declined to take part in peace negotiations between the Pastrana government and Marxist rebels of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, which has battled the Colombian state for four decades. Both Mr. Pastrana and FARC leaders last week invited the United States and Cuba to join a group of nations assisting in the on-again-off-again talks, which resume in March.
"This is an issue that the Colombian people and the Colombian president can deal with," said Mr. Bush, who appeared for brief remarks with Mr. Pastrana at his side. "We'll be glad to help Colombia in any way to make the peace. We'll be glad to help the Colombian economy through trade. But I won't be present for the discussions."
Mr. Bush was effusive in his praise for Mr. Pastrana, whose ambitious strategy to pacify the nation, promote development and curb drugtrafficking has been underwritten in part with $1.3 billion in mostly military aid from the United States. Mr. Bush has endorsed Plan Colombia -- a holdover from the Clinton administration -- but has discussed the need for limits on the extent of American involvement in Colombia and ruled out the use of American combat troops there.
"President Pastrana is a courageous leader who is dealing with very difficult problems," Mr. Bush said. "I am confident that with his leadership his nation will be better off."
In an interview this week, Mr. Pastrana asserted that his nation had "turned a corner" in several key areas. He cited the FARC's agreement to resume peace talks, the American-supported eradication of 75,000 acres of coca in two months in the drug-growing regions of Putumayo and Caqueta, and four quarters of growth in an economy struggling to emerge from its worst recession in history.
Despite that progress, Colombia experts and some lawmakers sounded a skeptical note. There will be no fast resolution to Colombia's problems, they said, citing, among other things, the need to establish the rule of law and to rein in paramilitary and security forces, which were harshly criticized by the State Department's human rights bureau this week.
"The jury's still out as to whether these are going to lead to sustained improvements in bringing the country to peace and greater control," said Michael Shifter, a senior fellow at the Inter-American Dialogue, a forum for hemispheric leaders.
Senator John McCain, an Arizona Republican who returned from a visit to Colombia earlier this month, called on the administration to chart a plan that addresses how long the American-backed effort will take and how much it will cost.
"I think I made the right decision when when we voted for this assistance," Mr. McCain said. "Not because of any wild enthusiasm, but because I believe there is no alternative."

HEADLINE: 3 New Reports Show Evidence Of Weakness In the Economy 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
As the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, prepared to testify before Congress today about the nation's economy, three reports offered new, if murky, evidence yesterday of economic weakness.
 Consumer confidence, which Mr. Greenspan has called a key measure for the coming months, fell in February for the fifth consecutive month, according to the Conference Board. Americans sharply slowed the pace at which they bought new homes in January, the Census Bureau said. And spending by consumers and businesses on large, long-lasting items fell last month, although the decline was largely limited to the purchase of cars and airplanes, the Commerce Department said. 
 Investors took the new statistics as evidence that the Federal Reserve was likely to cut its benchmark interest rate for overnight bank loans either at its March 20 meeting or even before. Bond prices rose, and traders pushed short-term interest rates to their lowest level since 1998. But all the major stock indexes declined, partly because the Fed did not respond immediately to yesterday's reports, analysts said.
Trying to stave off the first recession since 1991, the Fed has twice lowered its benchmark rate by a half-point this year, on Jan. 3, between regular meetings, and on Jan. 31. The rate, which directly affects many credit card rates and small-business and car loans, is now 5.5 percent. 
Despite the bond market's rally, the new economic data offered enough conflicting signals to add to analysts' confusion about whether the economy is headed for, or even already in, a recession.
The consumer confidence index, calculated from a written questionnaire sent to 5,000 households each month, fell in February to 107, still higher than it was for the first half of the 1990's boom, according to the Conference Board. Consumers continue to say that the current economic situation remains relatively good, but their expectations for the coming six months have reached an eight-year low. As a result, the overall index has dropped almost 25 percent in just six months, a plunge usually seen only during a recession. 
The Conference Board's report was largely consistent with the initial February findings of the University of Michigan, which conducts a monthly telephone poll and released its results Feb. 16. The Michigan survey also showed a sharp decline in people's expectations, although not as steep a decline as the Conference Board reported.
"There's no denying the economy is decelerating," said Mark Vitner, an economist at First Union Bank in Charlotte, N.C. "The debate is about whether the level of consumer confidence or the decline in consumer confidence is more important."
"It's a real perplexing time," Mr. Vitner said.
After an unexpectedly slow holiday season, retail sales picked up somewhat in January, when fewer major storms hit the United States than had in December. Large chains like Sears and Target, as well as American automakers, reported stronger sales than they had anticipated based on the poor final weeks of 2000.
That moderate strength has caused many economists to question whether the drop in consumer confidence was simply a blip that is likely to reverse soon, or whether it was foretelling a sharp fall in spending later this year.
During a speech in New York yesterday, Roger W. Ferguson, the vice chairman of the Fed, said, "Despite the sharp weakening in sentiment, household spending appears thus far to have held up well," according to a transcript released by the Fed.
The divergence between confidence and spending is "somewhat puzzling," Mr. Ferguson said, and it presents a challenge for policy makers.
Analysts have attributed the rapid decline in confidence to a number of factors, including the steep fall in many technology stocks, the rash of recent layoff announcements and the degree to which the Bush administration has emphasized the economy's weaknesses, partly to build support for its tax cut proposal. In February, the Conference Board's index of future expectations fell to 69, down from 116 in September. 
At the same time, though, the index measuring people's current feelings is 164, only 10 percent lower than it was in the summer of 2000 and still higher than in 1996 and 1997, when the economy was growing rapidly. 
"The individual components are telling two different stories," said Lynn Franco, director of the Conference Board's Consumer Research Center. "Only the expectations component is signaling a recession."
In part, the strength of the other component reflects an unemployment rate that remains near a 30-year low, because many of the announced layoffs have occurred overseas and the creation of jobs in the service sector has more than kept pace with cuts in manufacturing, economists say.
But the decline in the purchase of new homes suggests that people's worries may be starting to hurt one of the few areas of the economy that remained strong through December. Sales of new homes fell 10.9 percent in January, the Census Bureau reported yesterday.
Analysts noted, however, that home sales remained historically robust.
In addition to the January data, the Commerce Department released revised numbers yesterday for the final three months of 2000, showing more home sales for that period than earlier reports had and making January's numbers look weaker than they otherwise would have. 
"The absolute level of sales is still incredibly strong," Mr. Vitner of First Union said.
On Monday, the National Association of Realtors said sales of previously owned homes fell 7 percent in January to their lowest level in a year.
Home sales statistics often change significantly from one month to the next, and winter data is among the least reliable because most people buy homes in warmer months.
Also yesterday, the Commerce Department reported that orders for durable goods fell 6 percent in January, to their lowest level since mid-1999. Excluding military industry goods and other aircraft, however, orders rose 6.5 percent, after having fallen at an annual rate of 16 percent during the final quarter of last year.
"It looks like the trend is showing signs of bottoming," said Jay Feldman, an economist at Credit Suisse First Boston. Still, he added, "There really is something for everybody in the durable goods data."
Mr. Greenspan gets his chance to comment on it today.

HEADLINE: General Powell in the Middle East 

 BODY:
Colin Powell made a deft diplomatic debut on his just-completed six-nation trip to the Mideast, his first overseas journey as secretary of state. He listened attentively to regional leaders, built Arab support for a plan to refine and reinvigorate sanctions against Iraq, and even won a promise from Syria's truculent president, Bashar al-Assad, to send revenues from a recently reopened oil pipeline to an internationally monitored account instead of letting them go to Saddam Hussein.
 Some Bush administration officials have favored a more assertive approach to Iraq, built around American arms aid to Iraqi opposition groups. No one disputes that most of Washington's problems with Baghdad flow from Mr. Hussein's aggressive military ambitions. But Iraq's fragmented opposition has no realistic chance of ousting him. Rebuilding support for sanctions is the most effective way to keep Baghdad from reconstituting its arsenal of unconventional weapons. 
 The plan General Powell promoted concentrates on blocking Iraqi imports of arms and materials that can be used to make them. It would be enforced by tightening United Nations control over Iraqi oil revenues. Some oil money, like the proceeds from the Syrian pipeline, currently evades U.N. monitoring. In return for plugging these financial leaks, General Powell offered Arab leaders an easing of non-military sanctions and a more flexible approach to items that serve essential civilian needs, like refrigerated trucks and water pumps. If Washington can build a consensus around this approach before next month's Arab League summit meeting in Jordan, and President Assad follows through on his pipeline pledge, it may be possible to cut off most of the $2 billion a year in unmonitored oil money now reaching Baghdad.
General Powell also moved nimbly through his meetings with Israel's prime minister-elect, Ariel Sharon, and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat. He wisely played down an earlier State Department call for Israel to transfer tax revenues owed to Mr. Arafat's Palestinian Authority and instead emphasized easing travel and work restrictions on Palestinian civilians. Israel is more likely to move on humanitarian measures like this than to ease financial pressures on the Palestinian leadership.
For many of his Arab hosts, General Powell was already a familiar and admired figure from his days as the overall commander of American forces during the Persian Gulf war. But he gained new credit from his unpretentious diplomatic style and his recognition of growing Arab impatience with the suffering sanctions have brought to Iraqi civilians. 
Much hard work lies ahead for General Powell in the Middle East as he works to rebuild a regional coalition against Saddam Hussein, end the violence in the West Bank and Gaza Strip and revive Israeli peace efforts with the Palestinians and Syria. But he is off to an impressive start.

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET: THE ISSUES; 
Bush Underlines Pledge About Social Security

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON and ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 

 BODY:
President Bush made good tonight on his campaign promise to push for the creation of personal investment accounts within Social Security, telling Congress that encouraging workers to buy stocks and bonds is the best way to deal with the looming financial strains on the retirement system.
 But as he did in the campaign, Mr. Bush avoided any details about how his proposal would be carried out, including the likelihood that any overhaul of Social Security would include politically painful benefit cuts. 
 And to ensure that the issue did not complicate his push this year for a big tax cut, Mr. Bush promised only to establish a commission that would work out the specifics and report back to him in six months. Under that timetable, Congress would not be likely to take up legislation before next year. 
"Seven years from now the baby boom generation will begin to claim Social Security benefits," Mr. Bush said. "Everyone in this chamber knows Social Security is not prepared to fully fund their retirement. And we have only a couple of years to get prepared."
On Medicare, Mr. Bush's nationally televised speech to a joint session of Congress reiterated his general commitment to overhauling the program, which like Social Security will run into financial problems as the population ages. But it also highlighted his willingness to leave to Congress, at least for now, the details of the politically tricky issue and the associated topic of insurance coverage for prescription drugs.
"Clearly, the president's priorities right now are education and tax relief," Charles N. Kahn III, president of the Health Insurance Association of America, said before the speech. 
To some degree, Mr. Bush's election shattered the long-held assumption in both parties that proposing major changes to Social Security was political suicide. 
But, as Al Gore repeatedly pointed out during the campaign, Mr. Bush presented his plan as all gain and no pain, sidestepping the debate over whether restoring Social Security's health would require steps like cutting the guaranteed benefit, reducing cost of living increases for beneficiaries or raising the retirement age.
Mr. Bush also remained quiet during the campaign, and again tonight, on how the government would pay for the creation of the private accounts. Analysts put the cost at $1 trillion over the next decade.
Mr. Bush told members of Congress today that he had not yet settled on the Social Security commission's members, and White House officials said the commission would not be up and running before spring. In the past, Mr. Bush has indicated that he would like to appoint members from both parties who support private accounts.
Some Democrats said the commission was a stalling tactic and a way for Mr. Bush to distance himself from any difficult decisions.
"I think history tells us that commissions ultimately do very little to solve problems that are contentious and difficult," said Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, a Democrat who led an unsuccessful bipartisan commission on Medicare reform. 
If no changes are made to the system, Social Security will run into financial trouble in coming decades. 
Under current projections, Social Security will take in less through payroll taxes than it pays out in benefits starting in 2015, about the time the baby boom generation is retiring in large numbers. By around 2037, the system will have redeemed its store of government bonds, and after that would be able to pay only about 70 percent of promised benefits.
Some economists, including Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, say that improvements in the economy's long-term growth potential could further delay or even eliminate the problem. Social Security's trustees are scheduled to update their projections in about a month.
But for now there is general consensus among members of both parties that it would be prudent to act as soon as possible to assure Social Security's health. 
There is no consensus, however about how to do so. And it is unclear whether Mr. Bush will be able to persuade Congress to go along with a sweeping change to a program that Democrats consider to be the cornerstone of the social welfare system and perhaps their party's greatest accomplishment.
By agreement of the two parties, the projected surplus in Social Security funds -- about $2.5 trillion of a total federal surplus of $5.6 trillion over the next 10 years -- could not be used for tax cuts or new spending.
As a practical matter, that has meant the Social Security surplus would be used to reduce the national debt. But in his budget plan, Mr. Bush will use only about $2 trillion for debt reduction, saying the debt left after that point would be difficult or impossible to redeem in the next decade. As a result, his plan would leave aside $500 billion to $600 billion in excess Social Security revenues that administration officials said could logically be used to help pay for private accounts.
But Democrats attacked Mr. Bush's budget today, even before its details were released, saying the president was in essence raiding Social Security's trust funds in violation of the agreement to use the surplus for debt reduction. They also criticized Mr. Bush for not pledging to use the surplus being generated by Medicare -- $400 billion over 10 years -- for debt reduction. 
"I think there is a budget shell game going on," said Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader in the Senate. 
On Medicare, the new administration's more cautious approach contrasts with the ambitious "fast-track" schedule for Medicare legislation that Mr. Bush outlined during the campaign: immediate short term legislation to help with prescription drugs for low-income elderly and a task force that produced legislation for a complete overhaul of the program by September.
Besides the administration's decision to focus on tax cuts and education, there is another factor: Lawmakers in both parties have been decidedly cool to the administration's short-term proposal to help states provide some immediate prescription drug coverage to poor retirees. And leaders of the Senate Finance Committee indicated his idea for longer-term restructuring would not be the basis for their work.

HEADLINE: A Victory for Cleaner Air 

 BODY:
To the delight of environmentalists and the dismay of several industries, the Supreme Court unanimously reaffirmed the bedrock principles of the Clean Air Act yesterday, as well as the Environmental Protection Agency's authority to enforce that act with detailed regulations. The decision vindicated the clean air strategy devised by the outgoing E.P.A. administrator, Carol Browner, and challenged her successor, Christie Whitman, to move forward with a program to achieve the clean air targets set by Ms. Browner.
 The court confronted two main issues. The first was a 1999 decision by a three-judge federal appeals panel that had invalidated tough new air quality standards imposed by Ms. Browner to force major reductions in the amount of ozone and soot in the air. The appeals panel, reviving a discredited constitutional theory known as the non-delegation doctrine, ruled that Congress had improperly delegated its legislative authority to the E.P.A. In his opinion for the Supreme Court yesterday, Justice Antonin Scalia briskly disposed of this argument by asserting that the delegation of authority had been no greater than delegations to other administrative agencies that the court had upheld over the years. 
 The second and more important issue was the argument advanced by a coalition of industry groups that the E.P.A. administrator should have taken economic factors -- costs and benefits -- into account in setting the new air quality standards. This went to the very heart of the Clean Air Act. As written in 1970, and interpreted in several lower court decisions over the years, the act imposed one overriding obligation on the administrator -- to protect the public health "with an adequate margin of safety."
To the extent the act mentioned costs and benefits at all, it allowed the administrator the discretion to take them into account when setting timetables and figuring the best ways to reach the standards. But it made clear that only science, not costs, could shape the standards themselves. Here again, Justice Scalia was clear. The act, he said, "unambiguously bars cost considerations." 
The decision should encourage Mrs. Whitman to proceed with strategies devised by her predecessor to help all areas of the country move into compliance. As governor of New Jersey, Mrs. Whitman embraced these programs with enthusiasm, including Ms. Browner's hugely controversial regulations requiring cleaner diesel fuel. The campaign now under way by refiners and other industries to weaken these rules will pose an early test of Mrs. Whitman's resolve.
