HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET: NEWS ANALYSIS; 
A Short Shopping List

BYLINE:  By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 

 BODY:
President Bush's budget speech, with its emphasis on his tax cut, education proposals and debt reduction plan, reflected both his campaign and his record as governor of Texas, but it was more narrowly focused than most presidents have chosen to be in their first nationally televised address to Congress.
 While Mr. Bush in his speech tonight talked about issues like rebuilding the military, encouraging charitable contributions and fighting rising energy prices and racial profiling, he stopped short of offering an array of new programs and mini-initiatives. He talked of a government that was "active but limited." 
 Much the same could have been said of his speech.
Mr. Bush did not go quite as far as Gerald R. Ford, who said, "I have no legislative shopping list here this evening," when he addressed Congress just three days after Richard Nixon resigned. Yet neither did he offer the sort of vast legislative agendas that Jimmy Carter, Ronald Reagan, George Bush and Bill Clinton all presented to the Congress and the nation in their first speeches.
For this President Bush, a more focused approach is a familiar strategy. As Calvin C. Jillson, chairman of the political science department at Southern Methodist University in Dallas, said this week, "In each legislative session he identified one or two signature issues." 
During both of Mr. Bush's terms as governor, the issues he pushed were the same ones he embraced during his campaigns, much as his speech to the Congress tonight echoed his presidential campaign themes of education reform, big tax cuts and support for so-called faith-based charitable organizations.
In Texas, his strategy of hewing to a few issues allowed him to receive credit for legislative accomplishments like education spending, tort reform and lower property taxes. And by not becoming embroiled in too many legislative fights, he also largely avoided criticism on those contentious issues he ducked.
How well that will work in Washington is uncertain. The presidency is a bigger job than a governorship. Congress is here all the time, not just for a few months every other year, and the press is more skeptical. Most of all, the agenda is harder to control, and not just the legislative agenda. 
In five weeks in office, Mr. Bush has used his public speeches and appearances to try to rally support for his education plan, his call for a $1.6 trillion tax cut, his support for using religious groups to run community programs and his intention to restructure the military. 
But even with this disciplined communications strategy, the new president has often been overshadowed not just by his predecessor's scandalous departure, but by accusations of espionage at the F.B.I., a sunken Japanese trawler and a bombing attack against Iraq, which he called "routine." On each occasion, Mr. Bush was working so hard at staying on his message of the week that he seemed oddly detached from the events dominating the news.
Tonight he faced no competition when he said that tax cuts were required for the sake of fairness. Moreover, he said: "To create economic growth and opportunity, we must put money back into the hands of the people who buy goods and create jobs. We must act quickly."
But he also tried to anticipate the Democratic opposition by committing himself to debt reduction, a subject he rarely raised during his presidential campaign.
He insisted that his plan "pays down an unprecedented amount of our national debt, and then when money is still left over, my plan returns it to the people." In fact, his opponents will argue that it does the reverse, cutting taxes and paying down the debt with what is left.
The speech, and the follow-up coverage and discussion of it over the next few days, may allow him to seize the nation's attention at a critical moment.
As Leon E. Panetta, former Budget Committee chairman in the House and later both budget director and chief of staff for Mr. Clinton observed today, a president's first budget speech is really "his last campaign speech." From now on, Mr. Panetta said at a forum held by the Center for National Policy, a public policy organization with Democratic roots, the task is governing -- and of dealing with the historical truth that "every president, in the course of a political campaign, promises more than he can deliver."
Even before tonight's speech was delivered, Democrats were seeing that fault in Mr. Bush. Representative John M. Spratt Jr. of South Carolina, the senior Democrat on the House Budget Committee, argued that a tax cut as large as Mr. Bush wants would preclude reasonable domestic spending on other items he says he supports, like education and medical research. Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader, said Mr. Bush's argument that all the debt could not be paid off as "a shell game that allows him to spend $900 billion that he knows he needs for his other priorities." 
Mr. Spratt also argued that it was foolhardy to rely on 10-year surplus predictions. Even Bill Archer, a supporter of the Bush tax cut and the former chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said, "When you're looking at 10 years, you're in never-never land."
The Democrats, in essence, were demanding that Mr. Bush explain in detail how he will pay for the priorities he outlined in his speech, items from tax cuts to better schools that he insisted the nation could afford.
Mr. Bush's choice of a more limited agenda, though, may have more to it than Texas habits and the discipline of staying on message. Charles O. Jones, former president of the American Political Science Association and a scholar of presidential-Congressional relations, said it was a "perfectly rational strategy to emphasize a few things and see how most of the other things play out." Biting off too many issues at once, as Mr. Clinton found out in 1993, has its own costs.
Mr. Bush's more focused strategy, Mr. Jones suggested, may have two timely rationales. One is the close division on Capitol Hill: "Given the politics of a 50-50 government," he said, "it's real hard to come on like gangbusters with a long list of things which you must have." Second, he said, "In the context of basically good times, the public isn't saying 'do this or else,' " and there is probably no single problem that must be solved for politicians to protect their jobs in 2002 or 2004.
Within his party, however, Mr. Bush is under pressure to push his tax-cutting measure through quickly. Republicans worry that a defeat or a delay on this signature issue, even though voters are not yet clamoring for tax relief and some prefer using the government's surplus to erase the debt, could cripple Mr. Bush politically. That is why Republicans rose for a standing ovation when he said: "The growing surplus exists because taxes are too high and government is charging more than it needs. The people of America have been overcharged, and on their behalf, I am here asking for a refund."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TO BUSINESS; 
I Know You, You Know Me, Let's Sell Goods Online Privately

BYLINE:  By ROBERT STRAUSS; Robert Strauss frequently writes about business and technology.

 BODY:
A FEW years ago, Neil S. Novich, the chairman and chief executive of Ryerson Tull, was lamenting the torrents of paperwork in the offices of this Chicago company, a metals processor and distributor. There had to be a better way, Mr. Novich said. Faxes, order sheets and paper were everywhere. 
 So the information technology staff at Ryerson Tull created RyTEC, a private Internet exchange in which companies are connected with their suppliers and their customers. Now the company does $200 million a year in business, about 7 percent of its $3 billion a year in revenue, with its regular customers through the exchange. Those customers, using a password, can enter the RyTEC site and order items any time of day. The monetary savings are hard to calculate, Mr. Novich said, but the headaches eliminated have been remarkable. 
 RyTEC has reduced the torrent of paperwork, Mr. Novich said. "What it does most is reduce errors," he added. "When you have people manually entering hundreds of items, something can go wrong easily."
While not attracting the attention of public exchanges, which have languished, private business-to-business exchanges are thriving. Their use has been increasing because companies have found them convenient for tracking and monitoring sales while building customer loyalty.
A private exchange includes variations of closed-Internet supply systems that are used by businesses of all types. Some private exchanges operate between a company and its supplier; others are designed to help initiate business relationships between companies within a corporation; still others may be intended to provide a service, like technology support or the filing of statistics or information, for a company.
Bruce D. Temkin, an analyst at Forrester Research, an Internet research company, said that "1999 was the year of the public exchange."
"Industry consortia said they would reinvent the world," Mr. Temkin said. "But with public exchanges, you had to sell everyone on it and inform everyone how to use it and clear everyone who wanted to come in. Private exchanges, you deal with your steady partners. You tighten collaboration with those partners, and that is where efficiencies come in and relationships are continued."
Private exchanges have many guises. For example, the investment firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company owns several different businesses. One is Amphenol in Wallingford, Conn., which makes and distributes electronic cables and connectors.
When Mark Peppin, the purchasing chief for Amphenol, found himself in chronic need of office supplies, he turned to a private exchange consisting of firms owned by Kohlberg Kravis. On the private exchange, he found WorldCrest, an office supply distributor in Atlanta, which was able to help.
"I'm probably saving 12 to 15 percent from using an open office-supply company site" like Staples.com, said Mr. Peppin, who also finds the private exchange convenient.
"I'm a morning person," he said. "Now I can come in at 7 a.m. and knock out a few orders, where I would have had to wait until someone was in their office before. The Internet has made things like this almost imperative."
I.B.M. participates in private exchanges in three ways. As a computer services company, it builds systems for other companies that want to start private exchanges. As a seller of computer equipment and services, it has a private exchange for regular customers. And, like Mr. Peppin at Amphenol, John Wilson, I.B.M.'s director for business-to-business services, has to worry about whether there are enough toner cartridges for the hundreds of copiers in I.B.M.'s offices. So Mr. Wilson uses a private exchange to buy office supplies.
"The private exchange we use for buying office equipment has saved us millions in maverick buying alone," he said. "For instance, that toner goes out and a conscientious employee would go to Staples on his way home, buy one and expense it out of petty cash. Now we're on an Internet exchange. The toner is there before we need it. It's bought wholesale and the hassle is nothing."
Private exchanges, while seemingly simple, have not become viable until recently because of the storage and bandwidth capacity that are needed.
"The capacity has to be there to hold as much data as the customer and its suppliers want, plus it has to be fast and error-free, which means there had to be servers strong enough to do the work," said Mark A. Salser, the senior vice president for advanced technologies at Oracle, which designs and builds business-to-business exchanges. 
"People say it is not much different than what Yahoo and Amazon did, which is true to an extent," Mr. Salser said, "but for so many companies to have this kind of auction and data-management system, it was only available recently."
Tim Clark, an analyst for Jupiter Research, which tracks Internet businesses, noted another advantage of this type of exchange: "People like private exchanges because they keep control of customers and suppliers. They don't have to make things public that they don't want to." 
"In a way, this is just another advancement in technology," Mr. Clark said. "It is replacing faxes, which replaced phone calls, and so on. It becomes more and more error-free and, thus, saves everyone money."
But at least some business people want to preserve a part of the old style of operating. 
Dean Berman, a partner in Harbor Seafood, a seafood procurement and processing business in New Hyde Park, N.Y., has been using Gofish.com, an exchange for the fishing industry. He finds it efficient and cost-effective, but sometimes not as much fun, say, as using the phone.
"If I need Thailand tiger shrimp now, I can go there and get a good price -- it works," Mr. Berman said. "But sometimes I just want to get razzed by my Maryland suppliers about the Ravens beating the Giants, or razz them back about the Yankees.
"Business is about money, but it is about relationships, too," he said. "That's why the Internet is good, but it will remain only a part of our business."
